headline: Three sentenced in Chinese workers' riot
text: BEIJING (AP) - A court in eastern China has sentenced three men who led disgruntled migrant workers in ransacking company offices and smashing their way into a police station, the official Legal Daily reported Tuesday.The incidents on Oct. 17-18 last year were apparently sparked by the company's firing of the brother of one of the ringleaders, although relations between workers and management had been poor for some time, the paper said.Over 1,000 workers from the impoverished, inland province of Anhui working in coastal Zhejiang province joined in the riot, the paper reported.Angry workers marched off the job en-masse and smashed windows, office equipment and vehicles belonging to the Lizi Group in the city of Duji, the paper said.Workers then marched to the Paitou police station, attacking its gate with stones, staves and eventually smashing it down with a large slab of concrete. Police inside were attacked, the paper said.The next day, the group demanded wages and the release of detained workers, occupying train tracks and cutting rail service when their demands went unanswered, the paper said.On Sunday, the Duji court sentenced Miao Jinhong and Ni Xianfei to eight years in prison for disrupting transport and leading a crowd to attack government offices, the paper said. Another man, Li Keyou, was sentenced to four years, six months for disrupting transport.Tuesday was a public holiday and court officials were unavailable for comment. A man who answered the phone at company offices refused to comment, although a police officer who declined to give his name confirmed that the precinct had been attacked by migrant workers.Worker protests occur almost every day in China, many of them sparked when state enterprises' move to shed workers and cut losses.Anxious to prevent organized mass unrest, China has come down hard on the leaders of such actions and those who attempt to form independent unions.

headline: Guangdong pupils protest tuition fees - looting, arson ensues.
text: Source: Nanfang Ribao, Guangzhou, in Chinese 20 Feb 01A begrudged villager and his cohorts instigated looting and arson of government offices under the pretext of protesting against unreasonable tuition fees in Xiancheng Town, Chaoyang, Guangdong Province, the Southern Daily reported. The villager sought revenge against the local government after being investigated for taking sand from village plots. On two occasions, the instigators rallied as many as 200 primary school pupils and protesters to demonstrate outside the town government office. Windows and cars were smashed, and the instigators set fire to the offices and looted equipment. Text of report by reporter Fang Yiqing and correspondent Li Xisong, carried by Chinese newspaper from Guangzhou Nanfang Ribao on 20 FebruaryThis reporter learned last evening from a pertinent department of Shantou City that Chaoyang City's Xiancheng Town on 11 February witnessed a malignant, well-organized, and premeditated incident of beating, smashing, looting, and burning the town government's office buildings under the pretext of student tuition problems. Thanks to the resolute approach of Shantou and Chaoyang city governments, the incident was quelled in a timely manner. During the whole process of handling, not a single civilian was injured. Thus far, the Xiancheng Town government has already resumed its office work, and elementary and middle schools in the town are holding classes as usual. Meanwhile, public security organs have already arrested 21 criminal suspects.At about 1300 on 11 February, a handful of illegal elements in Xiancheng Town organized 49 pupils of Xincheng Elementary School to march to the town government for a demonstration against the tuition problem. They poured into the government buildings and then instigated some masses, who were unaware of the truth, to dash into the government compound to beat and smash windows and cars there. Informed of this, party and government cadres of Chaoyang City and related departments immediately rushed to the scene of the riot for mediation and persuasion. At about 1600 that afternoon, the 49 pupils were brought back by their parents or teachers. However, a few illegal elements still stayed there to make trouble without fearing anything. At about 1800 that evening, these persons went so far as to set fires to government offices. Through the all-out efforts of cadres and policemen, the riot was basically brought under control around 2340 that night.At about 1000 the next day, these illegal elements once again incited some 200 masses in Xiancheng Town to make troubles at the town government buildings. Amid the chaos, these illegal elements frenziedly burst in the offices to loot office appliances and to smash and burn all the windows and equipment of the four office buildings in the government compound. After hearing this, the Shantou City authorities dispatched the police to the scene to help handle the case. Through the patient mass work and persuasion by leaders and public security cadres, the incident calmed down finally.Thanks to the resolute approach, the damages caused by this incident have been minimized. It was reported that during the whole process of the incident, some windows and office facilities of the government buildings were smashed and burned, three cars were damaged, and three policemen were injured only. No civilian was injured.On the afternoon of 12 February, Shantou and Chaoyang city governments convened an on-the-spot office meeting to deal with the aftermath of the incident and to specifically deploy and implement the following rectification and correction measures. First, a leading group composed of functional departments will be established to immediately investigate the tuition problems of local elementary and middle schools. And, all the unreasonable tuition fees will be returned to students at once. Second, various types of meetings will be convened to conduct legal propaganda and education among the masses. Investigation will be carried out, and evidence will be obtained promptly. And, organizers of the incident and troublemakers will be thoroughly examined and severely punished according to law. Third, the Xiancheng Town party committee and government will be instructed to clear the scene of the riot and to restore the office work as quickly as possible. Meanwhile, the control over social communities will be strengthened, and the order in production and daily life will be restored as soon as possible in order to minimize the impact from the incident. Fourth, an emergency meeting with the participation of party committee secretaries of various towns (neighbourhoods) will be held to report the course of the incident. Various towns (neighbourhoods) will be arranged to strengthen the ideological and political education among students. Furthermore, the collection of unwarranted fees and surcharges will be strictly banned in order to prevent such incidents from emerging in other localities and to ensure the stability of society.According to the initial investigation, the cause of this incident is: A villager in Xiancheng Town's Xinxing Village had a grievance against the town land station because he was investigated for privately taking sand from the village's cultivated land. Then, on the afternoon of 11 February, he secretly organized 49 pupils of Xinxing Elementary School to march to the town government to reflect the tuition problem and seized this opportunity to incite the riot. Now, public security organs are making all-out efforts to trace and arrest the criminal suspects at large.

headline: AFP: 2000 Chinese Coal Miners Clash with Police in Datong
text: BEIJING, March 9 (AFP) - Some 2,000 coal miners blocked roads and clashed with police in the northern Chinese city of Datong in a protest over redundancies and healthcare, a human rights group said Friday.?? ??? The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said the workers at the Baidong mine in Shanxi province were worried they would not find new jobs after the closure of their pit.?? ??? It said the 3,500 miners had been told they would get 20,000 yuan (2,400 dollars) each but that many had work-related health problems and feared they would not be able to pay medical bills.?? ??? The center said around 2,000 miners blocked the road between Datong and the mine Thursday, adding that during clashes with police one miner was beaten and taken to the local police station.?? ??? It said the miners then surrounded the police station and forced the release of their injured colleague.?? ??? Wang Xiaohua, an official with the local government-controlled trade union, played down the protest, saying only 200 miners had petitioned the mine bureau and that one miner had been injured by security guards.?? ??? "The miners are very sensitive, they are a little extreme and are uncultured," he said.?? ??? A police spokeswoman denied there had been any protest, but said 100 officers had been dispatched to keep order.?? ??? China, the world's largest producer and consumer of coal, aims to lower production to 900 million tonnes this year following a peak of 1.3 billion tonnes in recent years.?? ??? Shanxi is the center of China's coal mining industry and there are around 500,000 miners employed around the Datong area alone.?? ???? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Striking Taxi Drivers Clash with Police in Lanzhou, China
text: ??? BEIJING, March 13 (AFP) - Striking taxi drives clashed with hundreds of riot police around the provincial government offices in the northern Chinese city of Lanzhou Tuesday leading to scores of injuries and arrests, a Hong Kong-based rights group said.?? ??? Some 5,000 striking drivers surrounded the government offices in the capital of Gansu province prompting the government to send in some 300 police, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.?? ??? At mid-morning Tuesday police began beating back the protesters with over 20 suffering injuries while up to 10 demonstrators were taken away by police, the center said.?? ??? Locals in Lanzhou confirmed to AFP that the demonstration and clashes took place, but police told AFP that reports of 5,000 demonstrators gathering in front of government offices "was rumor".?? ??? A Lanzhou taxi driver told AFP by telephone that the drivers were demonstrating over an increase in fines by traffic police, rising road taxes and regulations requiring taxis to be outfitted with metal cages separating drivers from passengers.?? ??? On Monday, the drivers handed over a petition of their grievances to the government while also going on strike, the driver said.?? ??? Officials at the provincial government refused all comment on the demonstrations, while a spokeswoman from the Lanzhou city government confirmed that the petition had been handed in.?? ??? Another official from the taxi administration department under the city transportation bureau told AFP by telephone that the city government had promised to resolve the issue by Tuesday, while confirming that the new fees and regulations had been implemented.?? ??? "The strike began yesterday but some of the taxi drivers that continued to work got their cars smashed by the strikers," another taxi driver told AFP.?? ??? The information center said the demonstration was still going on late Tuesday afternoon.?? ??? Specifically drivers were demonstrating over a 2,500 yuan (300 dollar) road fee, a rise to 300 yuan for violations of regulations on picking up and dropping off passengers, and a 240 yuan fee for the installation of cages that cost 40 yuan, the drivers said.?? ??? China has seen a rising tide of labor unrest and peasant uprisings in recent years over fees, growing unemployment, a widening gap between rich and poor and rampant government corruption.?? ??? Wang Daming, a delegate to the Chinese People's Political Consulatitive Conference, said last week the number of petitions at the county-level and above had grown by 37 percent per year nationwide, with up to 85 percent of the complaints being "justified." ??? "Group incidents are on an upward trend with the behaviour becoming increasingly acute, some local township and county governments organs have been smashed, roads and railways blocked, and police and armed policemen beaten and public facilities destroyed," Wang said.???? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

Locals in Lanzhou confirmed to AFP that the demonstration and clashes took place, but police told AFP that reports of 5,000 demonstrators gathering in front of government offices.

headline: AFP: Chinese Workers Block Roads in Protest Over Unpaid Benefits
text: [multiple events] ??? BEIJING, March 26 (AFP) - Hundreds of workers in southern China's Guizhou province blocked roads in the provincial capital Monday and demanded up to a year in unpaid retirement and unemployment pay, reports and officials said.?? ??? Some 1,500 workers and pensioners from the Guizhou Number Seven Metallurgical Construction Company blocked several main roads in Guiyang, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.?? ??? The protesters also demanded that retirement pensions should be increased from 300 yuan (36 dollars) a month in accordance with provincial regulations, the center said.?? ??? Officials from Guiyang's Baiyun district government confirmed to AFP that the protests took place, but said only 300 people were involved and that by mid-afternoon Monday the protesters had peacefully dispersed.?? ??? Nearly 7,000 people, mostly construction workers, are employed by the company but some 3,000 retired workers and another 1,500 newly-laid off workers must also be taken care of, the center said.?? ??? In a related event, some 500 workers from the Xinye County Fertilizer Factory in central Henan province blocked streets in front of the county government office to demand a year of back pay, the center said.?? ??? Following the arrest of five managers of the factory in a corruption scandal last year, the factory was forced to stop production due to huge losses, leaving 800 workers idle, it said.?? ??? An official at the county offices told AFP that only 100 workers protested Monday morning and denied there was any corruption scandal at the fertilizer factory.?? ??? "This kind of thing doesn't happen very often, only several times last year.?? This is the first time this year and these kinds of things are unavoidable during the restructuring of state-run enterprises," the official said by telephone.?? ??? China has seen a rising tide of labor unrest and peasant uprisings in recent years over fees, growing unemployment, a widening gap between rich and poor and government corruption.?? ??? Tens of millions of people have also been laid off from loss-making state-owned enterprises in the past four years as the government tries to streamline the economy for membership of the World Trade Organisation.?? ?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP Reports on Worker Discontent in China's Shandong, Sichuan, Shaanxi
text: [multiple events] ??? BEIJING, April 2 (AFP) -- Several hundred disgruntled workers in eastern China demonstrated in front of local government headquarters on Monday in the latest report of discontent within the country's huge labor force as pressures mount from lay-offs and lagging pay.?? ??? Workers from the Zibo Chemical Fertilizer Company in Zibo city, Shandong province, marched to the government office to vent their frustration over lack of government support for the company, on which their livelihood depended, a local official told AFP by telephone.?? ??? "The company isn't doing well, and the workers hoped the government could do more to help it out of its trouble," said the official, who gave his surname as Zhang.?? "They dispersed after the government agreed to look into the company's trouble." ??? He said the number of demonstrators totaled 200, while the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy in a press release gave the number as 500.?? ??? According to the center, the company went bankrupt last year, throwing its 1,500 workers out of work.?? Zhang insisted it was still in business.?? ??? Also on Monday, teachers at the Guanyin Elementary and Middle School in southwestern Sichuan province's Suining city went on strike, according to the center.?? ??? The center said the strike, triggered after the teachers had not received any pay since early this year, left the school's 1,800 students unsupervised.?? ??? A Suining education official told AFP the teachers' action was considerably smaller than described by the Hong Kong-based center.?? ??? "It was just a handful of young teachers who came to school in the morning, but refused to teach," the official said.?? ??? In the third report of worker discontent, the center said 500 workers from a steel factory near Xian, capital of northern Shaanxi province, started blocking an intersection on Friday.?? ??? The workers, who wanted to draw attention to the factory's failure to pay them for the past 18 months, discontinued the demonstration on Saturday without achieving anything, the center said.?? ??? Market reform and intensified competition are heaping new burdens on the shoulders of China's blue-collar population, and millions enter the ranks of the unemployed every year.?? ??? They have few channels for voicing their grievances because the governmemt places strict curbs on independent labor activism.?? ??? China earlier this year ratified the UN Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, but excluded a provision in the convention that allowed for the setting up and joining of independent trade unions.?? ??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: PRC Police Move Protestors Away From US Embassy in Beijing
text: Text of report by Radio TV Hong Kong audio web site on 5 AprilIn Beijing, security police have detained several more protesters trying to put up posters condemning the United States outside the US embassy in the capital. One man frantically wrote "blood debts should be paid in blood" on a white banner to protest against the presumed death of the Chinese fighter pilot following Sunday's [1 April] collision. The protester was led away by police before he could finish writing.Source: RTHK Radio 3 audio web site, Hong Kong, in English 0800 gmt 5 Apr 01.
notes_human: http://www.epochtimes.com/gb/1/4/5/n73070.htm

headline: NE China Workers Hold Sit-In at Beijing Central Discipline Office, Protest Local Corruption
text: ??? An incident occurred in Beijing on 23 April where laid-off workers and farmers from Northeast China filed petitions in front of the office of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission in Beijing. Dozens of laid-off workers and farmers from Jilin Province and Liaoning Province who were fed up with corrupt government officials and the collaborations between officials and businessmen came as a group to the office of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission to file petitions and stage a sit-in demonstration. The police department sent out more than 40 police officers to the scene to keep a sharp lookout, while urging the demonstrators to leave. The demonstrators stayed in front of the office of the Commission for six hours and finally left after a police officer at the scene promised to relay their petitions to the leadership of the commission. During the incident, there was no clash between the police and the demonstrators. Nor was any demonstrator placed under arrest.??? In recent years, there have been many people in various localities coming to Beijing to stage demonstrations and appeal to the higher authorities for help. However, incidents such as the one that took place yesterday to file collective petitions in front of a major organization of the CPC Central Committee was quite rare.??? According to a well-informed source, the demonstration held yesterday started at 0930 hours in the morning. The petitioners came to Beijing by train from Northeast China on the day before yesterday (Sunday) [22 April], and then stayed in a hostel as a group.??? Collaboration between Corrupt Officials and Profiteering Merchants Kindles Anger among the People??? Scores of men and women petitioners arrived at the gate of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission at about 0700 hours yesterday morning. Some of them were in wheelchairs and some of them were retired workers. They complained against local corrupt government officials using their official positions for their own ends. As a result, local factories were unable to pay wages or even went bankrupt, they said. The petitioners asked the Central Discipline Inspection Commission to send out officers to investigate the local officials' corrupt practices and punish them according to law.??? In addition, some of the petitioners were farmers from Songyuan City in Jilin Province. They accused the local government officials of colluding with the local developers and paying far less for land compensation.??? Dozens of Police Officers on the Alert without Clashes??? The police department in Beijing sent out dozens of police officers to the scene to keep a sharp lookout. Meanwhile the police officers told the petitioners that they understood the their feelings and demands and that they would relay their petitions to the leading comrades of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission and the departments concerned. They also urged the petitioners to go back to their hometowns as soon as possible.??? It was reported that during the sit-in demonstration, the petitioners used no violent language. Nor did they put up any posters. They just sat there silently. On the one hand, the police officers were on the alert, while on the other hand, they talked to the petitioners for a possible solution to solve their problems. Persuaded by the police officers, the laid-off workers and farmers gathering outside the Central Discipline Inspection Commission left peacefully around 1400 hours in the afternoon.??? Beijing Notifies Local Governments To Handle Cases??? It was reported that the Beijing Municipal Government had yesterday briefed the local governments in Jilin and Liaoning on this incident, hoping that the local governments would be able to properly handle this incident. The police department in Beijing had not arrested any petitioner yesterday. However, this incident was in the form of a collective appeal to the higher authorities for help. It is possible that the organizer or organizers of this incident may be subject to penalties to a certain extent.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Ming Pao (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- well-respected, non-PRC-owned daily newspaper; contains well-informed features on and analysis of PRC and Hong Kong political, social, and economic issues]

headline: AFP: PRC's 'Strike Hard' Campaign Reportedly Led to Killing of 2 Protesters
text: ??? BEIJING, April 24 (AFP) - Chinese police killed two unarmed village protesters and wounded up to 38 others in a raid on a rural village in southern China, Amnesty International said Tuesday.?? ??? Over 600 armed police overturned roadblocks to Yuntang village, southern Jiangxi province and entered the village in the early hours of April 15 breaking into homes and waking people, the London-based rights group said.?? ??? "A crowd gathered in front of the local primary school and at 4:20 am (2042 GMT), according to witnesses, the police opened fire, aiming at the legs of the villagers," Amnesty said.?? ??? "However, when the villagers tried to defend themselves by throwing rocks and sticks, the police began to shoot higher." ??? Villagers had been protesting exorbitant taxes for three years and had refused to pay the rising taxes since the government raised them by some 30 percent in 1998, following devastating floods to the region, it said.?? ??? An official at the neighboring Yujiang public security bureau told AFP by phone Tuesday that the raid had been part of a "strike hard" campaign announced by Beijing at the beginning of the month.?? ??? Locals in Yuntang told AFP by phone that police had arrested five alleged ring leaders of the three-year protests, including Su Guosheng, who was arrested on April 14 before the police crackdown on the village.?? ??? "The strike hard campaign began on April 14, at that time many buses carrying some thousand armed police came to the village and cordoned it off," one villager, who refused to identify himself, said.?? ??? Another villager told AFP that several government working teams were in the village investigating the incident, while police ordered villagers Monday to bury the two men killed by police.?? ??? Villagers had initially refused to hand the bodies over to the police or local officials and had held them as evidence of the killings, he said.?? ??? "Local officials had called the villagers a "criminal gang", and police and other officials had clashed with them in 1999 and 2000, but this is the first time they have opened fire," Amnesty said in its report.?? ??? China's "strike hard" campaign was announced at the beginning of the month by President Jiang Zemin.?? It is officially aimed at "cracking down on evil forces and wiping out hooligans." Over 350 executions have been reported in the Chinese press since April 11.?? ??? Amnesty has voiced concern that the campaign may influence the proceedings and outcome of criminal and political trials.?? The group also said it believed Su Guosheng is at risk of torture.?? ?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]
locality_human: Yuntang village, Yujiang county of Jiangxi
notes_human: http://www.epochtimes.com/gb/1/4/20/n78781.htm             Hundreds of people gathered peacefully in front of an elementary school to protest a 30 percent rise in local taxes that went into effect in 1998 after floods destroyed the crops of many area farmers.The protesters have refused to pay the tax over the past three years.      Villagers had been protesting exorbitant taxes for three years and had refused to pay the rising taxes since the government raised them by some 30 percent in 1998, following devastating floods to the region, it said.?? ??? An official at the neighboring Yujiang public security bureau told AFP by phone Tuesday that the raid had been part of a "strike hard" campaign announced by Beijing at the beginning of the month.?  The deadly clash in Yuntang is the latest sign of instability in Jiangxi, a relatively poor province known as a cradle of Mao's Communist revolution. Another county not far from Yuntang was the site of another major, internationally publicized conflict last August, when more than 10,000 farmers protesting high taxes rampaged through township offices and the homes of officials. There is no sign that farmers from the two restless counties have joined forces, forming the kind of rural movement that the authorities are especially anxious to prevent.         http://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/20/world/20VILL.HTML?pagewanted=1)

headline: Workers in China's Liaoning Province Hold Demonstration
text: ??? According to information obtained by this center, over 1,000 workers of the Liaoyang City Ferroalloy Plant in Liaoning Province held a demonstration this morning in front of the city government building to protest against the court's action of forcibly taking away a lot of raw materials and other supplies from the plant. They requested that the city government do something for the livelihood of the plant's 8,000 workers. We have received confirmation of this demonstration from both the plant and the government department concerned.??? According to what we have learned, the above-mentioned plant, a state-owned enterprise, did pretty good business in the past. But, since the present plant manager took office five years ago, the plant has suffered losses due to improper management. As some workers of this plant told us, their leaders have frequently traveled abroad for sightseeing at the plant's expense, and it is their common practice to use the plant's money for feasting. Last year, with a loss as high as 1.05 billion yuan, the plant filed a petition to the court for bankruptcy. Before the issuance of the bankruptcy order, however, the court used dozens of trucks to carry away some 6,000 tons of raw materials and other supplies from the plant. This happened at 11 p.m. on 17 May. Even the head of the plant's Security Department, Chen Xin, had no previous information on this matter. The workers hold that the materials taken away by the court are the plant's property, which may be used as a source of funds for resettling the workers after they lose their jobs. Because of this, how to treat these materials should be decided by the workers rather than the court. During today's demonstration, the workers held banners reading: "By forcibly taking the property away, court officials have committed the most heinous crime; violation of law by law enforcers cannot be tolerated by the state law." "Investigate the reason for the 1.05 billion yuan loss," and so forth. When the parade of the demonstrators passed by the court, they stopped there and shouted slogans. Then, the demonstrators came to the city government building. Several dozen of them, as representatives, went into the mayor's office to talk with him, while the other demonstrators dispersed. The representatives left by 3 p.m., according to the plant's guard on duty. A staff member of the plant also confirmed that upwards of 1,000 workers demonstrated in front of the city government building. ??? Last week a delegation from Liaoning Province arrived in Hong Kong to solicit investment. In the opinion of this center, the first thing to do in addressing Liaoning's economic problem is to solve the management problems, such as the corruption of the plant leaders, misuse of the plant's funds, and cronyism. If these problems are not solved, overseas investors will have no confidence in their investment in Liaoning.??? Currently, Liaoning's real unemployment rate is more than 20 percent. As a matter of fact, the above-mentioned plant has been unable to pay its workers for a year. After the plant's bankruptcy, its 8,000 workers (including retired workers) will face acute difficulty in obtaining a livelihood.??????? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:

headline: Protest of Hangzhou Taxi Drivers Against Hefty Fees Enter 4th Day
text: ??? Our center has learned that about 500 taxi drivers in Hangzhou were today shifting over to the provincial government building after staging their protests outside the city government for three days, but were stopped by more than 500 public security police before they even reached the provincial government building.?? The taxi drivers were protesting against the imposition of a 30,000 yuan fee by the government.?? About 3,000 taxis will be affected by this measure.??? Our center has learned that the Hangzhou city government announced the introduction of a 30,000 yuan "operating fee" on taxis earlier this month.?? Since taxi drivers are only making about 2,500 yuan a month on the average, the new fee will come as a big burden to them.?? According to government regulations, this fee has to be paid again after a taxi has been sold to others.?? The taxi drivers are very unhappy about these policies.?? On 20 May, 500 taxi drivers (not driving) started their protest in front of the city government, but three days had passed without any government officials approaching them for talks.?? Today the taxi drivers tried to take their protest to the provincial government, but were stopped by over 500 public security police at a road junction about 500 [meters] away from the provincial government building.?? An armed police on duty at the gatehouse of the provincial government building confirmed to us that the protesting drivers were stopped at the road junction, and many taxi stands also confirmed to us news of the protests.23 May 2001[Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: Pedicab Drivers Protest in Changchun; Hebei Villagers Jailed for Leading Protest
text: [multiple events] ??? It has come to the knowledge of our center that about 500 pedicab drivers in Shuangyang district in the suburbs of Changchun staged a demonstration outside the district government office this morning in protest against an increase in management fees, while the sentencing of eight farmers in Hebei's Jize County who protested against high taxes has aroused strong resentment from the local farmers.??? Our center has learned that there are about 5,000 pedicabs in Shuangyang district, and most drivers are laid-off workers and local farmers.?? Since Changchun has had no rain for the past three months, more farmers are joining their ranks because of the drought.?? In order to prevent more people from becoming pedicab drivers, the Shuangyang district government recently decided to charge each pedicab driver an additional annual management fee of 2,800 yuan.?? This aroused the resentment of pedicab drivers, who began blocking the roads leading to the Shuangyang district government at eight this morning with placards bearing slogans like "We Need to Survive."?? It is understood that each pedicab driver only makes about 600 yuan a month, and a management fee of 2,800 yuan is a huge burden on them.?? A government official admitted to us that there was indeed a demonstration by pedicab drivers.??? Our center has also learned that over 2,000 villagers stormed the Fengzheng township government in Hebei's Jize County last September in protest against high taxes.?? On 11 June, eight of the village leaders were sentenced to prison terms ranging from three to five and a half years by the court for "assembling crowds to storm state organs."?? This has aroused strong resentment among farmers in Fengzheng Township.?? According to an informed source, the township recorded a substantially smaller income from grain last year compared with the same period of 1999 as a result of floods and insect pests, but the county and township governments set agricultural taxes at a much higher level than in 1999.?? The villagers of Zhongfengzheng Village under Fengzheng Township took their protests to the county government on 9 September last year.?? That evening, about 500 villagers from that village moved over to the township government with their petition for a reduction in agricultural taxes.?? When news of this spread out, people from other villages in Fengzheng Township joined the demonstrating crowd outside the township government.?? Things went out of control as angry villagers stormed the township government and police station, smashing windows and overturning police cars.?? In the end, 30 farmers were arrested.?? On 11 June, the Jize County Court sentenced the leader Tian Yumin to imprisonment for five and a half years.?? Tian Jianrui and Tian Shubin received a jail term of five years, Tian Qingxiang and Tian Zengfu, four years, and Tian Zhijiang, Tian Pengju and Tian Yumin, three years.??? The party branch secretary of Zhongfengzheng Village confirmed to us that several thousand villagers stormed the township government that evening.?? He said that it was mostly people from other villages, not their own villagers, who smashed and broke things.?? He also confirmed that news of the sentencing had indeed aroused strong resentment among many of their villagers.??? Rural questions will become volcanoes that may erupt any time after China's entry to the World Trade Organization.?? A marked increase in the number of massive disturbances can be expected.?? The authorities have already stepped up their suppression, but increased suppression is likely to trigger greater resistance.13 June 2001[Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: Workers Protesting Against Lay-Offs at Yanshan Petrochemical Complex
text: ??? Tens of thousands of workers have been protesting against lay-offs at the Yanshan Petrochemical Complex, a subsidiary of Sinopec Corporation and one of Beijing's largest state-owned enterprises.??? Refinery staff said workers and pensioners had been involved in a series of demonstrations, strikes and go-slows for the past 20 days.??? "The situation has now become critical," one worker, surnamed Zhang, said.??? More than 100,000 workers are employed at the massive refinery complex in Fangshan county, a satellite town of Beijing.??? The China Petroleum and Chemical Corp -- China's second largest oil company, owns Sinopec, which is listed on Hong Kong's stock market.??? It has promised investors it will carry out drastic cuts among its 500,000-strong workforce to raise profits and is planning to issue A-shares to fund expansion proposals.??? Workers said they feared for their jobs as the company hived off poorly performing assets. Pensioners are concerned they will not be paid once the changes have been implemented. "We think this is to do with [China's] entry into the World Trade Organisation," Mr Zhang said.??? More than 1,000 workers from the corporation's transport subsidiary have refused to turn up, bringing many activities to a standstill. Workers deny they are on strike but are insisting the management come forward and hold direct negotiations with the labour force.??? "We are all very angry about what is happening," said one. "We don't know what our future will be like. The leaders are refusing to talk to us."??? Workers from other subsidiaries are also taking industrial action amid rumours that the company is preparing to sack as many as 10,000 employees. "We want to keep our iron rice bowl because we have been working for the company for many years," another staff member said.??? An official from the administration admitted the plant was racked by industrial strife but insisted the workers were being misled by unfounded rumours.??? "It is normal for there to be conflicts between workers and management," Xiao Du said. "The company is undergoing reform to boost production and reduce labour needs. Those workers nearing retirement age are being asked to step down, it is totally voluntary."??? The management was now involved in intensive "ideological work" with staff who were earmarked to loose their jobs. Mr Xiao insisted there would, be only "a few thousand" job losses.??? Workers are apparently being offered redundancy packages tied to their years of service. According to some, those with more than 20 years' service will be offered 100,000 yuan (HK$94,000).[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper]
source_human: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English
notes_human: More than 100,000 workers are employed at the massive refinery complex in Fangshan county, a satellite town of Beijing

headline: PRC's Guangxi Shangbao Paper Said Ordered To Close
text: ??? Our center has learned that "Guangxi Shangbao [Guangxi Business Daily]," a privately run commercial newspaper that enjoyed the largest circulation in Guangxi, was ordered to close on 7 June by the Guangxi Autonomous CPC Committee.?? About 700 personnel of the newspaper face unemployment.?? On 11 June, personnel at the newspaper staged a demonstration.?? Public security personnel arrested three of the demonstrators.??? Our center has learned the following fact: "Guangxi Shangbao" previously was under the Guangxi Regional Economic and Trade Department.??? In 1999, Chongqing's Lifan Motorcar Group invested in the newspaper.?? As a result, its circulation steadily increased.?? Currently its circulation reached 200,000 copies, with handsome profits from advertisement.?? CPC authorities have always been afraid of the expansion of local privately run newspapers because the rapid growth of these newspapers in the market will lead to the loss of their public opinion front.?? Owing to these facts, they have always adopted a suppressive attitude.??? Since the beginning of this March, the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee has exerted pressure on "Guangxi Shangbao," urging it to merge with "Guangxi Ribao [Guangxi Newspaper]."?? Such a practice has caused great dissatisfaction at "Guangxi Shangbao."?? It resolutely refused to close and merge itself with "Guangxi Ribao."??? With the closure last month of "Shu Bao [Shu Newspaper]" and "Shangwu Zaobao [Commercial Morning Newspaper]" by the order of the Sichuan Provincial CPC Committee, the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee immediately sent its personnel to Sichuan to learn from the experience gained in Sichuan Province.??? On 7 June, the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee suddenly announced that "Guangxi Shangbao" should be closed immediately.?? Meanwhile, 700 personnel of "Guangxi Shangbao" should wait for the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee to help them find another job.?? The closure order, like an earthquake, created quite a shock among the personnel of "Guangxi Shangbao."?? Being extremely unhappy, they decided to stage a demonstration in Nanning on 11 June.?? On the morning of 11 June, some responsible persons of the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee went to the newspaper office and tried to persuade the personnel of "Guangxi Shangbao."?? The workers surrounded these responsible persons.?? During chaotic fighting, some of these responsible persons were injured.?? Later, the authorities sent scores of public security personnel to the site and arrested three of the demonstrators.?? An employee of the newspaper confirmed that the newspaper has been ordered to close.?? He also said that personnel of the Guangxi Regional CPC Committee are afraid to come to the office of the newspaper.?? Therefore, the future of these 700 employees is unknown.?? But he believed that many of the employees would become unemployed.??? Privately run newspapers have witnessed a series of setbacks in China.?? Sichuan's "Tuopu Group" last year invested 50 million yuan in "Shu Bao" and "Shangwu Zaobao."?? At a time when they planed to expand their business, they were suddenly ordered to close in May.?? Meanwhile, Sichuan recently published a new party newspaper "Chengdu Ribao [Chengdu Newspaper]."??? China has witnessed rapid growth in newspapers.??? About 20 years ago, there were only 100 party-run newspapers.?? Now there are 2,200 newspapers, including some tabloids with varieties of contents.?? The newspapers have increasingly attracted citizens' attention.?? On the contrary, party-run newspapers usually carry long speeches made by leaders.?? As a result, these party-run newspapers have increasingly lost their market.?? They have tried to maintain their circulation by forcing individuals or units to describe them.?? Some CPC leaders are worried that these privately run newspapers will cause CPC authorities to lose control of public opinion.?? Therefore, they have tried to force these privately run newspapers to close since last year.??? But such a move has met strong resistance.?? With economic development, some large business groups have begun to invest in newspapers.?? They wish to gain economic profits.?? They also wish to expand their influence.??? However, they do not have any protection for their investment.?? An administrative order can force them to merge with others or to close their business.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: Shandong Dissidents Stage Sit-in Demostration Against Persecution
text: ??? It has been learned by this center that Yan Peng, a well-known dissident in Shandong, was taken into custody as a criminal suspect by the public security bureau of Qingdao City on the morning of 14 July. His house was searched by the police. Yesterday 12 dissidents in the province published an open letter of protest, while three dissident representatives staged a sit-in demonstration in front of the Qingdao Public Security Bureau to protest against such persecution by the authorities right after Beijing had won the right to host the Olympic Games.??? According to what Yan Peng's wife, Zhong Xianye, told us, her husband was detained by the public security authorities at the Guangxi Customs on 11 July when he was going to Vietnam for sightseeing as a member of a tourist group. On 14 July, representatives of the Qingdao Public Security Bureau came to her house and told her that Yan Peng was formally put into criminal detention on the "suspected charge of illegally leaving the country." The public security personnel then searched her house and took away a computer and some other things. Learning of this, dissidents in Shandong were quite indignant. They opined that as Yan Peng had completed all legal procedures for his Vietnam tour and he was arrested in Guangxi, this was an obvious case in which the authorities framed a dissident with a trumped-up criminal charge. Yesterday morning, three dissidents in Qingdao, namely, Mu Chuanheng, Li Xielin, and Mu Xiaobo visited the Qingdao Public Security Bureau, but the personnel there refused to talk with them. To express their protest, they sat quietly at the gate of the public security bureau despite the broiling hot weather. Later, 12 dissidents issued an open letter to the international community, saying that the Chinese Communists had promised to improve the human rights situation when bidding for the Olympic Games, but persecuted a dissident right after obtaining the right to host the games. This is cheating the public of the international community, the letter concludes. Today, Mu Chuanheng and others have hired a lawyer for Yan Peng.??? Yan Peng, 38, took part in the 1989 democratic movement. He once ran a computer company and was one of the earliest dissidents using the Internet. He has helped many dissidents in this country to go on line and use the Internet. Because of this, he has been arrested several times by the public security authorities. ??? Before Beijing succeeded in its Olympic bid, a number of "subversive cases" originally scheduled to be tried shortly had been held up. Now that it has won the right to host the Olympic Games, these cases are expected to be tried one after another. According to our prediction, in August and September, 20 dissidents will be brought to trial on the charge of "subverting the state power." These 20 dissidents, including Li Wangyang, Yang Zili, Xu Wei, Huang Qi, Lu Xinhua, Wang Jinbo, and Hu Mingjun, may be given the heavy sentence of more than 10 years' imprisonment.??? Before voting for the Olympic host, many members of the International Olympic Committee believed that making Beijing the host city would help China improve its human rights situation. As this center views it, however, this is merely a wishful thinking. In reality, giving Beijing the right to host the Olympic Games can only beef up the Chinese Communists' one-party dictatorship, thereby making China's road to democracy even longer. The most fundamental reason that human rights are infringe upon in China is one-party dictatorship. This is because the Chinese Communists' basic purpose of suppressing dissidents is no other than preserving their one-party dictatorship.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: AFP: Police Clash With 1,000 Farmers Protesting Corruption in Guangdong
text: ??? BEIJING, July 29 (AFP) -- More than 450 police clashed with up to 1,000 farmers during a protest against alleged corruption in a village in southern China's Guangdong province, state media said Sunday.?? ??? Thirteen villagers and some 10 police officers were injured in the clash Wednesday at Xihai village, Beijiao township in the city of Shunde, the Yangcheng Evening News said.?? Police detained 19 people.?? ??? A group of 1,000 protestors blocked a highway and paralyzed traffic in the morning, prompting local officials to call in 200 police officers who dispersed the protestors.?? Five villagers were detained.?? ??? In the afternoon, 1,000 demonstrators returned, this time surrounding the Communist Party village committee's office.?? ??? Some of the villagers pushed past a police blockade, throwing stones and bricks at the office building, smashing windows and damaging offices as well as several vehicles, including police vehicles, the report said.?? ??? Some 450 police officers were dispatched to the scene.?? ??? The protestors were angry that they had not seen any of the money raised by public land sales and rentals spent on their village, the report said.?? ??? Villagers also suspected Communist Party cadres had spent public funds at casinos in the nearby former Portuguese enclave and regional gambling hub Macao.?? ??? Shunde city officials later promised to investigate officials for alleged corruption, but said cadres had not been to Macao in years.?? ??? They also blamed the lack of funds going to the village on necessary procedures not having been completed.?? ??? Demonstrations are becoming more common in China, especially in the countryside, where peasants suffer from widespread corruption, high taxes and maltreatment by tyrannical local officials.?? ??? In 1999, 100,000 protests occurred, compared with 60,000 protests in 1998, according to the Hong Kong-based information center, which cites internal government statistics.?? Actual figures are expected to be much higher as many protests are not reported to the central government.?? ??? Most of the protests involved workers, while last year reports of up to 20,000 protesters blocking major roads or railways were not uncommon.?? Some demonstrations ended only after violent clashes with police.?? ??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: FEATURE-China puts infrastructure first in western push.
text: XINING, China, July 31 (Reuters) - Outside the gate of the Qinghai provincial government headquarters, more than 30 Tibetans stage a silent but futile protest against China's drive to develop its lagging western regions.The residents of rural Songduo county have travelled to the provincial capital Xining to protest against the seizure of their land in the name of the "Great Western Development" programme."The government took our land and didn't give any reason," said one man sitting on the ground outside the government offices. "What does western development mean? You tell me."Almost two years after China launched the development push, new highways, bridges and tunnels have sprung up amid the scarred brown hills surrounding Xining.But China's emphasis on big projects and infrastructure works has failed to improve the lives of many.For the farmers and herders of Qinghai, which borders Tibet, average income was 1,490 yuan ($180) last year, two-thirds of the national level for rural households with little growth from 1999.Qinghai has won three major projects in the programme - a $2.4 billion railway to Tibet, a $338 million potash fertiliser plant and a $300 million natural gas pipeline stretching 950 km (590 miles) to Lanzhou.None of the projects is finished yet."For Tibetan people, it's health, it's education, it's skills training, it's not big infrastructure projects, which facilitate more Han Chinese people moving into the area," said Alison Reynolds, director of the London-based Free Tibet Campaign rights group."They (Han Chinese) have more skills than Tibetans so will always be better placed to benefit from the employment opportunities that arise," she said.CHINA'S TRANSPORT WOESChina will invest $13 billion in Qinghai's infrastructure in the next five years with funding earmarked for more highways and three new airports, officials said.More basic infrastructure is needed before a wave of prosperity can wash over western regions, which lag far behind booming eastern provinces, they said."Transport is the basis of economic development," said vice mayor of Qinghai's Golmud city, Xia Jiaxiang.Chinese companies say the biggest problems for operating in the west are the big distances and high transport costs.For Qinghai Salt Lake Industry Co, builder of the new potash fertiliser plant, it takes up to seven days to ship products to markets in southern and eastern China by truck and rail.Salt Lake's freight charges are $20 a tonne, taking the price of its potash fertiliser to around $115, not much less than the same product shipped all the way from Canada.Officials of Golmud Oil Refinery, a branch of industry giant PetroChina Co, said the new railway to Tibet would lower costs and increase demand for its crude and oil products."After the economy develops, market demand will grow and we will benefit," said Miao Geng, the refinery's vice director.Golmud vice mayor Xia said the railway alone would create 50,000 jobs and swell the population of the western boomtown to 350,000 from the current 200,000.That is what worries human rights groups. Ethnic Tibetans account for only 21 percent of Qinghai's 4.95 million population and that ratio is shrinking."UNIVERSITY INFRASTRUCTURE"Analysts say western regions desperately need infrastructure but China should not neglect education, medical care and other programmes to help improve people's daily lives.It could take a decade for the western development drive to show results, they say.When China announced the first batch of western development projects last year, six involved transport, although the building of "university infrastructure" was part of the plan."Clearly an investment in people, in education, is probably the best investment any government can make," said Bruce Murray, representative for the Asian Development Bank in China."So more money clearly has to go into things like education and health to balance off the other investments in infrastructure and the environment."In Qinghai, the one environmental protection initiative is a scheme to stop farmers from growing rape and barley - a staple food crop - in exchange for 90 kg (200 lb) of grain and $2.40 in cash for every one-fifteenth of a hectare (0.17 acre).The plan to turn farmland into grassland because of overgrazing and rapid population growth has faced opposition from producers, who want more compensation."It's not enough, but what can I do," said Tibetan herdsman San Cheng Jia from his house on the fertile shores of Qinghai Lake. "If we plant more grass, I can raise more sheep and yaks. Beyond that, I don't know what western development means."($1=8.277 Yuan).
notes_human: "The government took our land and didn't give any reason," said one man sitting on the ground outside the government offices. "What does western development mean? You tell me."

headline: AFP: Falungong Members Begin Hunger Strike in Hong Kong
text: ??? HONG KONG, Aug 25 (AFP) - Hong Kong followers of the Falungong spiritual group began a hunger strike Saturday in solidarity with 130 fellow members staging a similar protest on the Chinese mainland.?? ??? Spokeswoman Hui Yee-han told AFP that police had threatened the protesters with prosecution for obstruction minutes after about 10 members started their indefinite protest outside the Chinese liaison office here.?? ??? She said police told the group that they were "obstructing the pavement" and were being a nuisance to the pedestrians and the public.?? ??? "The police warned us, saying that if we don't leave, they will prosecute us," she said.?? ??? The hunger strike in Hong Kong mirrors similar protests carried out outside the Chinese embassies in New York, Washington and London.?? ??? They were inspired by a group of some 130 followers held in Masanjia labor camp in China's Liaoning Province.?? ??? "The practitioners there have been on a hunger strike for three weeks after they were illegally detained and had their basic human rights violated," Hui said, adding that "they were close to death".?? ??? Falungong combines Buddhist-based philosophy and slow-motion meditation exercises, and advocates say it promotes clean living and good health.?? ??? It was banned by the Chinese government in July 1999 in a move seen by many analysts as a sign top leaders feared its ability to mobilise vast numbers of protesters.?? ??? But the movement is still legal in Hong Kong which enjoys a large degree of autonomy from Beijing under the terms of the 1997 handover agreement which saw sovereignty transferred from Britain to China.?? ????? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Relatives of dead in Chinese disco fire protest in Beijing - Hong Kong report.
text: Text of report by Radio TV Hong Kong audio web site on 11 OctoberThe relatives of some of the 309 people who died in a disco fire in Luoyang [Henan Province] last Christmas have staged a protest outside a Beijing court. Around 35 protesters stood in silence in front of the Supreme People's Court, wearing black tee-shirts and holding up a banner with pictures of the victims. They were demanding the prosecution of local safety officials in the city.Police watched the protest, but did not intervene. However, a Russian television crew's video tapes were confiscated. Twenty-three people have been sentenced in connection with the blaze, including nine safety officials.Source: RTHK Radio 3 audio web site, Hong Kong, in English 1000 gmt 11 Oct 01.
notes_human: disco fire in Luoyang [Henan Province] last Christmas

headline: Dissident Han Lifa reported confined to hotel prior to APEC meeting.
text: Text of report by Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy on 15 OctoberFive hundred Qingdao residents staged a protest against government policy on their relocation and two protesters were taken away after clashing with police.Prominent dissident Han Lifa was taken away by police from his home prior to an APEC [Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation] meeting.We have learned that about 500 relocated Qingdao residents have staged a protest this morning against the government's policy on their relocation in front of the seat of the municipal government. According to witnesses, two protesters were taken away after clashing with police. The municipal government confirmed the demonstration to us. Separately, the noted dissident Han Lifa was taken from his home by police prior to the APEC meeting. It is expected that he will be confined in a hotel during the APEC meetings.It has been learned that the main reason for the demonstration in front of the municipal government was that the protesters were dissatisfied with the government's relocation policy and re-building plan. The protesters are all from the Fushansuo relocation zone. Residents of the zone were relocated three years ago. The Weidong Real Estate Development Company was tasked with rebuilding the zone.Prior to their relocation, the municipal government had promised thousands of residents that after rebuilding, new residential quarters would be greener and not have many business facilities. But in reality, after rebuilding the zone, it has neither green nor public places for outdoor activities, but does have many business facilities. So the residents don't want to move back to the new residential quarters due to the bad environment.Starting yesterday, several hundred residents came to the municipal government to protest, and today there were about 500 people blocking the east gate of the municipal government. More than 50 policemen were sent to the scene by the authorities, and two protesters were taken away after clashes with police. The guard at the east gate of the municipal government confirmed that there were about 500 demonstrators in the morning at the seat of the municipal government, but left at noon.At present, the worker's protests and the relocation residents' protests are the two main origins of the city's demonstrations. The protest against relocation is related to conflicts of interest that arise from every quarter, mostly because officials collude with developers to satisfy developers in the cost of relocating residents.The APEC meeting will start soon. Shanghai's police have begun to control dissidents strictly. Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock the prominent dissident Han Lifa was taken from his home by three policemen from the Yangpu branch of Shanghai Public Security Bureau. Police told Han's family afterwards that Han would be held in a hotel for a period of time.No outside contact can be made with Han, so it is unknown in which hotel he is confined. It is expected that he will be released only after the APEC meeting ends. Han is one of the founders of China Democratic Party in Shanghai. He was sentenced to three years reform through labour in 1999 and got released this July. Recently, Shanghai police have strengthened control over dissidents in Shanghai. In 1998 prior to Clinton's visit to Shanghai, more than 10 dissidents were confined to a hotel or forced to travel to other places accompanied by police. It is expected the same thing will happen this time.Telephone: Han Lifa: 21-65410275 East gate of Qingdao Municipal Government: 532-5911139 Protesters: 532-5911610Source: Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 15 Oct 01.
source_human: Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy

headline: AFP: Five Jailed in South China for Inciting School Children To Protest
text: ??? BEIJING, Jan 2 (AFP) - Five people, including a farmer, have been jailed for up to 10 years for inciting school children and their parents to protest over high tuition fees and taxes in an unusual two-day riot in south China, sources said Wednesday.?? ??? Township government offices were burned, policemen beaten and officials' motorcycles stolen during the clash between about 1,000 students, parents and onlookers and about 300 police officers, a local government official told AFP.?? ??? The incident happened on February 10, 2001 in Xianchen township, in Guangdong province's Chaoyang city, about 200 kilometers (125 miles) east of the capital Guangzhou, but was not reported in Chinese media until after the sentencing on December 31.?? ??? Farmer Zhao Guoqiang, 37, who did not want to pay water fees and had other gripes with the township government, seized upon students' and parents' frustrations over tuition fees and mobilized them to confront the government, the Southern Daily said Wednesday.?? ??? A township government official told AFP by telephone that the demonstration involved about 500 protestors and another 500 onlookers, many of whom later joined the riot.?? ??? "Elementary students, middle school and high school students and their parents were participated.?? ...?? Many of the families were very poor.?? They had to pay 200 yuan (24 dollars) per semester in tuition," the official said.?? ??? The average per capita annual income of rural families in China is about 2,200 yuan (265 dollars), according to official statistics, but many families earn less than that and have at least two children.?? ??? Demonstrators attacked police, government officials and office buildings with stones and bricks and shouted slogans while some waved banners and flags as they roared through the streets on motorcycles, the official said.?? ??? They raided government office buildings, stealing office workers' personal belongings and setting fire to 107 rooms, the Southern Daily said.?? ??? Two hundred regular police and another 100 armed police were dispatched to the scene, but could not quell the protest until the second day, the official said.?? ??? Some 100 policemen and officials were injured, the official said, but he did not provide information on how many protestors were hurt.?? ??? Zhao, the ringleader, and four others who were considered organizers, were sentenced by the Chaoyang City People's Court on December 31, with Zhao receiving 10 years in prison and the others sentenced to five to six years imprisonment.?? ??? Eighteen others were also sentenced for taking part in the riot, but their sentences were not revealed.?? ??? The total economic loss from the riot was 2.6 million yuan (313,000 dollars), the report said.?? ??? Government officials did not agree to protestors' demands to lower tuition and water charges.?? ??? The demonstration points to growing unrest among China's farmers, who are frustrated over arbitrary and excessive taxes set by local government officials as well as the lack of rule of law in the countryside.?? ??? In 1999, the number of demonstrations reported to the central government reached 100,000 nationwide -- about 270 a day -- up nearly 70 percent from the previous year, according to a Hong Kong-based human rights center.?? More recent figures are not available but protests are on the rise, it said.?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Angry Chinese protesters call on Li Peng to pay back their money
text: BEIJING, Jan 16 (AFP) - More than 100 protesters gathered outside the offices of Beijing's People's Congress Wednesday, demanding the government reopen an investigation into an investment scam linked to the son of powerful Communist Party leader Li Peng."Li Peng, give us back our money," shouted the protesters, many clad in white T-shirts with their demands scribbled on them."We demand the return of the money we earned with our blood and tears."Protesters alleged a government ruling that the Xinguoda Futures Brokerage Co. was an illegal enterprise was a pretext to end further investigations into the company and protect the offspring of well- placed leaders.Several van-loads of police surrounded the protesters and separated them from onlookers, but did not make any effort to end the demonstration."Li Xiaoyong is the elder son of parliament head Li Peng, a high official of the People's Armed Police, and the main suspect in the 200 million yuan (24 million dollars) missing in the Xinguoda case," a flyer handed out by a protester said.The flyer alleged that the armed police's Kangda Trading Company had a five percent stake in Xinguoda at the behest of Li Xiaoyong, who garnered 1.2 million yuan commission in the transaction.Li also made away with funds as the company collapsed in 1998, other leaflets said.According to official state news reports, Xinguoda was run by Taiwanese businessman Cao Yufei, who was executed last year for bilking investors out of some 532 million yuan (64 million dollar) in investment funds.Protesters told AFP that for three years they have been beseeching the Beijing government to investigate the connections between Li Xiaoyong, other mainland business and government officials and Cao Yufei.The group holds regular protests at the municiple government and the offices of Beijing's Communist Party, they said.Leaflets dispersed at the demonstration also contained several pictures of the former Xinguoda manager playing tennis with powerful Politburo members Li Tieying, Luo Gan and Wu Bangguo.Luo Gan also serves as the head of the Communist Party's Politics and Law Commission, China's leading judicial and law enforcement body, known to Western diplomats in Beijing as the "police behind the police state."The leaflets claim that Cao and his cronies used pictures and videotape of their meetings with China's highest leaders to attract funds into their scam on the promise of impeccable political backing.Upon his execution last May, state television said Cao had cheated investors out of 320 million yuan, and that only 40 million yuan had been recovered, while Xinhua news agency said Cao was responsible for a 532 million yuan scam upon his arrest in 1998.sai/cs/th
notes_human: Li Peng's son scam investment

headline: China detains 20 Western Falun Gong protesters.
text: BEIJING, Feb 14 (Reuters) - Chinese police detained about 20 Western members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement on Thursday after a brief but lively protest in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, witnesses said.Demonstrators threw the square into chaos for about 15 minutes as they unfurled yellow banners and shouted "Falun Gong is good!" in a protest against China's crackdown on the banned spiritual movement. It was not immediately clear what their nationalities were.Some sprinted across the vast plaza screaming slogans as hundreds of uniformed and plainclothes police officers chased them. Police tackled some protesters to the ground, kicking and punching some, before wrestling them into police vans, witnesses said.Astonished Chinese tourists, sightseeing in the heart of Beijing for the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, crowded round to watch as almost every Westerner on the square was detained for protesting.It was the second demonstration this week by Western Falun Gong members in Tiananmen. China expelled a Canadian and an American follower of the movement on Tuesday, one day after they launched a Lunar New Year protest in Tiananmen.

headline: AFP - China: More on Apartment Residents Scuffle With Police Over Living Conditions
text: ??? BEIJING, March 2 (AFP) - Scuffles broke out Saturday between police and residents of an apartment complex in Beijing after a demonstration which tested the limits of official tolerance and underlined the growing assertiveness of China's middle classes. The protest, staged over plans for a new building near the Wangjing New City compound, had been permitted by the authorities, but was heavily supervised by uniformed and plain-clothes police.??? "As long as we stay inside the compound, the authorities can accept it," said one of the about 300 protesters. "All the police are here because they are afraid we might go out into the streets." ??? Towards the end of the otherwise orderly demonstration, police confiscated a tape from a foreign TV crew, triggering scuffles as residents tried to intervene. ??? Protesters and officers tussled, shouting and pulling at each other's coats, as the police tried to leave the compound with the tape. ??? Order again descended over the scene as organizers calmed furious residents with appeals shouted through a megaphone. ??? The demonstration eventually drew to a more peaceful conclusion, after 90 minutes. ??? The immediate target of the protest was the planned construction of a 33-floor apartment building nearby, which the residents feared would obstruct the view and dramatically lower the value of their apartments. ??? Residents said Wangjing's developer, Beijing City Development Group, had sold part of the compound area for the new project. ??? One demonstrator said this reflected the way Chinese society offered special advantages for well-connected businesses. ??? "Although this is not a political demonstration, in the end it's still about politics," he said. ??? At Saturday's demonstration, which started shortly after 10 a.m. (0200 GMT) in the center of the compound, residents patiently took turns airing their grievances over a prepared sound system. ??? Eager listeners, holding small yellow and pink banners demanding an end to the construction work, commented with angrily shouted remarks. ??? "Down with profiteers!" shouted one elderly woman, receiving a enthusiastic applause from the crowd. ??? "This wouldn't have happened just a few years back," said one of the demonstrators, who asked not to be named. "It shows that China is opening up and is gradually moving towards democracy." ??? Anecdotal evidence suggests that demonstrations by China's burgeoning and increasingly vociferous middle class are not uncommon. ??? The residents at Wangjing New City are typical of this new and bolder kind of Chinese citizen -- well-educated professionals who have often studied or worked abroad and seen civil disobedience in action. ??? The Chinese authorities appear undecided on how to handle this challenge, and in cases like Wangjing settle for compromise solutions in the form of disciplined protests within strictly defined boundaries. ??? "We didn't get final approval until late last night," said one of the organizers, a woman surnamed Li. ??? "The police placed the condition that it would have to take place inside the compound and not outside," she said.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]
notes_human: The protest, staged over plans for a new building near the Wangjing New City compound, had been permitted by the authorities, but was heavily supervised by uniformed and plain-clothes police.

headline: Chinese workers protest in northeast city - locals.
text: BEIJING, March 11 (Reuters) - About 5,000 workers from bankrupt factories protested outside a government compound in northeast China on Monday calling for the head of the local legislature to be sacked, officials and a rights group said.The peaceful demonstration at the headquarters of the Liaoyang city government in Liaoning province came as China's top legislative body, the National People's Congress (NPC), held its annual two-week session in Beijing.A security official in Liaoyang said the protest, which lasted the whole morning, was peaceful and well-organised."Those are workers from bankrupt factories. They waved banners demanding that Gong Shangwu, director of the city People's Congress, be fired," the official told Reuters.The workers made no other demands and refused to talk to officials, he said.The protest was the latest example of growing unrest among Chinese workers, millions of whom face redundancy under an expected onslaught of foreign competition following China's entry to the World Trade Organisation last year.Last week, Chinese leaders pledged to support workers by boosting welfare spending by 28 percent.The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said the Liaoyang workers were from six state-owned factories in the city which had gone broke or were on the brink of bankruptcy.Many of the workers had not been paid for up to 18 months, the centre said in a statement."The workers are strongly dissatisfied with the failure of the People's Congress to represent them and to supervise government operation," the statement said.
