Afterward, BEIJING, Jan 1 (AFP) - Two labour leaders arrested in March in northeastern China will be charged with subverting the power of the state, a crime which carries the possibility of the death penalty, rights organization China Labor Watch (CLW) reported Wednesday. The two were arrested in Liaoyang city in March following large-scale demonstrations in which thousands of people denounced corrupt local politicians and demanded greater help for laid-off workers.

headline: Beijing homeowners protest for redress.
text: BEIJING, March 13 (Reuters) - Disgruntled Beijing homeowners blocked a construction site on Wednesday they said was illegal, damaged the structural soundness of their apartments and threatened to impede their view.Several homeowners, including elderly Communist Party cadres, sat watch in a minivan parked blocking the entrance to the idle work site adjacent to their apartments at the Wangjing New City development and prepared to take their case to court.The protest began on the eve of the annual two-week session of the National People's Congress (NPC) due to end on Friday.It shows ordinary Chinese are finding new ways to seek redress in a tightly controlled system in which public protests are barely tolerated at the best of times, let alone during the NPC session.On the eve of the NPC, some 600 residents rallied inside the the complex, waving banners and chanting slogans that were approved in advance by police, who kept a close watch."The government showed us a model of the complex and we were sure it could protect its model," one resident surnamed Liu said at the construction site, now a hole 30 metres (100 ft) deep.Like Liu, hundreds of others who bought apartments at Wangjing in the mid-1990s felt secure because it was built by a government state firm and was called a model housing complex.None opposed plans for a three-storey building in a corner of the grounds.But when those plans were scrapped in favour of a 33-storey office complex that would tower three floors above the apartments and block their prime view of Beijing's fast changing skyline, residents felt betrayed."Originally, when I bought this land, it was to enjoy a certain environment. Now that environment is gone," Liu said."I think things like this tend to be a good sign. The public is gaining a bit more of a voice," one Western diplomat said. "And it's a good sign that these things are allowed."DOWN WITH THE PROFITEERS!The mostly middle-class residents say they have tried unsuccessfully to get the developers to explain the change of plan and produce the proper licenses. The developers could not be reached for comment.On a temporary wall surrounding the construction site, complaints are spray painted in one metre (three foot) high characters: "Down with the profiteers! Stop the work!"Similar messages and an open letter of complaint addressed to senior leaders, including NPC members, and government bodies, are taped to the windows of the minivan.The Wangjing protesters tread a fine line, but their complaints are steeped in the language of the ruling party and their complaints are economic, not political.Attempts by adherents of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement to protest in Tiananmen Square during the NPC were quashed within seconds this week and last. The Communist Party accuses the movement of political aims, which it denies."Our lives are at risk, our property is damaged and until now nobody has cared," the letter said, demanding an investigation into a crack that now runs up the wall of the apartment building abutting the construction site."More important is purifying the Party's character, protect the Party's interests, protect people's faith in the Party and its radiance," it said. "We hope party and government organisations will guard the gate of 'seeking truth from facts'."The protesters posted complaints in the hallway of one building in what one resident said resembled the "big character posters" used to air criticisms during the Cultural Revolution but also in in later demonstrations, including the 1989 democracy movement.They have also collected several hundred signatures against the building and in support of the effort to see the legal documents permitting the developers to build the offices."We don't think that's unreasonable," Liu said.

headline: AFP: More on Laid-Off Oil Workers Expected To Join Labor Protest in NE China
text: ??? BEIJING, March 14 (AFP) - A wave of protests by laid-off oil workers in northeastern China continued Thursday after two weeks of demonstrations thought to have been among the biggest seen in the country in recent years.?? ??? Former workers from the Daqing oilfield staged a sit-in protest in the city of the same name in front of the Petroleum Administration Bureau (PAB) office building.?? ??? One of the protestors, who gave his name as Yu, told AFP he was expecting 20,000 sacked workers to show up but police and company officials said nowhere near that number had materialised.?? ??? The protests in Daqing began on March 1 when about 3,000 former workers marched on the company, blaming management for reneging on commitments concerning severance pay and retirement and medical insurance benefits.?? ??? The firm recently demanded the sacked workers increase their pension and health care insurance premiums to 10,000 yuan (1,200 dollars) this year up from a previously agreed 3,900 yuan, Yu said.?? ??? Up to 50,000 protesters had demonstrated Monday, following equally large protests last week, while on Tuesday numbers had tapered off to about 20,000, Yu said.?? ??? Local police, paramilitary police and military units surrounded the PAB building for days to maintain order, but besides occasional pushing and shoving no heated confrontation had broken out, he said.?? ??? "It is hard to say how many protesters have been in the streets as they tend to exaggerate their numbers, while the company and government under-report," Han Dongfang of the Hong Kong-based China Labor Bulletin, told AFP.?? ??? The rights group has been monitoring the protests from Hong Kong and has aired the workers' demands on its Internet site.?? ??? Daqing is one of China's key state-owned oilfields and was once the crown jewel of China's state-planned economic system.?? ??? It is now a subsidiary of PetroChina, one of China's major petroleum companies, which is listed on the Hong Kong stock market.?? ??? An official at the Daqing company office confirmed Thursday a protest had begun but said the numbers were not big.?? ??? "The workers are out there now, but there are not 20,000 of them," a women in the PAB's security office told AFP.?? ??? Despite the size of the demonstrations, it had appeared that the company had not formally decided that the worker's actions were a protest, a decision that would put the workers in violation of the law.?? ??? "I can't say for sure, but it seems that the management is not yet considering the worker's action a protest, the workers are only handing over formal complaints," said the official, refusing to identify herself.?? ??? China has strict laws restricting protests and the organization of independent worker's unions.?? ??? According to the China Labor Bulletin, around 80,000 workers at the Daqing company have been laid off in recent years as part of China's ongoing economic reforms, which have seen millions lose their jobs nationwide.?? ??? China Labor Bulletin said workers had set up an independent union, the Daqing PAB Retrenched Workers' Provisional Union Committee, and elected representatives.?? ??? Yu said that no elections had taken place, but that representatives had been chosen to negotiate the workers' demands.?? ??? "We are not afraid of the authorities because we know we are right and that what the management has done is illegal," Yu said.?? ??? "Right now our tactics are to sit in and negotiate, but if the PAB doesn't meet our demands then we may have to take other illegal measures like going to Beijing to protest or blocking up traffic." ?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: AIDS Patients Protest Outside Henan Government Office Demanding Medicine
text: ??? BEIJING, March 26 (AFP) -- Eighty farmers from a village in central China, where many residents were stricken with the HIV/AIDS virus after selling their blood for money, protested outside government offices Tuesday, demanding medicine, a protestor told AFP. ??? Chen Yanjun, an AIDS patient, said the protestors -- all from the village of Wenlou in Henan province -- held a protest from 8 am (midnight GMT) until evening outside the offices of the Shangcai county government. ??? "We need effective medicine. The medicine they give us is useless," said Chen, whose wife died of AIDS last month and who has been tested positive for HIV and is showing signs of AIDS. ??? "We don't plan to go home soon. Going home just means dying." ??? Some 60 police officers stood nearby, Chen said. ??? County officials denied anyone had protested, but nearby residents said they saw about 200 people, including many spectators, gathered outside the government office. ??? "The protestors came on four tractors," said one resident. ??? The protest is the biggest held by AIDS patients to date. In December, four villagers with AIDS, including Chen, were arrested by county police for "disturbing public order when they demanded medication at a local hospital." ??? They were released after several days. ??? The farmers are at the center of one of the most shocking health scandals in China. ??? According to official figures, at least 100,000 people in Henan were infected with the AIDS virus after selling blood from the mid-1980's until the mid-1990's to boost their meager income. ??? They contracted the disease because health officials in Henan allowed blood stations using unsanitary blood-collecting methods to operate. ??? Independent Chinese doctors estimate the number of infected are much higher, and could easily be more than 500,000. ??? Most of the cases occurred in small villages like Wenlou where knowledge of the disease is scant and villagers were poor and desperate for money. ??? The Chinese government initially responded to the crisis with silence and inaction, but following media reports it finally admitted the problem late last year. ??? Local governments have opened a free clinic in Wenlou village, while stationing police there 24-hours a day to keep journalists out and to monitor villagers' actions. ??? But villagers said the clinic provides only basic medicine. As they watch family members and fellow villagers die in high numbers, many have begun demanding the government do more. ??? Many also suspect the medicine provided by the clinic is fake. ??? "We want medicine that will make the fever go away," Chen said. ??? Seventy to 80 people from Wenlou died of AIDS last year, while around eight people have died this year, said Chen, who has been one of the most outspoken AIDS patients from the village.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]
notes_human: AIDS: Some 60 police officers stood nearby, Chen said. ??? County officials denied anyone had protested, but nearby residents said they saw about 200 people, including many spectators, gathered outside the government office. ??? "The protestors came on four tractors," said one resident. ??? The protest is the biggest held by AIDS patients to date.

headline: UPDATE 2-Beijing retirees cry foul, protest outside plant.
text: BEIJING, March 27 (Reuters) - About 200 retired car workers blocked traffic in Beijing on Wednesday to protest years of overdue pension payments and corruption, dispersing peacefully only after factory officials agreed to meet them, witnesses said.The protest outside the plant was the latest in a rash of demonstrations across China by laid-off workers demanding back pay or compensation for thin retirement benefits at a time of wrenching reforms to the lumbering state sector.Frustrated elderly retirees told Reuters they crowded the gates of the ailing Beijing Automobile and Motorcycle Works factory early on Wednesday expecting to meet management but found themselves locked out.The retirees, some feeble and in their seventies, spilled into streets and blocked traffic for several hours along the busy thoroughfare in the eastern part of the capital, witnesses said.Police negotiated with the crowd amid a cacophony of car horns, and only convinced them to clear the streets after company officials agreed to hear their claims on Thursday morning at the plant, witnesses said.The protesters, who dispersed in the early afternoon, said officials pocketed or wasted profits from last year's sale of prime factory land to state broadcaster CCTV instead of paying pensions to laid-off workers and retirees."They sold off the land to CCTV and they divided all the profit among themselves," said one 70-year-old retiree.As the protest ended, she shuffled home in a white head scarf worn by manual labourers, leaning on a 68-year-old former co-worker as she crossed the street."For years they said they were going to solve our problems but instead they looked for all kinds of reasons to suppress us," said her younger colleague, who declined to be identified.Pensioners said they were owed as much as three to four years' welfare, housing and medical compensation, amounting to tens of thousands of yuan.Protesters said payments had dwindled to virtually nothing since a series of deductions and delays beginning around 1990, and their impromptu protest began only after they were barred from taking their grievances to the company."They said they would meet with us today, so we all came out at 8:30 (a.m.), but then they locked us out and wouldn't see us. All we could do was stand around on the street," said the 68-year-old worker.CROWDED SECTORBeijing Automobile Works once belonged to a state-owned conglomerate responsible for China's first joint venture, Beijing Jeep. That 1983 merger between Beijing Automotive Industry and the former American Motors Corp was inherited by Chrysler in 1987 and DaimlerChrysler in 1998.The Beijing Jeep venture took the quality assets of the factory where Wednesday's protests flared, and the plant was reorganised as a separate car and motorcycle factory.Production dwindled in the crowded sector, however, and was recently halted ahead of its imminent shutdown, said an official."Our production has been suspended and we are in the process of taking apart the plant," she told Reuters.About 5,000 still employed by the plant were facing forced early retirement or possible layoffs, workers said.The elderly women said they could not comprehend how a firm once tied to what was once China's most prominent joint venture could leave its veterans in the lurch."The company was profitable for many years and we had a lot to do with that," said the 68-year-old worker. "Then all of the sudden there was nothing."The 70-year-old, weakened by diabetes, described a vicious cycle of sickness and poverty."When we were young, we endured hardship and exhaustion at the factory, and now we are old and sick," she said."But they don't give any welfare for us to live on, so we get sicker. And then when we buy our medicines they don't reimburse us," she said.HOMES SEARCHEDGrowing discontent among retrenched workers has highlighted China's concerns over social stability in the sensitive run-up to a leadership transition late this year, when senior officials including President Jiang Zemin are due to step down from their Communist Party posts.In China's northeastern rustbelt, thousands of protesters have demonstrated in the city of Liaoyang and the oil town of Daqing in recent weeks, although both centres were quiet on Wednesday.A laid-off worker from Liaoning's Ferroalloy Factory said workers there were planning a new demonstration on Thursday after a two-day break."The elderly retirees among us are really tired and they need some rest," the worker said.Four labour leaders detained by police for their role in the Liaoyang protests remained in custody. Plainclothes police searched two of the leaders' homes on Tuesday for "documents and contact books" but did not find anything, witnesses said.

On 27 March, some 200 retired workers from the Beijing Automobile Works held a demonstration in front of the plant's gate to protest the plant's long arrears of their pension funds.?? The arrears, they claimed, have left them unable to maintain their basic livings.   A witness to the demonstration claimed that a number of retired workers who are in their 60s and 70s arrived in the early morning of 27 March outside the gate of the Beijing Automobile Works.?? Most of the demonstrators either stood or sat on the center of a highway near the East Third Ring Road in Beijing, impeding the circulation of vehicles and causing a serious traffic jam for several hours to nearby areas. ??? Some 30 public security personnel were at the scene to keep a close watch on the demonstrating workers. The police negotiated with the demonstrators and urged them to leave, without success. The police, however, did not take action to disperse them. It was only after the plant agreed to send a representative to hear their grievances then the demonstrators began to gradually disperse

headline: AFP: 150 Farmers Stage Sit-In Protest in Beijing over Government Seizure of Farmland
text: ??? BEIJING, April 11 (AFP) - About 150 farmers from a rural district of Beijing staged a sit-in outside government offices Thursday, demanding compensation for land the government repossessed for development.?? ??? The farmers squatted outside the headquarters of the Beijing People's Congress -- the city's legislature -- for several hours, taking up almost the entire sidewalk outside the government building.?? ??? There is a growing trend in China toward carrying out such protests, which get almost immediate reaction from a government wary of social unrest, and away from repeated individual appeals for help, which often go nowhere.?? ??? And the problems faced by the demonstrators are shared by an increasingly large number of Beijing residents, many of whom are having to vacate their property to make way for development.?? ??? The city is rushing to beautify ahead of the 2008 Olympics, and to put up residential housing and satellite towns aimed at boosting government revenues.?? ??? Thursday's demonstrators were farmers from Beishenshu village, in Tongzhou district, a mostly agricultural area southeast of the Beijing city center, which the government hopes to urbanize to stimulate economic growth.?? ??? A few years ago, the government began taking over the farmland and using it to build factories or shops, said the rice farmers.?? ??? But "not one family received any compensation," said a woman, who requested anonymity.?? "We have very little land left to farm.?? We have no way to survive, so we came here." ??? The farmers have been appealing to various levels of government for a long time, and organizing a large gathering outside government offices was their last resort.?? ??? An official surnamed Liu from the Tongzhou district government said the farmers were not entitled to compensation because they did not contract out the land for their use.?? ??? The farmers form a farming collective, and compensation has been paid to the village government for use on village-related services, such as road repairs and factory construction, he said.?? ??? Liu said money has been paid to village officials, but farmers counter they should be entitled to some individual compensation since land repossession has resulted in a loss of livelihood.?? ??? "Many people are scraping by doing odd jobs in the city, but even when we try to sell a little something, like fireworks, to earn money, they fine us," another villager said.?? ??? The farmers said the compensation process should be at least more transparent, making the money easier to trace.?? "The land is gone.?? Where's the money.?? That's all we want to know," a villager said.?? ??? At the Thursday event, the villagers were careful to avoid the appearance of protest, eschewing slogans and banners, and merely appealed for what they believe is their rightful compensation.?? ??? Two dozen police officers were dispatched to the scene to try to talk the protestors into dispersing.?? Several police vans and buses were parked nearby, ready to take the demonstrators away.?? No confrontation occurred.?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: PRC: Lanzhou Oil Workers Emulate Daqing Counterparts, Stage Demonstrations
text: ??? Demonstrations staged by laid-off oil workers have broken out in Lanzhou, an important city in the northwest province of Gansu.?? The demonstrators said they were influenced by the large-scale demonstrations staged by Daqing oil workers last month.??? Workers movement activist Han Dongfang told Tung Fang Jih Pao yesterday that hundreds of unemployed oil workers in Lanzhou staged a demonstration outside the government offices beginning from Monday.?? More than 400 people joined the demonstration on Tuesday.?? There were more than 300 people taking part in the demonstration yesterday.?? These unemployed workers have asked the authorities to issue the 3,600-yuan of social welfare funds held back.?? They also wanted to get the same treatment as the laid-off workers of state-owned enterprises.?? However, the authorities ignored their demands.?? As a result, the demonstrations are likely to continue.??? Han Dongfang said that local Lanzhou workers and officials told him that the demonstrations in Daqing encouraged the Lanzhou demonstrators.??? Plan to Take Action in Connection With Daqing Workers ??? Han Dongfang noted that this is the first time for protests on the same issue to be staged by workers of the same trade in two different cities in China.??? He said that the demonstrations in Daqing and Lanzhou might not necessarily be organized, but it seems that this is the beginning of action taken in connection with each other.??? According to another local Lanzhou witness, the demonstrations in the city have lasted three days in a row.?? A local official said that the situation "is not very serious" and that the leaders of the city have taken action to settle the matter.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Tung Fang Jih Pao in Chinese -- Non-PRC-owned daily newspaper (Oriental Daily News); targets a mass readership with emphasis on local and south China news but takes no strong political stands]Attachments:

headline: Pro-East Turkistan Demonstration in Xinjiang
text: ??? According to the information gathered by our Information Center, political protests began again in the Qumul region. On April 24 a demonstration took place in the Qardowe district where people gathered in the old city with slogans?? "Let us revive the Eastern Turkistan society", "Let us chase out the Chinese!" etc. Previously the police arrested 200 demonstrators but failed to find the organizers. On April 26 the secret police also organized a graphology tests in primary and secondary schools in Qardowe. ??? According to the reports, in 1999-2000 in Qardowe district a certain "Eastern Turkistan party" was organized in the district center. It led the fight against the Chinese regime, however, because of internal conflicts, the police arrested some members. Nevertheless, this year this organization stuck a number of mass protests against the Chinese authorities where some religious clerics joined them. The Chinese authorities suppressed these protests and arrested about 20 young Uyghurs.??? This year on March 11 seventeen Uyghur youngsters were arrested on charges of "weapon possession and causing threat to the Chinese workers".
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: PRC: Laid-Off Workers Demonstrate in Shanxi; Jeep Drives Into Crowd Injuring Six
text: ??? Our center has learned that 2,000 workers in Datong, Shanxi, who were forced to leave their posts, staged a demonstration and blocked traffic two weeks ago. During the protest a jeep drove towards workers and, as a result, six workers were seriously injured.?? Four worker leaders including Yao Fuxin, who were arrested in Liaoyang city, Liaoning province on 20 March, have been held for two and a half months, but formal arrest warrants have not been issued so far, and their families have not been informed to send for lawyers.?? The practice of the authorities has violated the "Criminal Procedure Law."??? Our center has learned that Datong Coal Mine Group Company (formerly Datong Mineral Bureau) forced more than 2,200 workers to leave their posts this May, but the company only guaranteed to provide workers with a 50 yuan living allowance each month.?? These extremely disgruntled workers had several times staged demonstrations in front of the government building of Datong city and even sent representatives to Beijing to hold a demonstration.?? On 20 May, the coal mine company agreed to hold consultations with workers, but it adopted hard-line attitude without making concessions after workers had arrived at the company.?? Hence, angry workers blocked Maogan highway connecting Datong city and the coal mines. At 1030 hours, a jeep with license plate number Shanxi B24739 suddenly drove towards workers sitting on the highway, and six people were seriously injured at the scene. The upper and lower limbs of four people were crushed and broken, which was so horrible to look at as they were badly mauled.?? They were immediately sent to the Mineral Bureau's first staff and worker hospital. Our center called the Mineral Bureau's correspondence and visitation department and a section chief surnamed Tan admitted that this accident had happened and expressed that many department were handling this matter.?? The Mineral Bureau's public security division also admitted that the accident had occurred, but declined to reveal where the injured workers were and why the jeep drove towards the demonstrators.?? Workers are planning to hold another demonstration because problems related to laid-off workers have not been resolved.?? Datong Mineral Bureau is China's largest coal-producing base.??? Our center has also learned that 30,000 workers in 20 factories in Liaoyang city, Liaoning province, staged a joint demonstration between 17 and 20 March.?? After the demonstration, public security staff arrested four worker leaders, whose names are Yao Fuxin, Xiao Yunliang, Pang Qingxiang, and Wang Zhaoming.?? On the day they were arrested, Liaoyang public security bureau, showed a notice of detention with the name "illegal rally" to their families.?? But according to the regulation of China's "Criminal Procedure Law," if people are not released within 30 days of detention, the Procuratorate should issue formal arrest warrants, and the public security bureau should inform their families to send for lawyers. The four people have been detained for two and a half months, but their families have not been notified yet. Our center called the arrest section of the Procuratorate and one staff member said that they made a decision but decided to keep it a secret.?? It is quite possible that the four people have been formally arrested and prosecuted.?? Worrying about media reports, the authorities did not inform their families of their decision or ask them to send for lawyers. ??? The Chinese government has admitted that after accession to the WTO, 20 million workers in state-owned enterprises will be laid off in the next five years.?? It feels simply helpless in the face of contradictions between state-owned enterprises and workers.?? Our center held that the way to settle conflicts is to let workers organize independent labor unions to seek a solution through consultation and negotiation.?? If Chinese authorities continue to arrest worker leaders, that will only make more workers take to the streets and hold demonstrations.?? Then there will be more and more such car accidents or conflicts between police and people, and the bloodshed will only make the demonstrators even harder to cool down, resulting in the escalation of contradictions. [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: PRC: Over 500 Laborers Protest Over Unpaid Wages in Chengdu, 3 Arrested
text: ??? Our center learned that over 500 workers at the Gaoshengqiao Motor Repair Shop, Chengdu City of Sichuan Province, blocked one of the key highways in Chengdu this morning in protest of their failure to receive wages for three months.?? At last, these workers clashed with more than 50 policemen, and the policemen injured at least five workers and arrested another three. The public security department and the motor repair shop informed our center of this news. ??? It was reported that this motor repair shop is a large state-owned enterprise and has 3,500 incumbent and retired workers.?? Thus far, this motor repair shop has not paid wages to their workers for three months due to the shop's poor economic results and suspected corruption by the leadership echelon. From 0900 today, more than 500 workers from this motor repair shop blocked the street near the Gaosheng Overpass on the First Ring Road and were loudly shouting slogans of opposing corruption and requesting wage payments. The First Ring Road is the vital communication line of Chengdu.?? From 1200, more than 50 policemen from the Wuhou Public Security Sub-bureau, the Jiangxi Street Police Substation, and the Chengdu City Antiriot Brigade began to clear the site.?? Then, the policemen clashed with the workers.?? According to witnesses, the policemen injured at least five workers, including a female worker, and arrested another three workers, one of whom was called Yao Dan.?? The names of the other two were unknown.?? The No. 1 Traffic Police Sub-bureau of Chengdu, the Wuhou Public Security Sub-bureau, the Jiangxi Street Police Substation, and the motor repair shop all informed us of the demonstration.?? But, public security departments refused to disclose the venue where the workers were detained.?? The motor repair shop informed us that Yao Dan was taken away by the policemen and that he was a worker at the Nan division of the Gaoshengqiao Motor Repair Shop.?? ??? According to the Chinese authorities, 20 million workers will be laid off from state-owned enterprises in five years after China's accession to the WTO.?? It is obvious that there will be increasingly more clashes between workers and plants.?? Since China does not allow workers to organize independent trade unions, workers cannot hold dialogues with plants.?? Blocking the streets is the only way that workers are protesting.?? However, blocking roads may lead to clashes and conflicts between policemen and civilians, stop up traffic, and bring transportation inconvenience to people.?? Unfortunate cases may take place occasionally just like the one in Datong, Shanxi, on 20 May when six workers were knocked down by vehicles and seriously injured during demonstrations.?? So, only when workers are allowed to organize trade unions will they be able to embark on the path of resolving questions peacefully.?? Moreover, most demonstrations resulted from strong dissatisfaction with corruption.?? Only independent trade unions are able to effectively supervise the corruption of plants' leadership echelons.?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:

headline: Laid-off Chinese oil workers take to the streets.
text: Text of report by Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy on 20 JuneOur centre has learnt that since last year, Shengli Petroleum in Shandong Province has laid off 21,000 workers through "terminating labour contracts by agreement". Workers held that Shengli Petroleum did not provide sufficient compensation fees and buy social insurance for them. Against this, they have been staging demonstrations and blocking several streets near the management bureau of Shengli Petroleum and in Dongying city since 17 June, and to date, nearly 1,000 people are still demonstrating. The labour union and the labour management bureau under the management bureau have confirmed the demonstration to us. This is another national oil workers demonstration following the demonstration held by Daqing oil workers.We have learnt that Shengli Petroleum, headquartered in Dongying city, Shandong province, is the second largest oil field in China with annual oil output of approximately 30m tonnes. Since June 2001, through "terminating labour contracts by agreement", Shengli Petroleum has laid off 21,000 workers. These workers' compensation fees are based on their length of service with one year standing compensated for 4,100 yuan, and workers' all relations with "Shengli Petroleum Ltd Company" are severed after they are laid off. The laid-off workers have disagreements with Shengli Petroleum in the following three fields. 1) Workers call on Shengli Petroleum to buy social insurance for them, and the annual average insurance fees for one person must reach around 2,000 yuan. 2) Workers demand jobs. 3) Some workers hold that the compensation fees are fairly low. Owing to the disagreements, workers have started blocking some streets and have been staging a demonstration in front of the management bureau since 17 June, and the number of workers has reached nearly 2,000 at most. The labour management bureau and the labour union under the management bureau have confirmed to us that there were nearly 1,000 people demonstrating this morning. According to the staff with the labour management bureau, these workers have no relations with Shengli Petroleum after their contracts are terminated so that the company will not need to buy social insurance for them. With regard to their employment problems, they should get their unemployment certificates from the government of Dongying city and call on the government to solve their re-employment problems. In the opinion of the labour management bureau, "terminating labour contracts by agreement" has been in effect since early June so the 2,100 workers have no relations with Shengli Petroleum. This is another oil workers demonstration following a demonstration staged by Daqing oil workers in March.Source: Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Jun 02.
source_human: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese

headline: AFP: PRC Police Detain 40 Protesting Their Relocation for Three Gorges Project
text: ??? BEIJING, July 20 (AFP) - Police in eastern China's Shandong province detained 40 people protesting their relocation to make way for the Three Gorges dam in southwestern China, a Hong Kong rights group said Saturday.?? ??? The protestors demonstrated Friday outside the government offices of Qingdao, where they were relocated a year ago, to demand the city help them resolve difficulties encountered since leaving Chongqing, said the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy.?? ??? The residents are among 1.2 million people who have to be relocated to other parts of China for the project, and among 20,000 resettled in Shandong province, which has one of the largest populations of Three Gorges emigrants, the center said.?? ??? There was pushing and shoving between dozens of police officers and protestors, who were later thrown into vehicles and taken away to an unknown location, the center said.?? ??? Local police and government officials either denied knowledge of the incident or refused comment.?? ??? The protestors are among 1,119 people from Chongqing's Zhong county who resettled in Qingdao's Jiaozhou city last August.?? ??? They were each given 1.2 mou (0.08 hectares) of land to farm, but the farms are far from where they live.?? To top up their income they have only a monthly government subsidy of 100 yuan (12 US dollars) to live on, far from enough to help them eke out a living, the center said.?? ??? The farmers, used to growing rice, are unfamiliar with growing the corn and grain crops of the north, lack farm equipment, and find the cost of rice in the north too expensive, the center said.?? ??? They also get into frequent fights with Qingdao locals, who speak a different dialect, and police and government officials side with the locals.?? ??? In October, six emigrants were severely beaten by more than 20 city workers, and on Thursday three more settlers were beaten, yet the problem has not been addressed the problem, the center said.?? ??? Protestors appealed to the government to help them pay for farm equipment, to reduce discrimination and to help others resettle in the Chongqing area.?? ??? The farmers' problems underscore the larger dissatisfaction caused by the dam.?? But state-controlled media has not reported protests because the government is eager to maintain public support for the project.?? ??? Some 22 cities and counties, and hundreds of towns and villages along the upper Yangtze River will be submerged when the world's largest hydroelectric power project is completed by 2009.?? ??? The government says the dam is necessary to generate electricity and to prevent flooding.?? ??? But experts question the need for the 27-billion-dollar project and warn of the damaging impact on the environment and archaeological treasures.?? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Column on 'Inside Story' of Recent Riot in Hunan Province
text: ??? Recently, 20,000 people in Shaodong County, Hunan Province, stormed into the county government and county party committee buildings and recklessly destroyed things in the buildings, evolving into the most serious incident of people storming the government in recent history of China. The incident has led to the dismissal of five officials, including secretary of the county party committee, but the incident is not completely over yet as there are still repercussions to this date. ??? The incident of 20,000 people storming into the office of county party committee in Shaodong County, Hunan, was caused by the following happenings. Shaodong County is a major economic county in Hunan Province. It is a transit as well as wholesale centerunan, H???? of various kinds of supplies. Therefore, cargo-shipping business has been very developed in the county. In the past, Shaodong County's shipping business was handled by individual residents who made quite big profits as shippers or shipping managers. Of course, because of the lack of effective management, the shipping business is fraught with problems. Contradictions between shipper and manager, between shipper and transporter, and between manager and transporter often lead to scuffles. In the meantime, it became very difficult for the government to collect tax. In order to solve these problems, Shaodong County Government decided to implement an effective management of the county's shipping businesses by having them concentrated in one locality. At the same time, it reissued the license for shipping operators. This has affected the interests of many people. ??? Officials should exercise utmost caution when dealing with civil cases??? People connected with the shipping businesses say, the county government did this because it could give the government an excuse to glean an extra income from these businesses. The operators of these businesses already paid a fee for the license to run them, now they had to pay for it again. Also, the fact they were all confined within the same locality further intensified the contests between them and made them more vulnerable to scuffles and clashes. Therefore, these people decided to go to the county government to get an explanation. Originally, they planned to gather a few hundred people for the protest. If the county government handled the case in an appropriate way, the situation would not have gone out of control. What the Shaodong County Government did was resorting to a brutal method by ordering armed police to arrest the protestors. This incurred the great wrath of the masses. Many people joined the protesters' ranks and began to beat the armed police. Under this circumstance, the armed police retreated into the compound of the county government and county people's congress to take refugee there. Consequently, more than 20,000 people stormed into the compound. At the time, the secretary of county party committee and other county leaders, afraid they might be beaten by the angry masses, avoided to have direct dialogue with them. Thus, the riot broke out. The angry masses turned over all of a dozen or so vehicles parked in the compound. Some of the masses, shouting at the top of their voices, even wanted to set fire to the cars. Fortunately, they were stopped by the cool-minded among the masses, thus preventing the incident from getting more serious. But what followed was still more horrible. No longer able to control their own emotions, many of the masses stormed into the offices of the county government and people's congress where they smashed to smithereens all office equipment including desks, chairs and computers. They also smashed all glasses in the offices and the office buildings, bringing an immense challenge to the controlling authority of the Shaodong County Government. This gave a severe shock to the Hunan Provincial Government, which immediately took action to dismiss the five principal officials directly responsible for leadership, including the secretary of the county party committee, and have them prosecuted. To ease the tense situation for the time being, it did not immediately arrest those who led the masses in destroying government facilities. But it can be certain those who took the lead in creating the disturbances will be investigated and prosecuted at an appropriate time. At the same time, concentrated control of the shipping businesses was also temporarily suspended.??? Officials should raise the level of their own management????????????????????????????????? ??? This incident shows that the grassroots officials in China are at a very low level in their administrative management. For the time being let's not talk about whether the county government was intent on making profit from the shipping industry. But what the county government should have done before it put this policy into effect is to fully solicit people's opinions in order to formulate an effective policy that gives even consideration to the interests of all sides, rather than formulating an one-sided policy according to its own taste and own interests without giving any thought to the interests of the masses.?? ??? Speaking from another angle, the government should have a crisis warning system which will make it possible for the grassroots level units to react immediately to the signal of a crisis to dissipate it. What is even more worthy of mentioning is that officials at all levels in China should exercise extreme caution in dealing with a crisis, instead of resorting to very brutal means that pay no respect to human rights and will only pour oil over the flames. ??? If the Shaodong County Government could see that it was dealing with very indignant masses and government leaders could appear in public to have a direct dialogue with the masses, the trouble would be reduced to the minimum and the crisis would be dispelled. Instead, the county's principal leaders took to ordering armed police to arrest people and made the contradictions become more intense. A crisis which could have been avoided became even more serious and the incident developed out of hand. Officials at various levels in China should draw a profound lesson from this incident. They should realize that the masses are no longer the masses of more than a decade ago when they would say yes to their every suggestion and were timid and overcautious. The common people in present day China are no longer afraid of government officials. headline: HK-based Labor Rights Web Site on Worker Protest in Sichuan
text: ??? By mid-August, retrenched workers at COEDC took up collective action demanding the following:??? -- unemployment allowance ??? -- adjusting the premium for their pensions; and ??? -- job placement or reinstatement for retrenched young workers.??? Failing to reach any agreement, about 800 workers started to stage sit-in protests outside the COEDC building on September 2. Since then, approximately 500-600 retrenched workers have been maintaining the sit-in protests every day.??? According to COEDC workers, the organisers put up banners and posters appealing to their fellow workers to sign up for collective litigation against Sichuan Petroleum Administrative Bureau (Sichuan PAB) and its subsidiaries. The workers believe they have legal grounds under Chinese Labour Law and Contract law since they were forced into signing the retrenchment agreement, and that the court should rule the agreement invalid. To prepare for legal action, the organisers started to raise funds to cover legal fees.??? The action sent the company into alert. A worker at Chuandong Development Company, another subsidiary of Sichuan PAB, told CLB that on the morning of September 2, COEDC management reported to the police, saying that Falungong members were making trouble outside their office. Arriving at the scene, the police stopped the fundraising activities right away and attempted to make arrests. Outraged by the police action, hundreds of workers surrounded the police for 11 hours. The workers finally allowed the police to depart when the public security authorities in Jiangbei District apologised to the workers for the arbitrary arrests and promised that it would not happen again.??? Further information obtained by CLB confirmed that as many as 4,000 workers from Sichuan PAB subsidiaries -- including Meter Repair Factory, Development Company, Drilling & Exploration, Well Logging Company and Main Desulphurisation Factory -- joined the sit-in on September 3. Around 500 workers were still protesting outside COEDC office on September 16, and the fundraising activities are still on going.??? The workers' actions in Chongqing grew out of a situation similar to the 3-month protests of Daqing oil workers, which began last March. One of the retrenched workers acknowledged that they had been receiving information on the Daqing workers protests through various channels, and that they had been inspired and encouraged by these workers' bold actions. He said, "The workers here view the courage ????????????????... of the Daqing workers with great admiration. We think that [they] have earned respect for Chinese workers. Chinese workers are grateful to the workers in Daqing." He went on to say, "The workers here wouldn't have had the idea and the courage to organise ourselves if not for the actions taken by Daqing workers in March."??? Like the Daqing workers, COEDC oil workers were cheated into signing the retrenchment agreement. Another retrenched worker described how they were forced to accept the retrenchment arrangement introduced in November 1999. He recalled that the management warned them of the consequences of not accepting the package -- they would simply be laid off if the company experienced financial problems, and they would only get small stipends of living allowance. Threatened by the bleak prospect, COEDC workers were left with no choice but to sign the 'agreement'.??? CLB called the parent company, Sichuan PAB, in Chengdu for their response to the protest action. We were told that soon after the protest, the department chief in charge of wage matters was sent to discuss the matter with the Chongqing municipal government. According to Sichuan PAB there were two main issues in question. First of all, Sichuan PAB had contributed to the unemployment insurance fund under the Sichuan provincial administration. They had no idea how the fund was managed after Chongqing broke away from the province as a municipal administrative unit, the Wages Department of Sichuan PAB said. Secondly, PAB felt the retrenched workers should be regarded as unemployed, a point dismissed by the Chongqing municipal government.??? China Labour Bulletin supports COEDC workers' action demanding their rights to pensions and employment. We also support their attempt to take up legal action in accordance with the Chinese Labour Law, Trade Union Law and Contract Law. CLB offers all possible assistance to COEDC workers in their legal fight.??? CLB has often reported on the unjust and unfair treatment inflicted on the Chinese workers over the past twenty years of economic reforms. Mass workers' protests in Daqing, Liaoyang and Sichuan send a clear message that the Chinese government's iron-fisted approach to workers???????????????? concerns deny them the freedom of association but has not killed the workers' will to fight for their legitimate rights.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Chung Kuo Lao Kung Tung Hsun WWW-Text in English -- web site, also known as China Labour Bulletin, founded by noted labor activist Han Dongfang, providing information on labor issues and activity in China, including efforts by workers to organize outside of party-controlled labor organizations.?? headline: Protests in China's northeast ahead of crucial Party Congress
text: [multiple events] BEIJING, Nov 4 (AFP) - Just days before China's key Communist Party Congress, labour protests have broken out in the northeastern city of Liaoyang, the site of major unrest earlier this year, a rights group said Monday.Around 1,000 metal and textile workers demonstrated about pensions and benefits Monday in front of the city government headquarters, the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said.The Tiehejin metal-working factory has already laid off 3,000 workers, while the Liaoyang Textile Factory is on the edge of bankruptcy, threatening the livelihoods of its 10,000 staff, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre said.In March, Liaoyang, in Liaoning province, was engulfed by some of the biggest protests seen in China for years, when up to 30,000 people hit the streets to complain about job losses and official corruption.Four labour leaders were arrested during the unrest and remain in detention.Mediators from the local government's complaints office were in talks with protesters, the Information Centre said.The complaints office refused to confirm this and referred questions to the city's propaganda department, where officials were unavailable for comment.Any major labour unrest in the run-up to the 16th Party Congress would be a major embarrassment for China's leadership.Ahead of the Congress, where a sweeping reshuffle of the party's top leadership was to begin Friday, security has been cranked up in Beijing. Elsewhere anti-crime crackdowns have brought a wave of executions.The Information Centre reported 400 brewery workers in neighbouring Jilin province have staged protests against a lack of heating in their company-provided apartments.The employees of Yuehai brewery in Changchun city -- where night- time temperatures are currently dipping to -10 Celsius (14 Fahrenheit) -- blame the lack of heating on corruption, the Centre said.Officials have sold a plot of land connected to the heating system to developers, leaving 244 icy apartments, workers have told the Centre.The brewery's manager, who gave his name as Li, confirmed a protest was ongoing but said it would soon be over."We are in the process of holding discussion to solve the problem," he told AFP, adding a deal would likely be reached Monday.boc/pw/lg

headline: Chinese university students protest road death.
text: BEIJING, Jan 8 (Reuters) - About 1,000 Chinese university students staged a rare protest this week, demanding better traffic safety measures after a schoolmate was killed in a road accident outside the campus gate, witnesses said on Wednesday.Student protests have been rare in China since the army crushed student-led demonstrations for democracy centred around Beijing's Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989.Teachers at Hefei University of Technology in Anhui province said about 1,000 students demonstrated peacefully outside the provincial government headquarters on Tuesday.One teacher at the university, 350 km (220 miles) west of Shanghai, said the city government had agreed to improve safety on the busy thoroughfare passing the campus gate after a truck killed one student and injured two others.Protests are not uncommon across China and are usually staged by disgruntled laid-off workers and over-taxed farmers.

headline: SCMP:  'Confrontations' Over Back Pay for PRC Migrant Workers Intensify as Lunar New Year Approaches
text: ??? Several hundred migrant workers demonstrated in front of a luxurious villa complex in northeast Beijing last week, blocking the gate and demanding wages.??? In Shenzhen, more than a dozen workers threatened to leap off an unfinished skyscraper. And in Jinan, a worker burned himself to death in protest.??? Another worker, Liao Dacheng, lost a leg when he attempted to commit suicide by jumping off a building. He was owed less than 1,000 yuan (HK$940) in back pay.??? One of the workers protesting outside the Greenland Garden complex in Beijing last week said the Hong Kong developer had apparently run out of money and vanished. The city had ordered the contractor to pay back the wages within a week.??? There were about 1,000 workers who were owed wages, some dating back two years.??? "I don't know if the contractor can pay. If not, we'll take to the streets again," he said.??? Beijing has set up a legal aid office to handle complaints from migrant construction workers, but a female official said only workers whose employers were registered with the municipal Commission for Building Construction could use the service.??? She said pay disputes had become more frequent and more confrontational this year.??? In a Xinhua survey of migrant workers in Beijing, Zhejiang and Anhui, 72.5 per cent of respondents said they had difficulty collecting their wages. Almost a third were never paid on time.??? More than half said they were the only breadwinner in their family. Their wages ranged from 500 to 800 yuan (HK$471 to HK$755) a month. The highest paid were those performing hazardous duties on construction sites, earning up to 1,000 yuan a month.??? The aggrieved workers often believed they had no recourse other than begging and haggling with their employers. Only 10 per cent thought of seeking help from the government.??? In Beijing, construction contractors owed migrant workers 2.2 billion yuan in back pay at the end of last year. Through government intervention, 140 million yuan had been paid.??? At Beijing station, a young man waiting for bus to Henan said he had come to Beijing in June and did odd jobs at a restaurant for about 50 yuan a day. The owner still owed him about 700 yuan, but he could not wait to be paid as the cost of bus tickets home could be prohibitively expensive at Lunar New Year.??? "I would have liked to buy some new clothes for my small son and for my parents," he said.??? Patting a burlap bag next to him, he said he settled for 25kg of lard as a present for his family and relatives in the village.??? He said he would try to collect the back wages when he came back after the holidays.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post in English -- Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper]

headline: About 500 angry Chinese workers block rail line.
text: BEIJING, March 10 (Reuters) - About 500 angry textile workers blocked a railway line in northeastern China on Monday demanding unpaid wages and unemployment pay from the government, said railway employees who saw the protest."There were four to five hundred of them blocking the railway. They stood on the railway, but were later dispersed," said a man who worked at a railway station in Jiamusi in the northeastern province of Heilongjiang."The train to Beijing was therefore delayed five to six minutes in leaving," he said.The protest was similar to one in December when more than 2,000 workers from the same bankrupt textile plant blocked a rail line and cut traffic on an airport highway, accusing company officials of embezzling their social security payments.An employee at Jiamusi's main train station said city and railway police went to persuade them to leave and protesters dispersed after about 20 minutes, he said.The plight of disgruntled workers laid off from bloated state-owned firms, like those in Jiamusi, is getting top billing at the annual two-week session of the National People's Congress, or parliament, meeting in Beijing due to end on March 18.The New York-based workers' rights group China Labour Watch said "labour representatives" from the factory had written letters to the NPC asking for help in solving the workers' problems, but had received no response.Last year, thousands of unemployed workers took to the streets, particularly in the northeastern "rust belt", over unpaid wages, pensions and alleged graft at flagging state-owned firms.Jiamusi city officials said the textile factory was near bankruptcy and workers were forced to scrape by on the minimum social benefit of 120 yuan ($14.50) per month.But China Labour Watch said even that amount was rarely paid on time."Jiamusi textile plant workers posted leaflets in their residential areas asking workers to go to the government building to petition on Monday," a city government official said by telephone from the frigid northeastern city.But government officials, including a vice-mayor and a deputy Communist party boss went to the plant to listen to their complaints, he said."The plant is in the process of bankruptcy. Basically the workers asked to speed up the bankruptcy so that they could get the one-off payment," the city official added.($1 = 8.28 yuan).

headline: More than 300 riot in China's Tianjin over SARS observation center [Corrected 05/10/03]
text: [multiple events] BEIJING, May 10 (AFP) - More than 300 people have rioted against the construction of a SARS observation center in north China's Tianjin municipality, state media said Saturday.The unrest, which is the latest in a series of SARS-related protests, took place Tuesday and Wednesday in the municipality's Hongqiao district, the Xinhua news agency said on its website.The protesters sought to prevent construction of the observation center by blocking the only street leading to the building site, the agency said.Wielding iron bars, they demanded the drivers of two trucks stop as they were trying to make their way to the building site, according to the agency.Three locals identified as ring leaders of the riot were later apprehended by police, the report said.Tianjin, which has recorded seven deaths from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), was also the scene of another, but apparently larger riot late last month.On April 27, some 2,000 villagers torched a school building earmarked as a SARS quarantine center and ransacked government offices in Chagugang town, a rural settlement.Xinhua said on Saturday that 13 people involved in that disturbance had later been arrested.The Chaguang riot was China's first reported instance of SARS- related social unrest.But one day after, on April 28, up to 500 villagers near Chengde city north of Beijing overturned an ambulance and stoned a hospital after they suspected a SARS patient was being transferred to the facility.ph/hwHealth-SARS-China-riot

headline: Shanghai detains 132 for protesting against forcible clearance [Corrected 05/02/03]
text: SHANGHAI, May 2 (AFP) - Shanghai police have detained 132 people protesting against the city's massive urban clearance projects, a human rights group said Friday.They were rounded up after they gathered outside the Shanghai municipal government offices Thursday, the US-based Human Rights in China (HRIC) said, quoting sources.The protest was the latest episode in a protracted dispute between officials and residents of several neighborhoods forcibly cleared for redevelopment.HRIC said the protesters shouted slogans such as "SARS is frightening, but forced removal is even more frightening," and "SARS is terrible, but dictatorship is even more terrible."After about 30 minutes, more than 200 Public Security Police sealed off the area, rounded up the protesters and loaded them into two buses.Demonstrators who arrived later were dispersed.HRIC said those arrested were sent to police stations in 14 different districts.One protester, Zheng Wanfeng, managed to call his family on his mobile phone and told them not to expect him home any time soon.None of those arrested had yet been released, nor had any of their family members been notified of their detention, HRIC added."We have no comment to make on this," an official at the Shanghai Public Security Bureau told AFP.In an effort to contain the spread of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), major Chinese cities, including Shanghai, have been cancelling or restricting large public gatherings."It would be regrettable if the authorities were using public health as a mere pretext for stifling this protest," said HRIC president Liu Qing.He urged Shanghai authorities "to use negotiation rather than detention and intimidation" to reach an acceptable resolution with families affected by urban clearance.Last month, police arrested three people in Shanghai who were planning to petition authorities in Beijing for breach of property rights over the same issue.Some community representatives traveled to Beijing in March to petition authorities over their grievances, but were rounded up by police shortly after their arrival and returned to Shanghai, HRIC said.mp/njChina-Shanghai-protest

headline: AFP: Farmers Protest Unfair Relocation Compensation at Shaanxi CPC Headquarters
text: ??? Farmers from five villages in Yanta district in the outskirts of Xian city, home to China's terracotta warriors, led a protest June 3 of more than 1,000 rural residents outside the Shaanxi province communist party headquarters.??? Unable to garner a government response, as many as 400 farmers gathered outside the offices again Monday, demanding the government properly compensate them for their loss of farmland and homes.??? About 100 police officers were dispatched to the scene, witnesses said.??? "There was no confrontation.?? They didn't arrest anyone," said a protester surnamed Zhang.??? He said the protesters disbanded after an official in the provincial party office agreed to give farmers a reply in three days.??? Residents of several of the villages joined the demonstration, which party employees confirmed took place but with many fewer participants than claimed by the farmers.??? The problem faced by the Yanta farmers is not an unusual one in China, where the government -- or developers in collusion with government officials -- decides unilaterally how much money to compensate residents whose property they want to tear down for redevelopment projects.??? In Yanta, officials conspired with real estate developers to pay farmers as little as 400 yuan (48 dollars) per square meter (1.25 square yard) of land they were claiming for construction, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy had said.??? New housing in the area can fetch five times as much, making for a huge profit for businesses involved, according to the center.??? Zhang said farmers were also upset because the government refuses to compensate them for the destruction of wells and grave sites.??? Although compensation terms for the farmers have yet to be resolved, the government has already begun dispatching crews to destroy orchards and farmland to make way for the construction.??? Four residents of Miaopotou village were beaten by a group of about 30 security guards sent by the developer in a skirmish over the unearthing of a coffin at a gravesite, Zhang said.??? Among the four was an elderly woman who remains hospitalized.?? Another victim was a young man whose arm was broken by the guards, Zhang said.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

text: ??? The Shanghai officials are embarrassed the residents are exposing their corrupt practices in the capital, the protesters say.??? The detained man, Qin Atai, who comes from the Putuo district of Shanghai, was among the crowd who had gathered outside the ministry to file a complaint.??? headline: AFP: Group Says China Increased Arrests, Violence Against HIV Positive Protestors
text: ??? The crackdown has been felt hardest in central Henan province where many farmers became infected with the virus causing AIDS by selling blood in government-approved schemes, ??? The New York-based Human Rights Watch (HRW) and other groups said villagers' reports have indicated there has been a toughening of approach even as China actively seeks international funding to fight AIDS.??? The charges came after farmers in one village in Henan told AFP last week 13 farmers who had allegedly participated in a protest to call for the establishment of a hospital were arrested in a night raid on June 22 in which hundreds of police beat them indiscriminately.??? Police confirmed the arrests and that of three other villagers in an earlier incident, saying they face charges of robbery and "attacking state offices."??? HRW said in a statement that police in Henan, where many villages are devastated by AIDS, are increasingly using arbitrary arrests and violence against HIV-positive protestors seeking access to treatment.??? "Persecuting HIV-positive protestors is doubly outrageous given that the state was complicit in their infection in the first place," said Joanne Csete, director of HRW's HIV/AIDS and Human Rights Program.??? "Henan authorities seem to want to sweep their role in the AIDS epidemic under the rug by silencing protestors."??? From the mid-1980s to 1990s, millions of villagers in Henan and other central provinces were infected with HIV through government-managed or approved blood collection centers.??? Officials were motivated by the high profits available from the domestic and international blood products industry and for villagers, the sale of their blood was a much needed source of income.??? Since the government finally admitted to the problem in December 2001 after initial silence, farmers have called for access to effective treatment, care for people with HIV/AIDS, or simply a reduction in taxes.??? They have also decried alleged official corruption and misappropriation of state AIDS funding.??? Local government officials responded to earlier protests with promises of aid and had detained a few people, but released them after a few days.??? But the response in more recent incidents has been more severe, HRW and others said.??? Besides the raid at Xiongqiao village, police also blocked 100 farmers from Wenlou village from getting near a hospital to protest discrimination against HIV-positive patients on May 17, when the World Health Organization was visiting to investigate the respiratory disease SARS, HRW said.??? Police severely beat one man, HRW said.??? Earlier in June, five HIV-positive residents of Xiongqiao went to the provincial capital Zhengzhou to complain about the lack of health care services in their village, but were seized and taken away.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Chinese Villagers Sentenced for Rioting Over Government Land Grab
text: ??? BEIJING, Nov 7 (AFP) - Thirteen farmers in east China's Shandong province have been jailed for up to four years after protesting the destruction of homes and requisitioning of farmland by the government, officials and a rights group said Friday.??? The farmers, from Daxue village, were sentenced by the Yutai county court on October 30 for the protests in Jining city, an official at the Yutai county prosecutor's office told AFP.??? The 13 were convicted of "obstructing public works and disrupting social order" stemming from the August 2 protest at the prefectural level offices of Jining city, the official, who refused to identify himself, said.??? City officials said about 100 villagers came to Jining to protest the destruction of homes, the relocation of some 1,300 villagers and the requisitioning of land to make way for a new mining operation.??? But the protesters "illegally" blocked the government gates with their tractors and fought with police, the official said.??? "These were not ordinary people coming to lodge complaints, they were crude and didn't listen to our advice," he said.??? According to the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, some of the farmers were dissatisfied with compensation payments after county officials began relocating them in January to construct the mine.??? They also suspected that local officials were pocketing funds from the mining operation that had been intended for home and land compensation, the center said.??? Besides moving some 1,300 people from their homes, about 100 acres (39 hectares) of farmland were also requisitioned, with the villagers being given only some 50 acres in compensation, the center said.??? Of the 13 sentenced to prison, three received four years with the rest getting lesser sentences.??? Social unrest has increased markedly in China as 25 years of robust economic growth has also been accompanied by a growing awareness of rights and dissatisfaction over the government's role in business.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

City officials said about 100 villagers came to Jining to protest the destruction of homes, the relocation of some 1,300 villagers and the requisitioning of land to make way for a new mining operation.BEIJING (AP) - More than a dozen Chinese villagers have been sentenced to up to four years in prison for fighting with police during a protest over their land, which was confiscated to make way for a coal mine, a human rights organization and court officials said Friday.Former residents of Daxuecun, a village in the eastern province of Shandong, clashed with riot police in the county seat of Jining on Aug. 2. The local police chief, three officers and 10 villagers were hurt, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.It quoted an unidentified government official as saying that villagers also smashed windows in the government office building.Thirteen villagers were sentenced by the Yutai County Court on Oct. 30 to between one and four years in jail on charges of disturbing social order and interfering with government work, the Hong Kong-based center said.Daxuecun's 1,300 residents were moved off their land in February before work had even begun on new homes and were forced to live in tents made of plastic sheeting, the center said.The work isn't scheduled for completion until April, it said, making it likely that villagers will have to endure Shandong's freezing winter in their temporary shelters.Many villagers were also angry at receiving new farm plots that totaled only half the size of their original fields and believed officials were skimming funds from their compensation package, the Hong Kong-based group said.Prosecutor Niu Fuchang said the charges and sentences were related to attacks on police, but said he couldn't discuss details. Court officials also confirmed the sentences, but declined to discuss the case further.The protest was among a wave of actions underscoring deep discontent with demolition and relocation projects that critics say often amount to little more than corrupt land grabs.Throughout China, urban residents are being moved by the millions to make way for new office and apartment buildings. Farmers, especially near the growing cities of eastern China, frequently lose their land to industrial zones or housing projects.Shandong, one of China's most densely populated provinces, has witnessed several recent incidents of mass unrest, most recently a riot last month in which 1,000 demonstrators stormed government offices to protest the death of a vendor they say was deliberately run over by officials.At least 100 people were arrested by 800 police officers in the riot in the city of Zou. The violence took place Oct. 28, one day after city officials confiscated the vendor's cooking utensils.

headline: SCMP:  Protesting Shenyang Investors 'Granted Audience' in Beijing
text: ??? On Monday, a group of 70 Shenyang Beihang Agricultural Trade market investors protested outside Beijing's Great Hall. Three protesters were injured by police as they pulled them away from the west gate. The protesters and their cause generated local media coverage.??? A day later, a deputy chief and a general secretary from the Huanggu District of Shenyang visited the group in their Beijing hotel, investor and protester Liu Zongwei said.??? "We wanted to add pressure," Mr Liu said, adding that although the problem had not been solved he was encouraged that they had met officials.??? "We've reached at least that most basic level," he said.??? They returned to their northeastern hometown on Wednesday after nine days in the capital.??? They came to Beijing to tell central authorities that the brother of Zhang Jianhua, secretary of the Communist Party's Shenyang Policy and Regulation Association, had made investors trade their ground-level space for a spot in the market's basement, Mr Liu said.??? Investors paid 16,000 yuan (HK$15,000) per square metre for the high-end property's ground floor, where they planned to sell goods on a time-share basis, Mr Liu said, adding the basement was worth 5,100 yuan per square metre.??? The brother had told the investors he had the authority to manage the market and charge a fee, Mr Liu said. "He didn't have the right," he added.??? A propaganda representative for the Huanggu district of Shenyang, where the market is located, said he was unfamiliar with the investors' case. Other Shenyang officials could not be reached for comment.??? In Shenyang, China's fifth largest city, 16 officials including the mayor resigned in 2001 for taking bribes from the mafia and gambling the money. Two of the officials received death sentences.??? Despite the crackdown, the odds are against the investors.??? They are among hundreds of people who have launched protests to central authorities in Beijing this summer, usually because they consider their hometown leaders too corrupt or irresponsible to solve local disputes.??? Most protesters in Beijing consider their slogans, signs and doorway sit-ins as last resorts, but admit these actions generally do not lead to resolutions.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper.?? Root URL on filing date:?? http://www.scmp.com]
