headline: Anti-Japan Sentiments Run High in Beijing, Shanghai over Diaoyutai, Poison Gas
text: [multiple events] ??? Popular "anti-Japanese" sentiments have been running high since August because of Diaoyu Island and the leakage of poisonous gas left by Japanese troops.??? Beijing: Burning of Japanese National Flag??? A number of young people wearing white protect Diaoyu Island T-shirts bearing the words "Japanese Get Out" gathered in front of the Japanese Embassy in Beijing in the afternoon of the 26th.?? It is understood that these young people all belonged to the "Alliance of Patriots," and they had come to the Japanese Embassy to demonstrate in protest against Japan for force landing Diaoyu Island again.??? There were more policemen outside the Japanese Embassy on the 26th than on other days.?? When the protesters took out the Japanese national flag and were about to burn it, the police came over to check their personal effects, but did not stop them.??? When the Japanese national flag was burning, passers-by stopped and cheered the protesters.?? After the burning of the Japanese flag, protesters hoisted a banner bearing the words "Diaoyu Island is Chinese Territory" and handed out flyers to pedestrians.?? Passers-by voiced strong support for their action.?? Local police and armed police fighters all along maintained order on the side but did not interfere with any action on the part of protesters.??? Shanghai: Presenting Letter of Condemnation to Japan??? It is understood that the "anti-Japan" activity in Shanghai on 27 August has been reported to the Shanghai Public Security Bureau for the record beforehand.?? Among the 10 persons taking part in the Shanghai protest was an ethnic Chinese residing in France.?? The legal adviser of the activity was a professor from the East China University of Political Science and Law.??? Protesters arrived at the gate of the Japanese Consulate in Shanghai at about two o'clock in the afternoon.?? They unfurled a banner bearing the words "Chinese Territory Diaoyu Island" and shouted the slogans "Diaoyu Island is Chinese Territory" and "Japanese Get Out of Diaoyu Island."?? They also demanded through telephone and the security guard at the gate that someone who "can represent the Japanese Consulate" should come out to accept the letter of condemnation.??? After waiting for 30 minutes, an official of the Japanese Consulate finally appeared.?? Protesters read out the condemnation and handed over the letter of condemnation signed by many people.??? There are hundreds of non-governmental "anti-Japan" groups in China.?? The most famous of these groups is the "Alliance of Patriots," which has members throughout the motherland.?? The Internet is their medium for the exchange of views.?? They have organized a number of sensational activities, including organizing the first landing of Diaoyu Island by Chinese non-governmental groups in June this year and presenting to the Ministry of Railway a letter signed by over 10,000 people protesting against the use of Japan's Shinkansen [technology] in the building of the Beijing-Shanghai express train.?? They are currently planning "a signature campaign by 1 million netizens demanding that the Japanese government indemnify Chinese poisonous gas bomb victims and thoroughly eliminate all poisonous gas bombs left behind."?? They will present the 1 million signatures to the Japanese Embassy in China on 18 September this year.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Wen Wei Po (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- Internet version of PRC-owned daily newspaper.?? Root URL on filing date:?? http://www.wenweipo.com]Attachments:

headline: Death toll in China flooding rises to 64 dead, 59 missing.
text: The death toll from rampant flooding in northern China's Shaanxi province since late August has risen to 64 dead, 59 missing and some 600,000 relocated, state press said Monday.The floods have inundated some 139,000 hectares (321,100 acres) of cropland in the Wei River valley and along its tributaries, causing some 5.93 billion yuan (717 million dollars) in damages, Xinhua news agency reported.The government was pouring in 6.0 million dollars in relief funds to aid the recovery of villages and farmers in the region, it said.The flooding on the Wei River was the biggest since 1981, with some 200,000 people left homeless after a dyke along the river in Hua county collapsed and inundated surrounding farmlands.Aid however has been slow to reach the worst affected areas and on September 4 thousands of destitute villagers ransacked government offices, breaking windows and overturning vehicles in Hua county, blaming authorities for not supplying relief.Police arrested up to 30 rioters, locals said.Hundreds of protesters also blocked the Xian-Tongguan highway for some four hours on September 5.sai/mp/br.

headline: More than 100 protest over property development at Beijing government.
text: More than 100 Beijingers crowded city government offices Thursday morning to protest a property developer's degradation of their homes inside a recently-built residential area.In a scene that has become increasingly common in modern China, they lined up in a disciplined file and marched into the government compound demanding to bring their grievances to officials."We were promised a nice environment, with just a green area and a six-storey building in front of our apartments," said Ding Shufang, a spokeswoman for the protesters, most of whom appeared to be in their 50s."Now the plan is to erect three tall buildings right in front of our homes, with 18, 16 and 11 storeys," she said.The protest was low-profile, without banners or slogans, although a woman at the front of the line carried a map of the original plan for the residential area in Beijing's Jingshan district.The protesters did manage to speak to municipal officials, but the answer they got - to take the matter to the city's planning bureau - did not satisfy them."Our next step could be to sue the property developer in court," said protester Yang Bingshi, as the group lingered at the city government's main gate, watched but not hassled by police officers.The group said in a statement that the issue had already resulted in violence as residents had been beaten when they tried to talk to construction teams working on the three disputed buildings.They claimed promises by city officials to immediately cease construction on the three buildings were broken, and that building continued incessantly.Chinese citizens, long cowed from public protest, seem to be emboldened of late and are more prone to airing their views in the country's otherwise tightly-controlled political system.Most actions are triggered over property disputes, such as a protest at a famous Beijing tourist market last month staged by vendors angry over city plans to tear down their stalls.ph/boc/lg.

headline: UPDATE 1-Anti-Japan protest in China over drag act.
text: BEIJING, Oct 31 (Reuters) - Angered by a risque drag act by Japanese classmates, hundreds of Chinese university students marched in the city of Xian for a second day on Friday, shouting anti-Japanese slogans and waving banners, witnesses said.It spotlighted the mixed feelings most Chinese have for Japan - an increasingly close trade, investment and tourism partner - but one China feels has yet to fully own up to its atrocities during 14 years of occupation until World War Two ended in 1945.Three Japanese students at Northwest China University in central Xian - best known for terracotta warriors dating from the Qin dynasty (221-206 B.C.) - wore red bras and cardboard helmets emblazoned with the characters for "China", "Japan", "Sushi" and "Ninja" in a performance on Wednesday at a cultural festival of the foreign language department, a teacher said.The university had decided to expel the Japanese students, a teacher said.The Japanese students "reportedly wore brassieres and hung false genitals (from) their waists, and they also threw scraps of paper from their underwear to the audience and gave obscene dances at the party," the official Xinhua news agency said.Chinese students took offence, saying the Japanese students were trying to humiliate China, witnesses said.Xinhua said the students handed a petition of complaint to the local government during Thursday's protest."But I don't think the Japanese were trying to humiliate the Chinese," said the teacher, who asked not to be identified, adding that a Japanese teacher was also involved."Our finding is that there was some misunderstanding. The Japanese students wanted to have some fun and, due to cultural differences, they were misunderstood by patriotic students."The Japanese embassy said it had sent a consular official to Xi'an but did not say what his role would be.

headline: Demonstrators in eastern China swarm government offices to protest vendor's death
text: BEIJING (AP) - About 1,000 demonstrators stormed government offices in an eastern China city to protest the death of a vendor they say was deliberately run over by officials who had confiscated his cooking materials, a human rights group and a police officer said Monday.At least 100 people were arrested by 800 police officers in the riot in Zou, a city in Shandong province, according to the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. No injuries were reported.The violence took place Oct. 28, one day after city officials in charge of keeping Zou looking good -- known as "city appearance workers" -- confiscated the cooking utensils of a vendor with the surname of Shao, the group said.Shao tried to stop them by standing in front of their vehicle but was run over and killed, the group alleged.The next day, demonstrators charged into the city's government and Communist Party offices and smashed furniture, it said, without providing other details.A Zou police officer who answered the telephone Monday evening confirmed that a mob of about 1,000 attacked the offices but refused to elaborate, saying he had just started working at the station. He would give only his family name, Li.Riots -- especially such a large one -- are rare in China, whose communist rulers allow no challenges to their monopoly on power. Activists are routinely sentenced to lengthy prison terms, often on vague subversion charges.

No injuries were reported.    ??? BEIJING, Nov 3 (AFP) -- Thousands of people in east China's Shandong province rioted last week, storming a government building and smashing and looting equipment after an official vehicle ran over and killed a vendor, residents and a rights group said Monday.??? The riot -- one of the largest in China in recent years -- occurred on October 28, a day after a confrontation between officials and a man selling fresh pancakes from a roving stove-wagon in Zoucheng city.??? The vendor, surnamed Shao, was selling the popular egg and onion dish on October 27 when some employees from the "city management" department confiscated his wagon, sources said.??? Shao -- seeing his source of livelihood being carted away -- blocked the vehicle's path.??? He was run over as a crowd watched, residents and the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.??? The next day, several thousand people stormed the city's communist party and government's offices in the same building, breaking through a police line of some 800 officers, residents and the Center said.??? "The rioters were not necessarily people angry over the vendor's death.?? They were laidoff workers and other street vendors who were being ordered to stop selling merchandise on the streets," said a local resident surnamed Cheng.??? "When they rushed into the building, some of the city workers had already gone home.?? The others were hiding and too scared to come out," Cheng said.??? Rioters broke down doors to 20 rooms and proceeded to smash and loot furniture and equipment, the Center and residents said.??? "They took computers, thermos flasks, even slippers," she said.??? Center director Frank Lu said a police officer told him the city's entire 800-strong police force was mobilized but could not stop the rioters.??? City police called for backup from three nearby cities, residents and Lu said, and eventually arrested up to 200 protestors.??? "They later released about 100 people, but approximately 20 are still in custody," said one resident.??? Officials Monday told AFP a riot had occurred, but played it down.??? "On October 28, several dozen people went to the city government to appeal, including the family of the vendor ... they smashed windows.?? These people stormed into the city government," said a city government office employee.??? "They have ulterior motives.?? The police came and arrested some people.?? "Several police officers confirmed to me that several thousand people protested.?? A few days later, they said several hundred.?? Now they're telling reporters several dozen," said Lu.??? A police officer at the Zoucheng city police station told AFP: "The city party committee ordered us not to speak about this."??? Authorities in the city called in backup forces and the city was being guarded by large numbers of People's Armed Police.?? Streets were cordoned off a day after the riot.??? Six employees of the "city management" office have since been detained, said Lu said, who added that the vendor's death ignited a strong reaction from residents because they were already angry with officials over unreasonable and harsh tactics.??? These often stem from an abuse of power or corruption by local government officials, especially in small cities and the countryside.??? Many of the rioters in Zoucheng were upset over a new regulation in June which restricted people from selling things on the streets, a resident said.??? "I heard the vendor wasn't intentionally run over, but that didn't matter to rioters," she said.??? headline: AFP: Protest Erupts After Fisherman Dies in Police Custody in China
text: ??? BEIJING, Dec 4 (AFP) -- More than 500 people protested outside government offices after a man died under suspicious circumstances while in police custody, a human rights group and relatives said Thursday.??? It is one of two such cases -- in northern Shandong province and southeastern Fujian province -- that have emerged at a time when public anger over police brutality and ineptitude is high.??? Police incompetence and negligence were blamed in several recently-reported serial murders, and earlier this year the beating death of a man in a police detention hall in southern Guangdong sparked widespread criticism.??? In one of the two latest cases, Chen Sitao, 27, died hours after being arrested for an argument at a karaoke bar in Xiyang Island, near Taiwan, off China's southeastern coast on the night of November 27.??? The police officer who arrested Chen, a fisherman, is notorious in Haidao township for routinely beating up detainees, Chen's uncle Chen Chuanhe and the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.??? The next day, Chen's body was found lying 20 meters (66 feet) outside the police station with head injuries, the uncle said.??? That day, more than 500 fishermen gathered outside the township government office demanding punishment for the police officer.?? They returned again the next day.??? More than 100 police officers later took the corpse away without confrontation.??? "He was not injured when he was arrested.?? We suspect one of the police officers beat him to death," Chen Chuanhe told AFP.??? A police officer in Xiapu county, however, told AFP Chen drank too much the night he was arrested and fell to his death from a roof when trying to escape.??? "This case is over.?? Some villagers didn't understand the situation and thought the police beat him to death.?? After the real situation was revealed, no one is causing trouble anymore," he said.??? In the other case, a Christian woman died a day after she was detained in Shandong on October 29 on charges of "taking part in illegal religious activities," the rights group said.??? After Zhang Hongmei, 33, was arrested in Jiudian township, Pingdu city, police tried unsuccessfully to get her family to pay 3,000 yuan (361 US dollars) in fines, the group said.??? When four family members went to the police station to demand Zhang be released, they saw she was tied to a bench, with numerous bruises to her legs, face and arms.??? The next day Zhang died.??? Police said she died due to blocked arteries, but family members said she was healthy prior to being detained and had never suffered such an illness.??? A Jiudian township police officer contacted by AFP said: "She died accidentally.?? I don't know the details."??? Family members reached by telephone declined to comment, but did not refute the rights group's version of events.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Hundreds Protest in Shanghai Over Lost Jobs; Allege Management Corruption
text: ??? SHANGHAI, Nov 5 (AFP) - Some 300 workers from a state pharmaceutical company in Shanghai demonstrated Wednesday outside municipal government buildings alleging management corruption and protesting lay-offs.??? "We want to eat, and we want to get paid," said one worker dressed in blue company overalls who gave his surname as Jiang.??? "Many of us haven't been paid for more than two years.?? It's because the leaders are corrupt that we haven't been paid," Jiang claimed.??? The peaceful march, under the watchful eye of scores of police, came on the day that 1,000 workers were due to be laid off from the bankrupt medicine maker.??? The company has shuttered operations and is to undergo a restructuring.??? "Yes, they are appealing because of the reorganisation of the company which will see them lose their jobs," an official from the bankrupt Shanghai Number 6 Pharmaceutical Factory said.??? Company officials were reportedly in discussions with the government to try and convince the demonstrators to go home.??? One worker, who had worked at the company for 23 years, said management had agreed to give them severance pay of 300 to 400 yuan (36 to 48 dollars) a month for life.??? "You tell me if that is enough?" said the worker, who said he usually earned 900 yuan a month.??? In the wake of nearly 25 years of reforms that are transforming China's economic landscape, angry citizens are increasingly taking to the streets to protest lay-offs or the loss of property in government sanctioned reurbanisation projects.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: HK Paper Reports on Clash Between Police, Villagers in Minhou County of Fujian
text: ??? A police-civilian clash caused by requisition of land took place a few days ago in Minhou County, Fuzhou.?? Villagers of Xinzhou Village were dissatisfied with the Village Committee's compensation of 3,000 yuan per person, which is only one-tenth of the amount fixed by the state.?? More than 300 villagers tried to block the start of the project on the requisitioned land, prompting the local authorities to send more than 500 members of the riot squad and armed police force to use tear-gas grenades and water cannons to suppress the villagers on the scene.?? Villagers threw stones at them in retaliation.?? Nearly 100 villagers were injured in the incident and 11 of them were sent to the hospital for treatment.?? Three of them, who were seriously injured, were hospitalized.??? 11 Villagers Detained ??? At 0600 the day before yesterday [15 Nov], about 1,700 villagers gathered at the construction site to block the project and confronted more than 10 policemen.?? Although they gradually left the site in the afternoon, more than 300 elderly villagers still stayed there.?? The police authorities sent a reinforcement of 500 riot policemen to the scene to use tear-gas grenades and water cannons to dispel the crowds.?? Some villagers threw stones at them in retaliation.?? Everything was in great disorder.??????? ???? Riot police finally used wooden clubs to dispel the crowds.?? Many villagers were thoroughly beaten and more than 100 villagers felt sick after breathing tear gas.?? The police arrested 13 villagers on the spot.?? headline: Human Rights Center: Buddhists Clash With Police Over Temple Demolition in Hunan
text: ??? Our center discovered that a special operation to "clear up and punish illegal religious activities" has been launched by the Longhui County in Hunan Province, closing down 31 temples, of which five were demolished.?? On 28 October, while local authorities were pulling down a big temple at the Dingtang Village in Yushan Township, 1,000 Buddhists staged a protest at the site and confronted 100 public security officers.?? In the end, the demolition was halted due to a broken bulldozer.?? The province's Religious Affairs Bureau and the local police station of Yushan Township have confirmed the operation with us.??? We have discovered that the temple concerned in Dingtang Village was built with the donation from 1,000 Buddhists living in 27 villages.?? The temple cost 150,000 yuan and could accommodate 1,000 people.?? Since the place is poor and each villager's average income makes up merely 500 yuan yearly, the temple was extremely difficult to build.?? However, when the county embarked on the operation to "clear up and punish illegal religious activities" this August, the temple concerned was labeled an "illegal religious venue" to be demolished and had thus aroused strong resentment among the Buddhists.?? On 28 October, 100 public security officers and cadres from the county's Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau arrived to pull the temple down but were besieged and met with resistance from over 1,000 Buddhist believers.?? During the clash, a bulldozer was broken and the demolition work stopped.?? Nevertheless, local authorities concerned carried on the operation and the temple was completely demolished last week.?? Thirty-one temples have been closed down by the county since August, of which five have already been pulled down.?? The province's Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau and the local police station of Yushan Township have confirmed the incident with us.??? The authorities' operation to pull down temples and churches everywhere in the country has seriously infringed upon the freedom of religion.?? The Deqing County in Zhejiang Province closed down 392 temples and 10 small-scale churches this year, of which four small-scale churches and 24 temples were demolished.??? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:ic1118.pdf

headline: Scores of protesters arrested outside China's Communist Party headquarters.
text: ATTENTION - ADDS more details, quotes ///Police in central Beijing Thursday rounded up scores of angry citizens who staged a protest outside the headquarters of the ruling Communist Party after formal complaints to the government fell on deaf ears.Police cars and vans descended upon the 40 or so protesters from eastern Shandong province only minutes after they began a sit-in outside the Zhongnanhai compound along Beijing's main Avenue of Heavenly Peace.The middle-aged and elderly men and women were demonstrating against a housing development project that resulted in some 300 people being evicted from their homes in the Sifang district of Shandong's Qingdao city last December, one protester told AFP."We've tried everything, we have gone to the Qingdao government to complain but to no avail," said one man, who refused to identify himself."Our homes were all privately owned, but I came back from work one day to find my house gone," he said."The developer destroyed our homes without coming to any written agreement with us."The protesters were taken to a police station next to the party headquarters where police appeared to take identification papers and the complaint documents from the detained.Another man said that a group of 60 or so people had come to Beijing three times to complain about the development project, but were unable to hand in their complaints.Security around the Zhongnanhai compound, where China's top leaders work and live, has been tight since some 10,000 members of the outlawed Falungong spiritual group protested a pending crackdown in April 1999.That protest was deemed the biggest in central Beijing since the 1989 Tiananmen democracy demonstrations were crushed by the Chinese military, killing hundreds, if not thousands, of people.China's booming urban real estate industry has largely been based on the requisitioning of old homes in centrally located areas, moving out the people and building up modern apartment blocks and high rise office towers.Disgruntled citizens have been complaining for years of inadequate compensation, forced removals and government and industry corruption that have led to vocal protests and frequent suicide attempts in recent months.sai/mp/rmj.

headline: 7,000 workers protest layoffs in central China.
text: ATTENTION - ADDS another protest and details about corrupt officials ///Seven thousand workers from an automobile parts factory blocked railroad lines and city roads in Xiangfan city, Hubei province to protest against planned layoffs, a human rights group said Sunday.The mass protest last week was followed Sunday by a smaller demostration involving 300 people from the city's Jinfangyuan textile printing factory, which had announced plans to layoff 500 of its 1,800 workers, the group said.The earlier protest at the XiangYang Automobile Bearing Share Company, Ltd. began last Tuesday, with workers blocking Xiangfan city's two major bridges, the lower portion of which were railway tracks, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.Roads remained blocked until Wednesday afternoon, disrupting rail traffic for three hours and road traffic throughout the city, the Center said.Ten of the workers were injured when more than 500 police officers dispatched to the scene tried to break up the crowds, leading to confrontations with the protestors, the Center said.Five of the protestors have been arrested and police are believed to be seeking another five workers for arrest, it said.The state-owned company, which is listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in southern China, had announced it planned to layoff about 3,000 of its 7,800 workers as part of plans to become more profitable by selling off its state-owned stocks.The workers were dissatisfied with the company's decision to pay laidoff workers 914 yuan (110 US dollars) for every year worked and to require dismissed staff to purchase the company-provided apartments they reside in.Employees, who now pay only 30 yuan a month in rent, would have to purchase the flats for about 900 yuan per square meter (10 square feet).Workers were also angry over alleged corruption at the company, the Center said. Three company officials are being investigated for corruption, it added.Provincial level officials met with some workers' representatives to discuss their complaints on Thursday, but the two sides have not reached an agreement.Company officials could not immediately be reached for comment.A police officer answering the phone at the Xiangfan city police department said he was not aware of the protests and that knowledgeable officials were not available for comment.On Sunday, the 300 textile workers also blocked roads. Their complaints were similar to that of the automobile factory workers - they found severance compensation too low.The protests came as the city's former communist party secretary Sun Chuyin has been formally arrested on suspicion of taking bribes worth 800,000 yuan, the Center said.The case has implicated 90 high ranking officials in the city, who are being detained for questioning, it said.In the wake of nearly 25 years of reforms to China's economic landscape, angry citizens are increasingly taking to the streets to protest lay-offs or the loss of property in government sanctioned reurbanisation projects.cs/bjn.

headline: Hundreds Protest Govt Land Grab In China - Report
text: SHANGHAI (AP)--Hundreds of people in Muslim northwestern China are launching protests outside government offices over plans to push them off their farmlands to build a dam, an overseas radio station reported Tuesday.Police arrested at least 16 protesters in the Xinjiang region's Yili county, the site of clashes between security forces and the region's Muslim Uighur native population in 1997, according to U.S.-based Radio Free Asia.The protests began Friday outside the offices of a reservoir and hydropower station planned for the local Tekas River, said the station, which is funded by the U.S. government.Authorities plan to move about 18,000 farmers, forestry workers and herders to make way for the reservoir, but protesters said they've been paid only 880 yuan (US$1=CNY8.28) out of CNY38,000 promised to them, the station said, citing anonymous witnesses.Calls to government offices in the area rang unanswered and the dam project had no listed number.Land seizures have sparked violent confrontations across China, with residents often accusing authorities of failing to compensate them adequately or of using violence to force them to move.Yet, any such protests would be especially sensitive in Xinjiang, where China harshly suppresses all attempts by the Uighur population to demand greater political rights.China claims it is fighting a low-level insurgency waged by Uighur groups who want independence for the region, but there have been few reports of clashes since the protests in Yili seven years ago.On Feb. 5, 1997, hundreds of young Uighurs took to the streets of Yili's county seat Yining, shouting "God is great" and "Independence for Xinjiang." Police and soldiers moved in and two days of beating, shooting and burning ensued.Uighur exile groups contend that at least 100 died and thousands were arrested.-Edited by Sharon Vong [ 15-06-04 0458GMT ]

headline: Beijing allays fears of entertainers' blacklist
text: Beijing yesterday sought to soothe anxious Taiwanese entertainers by saying it did not have a blacklist of pro-independence artists.The State Administration of Radio, Film and Television (Sarft) was quoted as saying it was not targeting performers.The statement, carried by the China News Service, came after Taiwanese pop princess Chang Hui-mei - known by her fans as A-Mei - was forced to cancel a performance last Saturday in Hangzhou after several hundred students chanted slogans outside her hotel, accusing her of favouring independence for Taiwan.The singer's performance of the Taiwanese anthem at President Chen Shui-bian's 2000 inauguration led to a mainland boycott of her which lasted more than a year.Before the statement from Sarft, a Taiwan Government Information Office spokesman had said that Taipei might retaliate if there were any boycotts of Taiwanese artists on the mainland.Taiwanese entertainers have been wooing the mainland market, which is far larger and lucrative than the island's.The China News Service reported Taiwanese singer Tsai Chin earned more than 1 million yuan for her Beijing concert in December. Another highly popular Taiwanese singer, Jay Chou Jie-lun, was estimated to have earned more than NT$100 million (HK$23.4 million) last year, with most of the sales coming from the mainland, the agency reported.Separately, Wang Zaixi , deputy director of the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, urged more Taiwanese media representatives to come to the mainland. He appealed to them to understand the mainland's policies towards Taiwan.

headline: Chinese police beat elderly women protesting outside nuclear talks venue
text: BEIJING, June 23 (AFP) -Chinese police dragged away and beat a group of mostly elderly women protesting outside the Beijing venue of six-nation talks on North Korea's nuclear program Wednesday, witnesses said.About 15 protesters, mostly elderly women, had gathered outside the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in western Beijing to protest against court corruption in Inner Mongolia, a pool reporter said.Police pushed them away from journalists and rounded them up.According to the witnesses, the protestors were taken away to a police van and some were beaten.The incident happened just minutes ahead of a meeting at the guesthouse between the chief US negotiator at the talks, James Kelly, and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi.Police were not immediately available for comment.mp/br

headline: CORRECTED - 300 protest at top Communist Party offices in Beijing.
text: About 300 people demonstrated outside the Communist Party's central administrative offices in Beijing on Monday against alleged human rights violations and corruption, participants said.Shortly before 8 a.m. people from around China with complaints against the government gathered spontaneously outside the central office of the Organization Department, an administrative arm of the party, to shout slogans and wave banners, participants said.Slogans demanded a "return of human rights" and tougher measures to control corruption, demonstrators said.Most protesters came from northeastern China, where layoffs and factory closures have caused unrest since the 1990s. Post-Deng Xiaoping economic reforms stopped production at the less profitable factories, but not all laid-off workers have found other jobs.Demonstrators chose the party offices because the Communist Party has as much power as the administrative side of the government, said Li Guozhu, 48, a laid-off worker from Heilongjiang Province.No one from the department met with the protesters, Li said. At 10:30 a.m., about 30 police and another 20 officials pushed the crowd away and took some to an unknown location, Li said.Department staff members did not answer phones Monday afternoon.Technically, protests are illegal in China without prior police permission. However, police tolerate smaller-scale demonstrations at other government offices in Beijing.The 300 were not afraid, Li said. "I lost my job, so I don't have anything," he said. "I fear nothing."

headline: 100 people from northeastern China protest in Beijing
text: About 100 people from Heilongjiang Province, a hotbed of land rights disputes and unemployment, protested Thursday outside a Communist Party office in Beijing after two days of larger protests at government offices in the capital.The protesters gathered outside the party's Organization Department in the morning and shouted slogans such as ''return my human rights'' and ''in search of a livelihood,'' as two police cars watched nearby, said Li Guozhu, 48, an unemployed man who joined the protest.Demonstrators brought petitions to the site, Li said, though no one from the party has come forward to look at them.On July 5, about 300 people from northeast China gathered in the same place, and last week 23 people threatened to commit suicide in the capital.On Tuesday and Wednesday, 200 people staged demonstrations outside the State Council's Complaints Office in Beijing, Li said. More had set out for the capital, he said, but more than 500 police officers intercepted their train and made some return.Li said the recent protests are to show the central government that authorities in northeastern China have failed to solve problems including unemployment.''You go somewhere and no one pays attention, the local governments don't pay attention,'' said Li, a teacher's college graduate who lived in Europe for nine years.But he said protesting the central government was unlikely to be effective.''Leaders in every province don't listen to the central authorities,'' he said.A common complaint in northeastern China, once a strong industrial base, is difficulty in finding new work after waves of layoffs following the closures of factories that were unable to survive market-economy reforms.The withholding of pensions and back pay from previous jobs are issues as well.The 23 who threatened suicide were coal miners that said they and other unemployed workers had not received a total of $10,000 in layoff payments due in the 1990s, according to Radio Free Asia. They were afraid the money had been illegally diverted.Other complaints concern land taken for development and the demolition of homes.Income gaps and government corruption have triggered anger among farmers and workers throughout China, resulting in a growing number of petitioners coming to the capital to present grievances.Officials in Heilongjiang are particularly corrupt, said Li Chunming, a Beijing history scholar who has done research in northeastern China.

headline: Group Says Chinese Police Shot At Villagers During Raid
text: BEIJING (AP)--Police shot and wounded at least four people Monday during a raid on a village in central China to detain the alleged leaders of a protest over land sales, an activist group and a hospital employee said.The raid took place in Shijiahe, on the outskirts of the city of Zhengzhou, where villagers have accused Communist Party officials of illegally selling land and stealing the proceeds, the Free China Movement said in a statement.Some 600 officers from the paramilitary People's Armed Police took part in the predawn raid to arrest the protest leaders, the Washington-based group said. It said police opened fire when neighbors tried to block the arrests.Four were being treated for "serious gunshot wounds" at the Zhengzhou Central Hospital, a woman who answered the phone at the hospital's emergency room said. She refused to give her name.The Free China Movement put the number of injured people at 30, but the hospital employee said she didn't know about other cases.Spokesmen for the Zhengzhou municipal and Henan provincial governments said they had no information on the incident.Violent clashes between villagers and police or tax officials have been reported in areas throughout China, though few as large as the incident reported in Shijiahe.A growing number of confrontations stem from complaints that local officials are improperly seizing land for commercial development, forcing farmers off their plots and destroying houses.The protesters in Shijiahe accused local party officials of stealing some 40 million yuan ($1=CNY8.28) from land sales, according to the Free China Movement.-Edited by Jessica Tan [ 02-08-04 1010GMT ]

headline: Kyodo: Beijing Arrests 2,300 Protesters to Stop 7 Aug Tiananmen Demonstration
text: ??? Beijing, 10 Aug, Kyodo -- An informed source revealed on 10 August that a demonstration of 20,000 peasants and workers protesting the corruption of local bureaucrats and other issues had been planned on 7 August at the Tiananmen Square in Beijing.?? However, the authorities arrested the organizers on 6 August and rounded up some 2,300 people at the Beijing South Train Station and near Tiananmen, preventing the demonstration to take place.??? Planning a protest rally at the Tiananmen in itself is extremely unusual.?? 7 August also coincided with the Japan-China Asian Cup soccer championship match.?? It appears that the Chinese government had suppressed the demonstration by force.??? Due to the widening gap between the rich and the poor in China and the corruption of bureaucrats and forcible expropriation of land, there is increasing discontent among the peasants and citizens.?? There has been a rapid increase of direct appeals to the central government to seek redress for the people's problems since a few years ago.??? According to the source, Li Xiaocheng, an activist who organized the demonstration, had planned the protest rally in light of many petitioners being beaten to death or detained illegally by the authorities.?? An application he submitted in the second half of July for holding the demonstration had not be rejected.?? However, he was arrested by "public security officials posing as reporters" on 6 August.??? According to the application, the demonstration was meant to appeal to the central government and human rights groups in foreign countries about the suffering of the petitioners and to demand compensation for people who had been beaten to death.??? Some 2,000 people who heard about the plan arrived at the Beijing South Station from all over the country from the evening of 6 August to the early hours of 7 August.?? However, they and some 300 people who assembled around Tiananmen were rounded up by the waiting public security police.??? According to the Supreme People's Procuratorate, a total of 530,000 cases of direct petitions were processed last year in China.?? There were many cases where the local governments mobilized public security officials or thugs to beat up the citizens' representatives to stop them from petitioning.[Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo Clue II (Internet Version-WWW) in Japanese -- Japanese language service of largest domestic and international news agency, Kyodo News owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]

headline: China homeowners defy Summer Palace power project.
text: BEIJING, Aug 13 (Reuters) - China's staid middle class put on a rare show of defiance on Friday over a power project they said is threatening their health due to the proximity of pylons to their homes and some fear may ruin the Summer Palace landscape.Residents of the scenic middle-class neighbourhood of Baiwang in western Beijing near the Summer Palace, once the garden of China's emperors, argued that pylons near their homes were a health hazard and petitioned the Beijing Environmental Protection Bureau to move power lines below the ground."Let reporters in. Let reporters in," more than 100 petitioners chanted outside the bureau, where only selected reporters of mainstream state media were allowed into an unprecedented government hearing on the environment."Freedom of the press. Freedom of the press," shouted the residents, who wore white T-shirts printed with the slogan "Take down steel towers harmful to people."It was Beijing's first public hearing on the environment since the July 1 promulgation of a law requiring the government to hold hearings on controversial issues.Six petitioners were allowed into the three-hour meeting, but the rest, and most reporters, were barred.Police reinforcements arrived, but no arrests were made."Unity is strength. Unity is steel. Unity is iron," the petitioners sang, quoting an old communist revolutionary song.A power cable across the sky upset the view of the Summer Palace, a favourite retreat of Empress Dowager Cixi in the late 19th century and a major tourist attraction, complainants said.China's middle class is one of the biggest benefactors of economic reforms and is usually politically tame. They quietly go about making money and keep their heads low in a society that until recently despised private entrepreneurs.The more than 3 million people who took to the streets in various protests across China last year were mostly laid-off state workers and disgruntled farmers.Residents of Baiwang neighbourhood, home to about 1,000 families, said they believed electromagnetic radiation from the 50-metre (164-ft) pylons near their homes was a health hazard."Electromagnetic radiation would give our children leukaemia and cause cancer," Zheng Haiyan, a 30-year-old businesswoman who bought a 165-square-metre (1,776-square-ft) flat for almost 1 million yuan ($120,000), told Reuters.Hao Zhiqiang, a 40-year-old engineer, said: "No resident dares to enrol his children in a kindergarten next to a pylon."The project has knocked down prices of flats in the neighbourhood by about a third, several residents said."No one will want to buy our homes. And we have loans to repay," said 40-year-old housewife Fang Xiaomei, who bought a 150-square-metre (1,615-square-ft) flat for 920,000 yuan.Pylons have been erected near the neighbourhood but lines have yet to installed after residents took turns manning the structures around the clock to stall construction. Residents phone police when power company workers arrive at the scene.GREEN PYLONSPower authorities painted three of the pylons an environment friendly green to try to appease residents.Asked if she feared repercussions, Tan Hongyang, a 42-year-old teacher, said: "Our democracy has reached a certain level. I don't think people will be arrested for speaking up."But some residents had doubts about the hearing."It's just for show. It's not the real thing," a housewife who spoke on condition of anonymity said, adding that municipal health officials were not invited to the hearing.An official with the Beijing Environmental Protection Bureau said the hearing would help decide whether construction could continue. An official of the power company declined to comment.Chinese authorities are torn in many places between economic development and environmental protection.As power shortages spread to more than two-thirds of China's provinces and regions, electricity producers have poured billions of dollars into building new generators. They are scrambling to make up an expected 40,000-megawatt shortfall this year. (Additional reporting by Cher Gao).

headline: China peasants protest "police-led attacks" - group.
text: BEIJING, Aug 26 (Reuters) - Chinese police and hired "thugs" in the southeastern province of Fujian assaulted a group of peasants in a dispute over a factory, a human rights group said.Peasants staging a sit-in protest against government seizure of a village factory were attacked on Aug. 1 by more than 100 police officers and 14 men recently released from labour reform camps, Human Rights in China (HRIC) said.At least 15 people were injured in the attack."Most of the villagers attacked were women, and conditions ... have deteriorated because they are too poor to afford the necessary medical teatment," it said.Villagers had pooled money to buy a 5,100-sq-m (54,900-sq-ft) factory but the local government took it over without offering any compensation, the group said.The Aug. 1 attack was the most recent in a string of scare tactics by officials in the province, it added."On May 6, a total of more than 300 police officers and unidentified civilians surrounded Manli village and beat up villagers regardless of sex or age. One woman committed suicide ... to protest," the HRIC report said.The villagers have sent an open letter to the provincial and central governments calling for investigations, it said."The Chinese government should carefully investigate the allegations ... and carry out whatever measures are necessary to address the acts of injustice", HRIC president Liu Qing said.The letter was seen as a last resort effort to secure official recognition of the villagers' plight.Local officials declined to comment on the case.Recently, three people involved in protests in Fujian's capital were given sentences ranging from five months to one year for "disturbing the public order," a government Web site said.An online commentator condemned the punishments, calling on the government to learn from Hong Kong, Macau and Singapore."Only a government that loves its citizens and fairly enforces the law can win the trust of the people. They shouldn't use these punishments to repress the people," the commentator said.More than three million people staged about 58,000 protests across China last year protesting against corruption, forcible land seizure and unpaid wages.Authorities frown on public dissent and often arrest and jail leaders of such movements.

headline: Petitioning Beijing --- Police Greet With Force Sea of People Airing Local Grievances
text: Beijing -- CHINESE POLICE are resorting to violent tactics to cope with the growing number of protesters who show up in the capital each day, highlighting stress fractures in a national justice system ill-equipped for China's transformation into a capitalist society.A continuing police campaign to sweep thousands of petitioners out of the capital ahead of a key meeting of Communist Party leaders next week has surprised human-rights activists for its scale, duration and tactics. The activists allege that police are using electric batons and tranquilizers to shepherd people onto buses to be taken home.Even before the campaign started a week ago, sporadic confrontations between police and petitioners have resulted in violence. Witnesses say that in one incident last month they saw an old man throttled to death by officers at the Supreme Court. The Wall Street Journal has submitted questions to the government about that assertion.As petitioners are ferried out of the capital, others continue to arrive in search of redress for unresolved conflicts with provincial governments.The pilgrimages to Beijing are a serious side effect of a judiciary that enjoys little independence from the ruling Communist Party -- a system that makes it hard for plaintiffs to receive fair hearings in local courts over matters such as corruption, land seizures, excessive taxation and unpaid wages. The result is a stream of people who, like their Confucian forebears during imperial times, journey higher and higher up the government bureaucracy in search of a righteous official who will hear their complaints and deliver justice.That a country should face a rise in popular protests amid wrenching economic changes is hardly surprising. "But what is more unique to China is the unavailability of legal avenues for people to express their anger," says Murray Scot Tanner, a specialist on Chinese politics and law enforcement at Rand Corp, a research organization based in California. "One of the best ways to bring attention to your cause is to yue ji -- to take your protest to a higher level."The official tactics used to deal with the crowds of petitioners outside central government offices challenge expectations that China's new leaders will be more tolerant of dissent than their predecessors. Outside the government's main appeals office on a recent morning, scores of official vans and cars from more than a dozen provinces sat waiting to retrieve detained petitioners, some of whom were dragged to the vehicles by uniformed and plainclothes police.In a statement released Thursday, New York-based Human Rights in China cited petitioners who said they were beaten, prodded with electric wands, and held in a sports stadium before being shipped out of the city. The group said police from the northeastern city of Benxi, Liaoning Province, drugged the food they offered their detainees before loading them into paddy wagons and taking them to detention centers back in their provinces."Recently we have been notified several times by higher-ups that we should retrieve petitioners from Benxi," said an official reached by phone at the Benxi appeals office. He added: "I haven't heard of using drugs" to knock people out.Human Rights in China said some 36,000 people have been removed from the capital since the start of the campaign, though people who have witnessed the crackdown say it is impossible to gauge whether the number is that high.A policeman at Youanmen police station, which is involved in the campaign, said "We have organized several petitioner sweeps under the guidance of the Beijing Public Security Bureau's General Security Team. Now we are seeing fewer petitioners than before." He declined to say how many had been taken away.Whatever the figure, central government authorities have admitted publicly that the number of petitioners trying to make it to the capital is increasing. These petitioners are the spillover of local protests around the country that are rising in number by at least 9% each year since 1993, to 58,000 protests last year, according to published public security data cited by Mr. Tanner of Rand.There aren't any indications that such protests, increasing though they might be, pose a threat to the Communist Party's grip on power. "A sense of perspective is necessary," says Mr. Tanner. "There is still no nationwide independent political party in China, no nationwide trade union, student union, peasant association, or religious group. Nothing."

headline: PRC: Over 50 Shaanxi Villagers Wounded in Clash With Police Over Land Requisition
text: ??? Yulin city, Shaanxi Province, is an old revolutionary base area of the CPC.?? Clashes between policemen and civilians have occurred on five occasions in the city since last year due to the government's expropriation of farmland.?? Policemen also opened fire at villagers.??? Eighty percent of the forest land has been transferred to development agencies, and?? 40 percent of it has been destroyed.??? Local peasants maintain that the land is collective land and not what the government regards as "state-owned land" and therefore reject the compensation program of the authorities.?? headline: SCMP:   Shenzhen Workers Gain 170 Percent Pay Rise After Protest
text: ??? Shenzhen workers who paralysed traffic for four hours with a protest two days ago have won a 170 per cent pay rise.??? The employees of Computime -- a Hong Kong joint venture -- were back at work yesterday after successful negotiations.??? About 3,000 workers protested outside the Computime factory on Wednesday, claiming they had been cruelly exploited by their management.??? Workers said their basic pay, at about 230 yuan, was well under the 574 yuan monthly minimum wage set by the government in Guangdong. They also said they worked extremely long hours.??? They blocked a section of a main road for four hours, causing massive congestion that paralysed much of the city's traffic.??? The move forced management to back down and hold talks with the workers' representatives. The workers yesterday claimed they were victorious.??? "The company told us this morning that our basic salary will be raised to 620 yuan. We will resume our work. Let's see if they live up to their promise at the end of this month. If not, we will take new action," said one of the workers.??? The factory was back to normal yesterday, although police officers were still stationed outside.??? In a press release issued by Computime International in Hong Kong, the company maintained that it had given its manufacturing partner in Shenzhen enough pay and benefits to comply with government requirements. It confirmed that normal production had resumed.??? Meanwhile, a local official told Shenzhen newspapers police might take legal action against the protesters.??? But the workers yesterday said they conducted the rally only after they had exhausted all other methods.??? "The pay is so low. We are fighting for survival. We tried to negotiate with the management and we tried to complain to the government. But nobody cares about us," said one worker.??? "In the end we had to organise a protest. The government has itself to blame."[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper.?? headline: Rioters burn and loot in west China demonstration.
text: BEIJING, Oct 20 (Reuters) - Rioters in the western Chinese region of Chongqing burned police cars and looted government buildings after a quarrel between residents escalated into a riot involving thousands, residents and officials said.The angry crowds gathered on Monday night during a quarrel between fruit market workers and a delivery boy, after one worker passed himself off as an official and threatened to use his rank to resolve the dispute in his favour, state media said.That caused bystanders, angry at the attempted abuse of privilege, to become involved in the dispute. Residents said crowds grew to more than 20,000 after cars and buses passing through the area stopped to watch.An official news report posted on the Wanzhou government's Web site ( www.wz.gov.cn) said five were detained for burning and overturning police cars and stealing a computer from a local government building. It did not say what caused the disturbance.A Wanzhou official said more than 10 had been detained."I heard some protesters burned police vehicles and police fired tear gas," said a hotel employee at the Changcheng Chang Hotel in Wanzhou district near the riot scene.China has seen mounting anger against abuse of privilege as the gap between rich and poor widens, with hundreds of millions of peasants left out of its economic boom.A case last year in which a woman killed a farmer with her BMW but was let off with a suspended sentence attracted wide attention and the investigation was eventually reopened.A Wanzhou police officer acknowledged there had been a "security disturbance" on Monday but declined to give details.EMERGENCY MEETINGLocal officials were still appealing for calm on Wednesday and the Wanzhou Web site said local government and Communist Party officials had held an emergency meeting at 4 a.m. on Tuesday to discuss the situation."Everyone has a responsibility to preserve stability," said one headline on the Wanzhou site.Government and party officials pledged at the meeting "to seriously punish the lawbreakers and troublemakers in this mass incident in accordance with the law, and seriously punish any party members who ... participated in it to stir up others to create trouble", the Web site said.They also stressed that no officials were involved in the dispute that sparked the protest, only a man who passed himself off as one.A report in the official People's Daily put the crowd only at "hundreds", but referred to "beatings, robbing and burning" and said those involved would be punished.Protests have become increasingly common in China, fuelled by corruption and the widening wealth gap, but authorities are keen to quickly quash dissent and preserve stability.

headline: AFP: 'Small Number' of Retired Workers Continue Protest in Anhui Over Pensions
text: ??? BEIJING, Oct 25 (AFP) - Up to 10,000 retired workers have protested for several days running in central China, demanding the government address insufficent pension funds in the face of rising inflation, local officials and a rights group said Monday.??? The protests in Anhui province began Friday and continued Monday as retired workers in Bengbu city gathered in public squares and in front of government offices, said an official surnamed Ma at the city's office for retired workers.??? "From October 22 to 24, in the main public areas of the city a lot of workers gathered, the most at any one time numbered some 10,000," Ma told AFP.??? "This morning (Monday), there were still a small number of workers that were still in the streets and were not listening to the orders of the police.??? "I've heard that several people have been detained."??? Police have ordered the retirees to return to their homes and stay off the streets, he said.??? The Hong Kong-based China Labor Watch said the retirees blocked streets and main thoroughfares in Bengbu on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and by Monday the numbers had grown to "several tens of thousands.??? Police and other city government officials refused to comment.??? Bengbu, located in one of China's poorest provinces, is a city of some 3.3 million people, but registered urban residents make up only about one third of the population.??? According to Ma, the protests began after six retired leaders from six of the city's main factories demanded in an open letter that the city and the State Council, China's cabinet, address the difficulties retirees were facing off their meagre pensions.??? The protests prompted an emergency meeting on Sunday, with the city government agreeing in principle to raise pensions by 60 yuan (7.2 dollars) a month, provided that the central government agrees, Ma said.??? "Bengbu has 70,000 retired (urban) workers so this plan needs to be approved by the State Council because the city does not have enough money to pay for it all," he said.??? Average pensions are between 400 and 600 yuan (48 and 72 dollars) a month, he said.??? China's inflation rate hit 4.1 percent in the first three quarters of 2004 and 5.2 percent in September from a year ago, driven by rapidly rising food prices.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Up To 100,000 Farmers in Violent Clashes Over Dam Project in China
text: ??? BEIJING, Nov 1 (AFP) - Up to 100,000 farmers clashed with police in southwest China, protesting compensation payments for farmland requisitioned to make way for a hydroelectric plant, local residents and reports said Monday.??? Unrest at the Pubugou hydroelectric project on the Dadu river in Sichuan province began last Thursday and peaked Friday when locals marched on the Hanyuan county government offices carrying the corpse of a dead protester, Hong Kong's Sun Daily said.??? Several people reportedly were killed in the clashes, while scores were injured as some 10,000 People's Armed Police descended on the area to maintain order, it said.??? The demonstrations succeeded in stopping the project which was scheduled to dam the river on Thursday.?? Marchers also ransacked government offices in Hanyuan, it added.??? "It happened on the 29th.?? It began during the day and lasted until eight or nine in the evening," a man at the Hanyuan county government who identified himself as Liu, told AFP.??? "There were many many people involved, I don't know exactly how many."??? The paper said 100,000 farmers were involved although an official at Dashu township said there were only 20,000 protesters and that by Monday construction on the dam project had recommenced.??? "On the day of the protests there were about 20,000 people that went to the construction site.?? I don't know if anyone died because I didn't go to the scene," the official told AFP without identifying himself.??? "At the moment no protesters are at the construction site."??? The lands of some 100,000 farmers in 40 townships spread throughout three counties are expected to submerged by the dam project, he said.??? The Dadu river is a tributary of the Min River, which eventually flows into the Yangtze River, China's longest.??? Up to one million farmers, many unhappy about their future prospects, are expected to be relocated to make way for the Yangtze's Three Gorges Dam, when the world's biggest hydroelectric project is fully completed by 2009.??? Hong Kong's Apple Daily said Hanyuan local government had placed a news blackout on reporting of the recent unrest.??? "There was no such incident," an official at the Hanyuan propaganda bureau told AFP when asked about the demonstrations.??? Efforts to stifle news of the protest comes as the local and national governments implement plans to build scores of new dams in the Yangtze River basin in a bid to quench China's growing demand for energy.??? According to the Apple Daily, protesters shouted "End official corruption" and voiced support for Premier Wen Jiabao's recent statements on putting and end to the rampant requisitioning of farmer's lands.??? Over the last five years local officials throughout China have been widely accused of using their largely unchecked powers to enrich themselves by requisitioning farmlands and prime urban real estate while promoting development projects.??? Under Chinese law, all land belongs to the state.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: WWP: Wuhan Police Clash With Protesters by Wal-Mart Demanding Relocation Compensation
text: ??? Wanda-Walmart shopping mall, a joint investment by the Dalian Wanda Group and Wal-Mart, officially opened for business today in Wuhan.?? Shortly after the ceremony began, several dozens of elderly people unfurled banners that read "Our houses were pulled down due to reconstruction projects in old cities; compensation was not given according to the policy," "Feeling helpless in the face of low-priced exploitation," and "People shed tears because bureaucrats and businessmen protect one another."?? Protesters on the spot demanded that the government pay back the overdue relocation compensation.?? Numerous passers-by surrounded and watched the conflicts that broke out between protesters and security personnel and the police who were keeping order there.?? ??? An old man from one of the relocated families told reporters that they used to live in a residential building where the shopping mall is now situated.?? When the resettlement project began, residents refused to move out of their houses since no agreement was reached on the amount of compensation.?? Subsequently, the water and electricity supplies of the entire residential area were cut off and residents had no choice but to move out.?? According to the original arrangement, relocated families would receive 2,600 yuan per square meter as relocation compensation.?? However, each family ended up receiving 1,400 yuan only after a 20 percent "handling fee" was deducted.??? Because security personnel and police kept protesters from the relocated households to stay on the sidewalk, the opening ceremony proceeded smoothly.?? The relocated families sat around the rostrum to stage a protest after the ceremony ended.?? No responsible person from the local government or the Wanda Group has commented on the incident so far.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Wen Wei Po (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- Internet version of PRC-owned daily newspaper.?? headline: Hong Kong Paper: Protesting Guangxi Peasants Dispersed by Force
text: ??? Following the government-peasant conflict in Hanyuan, Sichuan, it was also reported that a large number of peasants staged a sit-in in front of the government of Guilin, Guangxi, in protest against the forced occupation and reselling of land by the authorities.?? The Guilin authorities dispatched anti-riot police to disperse the masses by force.?? ??? According to a report released by the China Information Center, the masses in Heping village, Chuanshan township of Guilin's Qixing district said that the city government had illegally changed the collective-owned land into state-owned land without approval and sold the land to developers without permission.?? On 12 November, several hundreds of the masses with their families went to the city government to stage the protest.????? ??? Police Reportedly Entered Village to Arrest Troublemakers ??? The city government immediately sent several hundreds of anti-riot police.?? Villagers were pushed, dragged, pulled and dispersed into vehicles and driven to the city gymnasium.?? Roads leading to the Guilin city government were all blocked.?? No vehicles or personnel, reporters in particular, were allowed to enter.?? The report said that the scene was full of crying, shouting and cursing and was extremely chaotic.?? The report said that by noon that day, the Guilin city government again dispatched a large number of anti-riot police to the village to arrest the leading troublemakers.?? During the operation, anti-riot policemen used their batons and shields to assault the peasants.?? Some of the elderly people, women and children were knocked down.??? ??? headline: SCMP: Shenzhen Workers Protest Lay-Offs Without Receiving Compensation
text: ??? Hundreds of workers who face being laid off by an electronics manufacturer in Shenzhen protested outside the factory yesterday after management refused to pay compensation.??? The workers, employed by home-appliance manufacturer Durable in Baoan district, started protesting on Monday.??? They clashed with factory security guards yesterday morning after the factory refused to let them leave the complex. The workers forced open the factory gate and blocked the entrance. More than 100 police officers and local militia were called in to keep order. One worker was arrested.??? The factory, previously owned and operated by a Hong Kong company, was sold to a mainland company in September. Workers say the new owner planned to relocate the factory to Zhuhai and lay off the 3,000 workers in Shenzhen by the end of this year.??? The workers claim management is refusing to pay the compensation they are owed, and did not pay their social or medical insurance.??? "We have signed a contract with the factory. If they want to lay us off, they have to give us one month's salary as compensation. They also should pay for our social insurance and medical insurance. But they didn't," said one worker.??? The crowd dispersed in the afternoon. The workers said management had refused to negotiate with them. Workers vowed to continue their protest today.??? "They can't run away from their responsibility. I have worked for the factory for many years and if the company wants to get rid of us, it should treat us with respect," said another worker.??? The workers also claimed that they were badly paid. Their average salary was slightly lower than the minimum wage in Guangdong ? 574 yuan a month.??? "We have worked here for years but the salary remained the same. Our salary is only enough for basic living. We have nothing left to send back to our family," said a female worker.??? She said many of her friends had left Shenzhen because working conditions in the city were too harsh.??? A staff member at Durable's office yesterday denied there was a protest outside the factory.??? "Some workers just want to sit outside and cool their heels together. There is no protest," she said.??? She said the company had treated its workers well and it was not clear whether it would relocate to Zhuhai.??? "If anyone says we did not treat our workers well, let them show proof," she said.??? Labour disputes have become increasingly common in Shenzhen, with workers often complaining about being underpaid and ill-treated.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper.?? headline: HK Paper: Shenzhen Residents Protest Against Rising Crime in Residential Areas
text: ??? The public law and order situation has once again caused disaffection among local residents.?? The day before yesterday, in the afternoon, over 100 residents of the Gongming Yulu community district in Shenzhen surrounded the Gongming Neighborhood Office to protest against thieves, robbers, and "street racers" running amok in the community district.?? They demand that public security organs strengthen a crack-down on criminals and groups with connections to organized crime.??? According to a local resident, there were already incidents of beating, smashing, and looting in the community district involving newcomers from outside Shenzhen happening a couple of years ago, and residents mostly tolerated them.?? But now "street racers" from these groups connected with organized crime are even committing extortion and knife-wielding robberies at residents' homes.??? It has been reported that what has provoked public anger among residents is a recent incident of car-smashing and beating.?? ??? According to a resident who was beaten, he was driving his private car into the community district on that afternoon, when he suddenly felt his car being hit.?? When he got out of the car to check, he was surrounded by several men with non-local accents who claimed that their motorcycle had been damaged and insisted on being compensated. ??? The resident firmly refused to pay.?? Then the community district security guards arrived at the scene and suggested calling the police.??? But just as the security guards were calling the police, the men also made a phone call.?? A few minutes later, a dozen men suddenly dashed out of the entrance of the community district and began to beat the resident.?? A hospital checkup confirmed that the bones in his hand were broken.??? After a meeting, several dozen residents decided to collectively protest to the government and to demand a crackdown on criminals by public security organs.?? On the afternoon of the day before yesterday, they drove to the Gongming Neighborhood Office and hung two banners in front of the office building calling for a crackdown on crime.?? The action caused anxiety for the authorities, as several government employees hurriedly came to talk with the residents.?? ??? The chief of the local police station also came specifically to explain to the residents how the police were handling that car-smashing and beating incident.?? He said the six newcomers suspected of car-smashing and beating had been arrested.?? They were all men from Guizhou and were still being detained by the police for investigation.?? ??? However, the police chief also frankly conceded that, although the six men were suspected of being "street racers," they might be let go due to insufficient evidence. ??? Obviously the answer from the police chief could not satisfy the residents, who strongly demanded to talk to his superiors.??? The secretary of the political and law committee of the Gongming Neighborhood later arrived at the scene.?? He agreed to hold face-to-face exchanges with the residents and promised that the government will selectively carry out a series of campaigns to crack down on crime.?? Only then did the residents peacefully disperse.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Sing Tao Jih Pao (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- Internet Version of non-PRC-owned daily newspaper; contains features on and analysis of PRC and Hong Kong political, social, and economic issues.?? headline: China police chief urges stability in wake of unrest.
text: [multiple events] BEIJING, Dec 27 (Reuters) - China's police chief has pressed security officials to "properly handle" riots and protests after a weekend clash between thousands of workers and local police in the southern province of Guangdong, state media said on Monday.The incident was the latest in a string of riots and clashes in rural China, all sparked by seemingly minor issues, that have highlighted discontent over rampant corruption and abuse of power and a growing rich-poor gap.China faced a hard road in maintaining social stability, Public Security Minister Zhou Yongkang told police chiefs from around the country at a Beijing conference on Sunday, a day after the unrest in Dongguan county, the China Police Daily said.Up to 50,000 workers upset over mistreatment by local security guards clashed with police in the town, throwing rocks and bricks and torching four police cars, a Hong Kong newspaper said on Sunday.Zhou urged public security organisations to improve methods for handling conflicts and "to positively prevent and properly handle massive incidents", the Legal Daily said."We absolutely do not allow people who harm the country's security and stability to form organisations, and absolutely do not allow activities which harm the country's security and stability to spread," Zhou was quoted as saying.Chinese media are barred from reporting on most protests and the paper made no mention of specific incidents.This month, two policemen were killed after 200 workers converged to seek the release of colleagues in detention in northern Shanxi province, and a scuffle between street performers and officials in the southwestern region of Guangxi escalated into a riot involving 10,000 people.In October, China declared martial law in part of central Henan province after at least seven people were killed, 42 injured and numerous houses set ablaze in clashes between minority Muslims and Han Chinese.In the previous month, a quarrel in the southwestern metropolis of Chongqing escalated into a riot that led to looting of government buildings and burning of police cars.

headline: Taiwan Lien-Ho Pao Reports on 4 Dec Protest Near CCTV Studios in Beijing
text: ??? Some 1,000 people went to Beijing and gathered in front of Beijings's China Central Television Station [CCTV] on the morning of 4 December to air their grievances.?? The Beijing police arrested some of the protesters. ??? The mainland's "Legal Knowledge Popularization Day" fell on 4 December.?? In their morning news programs, CCTV, Beijing Television Station, and other media encouraged the masses to take part in legal knowledge propaganda.?? But they did not expect that --?? beginning from the early morning of 0700 hours [2300 GMT 3 December] -- a large number of people, after hearing the news programs, would gather in front of CCTV to air their grievances and call for justice.??? Some people who came to Beijing held letters of protest and shouted "It's Justified to Visit Beijing to Air Grievances," "Down With Corrupt Officials," and other slogans.?? The number of people swelled to 1,000 at one time.?? The traffic at bustling Changan Main Street, which is next to CCTV, was blocked for some time.?? The authorities urgently deployed the police force and urged the people to leave, and also arrested some protesters. ???
