headline: Chinese protest in Beijing against ex-Taiwan leader's planned Japan visit
text: Text of report by Ralph Jennings, carried in English by Japanese news agency KyodoBeijing, 20 December: About 30 people demonstrated outside the Japanese embassy in Beijing with flags, banners and slogans Monday [20 December] afternoon to protest Japan's plan to give former Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui a visa and to air discontent over other Sino-Japanese political issues. The demonstrators, mostly men in their 20s and 30s organized by a citizens group called the Patriots Alliance Network, stood at the embassy gates for about half an hour as 12 police cars blocked off the street.Protesters, some of whom have staged other anti-Japan demonstrations in Beijing, carried five banners, two flags and bullhorns or battery-powered microphones to shout their messages, most of which were read from a prepared three-page speech. "This is another case of interference in China's internal affairs and its support for Taiwan independence," protest leader Zhang Jianyou said. "In recent days, Taiwan separatist Lee Teng-hui, using the excuse of 'sightseeing in Japan,' has asked the Japanese government to grant a visa and has even received the Japanese government's approval in principle," he said, reading from the speech. "As Chinese citizens, we express the utmost anger."Zhang, voice breaking, and other demonstrators shouted, "Resist the Japanese government" and "Persist in opposing Taiwan independence." Although the shades were drawn in most embassy offices facing the protest, a staff member with the embassy's culture and education section stepped out momentarily with her Chinese interpreter to acknowledge the protest. The embassy plans to write a report about the activity for the Japanese Foreign Ministry in Tokyo.On Friday, Lee Teng-hui applied for a Japanese visa in Taipei. He would visit Nagoya, Kyoto, Kanazawa and Tokyo for five days beginning 27 December. Japan says Lee, 81, a Kyoto University graduate and fluent Japanese speaker, wants to go as a tourist. China's Foreign Ministry says Lee, Taiwan's Kuomintang president from 1988-2000 and an advocate for more distance between Taiwan and China, cannot be seen to visit without a tie to politics and asked Japan to reject the visa. China sees Taiwan as a breakaway province that must eventually reunite or face use of force.The protesters also brought up Japanese leaders' talk of discontinuing official development aid to China, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's visits to Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo and territorial conflicts in the East China Sea, where both countries want to explore for gas under the ocean floor. Banners read: "Strongly object to Japan's rude interference in Chinese internal affairs" and, referring to World War II, "Don't forget the insult to the nation - resist Japanese products."Zhang said Chinese Foreign Ministry officials had tried lately to improve Sino-Japanese relations, but Japanese leaders had undone those ties. He also declined to speak with Japanese media after the protest, describing Japanese media reports on Chinese affairs as "eight layers of dung". "Lee is definitely going to carry out separatist activities (in Japan)," he told other reporters. Ushered by police, who knew about the demonstration in advance, the demonstrators marched away from the embassy at about 2.15 p.m. [local time] singing the Chinese national anthem.Source: Kyodo News Service, Tokyo, in English 1020 gmt 20 Dec 04
source_human: Kyodo News Service, Tokyo, in English

headline: Ming Pao Reports Large-Scale Worker Protest Against SOE Corruption in Sichuan
text: In Sichuan's Luzhou City, an incident recently occurred in which, thousands of workers from a state-owned chemical factory blocked traffic in the streets and surrounded the factory leaders, while the local government called out nearly 1,000 antiriot policemen to clear the area.?? There were clashes in the ensuring confrontation between the police and the workers, with a number of people being arrested.?? Up until yesterday [19 Dec], the incident was still not over yet.?? It is understood that the incident was chiefly set off by the change in factory system, as well as the embezzlement and bribe-taking on the part of factory leaders, which brought the state-owned enterprise, which formerly had 5,000-plus workers and staff members and several billion yuan in assets, to the brink of bankruptcy, unable to pay wages for months.It has been learned that the state-owned enterprise where the trouble occurred is Luzhou City's Huoju (Torch) Chemical Group, the predecessor of a military industrial enterprise.?? The protest incident began last Wednesday evening (15 December), with large numbers of workers confining the factory leaders to the factory club.?? It was not until for o'clock early the next morning, while the workers were paying no attention, that the leaders succeeded in escaping.?? Several days later, more than 3,000 workers gathered at the main gate of the new factory area to stage a protest demonstration, calling on factory management to pay back wages and investigate corruption on the part of leaders, but the Luzhou authorities failed to promptly deal with the incident.?? As a result, some people adopted relatively radical measures, such as blocking traffic in the streets, giving rise to several hours of traffic jam on the highway between factory buildings and the downtown area.?? On the third day of the incident, in the name of keeping order the local government called up nearly 1,000 antiriot policemen to clear the area and, in the ensuing confrontation, there was a free fight for some time between the two sides.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Ming Pao (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- Internet version of well-respected, non-PRC-owned daily newspaper; contains well-informed features on and analysis of PRC and Hong Kong political, social, and economic issues.?? Root URL on filing date:?? http://www.mingpao.com]Attachments:mp1220a.pdf

headline: Kyodo: Fifty Farmers Detained for Protesting at China's Central Leadership Compound
text: ??? Beijing, Dec. 27 Kyodo -- Fifty farmers were detained Sunday morning for protesting legal system corruption at the gates of China's central leadership compound on Mao Zedong's birthday, a source close to the protesters said Monday.??? At about 9 a.m., the group from Zanhan County in Hebei Province gathered outside the Zhongnanhai compound in central Beijing to demonstrate against alleged corruption by the state procuratorate, which is essentially a national district attorney's office.??? Police minibuses arrived shortly after 9 a.m. and took everyone away, the source said.?? He said the police also detained 200 to 300 more would-be protesters at Beijing's southern railway station.??? Protests against perceived corruption in rural or industrial areas of China have become common over the past two years in the wake of layoffs following market economic reforms and government confiscation of farmland for development.[Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English--Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]

headline: SCMP: Small Group Protests at Japan Consulate in Guangzhou Over Diaoyu Islands
text: ??? Protesters shouted slogans and set fire to paper Japanese flags outside the Japanese consulate-general in Guangzhou yesterday.??? "Down with Japanese imperialism, death to the Japanese, boycott Japanese goods," the group of a few dozen students shouted for about half an hour while waiting for a consulate official to receive their protest letter.??? They later tried to persuade military guards to help deliver the letter to the consulate at Guangzhou's Garden Hotel. When this failed, they trampled on the paper flags and set fire to them, watched by more than 10 paramilitary officers and about two dozen uniformed and plainclothes police.??? A Japanese official later emerged and beckoned to the protesters to approach him but his gesture angered the youths who refused to allow their representatives to step forward. The official then went inside but reappeared to take the letter after police intervened.??? The protest, which ended after about 90 minutes, was part of a nationwide action organised online by several patriotic organisations.??? They said they were offended by Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's remarks on February 9 that it was only right that the Japanese government had taken over the lighthouse on the Diaoyu Islands.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper.?? headline: Chinese police detain demonstrators on Tiananmen Square during legislative session
text: BEIJING (AP) - Chinese police detained about a dozen demonstrators Monday outside Beijing's Great Hall of the People, where the national legislature is holding its annual session.About a dozen male and female protesters, including one elderly lady, pulled out leaflets and sat down on the edge of Tiananmen Square, facing the mammoth hall as reporters came down its front steps.Plainclothes and uniformed officers rushed up to grab the papers, and pushed and dragged demonstrators into a waiting van.Earlier in the day, several other people were also seen being pushed into a van.It wasn't clear who the demonstrators were or what they were protesting.The annual session of the National People's Congress routinely attracts people airing grievances over personal problems or alleged persecution, including in past years mass protests by members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group.A Beijing police spokesman, Liu Wei, said he had no information about the protests or any detentions on Tiananmen Square on Monday.Several other people have been detained in protests, either in areas surrounding the hall or outside other government offices, since meetings of the parliament and its main advisory body began on Thursday.Authorities always tighten security in Beijing during major government meetings, beefing up already sizable contingents of police and military guards and limiting access to Tiananmen Square and approaches to the hall.Security officers were seen questioning visitors attempting to enter the huge plaza Monday following the protest.

headline: TVB Carries Footage of Shenzhen Protest Against Japan's UNSC Bid
text: Over 1,000 people [today] staged a protest in Shenzhen against Japan's bid for a permanent seat in the United Nations Security Council [UNSC]. Protesters burned a Japanese national flag and smashed a signboard of a Japanese department store. Police on the scene have not stopped the protesters' actions.[Begin Chou Chao-lin report from Shenzhen] [Protesters were heard singing the Chinese national anthem] Protesters first gathered at the Shenzhen Cemetery of Revolutionary Martyrs to pay tribute to martyrs who died for the country. Later on, they held high Chinese national flags and shouted the slogans "Opposing Japan" and "Boycotting Japanese goods" while marching along the downtown area toward a Japanese department store, where they staged the protest. Demonstrators burned a Japanese national flag and trampled on a poster featuring Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi in protest of the revival of Japanese militarism. [Protesters were seen gathering outside the Seibu department store] In addition, they threw various materials at the Japanese department store. A signboard and some ornaments of the department store were destroyed. [Hundreds of protesters were seen beating a sign post outside the Jusco department store] There were around 200 to 300 policemen on alert at the scene. The police had videotaped the whole rally process but did not stop the protesters' actions. [Protester speaks in Mandarin] I come mainly to voice opposition against Japan's entry into the UNSC as a permanent member. [Another protester speaks in Mandarin] It is the patriotism suppressed in my heart that has been ignited. [Chou] Some protesters tried to storm into the Japanese department store. However, they were barred from entering by security guards. Some of the protesters climbed to the podium of the Seibu department store and waved the Chinese national flag. The crowd dispersed shortly afterward. There were five organizations that made appeals to the public through the internet to join this rally. However, some Shenzhen residents disapproved the actions taken by the protesters. [A Shenzhen resident speaks in Mandarin] They should have used peaceful means.[Chou] The Japanese department store sent personnel to clean up the spot shortly after the protest. Security is also tightened so as to prevent people from creating a new round of disturbances. [end Chou recording]

headline: More on AFP: 'Thousands' of Farmers Riot in China's Zhejiang; 80 Police Injured
text: BEIJING, April 11 (AFP) - Up to 80 police and other officials were injured when thousands of farmers rioted in eastern China after an elderly protestor was allegedly run over and killed by a police car, witnesses said Monday.Officers armed with clubs and shields used teargas to break up a rally by elderly women Sunday against the construction of a chemical factory in Huashui township, Dongyang city in Zhejiang province.During the melee at least one of the women was run over and killed, sparking large angry crowds to return to the scene later in the day when the protest turned violent, said a worker on the nearby Huangtianfan Industrial estate."The crowd was very angry -- they overturned police vehicles and broke their windscreens. Nearly the whole village turned up to protest," she told AFP, declining to be named.A nurse at the Dongyang City People's Hospital said between 70 and 80 people, mostly police and officials, were treated for injuries on Sunday. About 30 of them remained hospitalised, she said.The worker said there were at least "several thousand" people involved in the clash, while a local police officer estimated there were nearly 10,000 demonstrators.The police officer denied that anyone had died however. More than 300 police were mobilised to handle the protest, she added."People were throwing rocks ... [ellipses as received] it was chaotic and many people got injured," she said.An industrial estate was built in Huashui in 2001 and locals are against the construction of another chemical factory on the site, according to the Beijing-based Friends of Nature's website.They claim factories operating there spew toxic wastes and emissions into the water supply which has resulted in ruined crops and deformity among new-born babies."The folks are just worried that the poisonous chemicals would pose too much harm to them -- their vegetables won't grow and no one would want to marry the boys and girls from our village," the worker said.China has witnessed a slew of violent demonstrations over the past few months, often the result of large-scale constructions which are fuelling the country's economic boom.Farmland is often requisitioned against residents' wishes.Many local officials, often eyeing gains from lucrative land sales, collaborate with businesses and property developers to build industrial parks and factories, often without compensating local residents adequately.Last October, tens of thousands of people clashed with armed police in a string of protests over the building of the Pubugou Dam in the southwestern province of Sichuan.Around the same time, ethnic unrest broke out between Muslims and the Han majority in central province of Henan where at least seven people were killed.Last weekend, tens of thousands of anti-Japanese demonstrators took to the streets to protest Tokyo's decision to approve a new school textbook which China says glosses over Japanese wartime atrocities.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

notes_human: Chemical plants:  http://www.epochtimes.com/gb/5/4/12/n885871.htm     4/12:   A village in Dongyang, Zhejiang province, erupted in a massive riot on Sunday when over 30,000 villagers clashed with police who were disrupting a protest against pollution.Reports that police had killed some of the elderly women protesters sparked the chaos in Hua Xi village in Dongyang. More than 50 government vehicles, including 14 cars and at least 40 buses, were turned over and destroyed. A total of 128 people were sent to the hospital for treatment, and 36 were admitted for longer-term care.One resident told the South China Morning Post that police officers, armed with clubs and shields, tried to disperse the group of elderly women, firing tear gas."They arrived at the sheds at about 5am and began dispersing the women. A number of the women passed out after they were hit with electrified clubs... They just hit the elderly women," said the resident. He said he heard that at least two elderly women died after being run over by police cars. Some protesters even had their eyeballs fall out, said the resident, he added. The casualties could not be confirmed.Some protesters were whisked off by police cars.For about a month, the 200 elderly protesters had been staging an around-the clock vigil outside the Hua Xi Middle School, not far from an industrial zone. They were protesting against the heavy pollution emitted by 13 chemical plants 250 metres away. They lived in makeshift bamboo sheds they had erected.On Sunday morning, rumours quickly spread that at least one of the protesters had been killed, sparking a rush by 30,000 to 40,000 villagers to the site, the witness said. "This is like almost all of the town's population was there," he said.Residents said since the 13 chemical plants were erected in 2001, the pollution had affected the environment so badly that the soil was barren and local vegetables inedible. "The turnip's skin is white, but it's dark inside," said one resident who took part in the riot.Villagers had to give up farming and earn a living by working at small trades, he said. "At the beginning, there was just one factory; now there are about 13 of them. We complained to the city government, asking for the relocation of either the factories or the village, but got no response."One official even said the factories would remain there even if all the people in the village died," he said."Young people didn't dare [join the original protest], since if they did, they would have been immediately harassed," the resident said, explaining why most of the protesters were elderly.Dongyang government spokesman Chen Qixian last night denied that anyone was killed when the protest was broken up. He said 1,000 government officials, including at least 100 policemen, were used in the operation.An informed source said mainland media had been restricted from reporting sensitive news about Zhejiang for fear that it would discourage foreign investment in the coastal province, which has seen extensive investments from overseas, Hong Kong and Taiwan in recent years.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: Shanghai Municipal Government Spokesman Comments on Anti-Japanes Demonstrations
text: Shanghai, 16 Apr (Xinhua) -- About 20,000 students and citizens went to the streets in Shanghai to hold anti-Japanese protests and demonstrations on 16 April. In connection with this, Jiao Yang, press spokesman for the Shanghai Municipal Government answered reporters' questions.Jiao Yang said: Japan's wrong attitudes and actions on a series of issues such as its history of aggression triggered the masses of people's dissatisfaction. Today students and citizens in Shanghai took to the street in some parts of the city to stage spontaneous anti-Japanese protests and demonstrations, expressing their discontentment with the Japanese rightwing forces' violation of the Sino-Japanese relations. We hope that the Japanese side can seriously address the Chinese people's concerns and properly handle the history [of Japanese aggression against China] and other sensitive issues relating to the feelings of the Chinese people.Jiao Yang said: In order to ensure the safety of Japanese organizations stationed in China and Japanese citizens in Shanghai, the Shanghai Garrison and other relevant departments have made great efforts in adopting timely measures in accordance with the law to alleviate the situation and maintain normal public order. The Shanghai Municipal Government has once again reminded local citizens that pursuant to the "PRC Law on Assemblies, Processions, and Demonstrations," whoever wants to organize assemblies, processions, or demonstrations must apply to and gain approval from the relevant public security authorities. It is hoped that citizens will remain calm and rational, express their aspirations in a lawful and orderly manner, and turn their patriotism into an impetus for studying and working hard; and will not join any unapproved activities.Jiao reiterated: Shanghai has a stable and harmonious society. The Shanghai Municipal Government protects the legitimate rights and interests of [foreign-funded] enterprises, organizations, and individuals in the city according to law. Shanghai is also capable of protecting the safety of foreigners in the city. [Description of Source: Beijing Xinhua Asia-Pacific Service in Chinese -- China's official news service (New China News Agency) to the Asia-Pacific region, established to replace Xinhua Hong Kong Service. The new service includes material previously carried by Xinhua Hong Kong Service and additional material specific to the Asia-Pacific region]

headline: Japan: NHK Shows Video on 16 Apr Anti-Japan Rally in Shanghai, China
text: Tokyo NHK General Television in Japanese at 0300 GMT on 16 April, during its regular noon newscast, carries approximately two minutes of video footage on an anti-Japan rally held in Shanghai in China on 16 April 2005.The report says that an anti-Japan rally is being held for the first time in the central part of Shanghai in China prior to the planned visit to China this weekend by Japanese Foreign Minister Nobutaka Machimura, and several thousand demonstrators have been marching in the city, holding up slogans in opposition to Japan's bid for a permanent UN Security Council seat. The demonstrators, mainly young people who appear to be students, began to gather at People's Square in the central part of Shanghai shortly before 1000 hours Japan time. They formed a group of several hundred demonstrators and staged a demonstration in protest against Japan. The anti-Japan rally is being held for the first time in Shanghai, and police officers are deployed along the street 10 meters apart to monitor the rally. The rally is being staged in an orderly way, and part of the group has been marching toward the Japanese Consulate General in the western part of Shanghai after leaving People's Square. The number of demonstrators has been increasing to several thousand, and 1,000 police officers have been on full alert after being deployed in front of the Japanese Consulate in Shanghai this morning. In Tianjin city, although about 200 people have gathered in a park there to protest against Japan, no major confusion has been reported so far. Meanwhile, no anti-Japan rallies have been staged at this time in Beijing, and police officers have been on full alert in areas near the Japanese Consulate General and Tiananmen Square after the call was issued urging the people to meet at the Square for a rally.[Description of Source: Tokyo NHK General Television in Japanese -- main channel of Japan's public broadcast network Nippon Hoso Kyokai (NHK)]

headline: CNA: Anti-japanese Protests Erupt Again In Several Chinese Cities
text: [Computer selected and disseminated without FBIS editorial intervention]Beijing/hong Kong, April 17 (CNA) -- Anti-Japanese protests erupted again Sunday as Japan's foreign minister arrived in Beijing, with protesters in many Chinese cities clashing with police.Witnesses said over 1,000 protesters marched toward Japan's consulate general in Shenyang, northeast China Sunday morning, with some 60 of them breaking through a police cordon and throwing rocks and bricks, and shouting "Go back to Japan!" The attackers clashed with police, but tensions were reduced as some people yelled "Chinese don't beat Chinese." No arrests were reported, except for several Hong Kong and Japanese media workers who were taken away for questioning and then later released.Japanese officials based in Beijing said some cars parked inside the Shenyang consular were damaged by the attackers.Earlier reports said thousands of people, mostly college and university students, were dispersed as they gathered at a shopping mall in Shenyang. Those who were not daunted then marched to Japan's consulate general, where they put up anti-Japanese banners and called on the public to boycott Japanese products.In southern China, thousands of protesters shouted "Boycott Japanese products" slogans in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province as anti-Japanese protests took place there for the third Sunday in a row.Holding banners condemning Japan's glossing over of its wartime atrocities in newly published history textbooks, the protesters waved Chinese flags and sang their national anthem as they marched toward Shennan Road, where Japanese-invested department stores were targeted.Police were seen making way for the protesters while also containing them to "designated areas" for the march. At one point, marchers threw objects at Japanese stores, destroying Japanese signs and trying to demolish advertisements for Japanese products, narrowly escaping clashes with the police.Anti-riot police with shields and batons were guarding two big Japanese department stores, each two or three meters away from the other to stop protesters from swarming into the stores, whose names were covered for fear of inciting Chinese anger.Still, the heavy police force failed to prevent windows at a Japanese noodle house from being smashed, witnesses said.In Guangzhou, capital of Guangdong Province, more than a dozen protesters were chased away by police when they were trying to set up anti-Japanese placards. Police also put up barricades around the city gymnasium and checked people's identity documents to discourage them from gathering.The police actions apparently did not stop some 10,000 people from marching in the streets shouting anti-Japanese slogans.In Zhuhai and Dongguan, two other Guangdong cities, protesters, totalling about 1,500 in each city, were seen shouting slogans such as "Boycott Japanese products." In Dongguan, a Japanese-invested factory was surrounded by over 1,000 protesters, who damaged the factory's doors and windows.Similar anti-Japanese protests were also reported Sunday in Nanning, Guangxi Province, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, and Shanghai.In Hong Kong, Japan's Consul General Takanori Kitamura said he is not worried about local protesters as he believes Hong Kong is a multi-cultural society where reason prevails.Kitamura said he believes the Hong Kong protest will take place peacefully and incidents of attacking Japanese consular offices will not happen in Hong Kong, as they had in China.Organizers said between 5,000 and 8,000 people will march in Hong Kong streets in protest against Japan later Sunday. [Description of Source: Taipei Central News Agency WWW-Text in English -- state-run corporation, only nationwide news agency in Taiwan. Root URL on filing date: http://www.cna.com.tw]

headline: SCMP: Guangzhou Authorities Step Up Efforts To Evict Villagers
text: Municipal authorities in Guangzhou yesterday stepped up action to evict 250 villagers camped on the site of a university town on Xiaoguwei Island.The villagers are protesting against the flattening of their homes to make way for the project. More than 100 policemen and three to four times as many officers from the urban management bureau surrounded the makeshift settlement while earthmoving machines tore down tents, and uprooted trees and bamboo groves.An elderly woman and another woman who had been left disabled after a scuffle with police last August were forcibly carried away in an ambulance before wreckers moved in and toppled their shack.Meanwhile, two elderly villagers engaged in minor scuffles with the demolition squad. The rest of the villagers looked on as their homes were destroyed for the fifth time since December 2003.Saying their eviction was illegal, the Guolang villagers have refused to move out. The municipal government claimed it had State Council approval for the massive university project but has declined to show evidence, even in court.The initial eviction measures between April 2003 and December 2003 went largely unnoticed, despite the deployment of thousands of police, dogs and helicopters.About 10,000 villagers were driven from their farms in an exercise that mobilised a record police force of more than 30,000, said Gao Zhisheng, a Beijing lawyer who champions displaced villagers' rights.The project involved the relocation of 200,000 people altogether, he said.The villagers feel their cause deserves the same attention as the controversial forced evictions from Hanyuan for the Pubugou hydropower project."It is the biggest such relocation in the country in terms of the people evicted and the police force used as well as the scale of the land requisition," Mr Gao said."They are fighting for their rights on principles and moral grounds and their burden has grown heavier while there is no end in sight ... it's very bitter for them."The Guangdong government has designated 4.6 billion yuan to acquire the land and compensate the villagers. But it has not explained how the funds have been used.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. Root URL on filing date: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: AFP: Eleven Chinese Villagers Jailed Over Unrest in Northern China
text: [protest was actually on 5/18]  BEIJING, Feb 9, 2006 (AFP) - Eleven farmers in northern China were jailed for up to five-and-a-half years after they stormed a local government office, state media said Thursday, in another example of rising social unrest.The farmers were accused of leading up to 200 other people in a storming of local county government and communist party offices in Gansu province in May last year, Xibu Shangbao, or the Western Commercial newspaper reported.The group on Yongjing county were reportedly enraged over the detention of their legal representative, who authorities said was not licensed.Several villagers tried to ram farming vehicles against the front door of the county government headquarters. They also reportedly detained an unspecified number of county government and party officials for over 12 hours.The Yongjing county court sentenced one farmer to five-and-a-half years in jail and another to five years, the newspaper said.Another nine people were sentenced to between one and two-and-a-half years, it said.Rising social unrest is becoming a major problem for China's authoritarian government as it seeks to maintain a firm grip on power while maintaining fast economic growth.The government said last month the number of incidents of unrest across China rose by 6.6 percent to 87,000 last year.One of the leading causes of unrest in recent years has been rampant land confiscation by local officials, who often collude with developers in lucrative real estate and industrial deals. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Thousands of Tibetans clash with Chinese security forces: report
text: BEIJING, June 2 (AFP) -Thousands of Tibetans in China's Qinghai province have clashed with security forces in a protest over alleged graft by officials, Radio Free Asia (RFA) reported Thursday.The violence occurred in the remote Yushu Prefecture on May 20-21, an official from the area was quoted as saying, reportedly describing the incident in Zado county as "not serious".Prefecture officials could not be immediately reached for comment Thursday, although a county official told AFP that "no such thing happened".The broadcaster cited sources as saying hundreds of security forces had been mobilised to guard government offices after the clashes, in which shots were fired and some county government buildings were torched.It was not clear whether there were casualties.Yushu Prefecture, in China's northwest, is a traditionally Tibetan area but under Chinese administration.The clash was sparked by county officials levying a "tax" of 1,500 yuan (180 US dollars) per person on people from neighboring areas who travel there to collect a valuable and rare medicinal fungus, RFA said.The official contacted by AFP acknowledged the tax was levied but refused to comment further.The fungus, known as yartsa gunbu, grows only at high altitude. It has been used as a supplement for centuries to enhance stamina and cure various ailments. The key Tibetan medicine commands high prices throughout East Asia.Local Tibetans accused the Chinese authorities of pocketing most of the money raised by taxing the lucrative trade.The recent unrest reportedly started when a number of Tibetans travelled to Yushu to collect yartsa gunbu and paid the local tax but were then barred from gathering the fungus and demanded their money back.Officials refused and instead summoned security forces, who then beat members of the crowd, striking some with electric prods, RFA reported.mp/fz

headline: Clashes break out as thousands protest for higher wages at Chinese factory
text: BEIJING, June 5 (AFP) -Thousands of workers clashed with several hundred police, who used tear gas to quell a violent protest for higher wages at a textile factory in China, a report said Sunday.The angry workers descended on the factory Friday morning and quickly forced the local security guards to flee, leaving behind their motorbikes which were pummeled with stones and set on fire, the Xinkuaibao newspaper said on its website.Several hundred police were called in and used tear gas to break up the crowd, which witnesses said had grown to as many as 4,000 people, the report said.Twenty-four workers thought to have organized the protest were arrested, it said.The workers at the Futai Cotton Textile Factory in Xintang township, Zengcheng city, were demanding more money after security guards at the village where the factory is located recently demanded that those renting housing pay a 15 yuan sanitation fee each month, the report said.The workers receive only about 700 yuan (84 US dollars) to 800 yuan a month.Company and local officials could not be reached for comment, but authorities were reported as saying they were investigating the matter in an attempt to mediate a solution.Local governments in China, however, are notorious for ignoring the plight of workers and for refusing to enforce labor laws, siding with employers to encourage more investment in their area.cs/sdm

headline: SCMP: PRC Imposes News Blackout on Wuxi Workers Protests Over Labor Disputes
text: Officials from the local government and the company confirmed that workers from the Wuxi Commercial Mansion, the city's biggest department store and a Shanghai-listed company, had staged sit-ins since Tuesday.A senior company official surnamed Zhang said the protest was mainly due to worker dissatisfaction with a government-led acquisition of the state-owned company in December by Shanghai's Junyao Group."A large number of people are still protesting in front of our department store despite the city government's intervention and our repeated promises that we will not lay off any workers," Mr Zhang said.He said a vice-mayor and many senior government officials had visited the scene and the protests had been quiet and peaceful.A report circulated in club. cat898.com, one of the mainland's most popular internet chat rooms, claimed more than 1,000 company staff were involved in the protests over fears they would be laid off.Mr Zhang denied the claims, adding that only 200 to 300 company staff, mostly shop assistants, had taken part in the demonstrations. The company has more than 2,000 employees.An official from the city's propaganda department accused the protesters of deliberately making trouble."The government has tried its best to protect workers' interests in the state-owned enterprise reform. The compensation for department store staff who want to quit is very high compared with other similar cases in the city as well as the province," he said.He admitted the government and company officials were partly responsible for the demonstrations for failing to hold effective talks with the workers."But we have already stopped the ownership reform in view of the situation. The fact that they still refuse to call off the protests shows they must have been spurred on someone," he added, without giving further details.Highlighting the authorities' fear that the demonstrations could escalate, mainland media, including Xinhua, were not allowed to cover the protest and discussions in local internet chat rooms were banned.The Wuxi Daily, a local government mouthpiece, has printed two strongly worded editorials against the protest in the past two days.Both officials denied the Junyao Group was involved in the dispute.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: 3 killed in Chinese riot, H.K. newspaper says
text: Three people were killed during a riot in which more than 100 taxi-drivers clashed with police in a major city in China's southern Guangdong Province on Tuesday, a Hong Kong newspaper reported Wednesday.The riot, Ming Pao Daily said, broke out in Tangxia town in Donggang after a taxi driver who was involved in a traffic accident with a private car claimed police were harboring the driver of the other vehicle.More than 100 other taxi drivers then drove to the government headquarters in the Tangxia on Tuesday morning to demand an investigation into the incident.During the demonstration, some protesters threw objects, smashing the windows in the building while others overturned motorcycles along the road, the paper said.Hundreds of riot police were dispatched to the scene to quell the crowd with batons and tear gas, it said.The report quoted unnamed sources as saying three people were killed and dozens more injured during the riot.An officer with the Public Security Bureau in Tangxia told Kyodo News he had learned about the incident on the Internet, but he refused to comment further.

headline: SCMP: Hundreds of Phone Subscribers Protest PRC Firm's Rate Increases
text: About 300 people gathered outside the Unicom office in Zhenhua Road for a second day demanding that the company reverse its decision. The protesters briefly clashed with security guards and police, and at least three claimed to have been beaten.The protests came after China Unicom announced last week that it was cancelling a special monthly mobile phone package that gave subscribers unlimited long-distance calls within the mainland for as little as 600 yuan a month.The package was launched three years ago as part of the company's aggressive promotional campaign to attract subscribers in Shenzhen.Customers had to pay 3,000 yuan to open an account, but the package was so popular that all available numbers, estimated at about 20,000, were snapped up before the promotion ended.Many of the accounts were re-sold on the second-hand market for more than 10,000 yuan each, according to Wang Lin , who bought 15 accounts to set up a private long-distance call company."I sold all my assets and invested them in these accounts. Now the company has suddenly decided to cancel the service. My money will go down the drain," the native of Hunan province said.More than 90 per cent of Shenzhen's residents are migrants from other parts of China.Most left their families behind for better career prospects in this booming border city and for many the telephone is the only means of communicating with their families."Both my son and my parents are in Hunan. I only go home once every year, but I call them every night to check if they are alright. But I wouldn't be able to afford this if I had to pay the normal fee," said a man who refused to be named.China Unicom said the decision to stop the services was made after the mainland's telecommunication regulatory body asked it to adjust fees."The authorities have asked us to revise the subscription fees to ensure a healthy market. We therefore had to make a change to the special package," read a China Unicom notice.Subscribers now have to pay 0.2 yuan per minute for long-distance calls within the mainland. China Unicom said it would offer a 60 per cent discount to current users until the end of this year.But the protesters said they would not accept the offer. Delegates from both side met yesterday to negotiate a compromise.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: Police arrest 10 following riot by thousands in eastern China
text: BEIJING, June 29 (AFP) -Police have arrested 10 people after thousands rioted in an eastern Chinese city following a traffic accident, state media said Wednesday, blaming the incident on people being "unclear about reality."Rioters smashed police cars, threw rocks at paramilitary officers and set off firecrackers in a police station during the incident which lasted for hours from Sunday afternoon to evening at Chizhou in Anhui province, the Chizhou Daily had said on its website.The Xinhua news agency said Wednesday the situation has been "basically calmed."The riot was sparked by an accident in which a car hit a pedestrian. The car driver and three of its passengers beat up the pedestrian who had to be taken to hospital.Xinhua said the driver and his companions were taken to a police station, but "some people unclear about reality" gathered outside the station and demanded police hand over the four attackers.It is common for small crowds to gather at the scene of traffic accidents in China, often out of curiosity but also to ensure justice is served.The crowd grew to 10,000 people, including onlookers and rioters.Some people smashed the car involved in the accident, setting it on fire, and also damaged several other cars. They threw rocks at the armed police officers at the scene, injuring six of them, the Chizhou Daily said.Xinhua said the windows and door of the police station were also broken.A nearby supermarket was ransacked and emptied within three hours, the newspaper had said.More than 700 police dispatched to the scene eventually managed to disperse the crowd. The four attackers have been detained by police, Xinhua said.The incident reflects the high degree of dissatisfaction and distrust with authorities in China, which often manifests itself in social unrest.cs/sm

headline: Hundreds of villagers in eastern China riot against polluting factory
text: SHANGHAI, June 30 (AFP) -Hundreds of Chinese villagers have marched on a battery factory which they say is poisoning their children and held 1,000 workers hostage, residents and officials said Thursday.About 600 people from Jianxia village in the eastern province of Zhejiang took control of the Zhejiang Tianneng Battery company and barricaded workers inside, resident Han Cheng told AFP.But a promise made Thursday afternoon by factory managers to stop production and carry out investigations helped defuse the tense five-day standoff."The problem has been more or less solved this afternoon," said a resident surnamed Huang in the village 150 kilometres (90 miles) south of Shanghai."Most people have started to go home after negotiations with officials and police and the factory will stop production for 15 days," said Huang."Factory leaders gave their promises and people are sort of satisfied for now, but now it remains to be seen if they'll keep their promises."Infuriated residents from the village of about 3,000 marched on the factory on Sunday, saying the pollution it produces when making car batteries is making their children ill."There are about 200 children in the village and they are all getting sick," said Han, who has a four-year-old daughter. "They are polluting the air and it has been going on for 15 years."Four people were hospitalised after factory workers and villagers fought each other, he said.Officials in Meishan township which oversees the village said they would run tests to judge the extent of the villagers' health problems and the environmental damage caused by the foreign-invested company."This can all be discussed over the table but it is not right not to allow workers to come out," said a Meishan official, refusing to be identified.Police refused to comment on the incident, while telephones at the plant were not answered.Social unrest that often turns violent is becoming increasingly common in China, reflecting a high degree of dissatisfaction and distrust of authorities and of businesses.In one incident Sunday thousands rioted in eastern Anhui province following a traffic accident, smashing police cars and attacking a paramilitary force sent to quell the angry mob.Although many companies in China today are private, local governments are often investors and therefore routinely overlook environmental issues or citizens' complaints, to ensure maximun profits.At Zhejiang Tianneng Battery factory, a private company with 750 million yuan (90.6 million dollars) in assets that also has Hong Kong and US investment of 12 million dollars, Meishan party officials form part of the management team.People in the world's most populous nation are also becoming increasingly well informed about pollution and demanding action for a problem that has plagued the country for years.China's top environment official this week lambasted the nation's failure to enforce environmental laws, saying greater enforcement is crucial to stemming worsening pollution."Non-enforcement and lax enforcement of laws and administrative inactivity are the main targets we must aim at," said Xie Zhenhua, director of the State Environmental Protection Agency.bms/sai/sm

headline: BEIJING
text: NORTH/NORTHEASTScores mob police station to demand release of protestersJILIN - More than 60 people mobbed a police station in Changchun on Thursday to demand the release of 12 detainees accused of injuring several officers the previous day. A three-hour standoff ensued when about 100 riot police and 200 other officers were sent to break up a rally on Wednesday, East Asia Trade News reports.EAST/SOUTHEASTFactory raid nets 900,000 packets of fake cigarettesJIANGXI - Police have seized more than 900,000 packs of counterfeit cigarettes during a raid on a factory in the town of Longan. The value of the seizure was estimated at 25 million yuan, and the factory was the biggest of its kind found in Jiangxi. Xinhua reports 21 people, including six women, were detained.Officials tap mayor for postof Quanzhou party secretaryFUJIAN - Provincial authorities have appointed Zheng Daoxi as party secretary of Quanzhou , the Strait News reports. Mr Zheng has been mayor of Quanzhou since March 2003.Suicide bomber attacks Fuzhou government officesFUJIAN - A man blew himself up early yesterday morning on an overpass on Guping Road in Fuzhou , an area housing the offices of several government departments. The bomb did not cause any other casualties, the China News Service reports. Police said they were still investigating the motives behind the incident.CENTRAL/SOUTHZhuhai bans battery-powered bicycles because of accidentsGUANGDONG - Electric-motor-driven bicycles are now banned in Zhuhai , Xinhua reports. The battery-driven bicycles, which used to be popular among youngsters, are now blamed for causing traffic congestion and frequent accidents. Xinhua quoted a public security official as saying that in the first five months of this year, two people were killed and 31 others injured in 166 traffic accidents involving the electrical bicycles.Hospital staff who left patient to die get suspended termsHENAN - Three doctors, a nurse and a driver at a hospital practising Chinese traditional medicine in Xinzheng have been handed suspended prison terms for dumping a patient by a roadside and leaving him to die of exposure. The patient was admitted to the hospital in November 2003 after sustaining severe injuries in a car accident. He could not speak or write, so was unable to identify himself or pay medical bills. The hospital's chief told the driver to abandon the patient in another city, the Beijing News reports.High cancer rate found near river polluted by paper millsHUBEI - Untreated sewage discharged from paper mills has been polluting the Baihe River for many years, Chutian Metropolis Daily reports. More than 100 people in Zhaiwan village, on the river's east bank, have died of cancer in the past three years, a death rate of about one in every 10 households. Most of the cancers affected the patients' respiratory and digestive systems.WESTFour dead, five missing afterdownpour triggers landslidesSICHUAN - Torrential rain in Luding triggered landslides on Thursday, killing at least four people. Five others were missing and six seriously wounded, Xinhua reports. The landslides severed power and water supplies, destroyed 36km of roads, and damaged 10 bridges and dams beyond repair. Direct economic losses were estimated to total 31.9 million yuan.Demolition workers injuredin clash with building ownersCHONGQING - Several angry building owners injured 14 employees from an office responsible for carrying out demolitions on Thursday. The staff were trying to demolish a building off Zhongshan No2 Road, cnradio.com reports.

headline: Thousands of farmers protest Chinese government-backed land grab
text: BEIJING, July 3 (AFP) -Thousands of farmers demonstrated against a government-backed land grab in China's southern Guangdong province, with clashes erupting after police detained some protestors, a rights group said Sunday.Four villagers were rounded up by police Thursday evening after the farmers tried to block bulldozers from levelling about 670 hectares (1,656 acres) of land near Sanshangang village, the Empowerment and Rights Institute said.On Saturday, the third consecutive day of protests, demonstrators surrounded Sanshangang's public security bureau demanding the release of the arrested protestors, said Maggie Hou, an official with the independent institute."Some 200 demonstrators began the protest on Saturday, but by the evening several thousand protesters had arrived, with farmers from other areas also joining in," Hou told AFP.Around 600 police watched as protesters shouted slogans and carried banners that said "give our land back" and "the land law should be implemented equally", Hou said.At least one person, identified as Shao Shuntian, was arrested after clashes broke out with the law enforcement officers."Police clubbed her with a baton and began kicking her after she fell down. She tried to fight back and so they took her away."An independent American photographer, Scott Gorman, was also detained Saturday by local police but was released later in the day.Up to 7,000 farmers are being evicted from the land, in a murky process that began when several of the village leaders were bribed into signing blank contracts with the local land administrative office in 1992, the institute said.Guangdong province is known as the shop floor of China's booming export-oriented industry. Land prices have sky-rocketed in the past 20 years as thousands of factories have sprung up to take advantage of the region's cheap labor resources.sai/dv

headline: Veterans in pension protest rounded up - Police break up ex-servicemen's rally as PLA marks its 78th anniversary
text: Hundreds of ex-servicemen marked yesterday's 78th anniversary of the founding of the People's Liberation Army by protesting outside a PLA office in Beijing.One witness said he saw many people being taken away by police.The petitioners, who were seeking action over economic woes caused by a lack of social security, gathered as PLA garrisons nationwide held Army Day ceremonies.A shopkeeper in Aimin Street, Beijing, said the petitioners gathered outside the gate to an office of the PLA's General Political Department. The crowd, including passers-by, could have been in the thousands."I saw hundreds of people taken away by police as they were petitioning about 7.30 this morning when I came to open the shop," he said. Several other nearby residents confirmed that they had also witnessed the ex-servicemen's protest.By the afternoon, several dozen police officers were patrolling the area and about a dozen police vehicles were parked nearby. An armed officer guarding the office gate said the office was not open.Yesterday's incident followed a petition in April, when several thousand military veterans gathered at the same office, seeking better treatment from the state.Among those seeking more action in April was Korean war veteran Gan Guozhong , who died last month from a bone disease.Gan, who was unable to afford hospital treatment, spent the last six months of his life bedridden at home.Despite his war service and battlefield injuries, the government did not cover more than 60,000 yuan in medical expenses over the past decade, and his family continues to shoulder the debt.As a veteran, the government assigned him a job in a state-run company in Heilongjiang's Heihe city in 1976 but the company went bankrupt after Gan retired in 1993 and he lost his pension and medical benefits.The pension was resumed in 2000, but not the medical coverage.Gan petitioned state leaders for 10 years and they forwarded some of his letters to the local government.His son Gan Baolin , also a veteran, said no clear-cut policies existed to deal with cases like his father's.Gan Baolin said it was understandable that veterans would go to Beijing to petition."They once fought for the nation, risking their necks," he said. "Now they are old and society has changed a lot, but they haven't got love or care from society or the government."My father left the world with regrets."

headline: Protest over boy's death
text: A group of villagers from Guangdong and their Hong Kong relatives yesterday marched on a hospital in Huizhou demanding justice over the death of a boy nearly three weeks after he was bitten by a rabid dog.Eighteen-month-old So Kar-hai and his mother were admitted to Boluo County People's Hospital after they were bitten by the dog on July 7. The boy was bitten three times on his face, while his mother was bitten once on the arm.While the mother was discharged after treatment, the toddler remained in hospital and died of rabies 21/2 weeks later.Bereaved family members said yesterday the hospital had failed to inform them it did not have one of several injections required to treat rabies after charging them 600 yuan for the injections.After meeting hospital representatives, the boy's father said they were still adopting a tough stance."The hospital's attitude over the meeting is very slack as it keeps saying it should not be held responsible for my son's death," he said. "We hope media coverage will force the hospital to admit its responsibility. If not, we plan to organise a protest march."Mr So said he feared for his wife as she, too, had not received the required treatment. The hospital was not available for comment.

headline: China protest turns ugly as demonstrations spread
text: BEIJING, Aug 9 (Reuters) - Thousands of residents of a central Chinese city ransacked government offices, trashed cars and attacked a police station after police dogs bit petitioners while breaking up a protest, a resident and media said.It was the latest in a string of outbursts as discontent grows in the world's most populous nation over a range of issues including a widening wealth gap and widespread corruption.About 100 residents from Daye, a city within the larger city of Huangshi, petitioned the Huangshi government on Thursday over a plan to change its status to that of district, Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po newspaper reported on Monday.An online bulletin board with postings by people claiming to be witnesses said the protesters felt that downgrading Daye to a district would allow Huangshi to siphon away its funds.The change in the status of Daye, rich in mineral resources, would "affect the interests of a small number of people" in the city in Hubei province, a police official said by telephone.But more than a few Daye residents were apparently upset by the pending change. Police ultimately brought out dogs to end the protest and four petitioners were bitten, the newspaper said.Two days later, on Saturday, a crowd of about 10,000, angered by the dog attack, converged on the Huangshi city government and party offices, smashing windows and property, Wen Wei Po said.A Huangshi hotel employee who gave only her surname, Li, also said that about 10,000 people participated.The crowd wrecked more than 10 vehicles, the newspaper said.The city government in Huangshi, some 600 km (370 miles) west of Shanghai, appealed for calm on Tuesday."The city party committee and government call on the entire city to make clear the distinction between right and wrong, keep calm, and not be poisoned and bewitched by a small number of people with ulterior motives," it said on a government Web site.Hotel employee Li corroborated the Wen Wei Po's report on the reason for the protest. Several other residents said the case was too sensitive to comment upon.Li said there were rumours that people had been paid to take part. "These people were really fierce. I think there must be someone or some group behind it, otherwise the common people would not care about such government affairs," she said.But postings on the online bulletin board denied the demonstrators had been hired.Calls to the Huangshi government office authorised to comment on the violence went unanswered. Other officials declined comment.Land disputes, corruption, abuse of power and a widening rich-poor gap have led to a rise in the number of protests in recent years. A Hong Kong newspaper quoted the Minister of Public Security as saying there were more than 74,000 last year alone.The protesters blocked the highway between Huangshi and Wuhan, and stopped traffic on a bridge, the city government said on its Web site, quoting the Huangshi Daily.The government urged the people not to spread rumours about the incident and called for stability. But it warned it would "resolutely and severely" punish people involved in the attack.
notes_human: Use dogs: Officers from the paramilitary People's Armed Police turned police dogs on the protesters and four were bitten. Several were beaten by the officers, the report said. Two days later, more than 10,000 residents from Daye massed outside the Huangshi city government office and smashed the windows and air conditioning units on the first to fourth floors, the report said.The incident began last Thursday when hundreds of residents from the city of Daye in Hubei province, angry over a plan by the larger city of Huangshi to annex it, demonstrated outside the Huangshi government office, the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Po newspaper said.Officers from the paramilitary People's Armed Police turned police dogs on the protesters and four were bitten. Several were beaten by the officers, the report said.Two days later, more than 10,000 residents from Daye massed outside the Huangshi city government office and smashed the windows and air conditioning units on the first to fourth floors, the report said.Messages by people claiming to be eyewitnesses and seen on Internet bulletin boards Wednesday said nearly 20,000 people were involved in the protests and some blocked roads for two hours.The protesters also smashed more than ten government vehicles and overturned some of them, the reports said.Some 1,200 People's Armed Police were sent to the scene and later used tear gas to try to disperse the crowd, according to eyewitnesses.Two people were detained but later released due to pressure from the crowd, they said.Officials at the Huangshi government refused to comment Wednesday. Employees at the propaganda department told AFP that initial statements posted by the city on its website to explain the incident had been deleted.The Hubei provincial government also refused to comment.The Huangshi government has suspended plans for the annexation and urged Daye city residents to remain calm, a local TV station was cited as saying.Large-scale protests and riots have become common among Chinese frustrated by massive corruption and illegal land requisitions.[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Protest over factory pollution in China leaves dozens hurt after clash with police
text: BEIJING (AP) - Villagers staging a protest over pollution at a factory in eastern China clashed with police, and officers later beat them for participating, leaving dozens injured, witnesses and medical officials said Sunday.A large group of people gathered Saturday outside the Tian Neng Battery Factory in Meishan, a town in Zhejiang province, to demonstrate against what they said was lead pollution, villagers said."Police fired tear gas into the crowd and beat innocent bystanders," said a villager who refused to give his name. "I also saw some ambulances go through the area to pick up injured people."The man, reached by telephone, said he witnessed the protest and that "many, many people" were involved.A woman at the emergency ward of the Changxing County Hospital said between 60 and 70 people were treated Saturday for minor injuries related to the incident. She said most had been discharged by Sunday, but refused to provide any other details or give her name.A medic at a first aid center in Changxing said "several people" arrived in police vehicles for treatment after being hit by stones or roughly pushed. He gave only his family name, Wang.Another villager, who did not want to give his name for fear of retaliation against his family, said about 1,000 police officers later went to villages and harassed and beat the participants, injuring at least 10 people. The police were holding shields and wearing helmets, he said.The man, who said he was told about the incident by witnesses, said many residents sought revenge later that night by "breaking into government offices and burning police cars."He said the protesters wanted the factory to shut down or move, but the company's officials had refused. He did not provide any more details.Telephones either rang busy or were not answered on Sunday at the factory and at Meishan police and government offices. A man who answered the phone at the Changxing County government office, which oversees Meishan, said he had "never heard of the case."Such scenes of frustration are becoming more common as villagers in rural China vent their anger against corruption, pollution and the seizure of land for real estate development.While the central government says it is concerned and wants a peaceful resolution of disputes, local authorities -- many indifferent or bullying -- usually end up dealing with the situations, which often turn violent.Another villager reached by telephone said the pollution dispute escalated into "a conflict between the policemen and the locals.""Several people were injured," said the man, who gave only his surname, Zhou. "There are still many police around today."Residents said thousands of police were guarding the factory and government offices on Sunday, but no violence broke out.Last month, farmers in Shengzhou, another Zhejiang town, attacked a pharmaceutical plant with rocks and tools and forced it to suspend production, saying the chemical runoff stunted crops and caused a rise in cancer and birth defects.A second confrontation followed when the plant resumed operations, and farmers and police were reportedly injured.In April, at least 30 people were injured elsewhere in Zhejiang when police clashed with villagers who set up bamboo huts in an industrial complex to protest pollution.

headline: One hundred on hunger strike in China over land dispute, corruption
text: BEIJING, Aug 31 (AFP) -Around 100 people began a hunger strike Wednesday in southern China over a village chief's alleged corruption and a dispute over land requisition, villagers said as police arrested several protestors.Dozens of residents of Taishi village in Guangdong province have been protesting in front of the Panyu district government office for the past few days to demand it remove Chen Jinsheng, they told AFP.It is the latest in a series of protests over land rights in rural China and highlights the increasingly contentious problem which threatens to boil over into larger-scale conflicts across the country.As of early Wednesday, around 100 villagers had stopped taking food in a desperate move to force the government to oust Chen.They accuse him of selling their farmland to property developers without their approval and embezzling village funds."If they don't remove him, we will stage this hunger strike indefinitely. If there is no answer, we won't go," said a villager surnamed Huang.He said about 100 police officers descended on them Wednesday morning and arrested three or four protestors."They are arresting people who are talking on mobile phones or are taking photos," said another villager, Feng Jianming.Feng said there were also around 100 people protesting outside the Taishi village government offices."People here are extremely angry ... we're not afraid, if they want to arrest, let them arrest the whole village," Feng said.Having lost his family's land, Feng said he has only been able to earn a meagre income as a motorcycle taxi driver and many other villagers have been forced to leave to find jobs elsewhere.Both Panyu district and Taishi village governments refused comment, as did Panyu police.Two weeks ago an estimated 800 people from Taishi clashed with hundreds of police, resulting in several injuries and the arrests of seven residents. Four have since been released.Guo Feixiong, a lawyer for some of the villagers, said police in Guangzhou city, which has jurisdication over the village, have agreed to investigate those arrests.In a separate incident, more than 110 rural families in the northwestern province of Gansu are suing their local government over illegal land seizures and forced demolition of their houses, the China Daily reported Wednesday.Land requisition by the state has become one of China's sharpest social issues, with an increasing number of evicted people accusing government officials of illegal land grabs to enrich the ruling elite.In China all land is owned by the state, giving local officials tremendous powers.vy/mp/ben

headline: HK Journal: 200,000 Peasants Surround City Government in Yunnan on 13 Aug
text: Beginning 12 August, more than 100,000 peasants in the Yuqi district, Yunnan province, whose livelihood is growing tobacco, surrounded the Yuqi City CPC Committee and the City Government for four consecutive days in protest against the authorities' practice of purchasing their products with lower than average prices. At the climax of the protest on the evening of 13 August, the masses of people who attended the gathering to make a stand against the authorities reached 200,000 people. More than 300 large tourist buses had parked around the area to show support in a way which was gigantic in scale.Twenty Million People Live on Pornographic Industry The Bulletin [Jianbao] published by the state revealed on 11 August that according to a report of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences [CASS,] although the pornographic and entertainment industry must be banned, it can never be banned. The more the authorities try to prohibit it, the more it will be controlled by criminal (syndicates) [hei she hui] and be full of the evil of pornography [huang]. The pornographic industry provides jobs for 20 million people and its annual turnover amounts to around 600 billion to 800 billion yuan. The problem is how to enact a law to regulate the industry and prevent crime syndicates from collaborating with public security to control the industry.[Description of Source: Hong Kong Cheng Ming in Chinese -- Non-PRC-owned monthly magazine ("Contending"); focuses on political issues in the PRC; tendency to sensationalize]Attachments:

headline: SCMP: Shoe-Factory Workers in Police Clash
text: More than 150 shoe-factory workers clashed with Guangzhou police in a violent protest over low salaries and delayed payments. ? The workers -- most of them women -- marched to a Guangzhou freeway on Thursday morning, blocking traffic and demanding government help to recover unpaid salaries, the Information Times reported yesterday. ? The local government mobilised 200 police officers to disperse the protesters, but the two sides clashed as the workers pelted police with rocks and debris. ? The authorities had to use tear gas to drive the crowd away, the report said. Five workers were placed in custody and charged with assaulting police, while several protest leaders were also detained. ? The local government later held a meeting with the workers and promised to help them get the back pay and salary increases. ? The report said the workers were angry because of repeatedly delayed salary payments. Many workers were taking home as little as 100 yuan a month, far below the 510 yuan minimum salary set by the city government. ? The shoe factory opened in June. It was not clear whether the government had punished the management. ? Worker protests have become increasingly common in the Pearl River Delta in recent years. ? ? ???? headline: HK Daily: 10,000 Chongqing Workers Rally for Wage Arrears, Clash With Police
text: ?? Workers took to the streets to stage protests because of the bankruptcy and wage arrears of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation [name as transliterated; chong qing guo ying te shu gang tie gong si].? The issue dragged on for two months and is yet to be resolved.? On 2 October, over 10,000 workers of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation once again took to the streets to protest the company operators on fraudulently declaring bankruptcy but actually evading debts. ?Since Chongqing will hold the Fifth Asia-Pacific City Mayors' Summit on 13 October, the authorities conducted strict surveillance over the workers and issued warnings to them via television broadcast. ?? The Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation declared bankruptcy in June 2005.? However, the workers discovered that it was actually a hoax: The Huadong Corporation under the government seized the opportunity and took over the right to use the land under the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation's factories.? It is a case of transferring state property where they fraudulently declared bankruptcy but actually divided up the property among themselves.? Meanwhile, the Huadong Corporation is operating under the signboard of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation.? Since 12 August, nearly 2,000 workers and their family members took to the streets to petition, urging that they get back their wage arrears and that a series of issues brought along by the bankruptcy should be resolved.? Their rallies caused traffic jam.? On 13 August, the local policemen forcefully dispersed and beat up the protesting crowd. ?? The workers and the government authorities held talks but the government never honored its promises.? On 2 October, over 10,000 staff and workers of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation and their family members had no choice but to stage another protest once again.? They displayed banners, including "We strongly urge that Vice Mayor Huang Qifan give the workers of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation a satisfactory answer," "We want equality," and "We vow never to give up until we attain our objectives." ?? Recently the Chongqing authorities have begun to conduct strict surveillance over the workers' protesting activities.? They have also televised the leaders' speeches via the factory televisions, threatening the workers to remain calm and not to act impetuously.? However, the workers of the Chongqing State Special Steel Corporation said that they are not afraid of the government's pressure.? They said that they would ask more workers to participate in the protests and attract the central authorities' attention so that the central authorities would directly dispatch personnel to resolve the issue. SCORES of Chinese workers have been injured, with up to 20 taken to hospital, after police broke up a 10,000-strong protest over lay-offs from a state-owned steel factory in the northwestern city of Chongqing.The workers' protest, one of the largest reported in China since 1989, threatened to derail Chongqing's efforts to attract foreign investment at the Asia-Pacific Cities Summit it hosted this week, to which Australia sent the biggest delegation.

headline: HK: Shenzhen Workers Protest Loss of Assets, Compensation in SOE Restructuring
text: Hundreds of workers from a state-run construction company in Shenzhen held an open assembly yesterday in protest of the draining of state-owned assets by their company in the course of restructuring and the failure to issue them their compensation in accordance with regulations, plunging the lives of the workers into difficulty.? Protesters demanded that the Shenzhen City Government investigate the loss of the state-owned assets of their company and publicize the results and supervise and urge the company to compensate the workers according to regulations.? The authorities sent duty personnel to communicate with the assembled workers, but the talks resulted in nothing.? Some of the workers told this newspaper that they were not opposed to the restructuring of the state-owned enterprise but were dissatisfied with the serious draining of state-owned assets.? They were protesting against the neglect of workers' benefits in the course of the restructuring and the situation in which "leaders are oozing with riches while workers are so poor that they cannot even afford a house." At around 1300 yesterday afternoon, about 300 to 400 people gathered at the front gate of the Tehao Stock Company, which is near the Armed Police Hospital in Honggang Xicun village, Shenzhen.? All of them were company workers, many of them over 50, together with their families, Soldiers-Turned-Workers, They Were the Earliest Ones Involved in the Development of Shenzhen Tehao Company was formerly the state-run Shenzhen No. 1 Construction Company under the Shenzhen Jianye Group, formerly an entity established for the collective transformation of soldiers into workers by the PLA capital construction engineering corps in the mid-1980s, when the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone was being established.? The workers in the early years were all soldiers.? Dubbed "Shenzhen pioneer workers," they made enormous contributions toward the building of the special economic zone. Doubts About the 600-Million Debt and Demand That the Authorities Investigate As understood, these "pioneer workers" gathered for a protest because, one, they were opposed to the serious draining of state-owned assets caused by the company in restructuring; and two, they were dissatisfied with the company's failure to give workers compensation, as required by regulations, in the case of restructuring.? They pointed out that as a key state-run construction company in Shenzhen, which once was involved in many large-scale projects there, it surprisingly claimed that it was carrying a debt of 600 million [currency not stated] during an asset valuation in the course of its restructuring.? This was doubtful.? The senior management of the company is miles apart from the rank-and-file of the company.? Some workers have worked in Shenzhen for decades and still cannot afford a cheap apartment, whereas many senior staff members own several apartments, villas, and quite a number of private vehicles. Senior Staff Members Own Several Villas, But Workers Cannot Afford a House As pointed out, state and Shenzhen City Government regulations provide that workers be compensated with appropriate subsidies and compensation separately by the government and the company.? However, the workers have received only the government subsidies, but so far have not received compensation from the company.? On the contrary, the workers had to pay for their old-age insurance themselves.? An old worker surnamed Ding said in great agitation that his family, he himself, his spouse, his son, and son-in-law all worked for the company.? With the restructuring of the company they were all retired.? Now they have problems even with accommodation.? This is quite unfair. Some at the assembly said angrily that when they started out in Shenzhen they were wearing army uniforms; they ate rotten vegetables, lived in sheds, and all the possessions they had were a few rusty steel pipes to support the sheds with and a few broken wooden cases.? The company succeeded because the workers paid for it with their youth and sweat, and they cannot stand by watching the assets that belong to the state and workers being mysteriously drained; much less can they accept their well-deserved compensation being gobbled up.? They strongly demand that the Shenzhen City Government intervene and investigate and see that there is justice for the workers. Though excited and loudly complaining among themselves, the workers at the assembly did not do anything out of line.? No leaders of the company came out to meet them.? Two duty personnel from the Shenzhen City Labor Department arrived and communicated with the protestors, but talks between the two sides did not lead to anything.? The assembled workers finally dispersed peacefully. Information indicates that in the mid-1980s, in order to develop the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, the Central Military Commission ordered 20,000 soldiers from a capital construction engineering corps into Shenzhen to take up construction duties.? Later all of these soldiers transferred into civilian life collectively and stayed behind in Shenzhen, becoming an active force in the city's early construction.
