headline: SCMP: Strike Ended By Promise of Payment
text: About 400 workers at a Sichuan paper mill ended a week-long strike yesterday after the buyer of their factory promised to settle overdue compensation payments by the end of this month. ? The pledge by the new owners, a joint Hong Kong and Fujian consortium, came after more than 100 workers from the An County Papermaking Factory staged a protest outside the provincial government office in Chengdu to draw attention to their case. ? Some of the protesters walked the 120km from An county to Chengdu. ? But Zhang Zhouhua, one of the protest leaders, yesterday said he was unconvinced that workers would get their payments, despite management promises. ? "But all of us have returned to work, otherwise we will not get anything," said Mr Zhang. ? Under the terms of the consortium's takeover, the factory's 720 workers were promised 899 yuan for every year they had worked for the old company. ? But no payments had been made two months after the takeover and 400 workers went on strike on October 25. ? Mr Zhang said 30 to 40 police officers and six police cars were deployed to detain workers joining the strike on Tuesday. ? "Police flung them into vehicles, treating them like human freight." ? The workers decided to petition officials after the rough treatment. ? Factory spokesman Deng Yimao yesterday said the compensation had not been paid because they had not received the money from the new owners. ? ? [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: AFP: Chinese Villagers Claim Four Killed When Police Open Fire During Protest
text: BEIJING, Dec 7 (AFP) -- Soldiers in southern China's Guangdong province killed four people when they opened fire on more than 1,000 villagers protesting the construction of a power plant, residents said Wednesday.The clash happened Tuesday evening in Dongzhou village in Shanwei city when hundreds of officers from the People's Armed Police -- a unit of the People's Liberation Army -- were sent in to disperse the villagers, residents told AFP."The People's Armed Police entered the village, they opened fire and shot to death four people," said a villager by telephone."Two died in a local hospital and two were taken to a hospital in Shanwei's urban center, but they died too," he said before his phone appeared to be cut off.A teacher at the Dongzhou Middle School said he did not see the incident because he lived outside the village but learned about it when he arrived at work Wednesday."It's mainly because of land dispute. Compensation was one of the problems," said the teacher, who declined to be named.According to locals interviewed by the US-based Radio Free Asia, the villagers had been demanding the government compensate them fairly for building the power plant, but their requests were denied.Tensions have escalated for many months and came to a head on Tuesday, according to villagers and protesters quoted by Radio Free Asia."They were firing shots. But they were afraid to move in. We had blocked the roads with water pipes, gasoline and detonators," a villager who called RFA late Tuesday said.Another villager Radio Free Asia quoted said "many" villagers had suffered gunshot wounds."I dont know what kind of guns. I just know they were using real bullets on us. No policemen were wounded," the villager said.Radio Free Asia said it had confirmed two people had been killed, and quoted villagers as saying four had died.The villager who spoke to AFP said the government began building the power plant last year.The power plant will be a coal-fired operation that occupies a large amount of land and prohibits villagers from using a nearby lake for raising fishery products and collecting other aquatic products."They didnt get the villagers' permission to take the land. They didn't compensate villagers enough. That was the main reason for the dispute," the villager said."Now we can't even use the lake. We have very little land. We depend on raising fishery products to make a living."When contacted by AFP, Shanwei city police and city government officials said they did not have any knowledge of the incident and declined to comment further. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Chinese Catholic Priests Insist on Property Return in Tianjin Ahead of Christmas
text: BEIJING, Dec 23 (AFP) -- Catholic priests and nuns who lobbied for the return of property seized by Chinese authorities are insisting their demands be met, an official said Thursday, despite reports of attacks against them.An official at the Shanxi provincial religious bureau in northern China said some of the priests who travelled to the northern municipality of Tianjin to lobby for the return of church property stayed there ahead of Christmas."Some of them have returned but some are still there," the official, who gave his name as Ning, told AFP.The Catholic Asia News agency said a group of 48 priests and two nuns went to Tianjin from Shanxi to ask for the return of several western-style buildings which were owned by their diocese before being confiscated by the Communist regime after 1949.Despite a promise to return the properties more than 10 years ago, the government has not handed back the properties, according to the agency.Last Friday, a group of priests and nuns were beaten by 30 people with steel bars, clubs and bricks after they demonstrated in front of Tianjin's city hall, according to the agency.One priest was knocked unconscious, a nun was hospitalised with head injuries, and four other priests were in a bad condition, it said.A spokesman for the government-backed Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association said the priests had returned to Shanxi and mediation between the church and property developers were underway."First, the church's legitimate rights have to be protected. Second, the problem has to be solved legally through dialogue in order to safeguard social stability," Liu Bainian told AFP.But an official at the Tianjin religous affairs administration said the issues had not been resolved and relevant authorities between Tianjin and Shanxi were still discussing how to handle the dispute.Tianjin government officials declined to comment, saying the government had no knowledge of the dispute.The case was reminiscent of a reported conflict in the western city of Xian last month when 16 nuns were apparently beaten while attempting to prevent the demolition of a Catholic school that city authorities had sold to a developer. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Further on Hundreds of Chinese Villagers Clash With Police Over Land Grab
text: BEIJING, Jan 14, 2006 (AFP) - Hundreds of villagers in southern China clashed with police after about 1,000 officers were sent to break up demonstrations against land requisitions, residents told AFP Saturday.Several people were hospitalised after being beaten by regular and military police, a villager said, adding that many more were suffering lesser injuries.Police in Zhongshan city, Guangdong province, confirmed that the protests started on Wednesday but refused to give more details."Yes, it happened. But we are not sure about the number of people involved," a duty officer surnamed Chen told AFP. He declined to comment on whether police had broken up the demonstrations.Various accounts from villagers put the number of protestors between 1,000 and 3,000 at the peak of the demonstrations earlier this week.A villager, who declined to be named, said the numbers quickly dwindled after police armed with batons started beating people."Now people are too scared to go," another villager told AFP. "There are so many police about. They are armed with batons." She said on Friday night there had still been more than 100 people protesting.Villagers had started a sit-in protest outside the Sanjiao township government office over inadequate compensation for farmland forcibly taken from them. When their pleas went unanswered, they started blocking a motorway."That used to be our land, so it was reasonable for villagers to re-occupy their own land," said another villager, who also declined to be named."People are so angry," he said. "People have hardly enough to live on and the local officials have millions (of yuan) in their own accounts."Villagers said the local government had started selling their farmland to companies more than 10 years ago but had given each villager just 400 to 700 yuan (49 to 86 dollars) per year in compensation.They said they had put up with it for years but that the money was not enough to live on with the rapid price rises in China in recent years."How can we live on that in this day and age?" she said. "We are unskilled farmers, we can't find proper jobs."One of the residents said his family used to own three 'mu' of farmland (0.2 hectares), on which they grew sugar cane and vegetables. But the government had sold their land for 100,000 to 200,000 yuan per mu."As a citizen in this society, we have a duty to obey the government, but things are just getting ridiculous," he said. "What choice do we have now?"An elderly villager surnamed Chen told AFP that police had set up road blocks around the village and were barring outsiders from entering.A staff member at the village government told AFP the incident was over."It was just a small argument," he said. "It has already been dealt with."As China's economy continues to race ahead, violent clashes over land requisition have become increasingly common as a result of local officials' frequent collusion with property developers.Farmers who have had their lands confiscated for little or no compensation often have little recourse and their frustrations boil over into violent clashes with the authorities.In the past few months alone, Guangdong province has seen several major cases of unrest.As many as 30 protesters were shot dead by police in a confrontation in Dongzhou village last month, according to villagers.The confrontation stemmed from the local Shanwei city government's refusal to pay villagers adequate compensation for taking their land to build a coal-fired power plant, which will also threaten their income from fishing.In another incident widely regarded as a test case for village democracy, residents of Taishi village, Panyu city, clashed with authorities as they tried to unseat the local village chief whom they accused of illegally selling village land for private gain.The dispute turned violent last summer when police roughed up and detained scores of villagers and activists. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

BEIJING, Jan 15, 2006 (AFP) - Scores of protesters were injured and at least one person was feared dead as hundreds of police in southern China used electric batons to quell a land protest, locals said Sunday.Up to 20,000 people from several villages in Guangdong province's Sanjiao township near Zhongshan city gathered on a highway just after dusk on Saturday to continue protests that had begun earlier in the week."Between 30 to 50 people were injured as police were attacking anyone they saw," one villager named Tan, told AFP. "There is a lot of talk that a 13-year old middle school girl student was killed in the attack."Officials answering phones at the Sanjiao township government and police stations on Sunday refused to comment on the incident."You need to contact the Zhongshan government, so far we cannot say anything," a policeman at the Sanjiao police station said.Officials from Zhongshan government, which administers the region, were unavailable for comment.Tan said villagers had begun demonstrations in the evening to avoid police cameras that earlier in the week had been recording the protests.Another villager confirmed the Saturday night clash, but refused to discuss it in detail out of concerns that the government would retaliate by arresting him."I am afraid I will be arrested if I discuss this," the man said, adding that local officials had imposed a news blackout.Hospitals which on Saturday reported receiving injured protests, refused to comment Sunday.Villagers were protesting compensation for land taken to build a local road leading to the highway, as well as the acquisition of 200 hectares for a Hong Kong developer, Tan said.As China's economy continues to race ahead, violent clashes over land requisition have become increasingly common as a result of local officials' frequent collusion with property developers.Farmers who have had their lands confiscated for little or no compensation often have little recourse and their frustrations boil over into violent clashes with the authorities.In the past few months alone, Guangdong province has witnessed several major cases of unrest. As many as 30 protesters were shot dead by police in a confrontation in Dongzhou village last month, according to residents there. headline: SCMP: Hundreds of Protesters Clash with Armed Shenzhen Police After Vice Raids
text: Hundreds of protesters clashed with armed police outside the Shenzhen government office yesterday after authorities shut down dozens of discos and massage parlours in an attempt to clean up the city's image. The protest was one of the largest in central Shenzhen in recent years. More than 3,000 people - most of them workers at nightclubs and massage parlours - marched to the government office in Futian to voice their anger. The authorities despatched 5,000 armed police, security guards and plain-clothes officers to the scene. The two sides faced off near the government building and the roads had to be closed temporarily. "I saw hundreds of armed police arrive by bus. They surrounded the protesters and told them to disperse. There were some minor clashes and about 10 people were arrested," said a taxi driver who witnessed the protest. He said some of the protesters were stripped down to their underwear by the police. Armoured vehicles were also called in. Police dispersed the crowd after about half an hour. The protesters were put in buses and taken away. The showdown came after the Shenzhen government closed more than 100 discos and nightclubs in the Shazuicun red-light district on Wednesday. The authorities said these premises were operating without proper licences. The city government has launched several anti-vice campaigns over the past two years to try to clean up the area.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: SCMP: Chinese Workers Battle Police in Latest Episode of Growing Social Unrest
text: Hundreds of military police clashed with protesting workers from a bankrupt state-owned arms factory in Chengdu , Sichuan province , last week, leaving at least one in critical condition and many others injured. Two workers approached by the South China Morning Post confirmed the clash, reported on the Boxun website, had occurred.?The incident in Shiling township, Longquanyi district, is the latest in a spate of conflicts between civilians and military police that have taken place against a backdrop of growing social unrest. It also highlights the plight of workers when state-owned enterprises go bankrupt and are privatised. The Boxun report said 1,300 military police entered Shiling and tried to save the factory boss, who was taken hostage by disgruntled employees on Wednesday night. It said the boss was planning to sell the 300 million yuan factory at a discounted 80 million yuan. Government compensation of 200 million yuan for workers to be laid off had also been held up. Sources said the workers were holding the factory boss as a bargaining chip in their negotiations to buy up the facilities and continue operations. The clashes started when thousands of workers prevented military police from rescuing the boss. Over the course of two hours, police surrounded the factory, turned off street lights, blockaded crossroads, and attacked workers and passersby with electric batons. The report said at least one person was left in a critical condition and many other workers were injured. The exact number of victims could not be confirmed. The fate of the boss was not mentioned in the report. Shiling township police yesterday directed inquiries to Chengdu police, saying they had not heard about the incident. The Chengdu police propaganda office could not be reached for comment. The No354 Factory has been operating for about 40 years, employing about 3,000 workers, and providing support such as education and medical benefits to their 8,000 family members. It has been undergoing liquidation since September. Workers wanted to use their government compensation, which was still under negotiation, to buy the factory, one worker said. Last month, a substantial number of workers agreed to pool their payouts to fund the buyback. However, the boss disagreed. Many arms factories have faced a similar fate since former president Jiang Zemin ordered the military in 1998 to surrender its sprawling commercial empire and sever its business ties as part of a crackdown on corruption. Protests from workers over inadequate compensation and back pay following the privatisation of state firms have been rife on the mainland.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: China hunger strikers condemn govt suppression
text: [multiple events] BEIJING, Feb 9, 2006 (AFP) -At least 370 people in China have joined a rolling hunger strike to protest recent attacks by authorities on social activists, a lawyer who initiated the campaign said Thursday.Gao Zhisheng said at least 170 people in Shanghai and 200 in Beijing had been taking turns to stage 24-hour hunger strikes to show their solidarity with the activists."Our aim is to express solidarity with all the citizens who have been oppressed by this obscene regime," Gao told AFP."There has been a series of cases recently in which rights activists have been beaten up by authorities," he said.Gao cited the case of prominent activist Yang Maodong, widely known by his pen name Guo Feixiong, who was allegedly beaten outside a police station in Guangdong province last week as police looked on.Yang was detained by police in Beijing on Wednesday as he attempted to hand in a petition for China's senior leaders at their compound near Tiananmen Square, fellow activists said, adding that he had not been heard from since.Yang's letter had condemned the communist regime's continuous crackdown on activists and scholars who helped farmers protect themselves against forced land requisition, as well as criticising escalating suppression of media freedoms, they said.Up to six other activists who went to support Yang on Wednesday were detained, said Qi Zhiyong, who lost a leg after being shot by a soldier in the bloody Tiananmen crackdown in 1989. He said he was also held for two hours and was taking part in the hunger strike protest.Beijing police refused to comment on the detentions.Other activists supported by the campaign included Chen Guangcheng, who had been under 24-hour surveillance at his home since September after exposing the forced sterilization of women in Shandong province, Gao said.Gao was disbarred late last year after he condemned the government for its persecution on the Falungong spiritual sect, which was banned in 1999."We must do what we can," he said. "Through this, we hope to awaken Chinese people's understanding of this uncivilised regime. We should live like humans, this is a very basic demand and is a very reasonable demand."Gao said the hunger strikers included ordinary citizens staging their protests privately.vy/kma/lod

headline: AFP: Hundreds in Taiyuan Protest Over Beatings in China Land Project
text: BEIJING, Feb 17, 2006 (AFP) - Hundreds of people protested in northern China after hired thugs beat local residents who refused to make way for a real estate project, state press said Friday."Several hundred" residents in Shanxi province's Taiyuan city center began gathering in protest Thursday afternoon after three people were hospitalized from the beatings, the Taiyuan Evening News reported.Police and government officials in Taiyuan refused to comment on the unrest and the exact number of protestors could not be determined."These gangs of youths are coming in bullying residents and people come and throw rocks at windows at night. We really feel scared," one resident was quoted as saying.Police arriving on the scene tried to maintain order, the paper said, but protesters began blocking the police cars and demanded that the hired thugs be arrested.Poorly compensated land requisitions, often backed by local governments in collusion with land developers, have been behind a spike in social unrest throughout China in recent years.The number of "public order disturbances" in China rose by 6.6 percent to 87,000 last year, the government said last month. This compared with just 10,000 such incidents in 1994, according to government figures. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP Told: Chinese Police in Shandong Round Up Villagers for Clashing With Police
text: BEIJING, Feb 23, 2006 (AFP) - Police in eastern China's Shandong province have rounded up more villagers suspected of clashing with police in an ongoing dispute over coercive family planning policies, an activist said Thursday.Up to 10 policemen arrived at the house of Chen Guangjia in Dongshigu village early Thursday, knocked down a wall to his home and forced him into an awaiting police car, leading activist and Chen's cousin, Chen Guangcheng, told AFP.Chen Guangjia had been active in protesting against forced abortions and forced sterilizations by local officials eager to fulfill China's "one child" family planning policies, Chen said."We also think this is part of a crackdown following the February 5 incident when villagers clashed with police," Chen said.The incident erupted after police refused to intervene in the beating of Chen's nephew, Chen Hua, and instead arrested him, he said.This infuriated some 400 villagers who protested in front of local government offices and clashed with police, overturning three police cars.Villagers believe that the thugs were hired by local officials seeking revenge over the family planning accusations, Chen said.Chen Guangcheng, 34 and blind, has himself been under house arrest and repeatedly beaten since September after he brought charges against local officials for the coercive measures.Provincial or central government leaders have refused to intervene in the dispute, even though the coercive practices are illegal.Two other activists who have sought to help Chen in his efforts to protect local rights, were also arrested last week for their alleged involvement in the clash, Chen said.Local police refused to comment on the detentions.The London-based rights group, Amnesty International has protested the action by the authorities and raised concerns that Chen Hua has been beaten or tortured in jail. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Chinese hunger strikers say police closing in as protest spreads
text: BEIJING (AP) - Chinese police are watching and detaining participants in a hunger strike aimed at freeing political prisoners as new volunteers -- maybe hundreds -- emerge to join the protest, according to participants."The police in different cities, including Beijing, are starting a mass hunt for hunger strikers," said Gao Zhisheng, an activist and lawyer in the Chinese capital.The protest is China's most widespread since 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations and is an unusual challenge to the ruling Communist Party, which usually quickly stamps out any public sign of dissent.Police have detained at least a dozen protesters, according to their relatives and other activists. Officials haven't confirmed the existence of a crackdown, or given details of individual cases.Many of the protesters are fasting for a day or two at a time -- some publicizing it on the Internet."It's like the first domino falling," said Zhang Jiankang, a lawyer in the northwestern city of Xi'an, who started a one-day fast Monday."I hope it can bring more conscience to the people in the Communist party, and more freedom and more democracy to China," Zhang said.But authorities are paying attention, Zhang and others in the movement said."Around 11 p.m. last night (Sunday night), three policemen visited my home," Zhang said. "They suggested that I not go on hunger strike, and said they hoped I can tell them of my whereabouts in the future."Phone calls Monday to the press office of the Beijing police headquarters weren't answered.Gao said Sunday that about 70 people in 18 of mainland China's 32 provinces and regions have phoned or e-mailed him and volunteered to join some 900 people already taking part in the protest."Thousands more have offered to join through postings on a number of Internet Web sites," Gao said.Zhang said he's received a lot of encouragement -- mostly from lawyers and college students in his province, Shaanxi -- after announcing his plan to join the movement."They send me text messages through cell phones and call me to show their support," he said.Such a show of boldness could not only trigger a move by China's ever-efficient authorities to silence a noisy problem -- it could spark dangerous anger in a system that's institutionally conscious of saving face.But Gao said the momentum has become so disturbingly strong that he's now urging eager volunteers who are contacting him to back off."We don't want any more innocent people to get involved," he said.Gao, Zhang and a core group of five others have gone so far as to publicize their names.Gao has defended dissidents and practitioners of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group in court. He is known for sending open letters to Chinese leaders criticizing government policies."Even if our human bodies are eliminated, our family members will continue with the hunger strike protest against state tyranny, persecution and state powers behaving like organized crime groups," he said.Chinese activists often complain of being beaten by plainclothes police, or thugs hired by officials.Gao said the hunger strikers would stop if authorities release dissidents sent to labor camps, a practice he said "violates China's constitution and human civilization."However, he said that even if dissidents were released, he and other protesters would start again after six months or a year to protest what he called general police aggression against anyone who shows a hint of public defiance, or even disagreement."The police are becoming more like hoodlums," he said, calling them an expression "of tyranny -- of power with the character of organized crime."

headline: AFP: PRC Police Allegedly Beat Protestors Outside Great Hall of People on 14 Mar
text: BEIJING, March 15, 2006 (AFP) - Police beat and arrested three protestors outside the hall where minutes earlier China's Premier Wen Jiabao had promised to protect citizens' rights, witnesses said Wednesday.The incidents happened minutes after Wen's once-a-year press conference for hundreds of foreign and local journalists held Tuesday at the end of the annual session of parliament at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.In one case, a couple and their two young children who looked like they were from the countryside knelt on the ground and pleaded for justice, said John Taylor, a journalist with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.The couple took off their coats, underneath which they were wearing white clothing with big characters written on them in red, Taylor said. They appeared to be protesting over the illegal seizure of their land."Then he started to wail and sort of kowtow and as soon as he started making noise, the police jumped on the couple," Taylor said.Other foreign reporters at the scene said the couple were then taken away by police.Minutes earlier, an elderly woman was arrested when she tried to hand out leaflets about her grievance to reporters who were leaving the hall after the press conference, said another foreign journalist who witnessed the event."They pushed her on the floor and beat her," said the journalist, who declined to be identified. The woman was then taken away.The leaflets supported late communist chairman Mao Zedong, under whose reign Chinese were at least equally poor, but criticized later leaders Deng Xiaoping and Jiang Zemin, who allowed economic reforms to create a serious wealth gap.About half a dozen foreign journalists, including Taylor, two Spanish reporters and two South China Morning Post correspondents, who filmed the incidents or tried to talk to the petitioners were detained by police for an hour.At the press conference, Wen professed a deep concern for ordinary Chinese citizens who had been marginalized during China's economic reforms, while saying people were free to express themselves."Every citizen in this country has the freedom of speech," Wen said, although he cautioned they still needed to follow the law and work within the "national interests".Hundreds of people who came to Beijing to air their grievances over government injustices were detained during the during the 10-day parliamentary session, activists and rights groups have said. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: 'Hundreds' of Villagers Protest Over Land Rights Near China's Tianjin
text: XIDITOU TOWNSHIP, China, March 16, 2006 (AFP) - Hundreds of villagers near a major northern Chinese city protested Thursday over their seized land, buoyed by Premier Wen Jiabao's remarks this week over their rights."Premier Wen said our rights should be protected -- we feel justified and heartened," said a female protester surnamed Meng from Luxinhe village, about 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the port city of Tianjin."Until they (the local government) talk to us, we will never go away."About 200 people from Luxinhe staged a sit-in protest in front of the Xiditou township government, which governs their village, on Thursday while another 200 protested outside a construction site in the village.One big banner read: "Give us back our land, we want to survive".Meng said the villagers' complaints dated back four years, with frustration over a lack of justice finally leading them to begin protesting at the start of this week.The protests come after Wen on Tuesday criticized local authorities who illegally seized farmers' land and said farmer's rights should be respected."We need to respect the democratic rights of the farmers, especially their right to independently operate their contracted land," Wen said in a nationally televised press conference after the end of the annual parliament session.Across China, farmers' land is often seized by corrupt local government officials and industrialists without adequate compensation, and then converted to either residential or industrial use at great profit.With frustration growing and protests on the rise, authorities have often cracked down brutally on the protestors. In one incident in southern China up to 30 protestors were killed, according to villagers who were at the scene.The number of "public order disturbances" in China rose by 6.6 percent to 87,000 last year, while "mass gatherings that disturbed social order" climbed 13 percent, according to government statistics.Although Wen offered encouragement to farmers on Tuesday, he gave no specifics about how their rights would be protected and avoided a question on whether it was right for authorities to use violence to suppress dissent.In Xiditou township, which is about 120 kilometers (75 miles) southeast of Beijing, the protest scene remained tense with police guarding the gate of the local goverment and closely monitoring movements of protestors.A handful of police vehicles were parked along the main road of Xiditou and villagers were afraid to be seen talking to a reporter. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: SCMP: Beijing Homeowners Up In Arms Over Developer's Three-Year Delay
text: Dozens of Beijing property owners protested yesterday outside the headquarters of a state-owned property developer, demanding the handover of homes they have already paid for. "We want our apartments. Tell us why you have delayed the project," the demonstrators shouted outside the Beijing Uni-Construction Group office. Li Gang , 29, a spokesman for the protesters, said they represented more than 3,000 property owners from the group's Cuicheng Xiaoqu Estate in Chaoyang district. They have yet to receive keys to their apartments even though they paid for the homes in full in 2002 and 2003. The owners were supposed to move into their apartments three years after they paid the money. "We suspect our money has been embezzled because some construction workers at Cuicheng told us the group owed millions of yuan in wages to the workers," Mr Li said. He said the owners had paid more than 3,000 yuan per square metre for their apartments, but none had been completed on schedule and construction had not started on some buildings due to be completed in June. "We have complained to the Beijing municipal government, the municipal construction committee and other government bodies, but none of them dare handle our case. That's why we have come here," Mr Li said. Protests over soured property deals have become a widespread phenomenon in urban areas on the mainland because of a lack of a transparency among developers and limited avenues of recourse for property owners. Protester Chen Jing , 48, said she paid 350,000 yuan for a 108 square metre apartment in 2003. "The contract said I would get my apartment in June this year. But as of yesterday, there was nothing at the site. I am so worried," she said. She had to sell her old apartment to pay for the new one and had spent more than 30,000 yuan renting accommodation for her family while they waited to move into their new home. The demonstration continued for more than an hour yesterday before a group construction manager agreed to meet the protesters. He insisted the company would stick to the construction timetable and all owners would receive the deeds to their properties in 2008. [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: SCMP: 5 Held After Villagers, Police Clash Over Illegal Sluice Gate in Guangdong
text: Mainland police arrested five village leaders from Bomei village in Shantou yesterday after a violent clash between villagers and officers sent to demolish a sluice gate which the government said was illegal.The five people were taken from their homes to a nearby hotel yesterday morning. They did not resist and were well treated by the police, according to one villager.Seven villagers have now been detained for organising the violent protest on Wednesday, in which thousands of villagers clashed with armed police.The villagers pelted the police with stones and Molotov cocktails, and the police returned fire with tear gas. At least six people were injured.Three local officials, including a deputy district director, were abducted by villagers during the chaos on Wednesday and are now being held as hostages near another sluice gate which the authorities have threatened to blow up.The situation was quiet but tense in Bomei village yesterday. Police did not proceed with attempts to destroy the second sluice gate, apparently worried about the hostages' safety.They haven't made any mass arrests and have been polite to those they have taken away, a villager said.On Wednesday, about 5,000 residents of Bomei village, in Shantou's Xilu township, tried to stop police officers who went to demolish two sluice gates the villagers built last year. The government said the sluice gates were illegal and had caused feuds among villagers in the area. The smaller of the two gates was blown up by police.An earlier report by Radio Free Asia quoted a villager as saying the sluice gates were the only source of irrigation in the village, with a population of more than 10,000.Several Hong Kong and overseas reporters were briefly detained yesterday in Shantou for covering the incident.??? headline: AFP: Beijing Residents Protest Construction of Olympic Games Power Plant
text: BEIJING, April 20, 2006 (AFP) - Some 200 angry Chinese citizens have protested the construction of an electricity substation in northern Beijing that is expected to supply power for the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games.The protest occurred on Wednesday at the construction site of the Nannigou Substation which is next to the 2008 Beijing Olympic Village, still under construction."We are protesting against the power plant because it is too close to our residential area," Sun Jintang, one of the protestors, told AFP."We are afraid that the power plant will be harmful to the health of the residents."The closest residential building to the plant is only 10 meters away, he said.Several hundred police were mobilized after the protesters gathered, but no clashes occurred, he said. Police refused to comment.The Beijing News reported that the construction of the plant only began on Wednesday.More than 3,000 residents, many of them retirees from the prestigious China Academy of Sciences, signed a petition last year to protest the construction plan, protestors said.But so far city officials have not responded to their demands, they said."We have asked for public hearings, we have written to the president and prime minister, but the government has not responded," Sun said.The power substation is one of four being built for the Olympic Games. But the other three stations are all being built on the "Olympic Green," a large park that will house several sports venues and the Olympic Village, another protestor said.The head of the country's environmental agency said Wednesday that environmental problems are threatening social stability as aggrieved residents increasingly resort to protests to make their voices heard.Pollution prompted at least 510,000 public disputes last year while protests related to environmental problems have been rising at an average rate of 29 percent a year, Xinhua news agency quoted Zhou Shengxian as saying. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: SCMP: Victory for Villagers in Battle Over 'Rigged Poll' for Chief
text: Complaints about a rigged election for a village head have prompted authorities in the Tianjin county of Ninghe to scrap the results and hold another poll in the next three months. More than 200 villagers from Zhaowenmin protested outside the Ninghe county government office on Saturday, alleging Friday's election was marred by intimidation, false ballot papers and attempts to buy votes. County authorities appointed officials to investigate the matter and, after finding fraudulent voting slips, ordered on Sunday that a new election be held. Their decision was seen by some as support for the villagers' demands for "a clean election" and "returning farmland", but some village representatives were concerned the new election would also be rigged. Farmers' representative Huo Changsong, 34, said even though more than 600 local residents had not voted in the election, the village committee had found a regulatory loophole to ratify the poll results. "In order to achieve enough ballots, our current village party head, Feng Hesong, mobilised 200 locals to force villagers to hand over their ballot papers," he said. Mr Huo said the 600 villagers who abstained from voting did so because they had heard that at least a quarter of the ballot papers had been "entrusted" to others. Other residents said the party chief's agents duped, threatened and bribed them to vote for the preferred candidate. Fu Heming, 54, said one Mr Feng's men offered her 800 yuan for her family's four ballot papers. "First of all, a gangster told me to vote for Huo Lisong , who is Feng's man. Then he offered me 800 yuan after I refused to promise him anything," she said. When Ms Fu rejected the money, she was threatened by Huo Lisong's 70-something mother, Shang Chunjiang . "She threatened to destroy my two electric welding stalls if I did not to vote for her son. That's why I did not vote," she said. Wang Shuyun, 50, said she refused to vote because she found so many ballots had been handed over to proxies. "They are so ignorant. You could find signatures in exactly the same handwriting among the ballot papers," Ms Wang said. "Why would I vote in such a dishonest poll?" Liu Tairong, a 60-year-old party member, said she also refused to vote because the rights to 125 hectares of farmland were sold to industrial enterprises during Mr Feng's two terms in office, but the community had not benefited from the transaction. "None of the villagers has ever been given one fen from it," she said. "We knew something was wrong when we found about 40,000 cubic metres of soil had been dug out and sold to an industrial site in January." Zhang Zhichao, another of the farmers' representatives, said construction workers told them 2.5 yuan was paid for each cubic metre of soil. "It's a waste," Mr Zhang said. "The soil is very rich and suitable for farming because it used to be a fish farm. The clay has more than 17 years' of fish manure in it." Mr Feng is under investigation for embezzling community funds so could not stand for re-election. The protesters said they were backing 61-year-old Huo Shenglin in the next poll, in the hope that he would fight for their land and soil. But they were also concerned that Mr Feng could still influence the result because he was still the village's party chief. The situation is similar to that in Guangdong's Taishi village, where residents were repeatedly thwarted in their attempts to dismiss their village head. Outspoken human rights lawyer Gao Zhisheng was not optimistic about the prospects for the Zhaowenmin villagers' struggle for democracy. "They technically just won the first round, but it was an exceptional case. "Villagers in Zhaowenmin are lucky because their county authority is willing to handle their complaint. But I don't think it is a common phenomena on the mainland," Mr Gao said. He said villagers would succeed in enforcing their rights only when the central government decided to improve the political system.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. Root URL on filing date: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Protesters block construction projects in S. China: report
text: [multiple events] Protesters from a dozen villages in the city of Shantou in southern China's Guangdong Province are protesting over land compensation at several construction sites, Hong Kong's Ming Pao daily reported Wednesday.The civil unrest has lasted for months as villagers are seeking to have compensation agreements with developers revised amid soaring land prices, according to the report.The Chinese-language newspaper said the local police were reluctant to use force against the people after what happened in nearby Shanwei city last year.Police from Dongzhou village in Shanwei opened fire at hundreds of protesters who blockaded a power plant over a land claim dispute in December, killing at least three protesters.In the latest unrest, hundreds of protesters have occupied a housing construction site in the city's Chenghai district, attacking security guards and employees at the site and clashing with police, the report said, adding that at least one police officer was injured and possibly killed.In nearby Batou township, protesters forced a wood-processing plant to stop running.The Shantou Public Security Bureau said it has not heard of such incidents.

headline: Violences dans une universit? chinoise
text: China. Thousands of students have been protesting since several days in Zhengzhou, in the center of the country, according to testimonies gathered by the AFP. A large part of them continued yesterday a sit-in in front of the administrative headquarters of the University, under the supervision of several hundreds of policemen. The dissatisfaction with the direction of the university seems to have been the spark. The students have left explode their anger last week after having learned that their diploma would more than the seal of the University of Zhengzhou, but that of a connected least prestigious of the institution. The violence occurred on Thursday evening with the ransacking of dormitories. The students threw the furniture by the front windows to spread in the city and to take to of storefronts and cars. Several demonstrators would have then been beaten by the police.The riots are not rare in China and the discontent university is a sensitive subject, especially since the bloody suppression of Tiananmen Square, in the spring 1989 in Beijing. The continuation of student protests for several days in Zhengzhou could testify to the embarrassment of the authorities and police of a leniency which rarely benefit the protests laborers or peasant.

headline: AFP: 10,000 Tricycle Riders Protest in Xian; 'Bigger Protest' Planned for 28 Jun
text: BEIJING, June 27, 2006 (AFP) -- More than 10,000 disgruntled tricycle operators have staged a protest in China's northern city of Xian demanding the right to ply their trade, demonstrators said Tuesday.They demonstrated Monday outside the city government offices against an order banning up to 30,000 three-wheelers from the streets of the ancient Chinese capital to ease traffic problems."The police arrested five of our elected representatives but this only hardened our resolve," one protester surnamed Zheng told AFP by phone."We are planning a bigger protest on July 28. We have sent out leaflets and we have been organizing citywide, but today our five representatives were released and they are passing on the government's request that we call off the protest."Zheng and others insisted that Thursday's protest would go ahead regardless. Government officials and police were not immediate available for comment.Some of the three-wheelers are used as taxis, others to carry goods.According to another protester surnamed Gui, several thousands turned up again at the offices of the city government on Tuesday, demanding the scrapping of the ban that is due to be implemented on July 5."We believe that there are up to 30,000 three-wheeled vehicles in Xian so this means that they are going to put 30,000 people out of work," Gui said."Most of us are unemployed or have been laid off from other jobs. Others are elderly guys trying to make some extra money."Slogans during the protests included "We don't steal, we don't rob, we don't fight, so why is our livelihood against the law?"Other banners read "Pitiful government, miserable unemployed, we must eat."Protesters said the government had ordered a media blackout and city television stations and newspapers were not reporting the unrest.They said there were no clashes with some 400 police on Monday."The government is now saying that they will begin registering the bike drivers to see how many are unemployed, how many are farmers and how many are migrant workers," Zheng said."They said they will give us a new plan on the ban in a month's time, but as of July 5 all three-wheeled bikes will be banned." [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Rally Staged for Chinese Activist Who Exposed Government Abuse; Trial Postponed
text: BEIJING, July 20, 2006 (AFP) - Around 200 supporters of a blind Chinese rights activist rallied outside a court where he was due to be tried Thursday, with 11 detained briefly after scuffling with police, participants told AFP.The trial of Chen Guangcheng, detained for nearly a year after exposing local authorities' use of abortions and sterilizations under China's one-child policy, was listed for Thursday but his lawyer said it had been postponed.Eleven activists who traveled from Beijing to the eastern province of Shandong to support Chen were detained after scuffling with men they said were plain-clothes policemen, one of the activists said.Veteran rights activist Zhao Xin said he and 10 others all wore T-shirts printed with Chen's picture and a slogan saying: "Free blind activist Chen Guangcheng." Each also held a copy of China's constitution.The eleven included rights lawyer Gao Zhisheng and dissidents Li Hai, Liu Jingsheng and Ma Wendu."We are exercising our civil rights through non-violent means," Zhao told AFP by phone, with he and another activist saying there were around 200 supporters in total at the courthouse in Yinan county.Zhao later briefly called back to say he and the 10 other activists from Beijing had been taken away in police vehicles.Beijing-based activist Hu Jia, who has been under house arrest since Tuesday to bar him from traveling to support Chen, said the activists were released a few hours later after being interrogated.Zhao suffered from a broken nose and Gao's arm was sprained during the morning's unrest, Hu said, adding that the plain-clothes police had taken their money, cameras and a laptop computer.Zhao was not reachable on the phone on Thursday afternoon. Local police declined to comment.Chen's lawyer Li Jinsong said the judge at Yinan county court told him the trial was postponed because prosecution authorities needed to gather more evidence. The trial had already been postponed from Monday.An officer at the court confirmed the postponement to AFP, saying more investigation was needed, but declined to give a new date.Chen, 34, known as a "barefoot lawyer" because he is self-educated, ran into trouble last year after exposing local authorities' abuse of the nation's population law which aims to ensure parents only have one child.He accused authorities in Linyi city, Yinan county, of forcing women to be sterilized and have abortions as late as eight months into their pregnancy, measures outlawed by the central government.Chen was placed under house arrest in September last year.He was officially arrested in March after about 400 people from his home village of Dongshigu protested against the treatment of him and his family, leading to clashes with police in which several people were slightly injured.Chen was charged last month with "willfully harming public property" and "gathering masses to disturb traffic order."Although the charges are not directly related to his expose of the Linyi city officials' one-child actions, international human rights groups and Chinese activists have said the legal maneuvers are aimed at silencing him.More than 100 Chinese intellectuals and dissidents signed an open letter to the government last month urging Chen's release.Rights groups such as Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch have also protested Chen's detention and raised concerns over reports that he had been beaten in jail."When Chen tried to make proper use of Chinas legal system, the response wasnt due process," Sophie Richardson, deputy director of Human Rights Watch's Asia division, said in a statement."It was house arrest, physical abuse and then disappearance by local authorities. His case is a textbook example of how little the rule of law really means in China." [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: China sentences eight to prison for fight over unauthorized church
text: BEIJING (AP) - Eight Chinese Christians have been sentenced to prison on charges that they led a crowd that fought with police in a failed attempt to stop the demolition of an unauthorized church, a government news agency reported.The sentence was handed down Saturday by a court in the eastern city of Hangzhou, where the clash occurred July 29 over a house built for use as a church, the Xinhua News Agency said.About 20 people were injured in the clash between 500 officers and 3,000 protesters in Xiaoshan district, human rights groups said earlier. It appeared to be one of the largest recent confrontations between police and members of an underground Chinese church.Shen Zhuke, convicted of being the principal perpetrator, was sentenced to 3 1/2 years in prison, while Ni Weimin and Feng Guangliang received two years and Luo Bingliang one year, Xinhua said.At least 10 government employees were injured, Xinhua said in the report late Saturday.The communist government allows worship only in churches, mosques and temples run by state-monitored religious groups.Members of the country's numerous underground religious groups are frequently jailed and harassed.The demolition in Hangzhou, southwest of Shanghai, followed orders from provincial authorities that month to crack down on "illegal religious buildings," according to the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy.

headline: AFP: China Arrests Roman Cathoic Bishop And Priest
text: BEIJING, Aug 3, 2006 (AFP) - A bishop and a priest from China's underground Catholic church have been arrested and dozens of other Catholics were detained after they protested the police action, a US-based rights group said Thursday.Yao Liang, 82, the auxiliary bishop of Xiwanzi diocese in the northern province of Hebei, was arrested last Sunday for the second time in 18 months, according to the Cardinal Kung Foundation.The group said it was unaware of the reason for Yao's arrest but he had also been taken into police custody in March last year.Li Huisheng, a 33-year-old priest from Yao's diocese, was arrested Tuesday and his whereabouts were still unknown, the group said.The local underground Catholic community protested their arrests and 500 police were mobilized early Wednesday, detaining about 90 protesters, it said.Around 70 of them have since been released while the rest were still under police detention, the group said, adding that two men were seriously injured and a pregnant woman had a miscarriage during the police action.A staff member surnamed Tan at Zhangbei county's public security bureau declined to comment Thursday, saying it was a confidential matter.Hebei province's ethnic and religious affairs bureau also refused to confirm the report."I have not heard of this, but if they are illegal the public security bureau would intervene," a staff member surnamed Yang told AFP.Catholic Christians are officially only allowed to worship in the state-sanctioned churches. Beijing insists on having a say in appointing bishops -- a condition that is unacceptable to the Holy See and many Chinese worshippers.Many of the leaders of these churches have been arrested and jailed, while the churches have also been regularly raided and shut down.Relations between China and the Vatican have been even tenser than usual in recent months after Beijing appointed a number of bishops without the Holy See's approval. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: SCMP: 'Shareholders Demand Action on Court Ruling'
text: About 500 shareholders in a Shenzhen investment company surrounded the local People's Intermediate Court yesterday, accusing the authorities of failing to carry out a court order against another firm which owes them more than 10 million yuan.The angry crowd - all shareholders in Shenzhen Shangsha Investment Co - blocked the front doors of the court at 8am, staging a sit-in protest and demanding to see the chief judge. All morning cases had to be postponed. The authorities mobilised hundreds of police to keep the crowd under control. Judges and court staff had to be escorted into the building by police. The crowd dispersed peacefully at about noon after their representatives reached an agreement with the authorities. Nobody was injured or arrested.Shangsha Investment rented a building to local furniture maker Oriental Fortune in 1996, but it has not paid any rent since 1999 and refuses to move out.The company sued the furniture maker two years ago and won the case. But local authorities failed to carry out the judge's order, saying they could not contact the person in charge of Oriental Fortune.Shangsha Investment tried to take back the building by force in March. But the furniture company again refused to leave and hired alleged triad members to guard the site. The two sides began fighting and had to be separated by police. "The police only arrested some of our people but did not touch the other side. It's obvious they have got some powerful connections," one shareholder said.The shareholders said yesterday Oriental Fortune owed them nearly 12 million yuan in unpaid rent. They demanded that the company hand back their property in compliance with the court order.The Shenzhen court agreed to look into the case yesterday. Oriental Fortune's general manager could not be reached for comment. Shangsha Investment was set up by residents of Shangshacun, one of the original villages in Shenzhen. The residents, mostly farmers, rezoned their farmland for commercial use after Shenzhen was made a special economic zone 25 years ago. All villagers became shareholders. Shenzhen's justice system has long been criticised. Many court orders cannot be carried out because of corruption, a lack of efficiency or intervention from the government.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. Root URL on filing date: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Man killed after row over half yuan Villagers storm office of power firm with body
text: More than 1,000 angry Sichuan villagers have stormed a power company's office carrying the body of a neighbour believed to have been beaten to death after a dispute with a company clerk over half a yuan, local media reported.Carrying funeral wreaths, the villagers from Hesheng village in Chengdu's Wenjiang district laid the body of 43-year-old Ye Yongqiang in the company's foyer on Sunday, and demanded that clerk Zhang Zhiqun be held responsible for Ye's death, the Tianfu Morning Paper reported.According to the report, Ye went to the office on Sunday morning with his nephew's wife, Hu Yongfen , to pay an electricity bill. Ms Hu and Ms Zhang started arguing over change of 50 fen, but Ye broke up the fight and returned home with Ms Hu.At about noon, six men and a woman arrived at the village by van and attacked Ye as he fled to a neighbour's yard. During the attack, one of the men made a reference to the argument, telling Ye he had no business intervening in the dispute, the report said.Ye died before emergency medical workers arrived to take him to hospital. Villagers took his body in a blood-soaked sheet to the company's office, tore a picture of Ms Zhang off the wall and placed the photograph on the corpse.An employee who answered the office phone yesterday said company officials had not taken any action over the incident and nobody had been assigned to deal with it.The employee said Ms Zhang was arrested by police on Sunday, but a political officer from the Wenjiang police station denied she had been arrested."[Ms Zhang] has not been arrested because the event is still under investigation. The media reports only contain the allegations of one side. No arrests will be made before the whole process is clear," the political officer said.He had no idea when details of the incident would be clarified.The political officer said Ye's body was removed from the power company's building after the Wenjiang district government negotiated with Ye's relatives. The body would not be buried before a conclusion was reached because it was needed for evidence.

headline: Xinhua: Two-Day Gathering Over Cancelled Satellite Class Ends at Fudan University
text: Shanghai, Sept. 4 (Xinhua) -- Students and their parents began to leave the gate of Chinese elite Fudan University in Shanghai on Monday after they gathered here Saturday and Sunday since the university cancelled an off-campus study program.More than 100 students and their parents protested at the university's gate after it announced on Friday the cancellation of the program, which was jointly managed by the university and a private supplementary school in the city's Yangpu District.The university said it decided to cancel the program after it had received reports of irregularities in recruitment and teaching.It promised to enroll the students who wanted to continue to study at the university, said the university.By Monday afternoon, half of the 739 students in the cancelled program had received a refund of their tuition from the university, but some of them still registered with the university.The gathering of students and their parents also disrupted the campus, said the university.The incident was caused by some teachers at the university who had carried out irregular recruitment in the name of the university, according to the university. [Description of Source: Beijing Xinhua in English -- China's official news service for English-language audiences (New China News Agency)]

headline: Thousands protest probe into teacher's death in China: report
text: HONG KONG, Sept. 8 -- Thousands of people, including high-school students, protested against what they claim was a botched investigation into a teacher's apparent suicide in eastern China's Zhejiang Province, Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao reported Friday.The protesters rejected the conclusion that Dai Haijing, 30, had fallen off from her residence on fifth floor to her death in August.Many believed Dai's husband, a prominent businessman surnamed Xie, was involved in her death, the paper said.It said the protest turned into a riot when police tried to disperse the protesters.The protesters accused the government of colluding with Xie and ''mishandling human lives,'' petitioning the government to reinvestigate Dai's death.Police clashed with protesters on Wednesday, firing tear gas, dispersing the crowd with batons and arresting at least dozen people.Thousands regrouped Thursday and gathered at the government office, the report said.Hundreds of riot police stood by but did not take strong action.The protesters then went to Xie's factory where property was said damaged.The province's state-run news website said Friday that the investigation concluded Dai was unlikely to have been pushed from her residence. It also concluded that while a bruise on her thigh was made before her death, other bruises were likely caused by the plunge and that she was alive before the fall.Other media revealed in August the contents of Dai's diary in which she said Xie had physically abused her and that she was suffering from depression.Government officials in Ruian where the school is located could not be reached for comment.==Kyodo

headline: AFP: Guangdong Villagers Injured in Clash With Police Over Land Requisition, Elections
text: BEIJING, Sept 14, 2006 (AFP) - Several thousand angry villagers in southern China clashed with police during protests over local land requisitions and village elections, police and reports said Thursday.Up to 17 people were injured when around two thousand villagers in Guangdong province clashed with police in front of the Shadui township government offices on Tuesday, Hong Kong's Apple Daily reported."There's was such a clash between villagers and police, it happened the day before yesterday (Tuesday)," a policeman in Shadui township told AFP by phone."I can't tell you more because we have not got enough imformation about it. We are discussing ... [ellipsis as received] we will issue a statement."Villagers were upset that local officals banned some villagers from voting in local elections, the paper said.The ban was implemented after the villagers had protested government compensation for farmlands taken over for development in the township.Over 300 police were dispatched to quell the crowd when the clashes occurred, it said.Land confiscation by local officials has become one of the fiercest social issues facing Chinese society as ordinary people accuse officials of colluding with developers to enrich themselves in lucrative land deals.In China, all land belongs to the state, giving local leaders tremendous power over land use rights.Although China's economy has boomed for nearly 25 years, a widening gap between rich and poor has played a leading role in growing social unrest nation wide.The number of "public order disturbances" throughout China rose by 6.6 percent to 87,000 last year, according to official statistics. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: AFP: Chinese Students Smash Police Car During Protests at College in Lanzhou
text: BEIJING, Sept 14, 2006 (AFP) - University students hurled bricks and bottles at a police car during protests in northwest China after a student was beaten up in a dispute over hot water, officials said Thursday.The incident -- the latest in a spate of campus unrest -- occurred Tuesday when a female student tried to fetch hot water in a dormitory of Lanzhou Commerce Studies College, according to university and police officials.The student wanted to avoid paying 0.10 yuan (1.25 US cent) to fill a thermos of hot water and tried to fill a smaller bottle instead, but a dormitory worker insisted she pay, a dormitory manager told AFP.The worker grabbed the student and hit her before a colleague pushed her to the ground, prompting other students to call the police.When police arrived, hundreds of students gathered to demand police investigate the case at the scene instead of taking the student to the police station.Police did not immediately agree and students hurled bricks and bottles at a police vehicle, smashing the windows.The incident ended five hours later when university officials intervened, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.The dormitory manager said around 200 students were involved, with only 10 smashing the car. The center said 5,000 students were involved."It wasn't a small incident. [ellipses as received] ... The students were very emotional. The workers were not cooperative," said a local police officer.No one was arrested, university administrators said.They blamed the sub-contracted dormitory, which has had a long-running dispute with students over fees, for the incident.Dormitory staff have beaten students and locked them out when they could not prove they had paid their fees, the Western Economic Daily reported last month.But the dormitory manager blamed the incident on the students' frustrations over job prospects."The students' moods are bad lately because it's hard to find jobs. This is one of the reasons for the incident," she said.In June students at a college in central China's Henan province rioted over being misled about which college that would award them their diplomas.The same month, students in southwest China's Sichuan province hurled bottles after school authorities cut electricity during a World Cup football match. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Protesters clash with Chinese police in Shenzhen
text: BEIJING, Oct 21 (Reuters) - Five hundred property owners in China's booming southern city of Shenzhen clashed with police during protests over government plans to build a highway, a Hong Kong newspaper said on Saturday.Residents of a housing estate in Shenzhen staged a sit-in protest on one of the city's busiest streets on Friday after government officials refused to talk to them earlier outside a "citizens' centre", the South China Morning Post said."We are all agitated and surprised," the paper quoted Tang Tang, a protest leader, as saying."We were informed of this construction project at the end of September. There haven't been any hearings for residents about whether they will be inconvenienced," she said.At least 10 people were arrested in clashes with police, but were later released after residents agreed to disperse. At least two people were injured, the paper said.

headline: SCMP: Guangdong Police Clash With Villagers Holding 'Corrupt' Officials
text: Thousands of villagers in Shunde, Guangdong , yesterday clashed with riot police who came to rescue officials trapped inside a warehouse by the protesters.Residents of Sanzhou village, who have been protesting for months against alleged land grabs and corruption by local authorities, suddenly surrounded the warehouse on Wednesday while dozens of government officials and foreign guests were holding an inauguration ceremony for the building.Hundreds blockaded the entrance with debris, stones and wooden boards. They said the warehouse was built on land that had been seized by the local government and sold to the developer.The villagers initially refused to let the officials and dozens of guests from Thailand, Germany, Britain and Hong Kong leave. They demanded the officials investigate the deal and punish corrupt village chiefs, according to one villager. Later they let the guests leave but still held a few local government officials hostage.About 1,000 riot police arrived at 10am yesterday and tried to disperse the crowd with tear gas, the villager said. They eventually managed to escort the officials out of the building.But protesters refused to leave and continued to clash with the police. It was not clear last night if any arrests had been made. "There are about 4,000 to 5,000 people this morning. We have been protesting against corruption for many months and we are very determined," the villager said.Yesterday's episode was one of the many incidents of rural unrest in the area recently. Shunde, an industrialised district under the administration of Foshan, has been plagued with corruption scandals and social unrest for months. It was originally a rural town but incorporated into Foshan a few years ago and underwent rapid industrialisation.Most of its farmland has been industrialised or converted for commercial use. But villagers say they have gained little from the development, with local officials teaming up with businessmen to illegally seize their land.Protests against alleged corruption had been reported in villages like Sanzhou, Xiashi, Xinmin and Xiyong in recent weeks.Tensions escalated after last year's village election - the only form of direct election allowed on the mainland - a village representative said. Many village chiefs appointed by local officials lost their seats to independent candidates sworn to weed out corruption. But the old guard refused to relinquish their power and clashed with the newly elected village officials.The standoff had erupted into violent clashes in recent weeks, a villager said. Scores of scuffles had broken out since last month."They hired thugs and brought their people to the village office. They kicked out the newly elected officials and refused to let us check their account books. We have tried to complain but the higher authorities have just ignored us," a village representative said.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: Police and demonstrators square off in Beijing over crackdown on dogs
text: BEIJING (AP) - Demonstrators angry over a crackdown on dogs staged a noisy protest in China's capital Saturday, decrying police killings of dogs and new limits on pet ownership.About 200 police strung up tape to cordon off the roughly 500 demonstrators -- many wearing buttons that said "Stop the indiscriminate killing" -- as they held up stuffed animals, waved signs and chanted near the entrance to the Beijing Zoo.Police detained at least 18 demonstrators in nearby vans for several hours before releasing them, protesters said. Police declined comment.Touching off the demonstration was new restrictions that limit households to one dog and ban larger breeds. Police in recent days have gone through city neighborhoods, seizing unregistered dogs and beating some of them to death, witnesses said."All of us who have dogs to walk are feeling very anxious," said Wu Jiang, a protester and pet shop owner who keeps a yellow Labrador retriever. "Most of us only dare come out at night and even then we have to be really careful."Keeping pets has evoked controversy in China for decades. Banned as a middle-class habit in the radical Cultural Revolution in the 1960s and '70s, dog-raising surged anew afterward with the introduction of free-market reforms.Complaints about vicious dogs, barking and excrement-covered sidewalks prompted Beijing to impose height limits in 1995, banning dogs taller than 35 centimeters (14 inches) from the city center. Many cities have enacted similar measures.A sharp rise in rabies cases this year led to a renewed clampdown across China. State-run newspapers reported Saturday that 326 people died from rabies in October, again making it the leading cause of death among infectious diseases.To enforce the crackdown, police in many parts of the country have beaten stray or unregistered dogs to death, sometimes in front of their owners.Beijing responded by raising fines for having unregistered and unvaccinated dogs, adopting the new one-dog-per-family rule and extending the ban on larger dogs from the city center to encompass the surrounding suburbs."We're asking city residents to go along with us and if they discover any unregistered or stray dogs to report to us by phone," the Beijing News quoted the city's vice director of agriculture, Ren Zonggang, as saying in comments on the government's Web site.In some cases, protesters said, dog-owners have been given as little as one week's notice to get rid of their large dogs or move to outlying districts. Protesters said the measures are not only inhumane but incorrectly place the burden of punishment on the dogs, not the owners."The main point here should be the way dog owners raise their dogs," said Jeff He of the International Fund for Animal Welfare in Beijing, who watched the protest from beyond the cordon of yellow and black police tape.Organizers of the protest said they had applied for a permit but had been refused. Though the demonstration was largely peaceful, anti-riot squads in helmets and dark uniforms were dispatched, plainclothes police milled through the crowds and large numbers of uniformed police sat in trucks down the street.Police tried to prevent reporters from taking pictures and warned protesters that they could suffer serious consequences for their actions."It was like martial law out there," said Wu Jiang, the pet shop owner. "We said to them 'We're taxpayers. Why are you treating us this way?'"Police used loudspeakers on a nearby van to urge protesters to take their complaints to a special desk set up inside the zoo. Nine representatives of the protesters were taken inside the zoo to discuss the protest with police, protesters said.

However, major newspapers in Beijing did not mention the protest yesterday.? Related articles posted at online pet forums had also been deleted. No dogs taller than 35 cm are allowed to be kept in the municipality.? Furthermore, each household is allowed to keep only one dog. The policy irked dog owners.? Quite a number of them had been making online contacts in recent days and asking each other to meet at the entrance of the Beijing Zoo to stage a protest at 1100 local time the day before yesterday [ 11 November], so as to demand for Beijing's authoritative department to "stop the killing of dogs." Beijing's public security department determined that the protest was an illegal assembly.? Several hundred public security officers already stood guard at the site and successively brought away numerous people, including many reporters.? As of 1515 on 11 November, heavy police manpower had dispersed the assembled crowds at the site. The protest was a large-scale mass protest rarely seen in Beijing, and it caught the attention of international media generally.? The Associated Press, Reuters, and BBC reported on the event.? headline: AFP: 2,000 Protest at Chinese Hospital Over Deaths of Child Patients
text: BEIJING, Nov 12, 2006 (AFP) - About 2,000 people protested outside a hospital in southwestern China over recent deaths of child patients and high fees before police forcibly broke up the gathering, a human rights group said.The public outburst on Friday was triggered by the death of a three-year-old boy after he was admitted to a hospital in Guangan city in Sichuan province on November 7, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said in a statement.It gave no further details on why the boy was sent to hospital.Local residents demonstrated over his sudden death, past incidents at the Guangan Second Hospital -- including the recent deaths of two other children -- and high hospital fees, the group said.Armed police broke up the demonstration, injuring ten participants and taking five people away, it said. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]
