headline: AFP Told: Dozens Injured in Clash With Police in Shandong Province Over Land Row
text: BEIJING, Nov 15, 2006 (AFP) - Dozens of villagers were injured when police cracked down on a protest staged by around 1,000 people in eastern China over confiscated farmland, witnesses said Wednesday.Residents at Zhangzhuang village in Shandong province demonstrated earlier this month at a construction site where new buildings were being erected to house them after their land was requisitioned by officials, they said.Villagers said the buildings were made of shoddy materials and cracks were already appearing in the walls.The dispute erupted 10 days ago after two villagers were arrested on charges of disrupting public order after they detained a local village official, demanding that he give an explanation.Anti-riot police used dogs to break up the protest and beat up demonstrators, they said."They sent in large numbers of police vehicles and many dogs, they were beating people up and people were bleeding," a resident who requested anonymity told AFP.She said 18 people had been hospitalized, although dozens were hurt during the clash. Six people have been arrested, and police were still hunting down protest leaders."Many people have gone into hiding and daren't go out because of that," she said.The resident said villagers were very upset because they had been barred from visiting their injured relatives in hospitals.Another local resident, a woman farmer surnamed Zhang, also confirmed the incident."The police descended on the protest with lots of dogs," he said in a telephone interview."After we lost our land, we have also lost our livelihood, we have nothing to farm on anymore," she said.Police at Zhangzhuang village refused to comment Wednesday.As China's economy continues to race ahead, violent clashes over land requisitions have become increasingly common as a result of local officials' frequent collusion with property developers.Chinese authorities are sensitive to signs of social unrest and often mobilize large numbers of police to break up protests.Police on Monday surrounded a hospital in a southwestern city after 2,000 people protested over the death of a child who was allegedly refused medical treatment. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: Pair suspended over death of teen waitress Action against officials said to be unrelated to mass protest
text: A county party secretary and a police chief in Sichuan have been suspended after hundreds of sympathisers and family members protested over the government's mishandling of the death of an underage hotel waitress.Wang Wei , Communist Party chief of Dazhu county, and Lai Jinsong , head of the county's Public Security Bureau, have been suspended from duty and ordered to undergo "self-criticism" over the mishandling of the death of Yang Daili , a 16-year-old waitress at Nest Business Hotel, on December 30, a county police officer said yesterday.He said Xu Feng , the hotel's legal representative, was also under investigation.According to residents of Dazhu county, news of the suspensions was announced on Saturday night on local television and came after hundreds of protesters - some accounts put the figure at more than 2,000 - gathered outside the county government offices that afternoon.But the police officer, who declined to be identified, denied the decision to suspend the two officials was related to the protest."The disciplinary committee [of the party] had already made the decision, but we were not obliged to announce it," the officer said, adding that only several hundred people "gathered peacefully" outside the government offices."There was no confrontation during the gathering. Nobody was injured and no property damaged. The gathering was very peaceful and the crowd left after 7pm," the officer said.He added that authorities had not mobilised riot police even though several roads near the government buildings had been blocked during the protest.Yang, who had been working at the hotel for less than a month, was allegedly gang raped after drinking spiked wine while entertaining three clients. She died later in hospital. Her classmates and family members, who have been gathering outside the hotel daily since January 12 demanding a quick investigation into her death, have drawn a crowd of sympathisers.The crowd grew to more than 4,000 on Wednesday, when the hotel put up a notice saying it was not linked to, or responsible for, Yang's death, triggering a riot in which the hotel was almost burned down.That night, breaking the silence they had maintained since Yang's death, local authorities announced that a hotel bartender and a police station director, who was involved in the hotel's operations, were being investigated.News reports said top leaders in Sichuan province had ordered a quick investigation into the case while stressing that any conflicts should not be intensified.Beijing recently issued a directive demanding that local police chiefs carefully handle social unrest, warning that they would face disciplinary action or lose their jobs if "mass incidents" - a euphemism used by officials for protests, riots and mass petitions - resulted in serious consequences.

headline: Police Restore Order in Hunan Province After Riots
text: BEIJING, Mar. 13 -- An estimated 20,000 people clashed with police in Hunan Province late last week, as a protest over rising transportation costs escalated into a riot, witnesses and overseas news reports said.On Monday, truckloads of armed police officers descended on an area of rural Hunan near the village of Zhushan to restore order. Some witness accounts on an overseas Chinese Web site, Boxun claimed that demonstrators refused to leave government offices in the area and that anti-riot police had used force to remove them.Several protesters and police officers were injured, Reuters reported. The South China Morning Post reported that one protester had been killed in a skirmish.Mainland Chinese news media did not carry reports about the unrest, which occurred during the annual two-week session of the Communist Party's legislative body.The protests were said to have been set off by concern about the inflated prices charged for public transportation during the Lunar New Year holiday in February.The government has taken a series of steps to improve conditions for peasants and migrant workers in recent years, and officials have claimed that incidents of rural unrest declined in 2006.But they acknowledge that discontent remains widespread and that China's rapid growth has not done enough to lift living standards for peasants and migrant workers.
notes_human: bus fare hike protested

headline: AFP Told: PRC Arrests Over 2,000 'Petitioners' as Part of Crackdown During NPC
text: BEIJING, March 14, 2007 (AFP) - Chinese police are using the annual meeting of parliament to crackdown on a wide range of dissent in what could be a dress rehearsal for the Beijing Olympics, activists and rights groups said Wednesday.The crackdown during the 12-day National People's Congress that ends Friday has resulted in the arrests of more than 2,000 petitioners and the surveillance and house arrests of dozens of activists, they said."I'm pretty sure that they have rounded up more than 2,000 petitioners this year," said Liu Anjun, a Beijing petitioner-turned-rights activist who is under house arrest told AFP by phone."The crackdown is much more severe than last year."According to China Rights Defenders, a group that organises through the Internet, "several thousand" people seeking to petition the government through official channels were arrested during the first week of parliament."Many Beijing rights defenders and democracy activists have been taken outside the city, placed under house arrest, are being followed or are being stopped from contacting others," the group said in a statement."The cleanup of the city is likely a dress rehearsal for ... the Olympic Games."Other dissidents and activists told AFP they were being followed and had been warned by police against causing trouble during the parliamentary meeting, and told not to meet foreign journalists.More than 500,000 security personnel have been mobilised for China's annual two-house parliamentary session, with police vowing to stop petitioners and activists from airing grievances, state press said last week."We must take measures to mobilise all police and resources to ensure that during this year's 'two meetings' period no rush of crowds come to Beijing to petition," the China Police Daily quoted top police boss Zhu Chunlin as saying last week."(We must) ensure that there is no big public security problems with petitioners that will influence the smooth carrying out of security work."Under the petition system, which dates back to imperial times, ordinary citizens have the right to lodge written complaints with the central government about perceived injustices carried out by local authorities.New York-based Human Rights Watch issued a statement Wednesday that raised similar concerns over human rights and the 2008 Olympics."If this is how the government is going to deal with dissent before and during the Olympics, it will backfire spectacularly," said Brad Adams, Asia director at Human Rights Watch."The heavy-handed measures we have witnessed in recent weeks are completely out of line with the expected behaviour of an Olympic host. They show China as a repressive police state, instead of the modern country its leaders hope to portray."Rights activist Liu pointed to the irony of Chinese President Hu Jintao's stated ambition of creating a "harmonious society" and the treatment given to him."If parking a police car one metre outside your door and following you everywhere you go is harmony, then this is what we are going to have to expect," Liu said. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]
notes_human: for 2008 Olympic

headline: South China protesters disrupt rail traffic
text: BEIJING, March 22 (Reuters) - Scores of people invaded railway tracks and disrupted rail traffic along a main line straddling Shanghai and five provinces in south China for hours to protest against government rezoning plans, local officials said on Thursday.About 200 protesters stormed the Guixi city railway station in Jiangxi province on Wednesday and sat or stood on the tracks, a news portal run by the Jiangxi provincial government ( www.jxcn.cn ) said."They were instigated by a small group of people," it said.Guixi residents fear their city will have to subsidise the relatively poorer Yuehu district if some parts of Guixi are merged with Yuehu. The protesters were also irked the government denied them any say in the merger.Officials said the merger was still being deliberated.China has witnessed an increasing number of protests and riots, often in rural areas, in recent years, fuelled by a widening wealth gap, corruption and official abuse of power.Several people were injured when protesters clashed with police, a Guixi city government propaganda official surnamed Jiang told Reuters. He declined to elaborate.Postings on another Internet site said police used tear gas. One resident said demonstrators burned vehicles.Train services between financial hub Shanghai in China's east coast and Kunming, capital of the southwestern province of Yunnan, were not restored until about six hours later. The east-west line also straddles provinces of Zhejiang, Hunan and Guizhou.Scores of passenger and freight trains were delayed. Local officials declined to give an estimate for economic losses.Government officials made door-to-door visits on Thursday to try to convince residents not to take to the streets again, the propaganda official said.The stoppage attracted hundreds of onlookers, the Jiangxi government-run portal said. But a local resident reached by telephone and Internet postings put the number at thousands."There was a sea of people. I've never seen so many people in this place before," a receptionist at a hotel near the station said by telephone. "Lots of armed police and anti-riot police arrived. It subsided after dusk."The crowd dispersed after provincial governor Wu Xinxiong went to the scene to placate them, the Jiangxi portal said.No arrests were reported. Defendants convicted of halting rail traffic in China face up to five years in prison.Thousands of protesters clashed with police in the southern province of Hunan last week, as a demonstration over rising transportation costs escalated into a riot.
locality_human: Guixi city railway station in Jiangxi
notes_human: Guixi residents fear their city will have to subsidise the relatively poorer Yuehu district if some parts of Guixi are merged with Yuehu. The protesters were also irked the government denied them any say in the merger.Officials said the merger was still being deliberated.Police fired tear gas in violent clashes with protesters who blocked a key railway in eastern China, witnesses said Thursday, in the latest case of rising social unrest plaguing the country.Witnesses said thousands of protesters and onlookers gathered on Wednesday at the main railway station in Guixi township, Jiangxi province, to demonstrate against a pending merger of their town with a larger city.

headline: Report: 1 killed, 4 injured in land dispute protest in southern China
text: BEIJING (AP) - One man died and four others were injured in a clash with authorities over land in southern China, a report said Thursday, the latest confrontation sparked by complaints of illegal seizures.The violence in Ganyi in Hunan province occurred Saturday when residents condemned the village's party secretary at a meeting for selling a piece of common land without their knowledge, Hong Kong's South China Morning Post reported.Citing an unnamed villager, the newspaper said the party chief's two brothers attacked village representatives at the meeting and were later beaten in retaliation. One brother died, it said.Protests have risen sharply across China in recent years as ordinary Chinese vent anger over official corruption, a growing rich-poor gap and land confiscations. Earlier this month, a protest in another Hunan village turned bloody after 20,000 area residents clashed with police over rising bus fares. Reports said at least one person was killed.When contacted, villagers in Ganyi said they were unclear about the incident or hung up immediately, a common response in China where residents refuse to talk about sensitive issues for fear of retaliation from authorities.An official from the provincial Communist Party office, who gave only his surname Ke, confirmed there had been a dispute in Ganyi but said he had no details. Calls to the police station at Yongzhou, the city that oversees Ganyi, rang unanswered.The Post said Ganyi was cordoned off after hundreds of policemen stormed the area and detained villagers.An unidentified villager told the daily that the party chief had been selling trees and land to lumber companies."Our village has a tradition that each villager can climb the hill and cut down two trees for his coffin," he was quoted as saying. "But since last year, we have been stopped ... and told that both the trees and land now belong to lumber companies."He said an offer by the Ganyi government to pay five trees to each villager was "unbelievably low" and would not be accepted.The Ganyi confrontation comes days after China's legislature passed a property law which offers the same protections for private and public property. The mandate would bolster the rights of farmers who frequently lost their land to infrastructure and housing projects, with little or no compensation.
locality_human: Ganyi, police station at Yongzhou, the city that oversees Gany

headline: Hundreds of ex-soldiers petition Beijing for jobs Police sent to capital to bring protesters home
text: Hundreds of representatives of demobilised soldiers across the nation have headed to Beijing to protest against their local governments' failure to find them new jobs as required by a central government directive.Protesters said police from their home towns had been sent to the capital to bring them home.Qiao Yanbin , one of the representatives from Shandong province , said local officials had sent a large number of police officers to Beijing South Railway Station."Myself and three friends were sent back to our home town in Yantai on Wednesday by local police," Mr Qiao said. "All of us were shoved into cars as soon as we reached the station."          [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. Root URL on filing date: http://www.scmp.com]Mr Qiao said many police cars were stationed outside the railway station to intercept representatives from other regions when he arrived.Representatives of soldiers have been streaming into Beijing to petition the central government since the National People's Congress ended last month and security measures in the capital were relaxed.The protesters have been complaining about local officials' failure to find them work even though President Hu Jintao has been urging local governments and party units to find work for demobilised cadres and soldiers since 2003.The PLA has demobilised 1.7 million soldiers in more than two decades. Between 1997 and 2000 alone, 500,000 troops were rendered redundant. The demobilisation drive is aimed at freeing up more resources to aid the nation's modernisation drive.However, finding new jobs for demobilised soldiers has faced a lot of challenges amid economic reforms and privatisation of the state-owned sectors since 1980s, as the nation struggles to cope with growing joblessness.Hubei representative Shu Junping , 43, who has stayed in Beijing since 2004, said he had heard of soldiers killing themselves and suffering mental problems after failing to have their voices heard."At least 100 representatives from across the nation are now living like vagabonds like me in Beijing, with many of us seeking jobs here or begging and sleeping on the streets," said the former lieutenant who served on the Sino-Russian frontier in Jilin for nine years.He said some protesters had spent more than 20 years in Beijing complaining about unfair treatment by military officials and authorities.Human rights activist and founder of the 64Tianwang website, Huang Qi, who has been voicing concern about the demobilisation problem for almost nine years, said the demobilised soldiers had been conveying their complaints in a rational way."The authorities have also avoided using violence," Mr Huang said. "But I am worried that the protests will develop into irrational conflicts or spiral out of control if Beijing remains reluctant to handle the problem properly."
source_human: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English

headline: SCMP: 300 Workers at HK-Funded Factory in Shenzhen Protest Late Wage Payments
text: About 300 workers of a Hong Kong-funded textile factory in Shenzhen yesterday staged a protest against delayed salary payments and new contracts, which they said management forced on them. Workers at Glad Garments in Yantian district staged a sit-in outside the factory. They later marched to a government office and demanded local authorities intervene. Workers claimed management had not paid them for overtime and said it last week tried to force them to accept contracts that will change part of their salary into discretionary bonuses. The district government sent officials to help negotiate. The factory agreed to let workers decide if they were willing to sign the new contracts and said it would pay the delayed payments. The crowd dispersed without incident. headline: AFP Told: More on Farmers Riot in China Over "One Child" Policy
text: BEIJING, May 21, 2007 (AFP) - Police clashed violently with protesters in southern China as thousands of angry farmers rioted over the nation's controversial "one-child" family planning policies, residents said Monday.Angry farmers besieged up to four township governments in Guangxi province on Friday and Saturday, with police and protesters clashing in at least one demonstration, they said.The demonstrations occurred after local governments this month dispatched "family planning work teams" to levy fines on families that were violating government population control policies, they said.One woman in Shapi township, speaking on condition of anonymity, said up to 20,000 people had gathered and rioted there on Saturday, hurling rocks, breaking windows and torching public property."The farmers were really angry because the family planning team was going around to homes and making farmers pay fines if they had too many kids," the woman told AFP by telephone."If the farmers had no money they took things from them. Property with value they confiscated, things with no value they destroyed."The work teams confiscated everything from livestock, to electronic goods and household items such as pots and pans and teapots, according to the woman and other accounts by locals posted on the Internet.Photos on the Internet showed family planning work teams dressed in military fatigues and helmets carrying sledge hammers as they marched through Guangxi villages.On Friday, similar demonstrations erupted in neighbouring Shuiming township, with locals confronting up to 1,000 police armed with clubs and dogs, one witness said."It's hard to say how many people were there, (but) you could say there was a sea of people," a man in Shuiming township told AFP also on condition of anonymity out of fear of government retribution.Hong Kong press reports said up to 50,000 farmers protested against the family planning policies in the four Guangxi townships in recent days. Residents and Internet postings indicated the situation was calm on Monday.Authorities were trying to impose fines ranging from 6,000 yuan (780 dollars) to more than 60,000, depending on how many children the families had, according to the residents contacted by AFP and the Hong Kong reports.Local and provincial government and police departments refused to comment on the unrest when contacted by AFP Monday.China has since the 1970s enforced strict family planning measures to control its population, which at 1.3 billion people is the world's biggest.Reports of abuse by authorities enforcing the law, such as forced late-term abortions and forced sterilisations, as well as arbitrary fines, are common.In general, China's urban dwellers are allowed one child, while rural families can have two if the first child is a girl.Online chatrooms were awash with postings on the unrest, with some saying that the provincial government had ordered the family planning crackdowns in regions where the population was growing too fast.Other postings said that local governments were levying the fines in order to raise salaries and bonuses of government workers in the impoverished province.The protests come against a backdrop of rising social discontent nationwide as the gap between rich and poor has widened during China's breakneck economic growth.According to the latest figures from the Ministry of Public Security, there were 87,000 protests, officially termed "mass incidents," reported in 2005, up 6.6 percent on 2004 and 50 percent from 2003. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: School accused of fraud
text: Fifty-two girls from the Ninth Secondary School in Ningbo , Zhejiang , and their parents protest outside the municipal education department office on Tuesday, saying they have been swindled by the school.They said it had promised to give the girls certificates after they completed a three-year English course, and ensure their entry into a nursing college. But now they have been told they are not qualified to take part in the college entrance exams, they said.The students also petitioned the municipal government office yesterday, and 100 police officers prevented them from entering the building. Two girls and one pregnant parent said they were beaten by police when officers detained a passerby who took a photograph of their protest. The students vowed to continue petitioning until authorities solved their problem.

headline: LHZB: More Rioting Against Family Planning Breaks Out in Guangxi 29 May
text: The "family planning storm" broke out again in Guangxi, China, yesterday. Yesterday afternoon, at the same time, a total of about 4,000 peasants in the three townships of Yangmei, Lingshan, and Licun surrounded in protest the local "family planning offices" or township governments and seriously clashed with police, nearly killing a female cadre at a "family planning office." Over 100 peasants were also wounded, and there were rumors that an old man was beaten to death by police. Peasants burned down auditoriums, and the clashes continued well into the night. Finally police unleashed dogs to bite people and expelled the masses with billies. @?@The three-story-high family planning office building was burned down by angry masses. "This is the largest clash between peasants and the government in the history of Yangmei township!" Eyewitnesses claimed that some policemen unleashed dogs, which bit and wounded many peasants.Eyewitnesses said that about 3,000 peasants in Yangmei township began to surround the local family planning office building at 1400 yesterday and almost killed a female cadre at the office, who "luckily fled in time to hide in the middle school behind." Subsequently, agitated masses at around 1500 threw gasoline to the family planning office building and seriously burned down the three-story-high office building.? "The fire burned for over half an hour, and all documents, wooden cabinets, and archives were destroyed!" In addition, at least two police vehicles and several motorcycles were also destroyed in fire. headline: SCMP: Hebei Province Pyramid-Scheme Sellers Held After Mobbing Police Station
text: Scores of members of a pyramid-sales scheme have been held in Baoding, Hebei province, after more than 200 people stormed a police station and injured nine officers on Sunday.The attack followed a police raid earlier in the day in which officers broke up a gathering of 200 non-locals engaged in pyramid-selling, the China News Service reported.Officers took two key members back to the Xinshichang community police station for questioning. More than 200 members of the pyramid scheme later milled around the station at about 4pm, armed with clubs, knives and bricks, and demanded the release of their colleagues.Nine officers were injured trying to stop the mob from entering the station, the report said. Some doors and windows were damaged."The (pyramid scheme members) kept breaking things while running from the second floor to the first floor... It was horrible. They even smashed police cars," a witness was quoted as saying.Yelling "kill the officers", they also chased police officers, who ran out of the building.The rampage lasted for more than 20 minutes before additional officers arrived and the mob ran off, the news agency said.The injured officers were sent to hospital. Scores of scheme members, most of them "very young", had been detained for assault and vandalism, while a search for others was continuing, the report said.Pyramid-selling was outlawed on the mainland in 1998 but has not been eradicated, despite repeated crackdowns. Last year Shandong police smashed a cosmetics sales scam that involved 500,000 people in 16 provinces.The mainland cracked 3,587 pyramid-selling cases last year and prosecuted 2,111 people, State Administration for Industry and Commerce figures show.There have been previous reports of scheme members storming police stations and injuring officers. [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: UPDATE 2-Hundreds of students riot in central China
text: (Adds details and background, paragraphs 5, 6 and 12)BEIJING, June 7 (Reuters) - Hundreds of Chinese students clashed with police and overturned and burnt their car after street inspectors beat up a female student, a police officer and witnesses said on Thursday, the latest in a series of public disturbances.Students from several universities in Zhengzhou, in the central province of Henan, went on the rampage on Wednesday after a student vendor was beaten by several inspectors as they cleared her unlicensed stall, a student witness told Reuters.Last June, thousands of students from the same city smashed windows and ransacked their campus in a riot sparked by anger over the wording of their diplomas."I was also selling things on the street, and I could not take it any more, when I saw them even beating up a girl, so I joined the riot by throwing a brick at the inspectors," a student from the Henan University of Finance and Economics said."I saw more than 10 people running after an inspector and trying to beat him, and some other people overturned a car and set fire to it," other student witness said by telephone.About 100 police, some armed with electric rods and shields, arrived on the scene, sealing the street and taking people away, the student said.The Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy put the number of students rioting at 1,000. One witness put it at 2,000.A police officer also confirmed the riot."A lot of students were rioting last night, and the situation was quite serious," the official, surnamed Wang, told Reuters. "The general city police office had to send more police to help," she said by phone, adding that the case was under investigation.The girl lost her front teeth in the clash and five students were detained by police, the rights centre said.Six inspectors were detained, two were sacked and four received warnings, the local Dahe News paper said, citing a government notice.Unrest of any kind is highly sensitive in China, whose Communist government prizes stability and brooks no challenges to its power. But student protests are an even more potent symbol because of a legacy of student activism, most recently in the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations on Tiananmen Square.Clashes between members of the public and the inspectors, known as "cheng guan" and mainly responsible for cracking down on unlicensed hawkers suspected of selling unsanitary food or low- quality goods, are common.In April, a roadside vendor in Beijing was given a suspended death sentence for slitting an inspector's throat.The inspectors were set up across China in the late 1990s to ease the burden on police and ensure cities were clean and orderly. But critics say they have become a huge interest group thriving on fines and confiscations with over-reaching power.A widening gap between rich and poor, corruption and official abuses of power have fuelled demonstrations and riots around the country that are often sparked by seemingly minor issues.
locality_human: Zhengzhou, in the central province of Henan

headline: China calls on Xiamen to rethink chemical plant
text: BEIJING, June 7 (Reuters) - A top Chinese environmental official called on the southern city of Xiamen on Thursday to rethink its plans to build a chemical plant after the prospect caused thousands to march in protest.Pan Yue, deputy head of China's State Environmental Protection Administration, also admonished local officials for not taking seriously the importance of environmental assessments, which he said could head off such conflicts."We hope the Xiamen city government can consult on the plan and make appropriate adjustments and do its utmost to change the current juxtaposition of the industrial park and the neighbourhood," Pan said in a notice on the ministry's Web site ( www.sepa.gov.cn ).Thousands of protesters marched through the city last week, demanding the government scrap its plans to build the plant to make paraxylene (PX), a compound used in polyester and fabrics, denouncing it as a threat to Xiamen's seaside environment.The city had already said it would suspend construction and do another environmental assessment, but protesters demanded the government scrap the project altogether, something the Xiamen mayor said he would consider depending on the outcome of the impact study.Pan said Xiamen had been dragging its feet on the new assessment and urged it to step up the process."Presently, several major incidents of environmental conflicts are because in city plans, environmental impact has not been appraised," he said."Environmental assessment plans are a profound means to limit the environmental risk from the process of rapid industrialisation and urbanisation."Pan also cautioned that building chemical plants near residential neighbourhoods could spur popular unrest, which China's Communist leaders are at pains to avoid."Many localities and departments do not give sufficient importance to environmental impact assessment plans in city planning, which can cause chaos (and) inappropriate industrial structures ...," he said.Environmental pollution, a consequence of decades of unchecked economic growth in China, has led to demonstrations and riots around the country, from uproar over a battery plant in the eastern province of Zhejiang to a run on bottled water in the northeast after an explosion at a chemical plant poisoned tap water supplies.Pan said local governments should consult with citizens, but appealed to residents to act calmly."We also hope public participation is according to law, rational and can form a healthy interaction with the government."
notes_human: chemical plant

headline: SCMP: China's Top Environmental Watchdog Slams Decision To Build Incinerator
text: The nation's top environmental watchdog has hit out at local authorities in Beijing over their approval of a controversial waste-treatment plant near a populated residential area, two days after a rare protest by hundreds of residents in the city centre. While the State Environmental Protection Administration's (Sepa) appeal for a postponement of the incinerator in the Haidian district was applauded by residents, it has been brushed off by local authorities.The 750-million-yuan incinerator project was planned by Haidian district to ease mounting complaints by people from at least two villages and eight residential areas over the unbearable stench from a landfill. Approved by the city's environmental bureau in 2005, construction was scheduled to start in March and the plant put into operation before the Olympic Games next August. But it has been delayed due to strong opposition from local residents, green groups and mainland media, including state television. More than 1,000 residents took to the streets on World Environment Day on Tuesday to demonstrate in front of Sepa's headquarters in Xicheng district. In a statement posted on Sepa's website, deputy director Pan Yue accused city authorities of violating a central government edict that banned waste-treatment projects near residential quarters."Given the sensitive location of the Liulitun waste-incineration and power plant, the city's environmental bureau should allow experts to hold more debates and give the public a bigger say," he said.Mr Pan quoted a document by the city's green watchdog in 1995 that had even voiced concerns over the grave environmental impact of the landfill - that was eventually built in 1999 - on local communities and the city's main freshwater channel, which was about 1km away. Sepa urged the city government to halt the incinerator pending further debate and said it would announce its final decision on the project soon.But local authorities have insisted the project will have no impact on people's health and should go ahead, saying the landfill, the only one in Haidian, cannot handle the 2,500 tonnes of domestic waste produced in the district every day.City and district officials said they had yet to formally receive Sepa's decision, even though Mr Pan's statement was carried prominently by mainland internet news portals. "We have not got Sepa's letter informing us of its decision and we understand it is not Sepa's final decision," said Du Shaozhong , a deputy director of Beijing's environmental bureau.Residents in Dongbutou and Tundian villages and Yihe Villas, while are within 1km of the landfill, say they have suffered from foul air for years and dare not open their windows. But their previous complaints to the government had been ignored. "It is good to hear Sepa's decision, but will it really be able to stop local authorities building the incineration plant?" asked a resident surnamed Wang from Yihe Villas.Environmental sources said Sepa had overestimated its clout."The statement was prompted by the Tuesday protest and designed to appease the people affected and maintain social stability," one source said. "But it received a silent protest from local authorities, and Sepa has obviously fallen foul of local authorities in the city."[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. Root URL on filing date: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Chinese residents clash with police over relocation
text: BEIJING, June 13 (Reuters) - About 5,000 people clashed with police in northern China last week during a protest against forced relocation, a Hong Kong human rights watchdog said on Wednesday.At least 20 people were injured, two women seriously, and three were arrested during the incident in the Inner Mongolia region last Friday, in which three police cars were smashed, the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said.Thousands blocked a highway in the city of Hohhot to protest against inadequate compensation for their homes' demolition to make way for a new plaza, it said."We're dealing with this carefully, but the situation is now under control," Meng Shude, spokesman for the Communist Party in Inner Mongolia, told Reuters.The incident comes as Hohhot gears up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.Chinese have become increasingly bold about protesting over home demolitions, pollution and corrupt land grabs as China's booming cities and factories swallow up neighbourhoods and farmland.Thousands marched in the streets this month in the southeastern seaside city of Xiamen to demand that plans for a paraxylene plant be scrapped.Villagers in Guangxi rioted and burned cars in May to protest overly strict enforcement of family planning policies.Official figures show the number of so-called "mass incidents" was 23,000 in 2006, compared to about 10,000 in 1994, but down from 74,000 in 2004.
notes_human: About 5,000 people clashed with police in northern China last week during a protest against forced relocation,         At least 20 people were injured and three police cars smashed in a riot over a construction project in Inner Mongolia, a human rights organization said yesterday. More than 5,000 protesters clashed with 100 anti-riot policemen in Hohhot, the capital of the northern autonomous region, last Friday, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said. At least two female protesters were seriously injured and three were detained. The rioting began over the city government's decision to use armed forces to demolish residential buildings in a railway compound to clear the way for a project celebrating the 60th anniversary of the autonomous region's founding.Source: South China Morning Post website, Hong Kong, in English 14 Jun 07

headline: Report: Thousands in Chinese town protest forced eviction
text: BEIJING (AP) - Protesters clashed with police who were trying to evict a 90-year-old woman to make way for a real estate project, leaving 20 people injured in a southern China town, a human rights monitor and a newspaper reported Saturday.At one point the woman was on her roof with a homemade gasoline bomb, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy and the newspaper Beijing News said.Such conflicts occur regularly in China, where local authorities are seizing farmland and older housing to clear the way for shopping malls, luxury apartments and other projects.Violence erupted Wednesday after hundreds of police and firefighters tried to force the woman from her home in Shengzhou, in the southeastern province of Zhejiang, the reports said.The woman, Zhang Xinghua, has been fighting eviction since 2004 and is the last holdout in the neighborhood, the Beijing News said.About 20,000 people who gathered to protest the eviction clashed with officers, the reports said. The Information Center said 20 people were injured and six detained by police.There was no word on whether the eviction succeeded. An officer who answered the phone at Shengzhou police headquarters confirmed a violent incident occurred, but said he had no details. He refused to give his name.People evicted in such redevelopment efforts often complain they get too little compensation to buy new farmland or homes.Zhang was offered 2,500 yuan (US$325; euro243) per square meter (US$32; euro24 per square foot) for her home, but her family wants 4,000 yuan (US$525; euro390), the Beijing News said.
locality_human: Shengzhou, Shaoxing, in the southeastern province of Zhejiang
notes_human: About 20,000 people who gathered to protest the eviction clashed with officers, the reports said. The Information Center said 20 people were injured and six detained by police.

headline: Mass protest, police clash reported in Chinese city
text: BEIJING, July 2 (Reuters) - Clashes with riot police broke out in southwestern China last week after thousands of protesters besieged a government office, a human rights centre and a witness said on Monday.Friday's incident in Chongqing city's Youyang county was sparked when relatives of a school student who had been stabbed to death by a schoolmate claimed they were beaten by police as they protested in front of the school.The angry crowd then moved to the township government office, holding a banner saying "Murder in the School", a witness who was working at a hotel next to the office told Reuters."More and more people gathered around the county government, and the whole street was jammed for hours," she said by telephone.The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said the number of protesters was as much as 10,000.But the witness said she was not sure how many people were actually protesting, as many were simply onlookers who sympathised with the victim's family.Some in the crowd recognised an occupant of a government car as the deputy head of the county, demanded that he get out of the vehicle and then smashed its windows, the witness said.Dozens of police carrying riot shields were sent to the scene and had water-bottles thrown at them, she said.The human rights centre said that up to 200 police were involved, about 10 people were injured and several were detained.A Youyang township government official confirmed the death of the middle-school student, but declined to give more details.The local police, reached by telephone, declined to comment.A widening gap between rich and poor, corruption and official abuses of power have fuelled demonstrations and riots across the the country and are often sparked by seemingly minor issues.Last month, hundreds of Chinese students clashed with police and overturned and burnt their car after street inspectors beat up a female student.
notes_human: student death

headline: Thousands protest land seizure in southwest China
text: BEIJING, July 5 (Reuters) - Thousands of people protested for days against land seizures in southwestern China, besieging government offices and clashing with riot police, a human rights watchdog and a local resident said on Thursday.Eight people have been taken into police custody in Yanjia township in Chongqing municipality since Tuesday when up to 5,000 people took to the streets, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said in a faxed statement.At least 10 peasants were injured when they clashed with police, the group said. They smashed office equipment including computers and desks as well as two police vans.The peasants were protesting against land grabs to expand an industrial park and what they said was unfair compensation, the group said.Factories in the industrial park have refused to hire land-deprived farmers, it added.Yanjia officials reached by telephone confirmed the stand-off but declined to give details."It has been going on for three days. There were people injured in the fight," an employee of a local restaurant said in a telephone interview.Residents threw rocks at more than 100 parked police vans on Thursday, the group said.China is grappling with popular unrest as official corruption, pollution, miscarriages of justice or even seemingly minor issues serve as flashpoints for protests and riots.Land seizures driven by breakneck urban and industrial growth have been encroaching upon rural areas across the country. What is particularly explosive is that many officials are accused of colluding with developers to keep compulsory purchase prices well below the market rate.

headline: Chinese Villagers Protest Compensation For Land Lost To Dam
text: BEIJING (AP)--Thousands of villagers in southern China clashed with police during a protest over what they say is inadequate compensation for farmland flooded by a dam project, according to news reports Wednesday.Hong Kong's Mingpao Newspaper reported that about 10,000 villagers repeatedly engaged police over a four-day period last week when they tried to petition the local government in Guangxi province's Yantan Township, and to hold demonstrations near the dam.Property disputes and illegal land grabs have recently accelerated as China's economy expands at double-digit rates and farmland is gobbled up for factories, industrial parks and other lucrative developments.A Yantan villager, identified by the surname Li, said that the situation had calmed down and that local officials were negotiating with the villagers."They are very poor. They don't even have enough food," Li told The Associated Press by telephone Wednesday. He refused to give his full name.For four days beginning June 1, villagers carrying banners and chanting slogans surrounded the Yantan No. 2 Hydroelectric Power Station's staff residence, and marched to the dam site to demand more compensation, the newspaper said.It said several hundred soldiers and armed police were trucked in to help contain the protests, and five villagers were injured in clashes.There were arrests, though reports did not specify how many.The paper said Yantan farmland was flooded several years ago when the dam caused the level of the local Red River to overflow its banks.Villagers were enraged when the central government allegedly gave Yantan officials $370,000 last year to help compensate residents - but only a portion of it was distributed, according to the paper.Villagers claimed that local officials pocketed some of the money.The Mingpao said that villagers had been sporadically protesting since April, but that last week's demonstrations were the largest yet.The government has been giving every villager a subsidy of $4 per month regardless of how much land they lost, it said.Li estimated that about 3,000 villagers had protested last week, though he was unaware of anyone being injured.Phones at the Yantan government office and public security bureau were unanswered Wednesday. A government official with the Dahua Yao Autonomous county, which oversees Yantan, said there had been no demonstrations."Nothing happened here. Everything is normal today," said the official who, like many Chinese bureaucrats would only give his surname, Wang. [ 11-07-07 1341GMT ]
notes_human: Thousands of villagers in southern China clashed with police during a protest over what they say is inadequate compensation for farmland flooded by a dam project, according to news reports Wednesday.

headline: SCMP: 'Group Protesting Over Death of Child Beaten by Guards'
text: More than 1,000 people who protested outside a Hunan private hospital over a medical accident in which a 15-month-old boy died were attacked by about 100 unidentified men, state media said yesterday.Five people were injured during the clash, the website of People's Daily reported. It said more than 40 people, including the owner of the hospital, Lin Shiqiang , were detained by police for questioning, but they were later released. The boy's family accused Mr Lin of hiring thugs to beat up the protesters. The riot in Binzhou , Hunan, was triggered by the death of Duan Jiahao , who was diagnosed with influenza by doctors at Fukang Hospital. His parents took the baby to the hospital last Sunday because he had a fever.The boy's condition deteriorated in spite of treatment. He was transferred to a state-run hospital but died shortly after arriving. Doctors at that hospital said the boy had suffered from meningitis, not common flu, the report said.The boy's father, Duan Tangxian , demanded that Fukang Hospital pay 80,000 yuan in compensation for the misdiagnosis, but the hospital has refused.The father then gathered hundreds of relatives, friends and neighbours from his hometown and staged a protest outside the hospital on Friday. They put the boy's body in the centre of the hospital lobby and hung a banner calling for justice at the main entrance. The protest attracted hundreds of onlookers, a Fukang Hospital spokesman said yesterday.The protesters said they were attacked shortly afterwards by about 100 men armed with iron bars. The hospital spokesman acknowledged the incident yesterday and admitted that the attackers were hospital security guards. He said the demonstrators had blocked traffic, and that hospital officials had called the police to intervene, but their calls went unanswered, so they had no choice but to use force to expel the protesters."We just sent our security guards to protect the safety of our hospital because local police refused to help," he said. "In fact, they (the protesters) just wanted to blackmail us by creating chaos."The spokesman said Fukang Hospital was also a victim in the incident.He said its doctors had suggested that the family take the sick boy to a bigger hospital to have a comprehensive check-up, but the father had refused to listen. "We are only a small private hospital, and we know we are only capable of treating simple illnesses," the spokesman said. He added that the dispute had been settled but did not provide any details. [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: AFP: Thousands of Protestors Clash With Police Over Polluting Chinese Brewery
text: BEIJING, July 29, 2007 (AFP) - Thousands of protesters accusing a brewery in southwest China of polluting water supplies clashed with armed police, a human rights group said Sunday, the latest violence sparked by environmental worries.Several thousand residents in Sichuan province took to the streets to protest contamination of drinking and irrigation water by China Resources Breweries, said the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy.The angry citizens near Shifang city surrounded the factory on July 26, stopping production and holding up cargo, it said.More than 500 armed police were dispatched in what the report said turned into a "violent and bloody" confrontation. 20 people were injured and seven arrested, the report added.Police in Shifang city and Yuanshi township, where the factory is based, contacted by AFP Sunday refused to comment. Nobody answered the phone at the brewery, which is listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange.China's degraded environment has caused a rising number of riots and other forms of public unrest.The leadership in Beijing has put cleaning up its filthy environment at the top of its agenda, but frustrated citizens are increasingly taking matters into their own hands, as they did in June in southeastern China.Work on a billion-dollar petrochemical plant in Xiamen, a major port, was suspended after a text message campaign by protesters angry about industrial pollution.China's waterways have suffered severely during the nation's breakneck economic growth over the past two decades.More than 70 percent of China's waterways and 90 percent of its underground water are contaminated by pollution, according to government figures. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: HK Daily: Thousands of Tourist Guides Stage Sit-in In Front of Guilin City Hall
text: Thousands of Tourist Guides in Guilin Lodge Protests inFront of the City Hall; a 500-Man Police Force Detains 300 Demonstrators ToClear up the Area In Guangxi's Guilin, a well-known tourist city on the Chinesemainland, thousands of tourist guides of primarily domestic tourist groupsstaged a sit-in in front of the city hall for the fourth day recently to expresstheir anger over the official Guilin Ribao for reporting that touristguides resorted to deceptions for kickback purpose. However, in less than 12hours after the city authorities concerned admitted the impropriety of thereport and after the newspaper published an open apology, the authoritiesmobilized 500 public security personnel to brutally suppress the demonstrators,causing a bloody clash during which a woman who was four-month pregnant had amiscarriage, many people were battered, and the arrest of at least 300 people.The demonstrators, however, pointed out that they would continue to "takea break" (strike), beginning tomorrow. "Take them away, take them away! Arrest them, arrestthem!" Miss Chen, a mainland tourist guide, and over a thousand othertourist guides of primarily domestic tourist groups continued to stage theirsit-in before the city hall "as usual" on the evening beforeyesterday. During the sit-in, they sang the national anthem and the Internationale .A Pregnant Woman Has a Miscarriage As Result of PublicSecurity Officers' Beatings At about midnight when several tourist guides approached thecordon line set up in front of the city hall, a public security guardsurprisingly removed part of barricade to let the demonstrators in. However,after the demonstrators were behind the line, the guard suddenly yelled,"Catch them." Then the other guards there began to arrest thedemonstrators and used police batons to beat those who resisted. Most of theinjured demonstrators were female tourist guides. A pregnant woman who was four-monthpregnant had a miscarriage. An hour later, the public security officers pushed at least 300demonstrators onto the 40 buses already waiting there. According to Miss Chen,who was one of the demonstrators, the public security officers also pushed someonlookers and tourists who were there onto the buses. Meanwhile, fiveambulances also drove into the site. Miss Chen said, "They brought outmany people. All of them were badly battered." At about 0530 yesterday, the public security authoritiesgradually released the detainees after they were coerced to sign a writtenpledge to promise that they would not take part in any similar unlawfulassembly and petition ever again. According to an informed source, theauthorities were considerably displeased with the sit-in for days on end,claiming that they would "control and suffocate it within Guangxi" soas to stop the information from spreading to the central authorities. That waswhy they resorted to suppression, the source said. The Guilin city hall, in response to questions concerningthe incident, said that 400 people who claimed they were tourist guidesgathered at the entrance of the city hall and blocked a certain road section.It said that that the city authorities brought these people to the petitioncenter only after they failed to ask them to leave; and that "there wasneither any clash nor any people injured" throughout the incident. ? Meanwhile, Miss Chen said angrily that Guilin Ribao 'sapology two days ago, in addition to having no sincerity at all, also distortedthe facts. She said, "They said the vice mayor would come out to mediate, but there just wasn'tany government official coming out to give us an explanation the whole time. Weare very unsatisfied. The government's brutal suppression has truly broken ourhearts." In fact, she said, the authorities' move has aggravated the demonstrators'dissatisfaction and so, starting tomorrow, we will "take a break" indefinitelyuntil the authorities satisfy our demand. If the authorities continue to chooseto disregard us, she said, we do not rule out the possibility of taking a more vigorousmove, Chen said. Root URL on filing date: http://appledaily.atnext.com]Attachments:

headline: Hong Kong Daily: 1,000 Tianjin Residents Protest Over Compensation Fund Dispute
text: Under the hot sun for three consecutive days, nearly 1,000 Tianjin residents, who are to be resettled, staged a sit-in protest in front of the Tanggu District Government Office's buildings. They protested that the government did not reach any agreement with them on issues including the amounts of resettlement compensation. Consequently, they do not have any permanent residences and have been forced to rent rooms or rely on relatives and friends. Since 2003, the government successively involuntarily demolished households in Xinhezhuang Village, and evicted over 1,000 households out of their homes. As a result, 80 percent of them do not have any permanent residences. Many of them have been forced to rent rooms or even rely on relatives and friends. However, as of now, 129 defiant households have not been demolished yet. The residents to be resettled are dissatisfied with issues including resettlement compensation of over 600 yuan per square meter offered by the government. Therefore, beginning on 30 July, they staged a large-scale sit-in protest in front of the Tanggu District Government Office's buildings. It is the third day today [ 1 August]. It has been very hot for the past few days. Several protestors have been hospitalized after they suffered heatstroke and fainted. A Complaints Office spokesman said: All the resettlement procedures are legitimate. However, staging a sit-in protest outside government office buildings by nearly 1,000 people violates regulations governing petitions and complaints.? headline: SCMP: 'Tibetans Protest Over Activist's Arrest'
text: People protested in a Tibetan area in western Sichuan after the authorities arrested a man calling for the return of the Dalai Lama, Xinhua reported yesterday.More than 200 Tibetans protested outside a detention centre in Lithang town in Sichuan after an incident on Wednesday at an annual horse festival that attracted thousands of people. A resident, Runggye Adak, was detained after he climbed onto a stage which had been erected for officials, grabbed a microphone and shouted "separatist messages".The protesting residents appealed to police outside the detention centre to release him, Xinhua said, adding that the rally was peaceful and the crowd dispersed. But a Radio Free Asia report claimed about 200 people had been arrested. [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post (Internet Version-WWW) in English -- Internet version of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper. headline: Chinese villagers protest over "fake" Xinhua news report - HK daily
text: Text of report by Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post website on 15 August[Report by Stephen Chen: "Villagers Protest Over 'fake' News Report"; headline as provided by source]More than 50 villagers protested outside Xinhua's Sichuan headquarters in Chengdu yesterday, saying the official news agency had faked a news report about job creation.The protesters, mostly women from Wenjiang and Chenghua districts, massed in front of the Xinhua building at about 2pm with a petition demanding the agency correct a news report about district government successes in creating jobs for dispossessed villagers, witness Huang Qi said.Mr Huang said a Xinhua official accepted the letter but told villagers that agency leaders and journalists who wrote the article were not in the office, and so no decision about a correction could be made any time soon.Xinhua reported that 70 per cent of landless villagers were employed, thanks to the efforts of the Wenjiang district government leadership."We, 200,000 landless villagers in Wenjiang have never seen you reporters," the petition says. "The fact is most of us are jobless, hungry and homeless."We have been arrested, beaten up and robbed by local officials. But you never listened to us."Wenjiang villager Li Chunfeng said the highest payout to a family for their land was 8,000 yuan, plus a 100 yuan monthly subsidy."Many villagers remain unemployed seven years after the government took their land. No men went to the protest today, because they are afraid of being arrested," she said.Calls to Xinhua's Chengdu office went unanswered yesterday.Source: South China Morning Post website, Hong Kong, in English 15 Aug 07

headline: HK Daily: 1,000 Protesting Workers Clash With Policemen in Guangdong's Shenzhen
text: On the morning of 20 August, over 1,000 workers from Shenzhen's Baoan Feihuang Shiya Electronic Company [name as transliterated; bao an fei huang shi ya dian ye gong si] that produces cellular phone battery chargers for cellular phone suppliers including Nokia and Motorola expressed protests by blocking the traffic and staging a strike. They demand for better treatment. Many public security personnel came to the scene to disperse them and there were clashes between the protestors and the public security personnel. A report said that the public security personnel arrested several protestors. Answering on 20 August this newspaper's queries, Feihuang Shiya Electronic Company admitted the incident and said that the head office has dispatched personnel to negotiate with the workers.At 0730 on the morning of 20 August [Beijing time or 2330 GMT on 19 August], staff and workers from German-funded Feihuang Company, that is situated in the Hangcheng Industrial Zone, Xixiang Township, Baoan, gathered at Nantai Overpass near National Highway 107 to stage a protesting rally, demanding that the company improve their welfare and treatment. Shenzhen social order units and public security personnel promptly arrived at the scene to disperse them. Later the workers gathered at an open space near the toll gates at Sanwei Road. Subsequently, over 100 fully-armed riot policemen arrived at the scene. Together with other public security personnel, their total number was 500. They surrounded the workers. When some workers resisted, they were taken away.It Is Said a Worker's Leg Was Fractured.A report from the scene said: A worker's leg was hit and fractured, and three or four workers were arrested. The workers futilely asked the public security personnel to release their detained colleagues. Two hours later, the factory's senior officials came to the scene to negotiate with the workers, asking the workers to send representatives to hold talks at the factory. However, the workers were only willing to negotiate after their detained colleagues have been released. Both sided failed to reach any consensus. Subsequently, the public security personnel used loudspeakers to urge the workers to disperse. Otherwise, they would be dispersed by force. Later the workers successively returned to continue their strike at the factory.The Workers Attain Higher Wages But Lower Bonuses and Welfare.A striker told this newspaper: Even though the factory gave us higher wages earlier, it has reduced our bonuses and other welfare benefits. Meanwhile our workload has increased considerably. Now one person has to accomplish the normal workload of two people. The factory has covertly reduced the benefits of the staff and workers under the pretext of providing higher wages. She said: If the factory management refuses to make concessions, we will continue our strike on 21 August. At present, we are awaiting the factory management's response.Ch'iu Tzu-hui, official in charge of "the Campaign for College Teachers and Students To Supervise Immoral Enterprises" in Hong Kong, said: As of the evening of 20 August, four workers were still being detained and the factory management has yet to formally respond to the workers' demands. Answering on 20 August this newspaper's queries, Feihuang Shiya Electronic Company admitted the incident but denied the poor treatment to its staff and workers. It said: The strike inflicts losses for the company. At present, the head office and relevant leaders have dispatched personnel to negotiate with the workers.? headline: Highlights: PRC Sociopolitical Issues on Internet 31 Aug
text: Following are select summaries of sociopolitical issues found on relevant websites and through general Internet searches for 31 August.? The most significant issue during this reporting period was workers in Chengdu clashing with police during demonstrations at a factory.? Another significant issue involved the memorial for housing activist Liu Fengchi being blocked by police and cancelled.? headline: At least 1 dead, 20 injured in Muslim-Han clashes in eastern China
text: BEIJING (AP) - Clashes between minority Chinese Muslims and the Han majority last month left at least one person dead and 20 injured, a Hong Kong newspaper and human rights group reported Tuesday.The fighting in the eastern province of Shandong broke out Aug. 17 after a Hui man was caught stealing and beaten by several Han in the town of Shimiao, the Ming Pao newspaper and independent Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy reported.The Hui man, who was not identified by name, returned to the Muslim neighborhood where several thousand Hui gathered sticks, bricks and other improvised weapons and marched on the town's commercial district.Police tried to separate the groups but were overwhelmed by the sheer numbers and four police vehicles were smashed.Only after several hundred members of the paramilitary People's Armed Police were dispatched to the scene did the fighting come under control.The reports said the clashes had been labeled criminal activity and were currently under investigation, but gave no word of arrests.People who answered phones at Shimiao government offices refused to answer questions about the reported incident, a likely reflection of the sensitivity surrounding such violence. Official media do not report on ethnic clashes, the likely reason why word of the incident was only just now leaking out.Numerous violent incidents between Hui and Han have been reported in Shandong and the neighboring province of Henan in recent years, including a Dec. 12, 2000, clash in which police shot dead at least six Hui men.That incident was sparked by a sign hung from a Han market stall advertising pork that was halal, or approved for consumption by Muslims. Islamic dietary laws strictly prohibit the consumption in any form of pork, the staple meat of the mainstream Han population.China has about 10 million Hui citizens, along with a similar number of Turkish ethnic Uighur Muslims living in the country's far West.

headline: HK Paper: Demobilized Soldiers-Turned-Students in Heilongjiang Clash With Police
text: Following the recent disturbances involving demobilized soldiers in three railway schools on the mainland, the authorities have issued an emergency order for all demobilized soldiers in 12 railway schools nationwide to suspend their schooling and be repatriated to their native places. This measure triggered dissatisfaction among the students of the Qiqiha'er Municipal Railway School in Heilongjiang. About 1,000 students were involved in a disturbance and clashed with the public security and special police personnel arriving on the scene on the night before last (13 September), and at least 10 people were injured. In response to this paper's inquiry, a staff member at the Qiqiha'er Municipal Railway School confirmed the incident and pointed out that the authorities had dispatched a task force to handle it and that the situation had currently returned to normal. On the night before last, according to a report by the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, demobilized soldiers at the Qiqiha'er Municipal Railway School began to do damage to the teaching building and dormitory with beer bottles and also attempted to break out of the school and head for the railway station. Subsequently, several hundred public security and special police personnel armed with loaded weapons arrived on the scene to quell the disturbance, during which the two sides clashed. One Thousand People Involved in Disturbance in Protest Against Repatriation In the small hours of yesterday morning, the rumor of two demobilized soldiers being beaten to death triggered dissatisfaction among other demobilized soldiers, and demobilized soldiers nearby also came as reinforcements. During the incident, three police vehicles were overturned and damaged, at least 10 people were injured, and the public security personnel arrested five demobilized soldiers. The incident was not quelled until 0300 yesterday morning. It has been confirmed that there was no fatality. Five People Arrested, Curfew Imposed in School According to the information center, after the demobilized soldiers' disturbances in?three railway schools in Inner Mongolia, Hubei, and Shaanxi on 3 September, the Ministry of Railways issued an emergency order for over 6,000 demobilized soldiers in the 12 [railway] schools nationwide to suspend their schooling and be repatriated to their native places. But as no mention was made of resettlement and placement, the students were dissatisfied. It was reported that the Ministry of Railways made arrangements at the beginning of this year for demobilized soldiers to receive two-year training in secondary technical schools and senior vocational schools. Most of the Qiqiha'er Railway School students involved in this disturbance are demobilized soldiers newly admitted to the school. After the disturbance, the authorities have imposed a curfew in the school. Wu Zhanqun, a demobilized soldier from Qiqiha'er, told this paper that the demobilized soldiers with rural household registrations have been significantly short changed by the authorities: They are generally only given a demobilization fee of between 10,000 and 20,000 yuan and are not provided with any assistance and training. Consequently, it is difficult for them to find employment for lack of specialized skills. Johnny Lau Yui-siu, a local current affairs commentator, maintained that it is understandable why the demobilized soldiers are dissatisfied when their livelihoods can no longer be safeguarded following their demobilization. But relative to the huge number of demobilized Chinese servicemen, the ratio of demobilized soldiers involved in disturbances is not high. ? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Ming Pao (Internet Version-WWW) in Chinese -- Internet version of well-respected, non-PRC-owned daily newspaper; contains well-informed features on and analysis of PRC and Hong Kong political, social, and economic issues. headline: China River Raft Operators On Strike After Clash With Police
text: BEIJING (AP)--River raft operators on strike in a southern Chinese resort town tussled with police in the latest unrest involving disgruntled groups ranging from cab drivers to college students, a newspaper and local residents said Tuesday.Hong Kong's South China Morning Post newspaper said the raft operators were in price negotiations centered around a government-run company, which has taken over management of the brisk rafting business along a stretch of the Yulong River that carries tourists past the area's famous limestone peaks.Large numbers of raft operators gathered Monday, the start of the lucrative, week-long National Day holiday outside government offices in Yangshuo, said a man who answered the town's tourist hot line."Rafters want to raise their price, but the local government does not allow it, and there was a small conflict," said the man, who gave only his surname, Li.He said police and rafters shoved each other but no injuries were reported. Officers took away about a dozen people for questioning, Li said.The South China Morning Post said that police fired a shot into the crowd, which swelled to about 1,000, while trying to catch a protester. No one was hurt, it said.The government-run company had ordered the rafters to disband the 11 local enterprises they formed in 2004, the paper said.Under the government plan, rafters who earned 54.50 yuan (US$7) per trip would now make 37.5 yuan (US$5) instead, the newspaper said, citing a demonstrator named Pan Chenhua.No other details were given about the new pricing system.Telephones weren't answered at the Yangshuo County government office or the area's rafting service management center.A woman who answered the telephone at the Yangshuo police station said she couldn't comment because she wasn't authorized to talk to the press but said the "situation was normal" on Tuesday and there were lots of tourists in the area.Li said hundreds of rafters were on strike but would consider taking customers if they paid a higher price.The rafting route began in the 1990s and has become a booming business, the SCMP said. Yangshuo County earned 40 million yuan (US$5 million) from rafting trips during last year's National Day holiday, the paper said.Chinese authorities regularly struggle to defuse disputes over pay, regulations and working conditions amid rising inequality and cutthroat job competition despite the booming economy.Recent months have seen riots, strikes and demonstrations among demobilized soldiers, taxi drivers seeking to reduce monthly payments to their employers, and college students angered at receiving degrees considered less valuable than those promised. [ 02-10-07 0641GMT ]

headline: HK Daily: Hubei Villagers Injured During Protest Against Rubbish Pollution
text: ?The government of Yingshan County within the boundariesof Huanggang City in Hubei Province built a rubbish station in WenquanTownship, causing severe pollution to a local village. Since last month severalhundred villagers have staged a sit-down protest outside the rubbish station,preventing garbage trucks from dumping there, and calling on the government tohalt operations at the rubbish station. On the 3rd of this month authoritiescleared the scene of the protest and dumped rubbish by force using a forklift.At least five villagers were injured in the chaos. In response to an inquiryfrom this paper, a police officer from Wenquan Township's police stationacknowledged that an action to clear the scene did take place that day, butdenied that any villagers were injured, and asserted "It was handled inaccordance with the law." The rubbish station was constructed in 2003. It islocated on a hill more than a hundred meters high at the village of Shawanhe[Sandy Bay River] in Wenquan Township. But the rubbish station has nofacilities to prevent seepage. The piles of rubbish are not disinfected either.Thus a lot of filth and wastewater flows to the foot of the mountain, with avery adverse effect on the lives of the more than 300 villagers who live there. 400 people demonstrate, 2 arrested Beginning at the start of September this year, severaldozen villager households began a self-initiated protest demonstration at therubbish station. They also set up a barrier at an intersection to stop garbagetrucks from entering. Some of the villagers also hung a banner reading,"Garbage dump pollution, ordinary people must survive." They set uptents and started a sit-down protest. For a time there were over 400 protestersthere. According to reports, the villagers' protest caught theattention of local officials. Yingshan County's deputy head Guo Yinghu went tothe garbage dump to find out the situation. Testing of water sources in thevillage of Shawanhe revealed amounts of E. coli bacteria and chloride which farexceed standards. The government subsequently engaged in a dialogue withrepresentatives of the villagers, but the two sides could not reach consensuson the issue of moving the rubbish station. Several villagers hit and injured by forklift Because several hundred villagers were blocking the roadinto the rubbish station, on the 3rd of this month the police station inWenquan Township, along with personnel from an environmental protectionmonitoring and inspection battalion, took action to clear the area. They drovea forklift to forcibly dump garbage, at which time the two sides clashed.Several villagers were hit and injured by the forklift, and two villagersleading the protest were taken away by Public Security personnel. An official at Yingshan County's EnvironmentalProtection Bureau, a woman surnamed Wang, told this paper that construction ofthe rubbish station was part of a government plan, and was completely"reasonable and legal." She acknowledged that the rubbish station hasaffected the local environment. She blamed the chaotic situation in thatvillage for a temporary halt in the transport of rubbish to the rubbishstation. She said the government is handling the matter.
