headline: Large protest in South China, police office blasted in North - Hong Kong paper
text: Text of report by Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao website on 21 July[Unattributed special dispatch: "1,000 People Demonstrate at City Government Office in Guangxi; Scholar: Popular Discontent Could Erupt at Any Time Like Dry Firewood"](Ming Pao) - Several sanguinary conflicts and massive popular protests broke out in succession over the past few days in several inland regions. Following Guizhou's Weng'an and Guangdong's Huizhou, where disturbances happened earlier, Guangxi's Qinzhou City saw as many as 1,000 common people demonstrate outside the city government office a few days ago and at least 10 arrested. In the rubber farmer disturbances in Yunnan's Menglian County, which left two people dead and 55 wounded, there was still an assembly of a few hundred common people by yesterday morning [20 July] and a few hundred public security police were present to keep a lookout to prevent further disturbances. Chinese constitutional scholar Chen Yongmiao pointed out that popular discontent in the inland has reached the point where "dry firewood is everywhere" and would erupt at any time once there is tinder.In Qinzhou City, it is reported, more than 1,000 jobless workers and peasants who had to relocate to make way for new construction gathered in front of the local city government office's entrance on the 15th of this month over state-owned enterprises' ownership system reform, labour contracts, and issues in demolition and relocation due to land requisition that badly affected their livelihood and demanded that the officials resolve them. People Held Back by Armed Police Personnel, At Least 10 ArrestedWhen they were about to go to the city government office to express their support, a few hundred peasants were held back outside the city by Armed Police personnel and a dozen were arrested in the incident. Local officials came forward at that time to have a dialogue with the demonstrating public and promised to resolve the issues; only then did the public peacefully disperse.As for Menglian County's Dongma Town, where rubber farmer disturbances happened on the 19th, the Xinhua News Agency said that by 10.00 a.m. yesterday there was still an assembly of more than 200 rubber farmers outside the Dongma Rubber Company but the incident was already coming to an end.The day before yesterday more than 1,000 rubber farmers at Menglian's Dongma Town - out of discontent over forced land requisition and unfair compensation by the authorities as well as rubber procurement and other issues - went to the local Dongma Rubber Company's entrance to demonstrate and clashed with the more than 100 public security personnel present. Two rubber farmers were killed and another wounded by police fire. At least 55 people were wounded and 20 arrested in the incident. Public Security Bureau Building Explodes in HebeiAccording to information from the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, in addition, Hebei Province's Guangzong County Public Security Bureau exploded on the morning of the ninth of this month and tens of rooms in the building were shattered and at least 10 people wounded. After the incident happened, the local government imposed a news blackout. The explosion is suspected to have been caused by bombs planted by villagers discontented with the public security bureau.In the face of the successive occurrence of several sanguinary conflicts and massive popular protests, Chen Yongmiao indicated: These disturbances did not happen by chance but were caused by some local governments' prolonged violation of popular interests, the gradual diversification of social contradictions, and the failure to defuse contradictions between the common people and the government through economic development. These contradictions have brought popular discontent to the point where "dry firewood is everywhere" and "could kindle at any time once there is tinder."Source: Ming Pao website, Hong Kong, in Chinese 21 Jul 08

headline: HK Daily: Protest in Beijing Against Pollution From Waste-Incineration Factory
text: PKJP Caption: Protesters confront the police at Chaoyang Beilu (internet picture). ? ? ? ? ? ? ? The first week after the end of the Beijing Olympic Games, a fairly large-scale mass demonstration took place yesterday in Changying and Guanzhuang Areas of Beijing's Chaoyang District. More than 100 residents gathered and demonstrated on Chaoyang North Road and protested against the severe pollution to the environment and by the government's waste incineration factory, which has poisoned the residents of the region. The demonstration stopped the traffic of Chaoyang North Road for three hours. The authorities ordered a large batch of police officers to be on the alert. It is claimed that beating incidents have occurred. Burning 1,600 Tons of Waste DailyThe reason for the demonstration is that a strong foul odor has emanated from the large waste processing factory near Changying and Guanzhuan Areas, and the level of carcinogen, such as dioxin, found in its incinerated waste is 10 times higher than the average. A resident of Bolin Aiyue Community in Chaoyang District said that in addition to a medical incinerator, the factory's incinerators burn more than 1,600 tons of domestic waste everyday. The toxic dioxin produced by the incinerators has made hundreds of thousands of residents live breathing the poisonous gas. It is reported that the residents have been complaining about this issue for many years, but the government has not made an explanation yet. Moreover, the authorities planned to construct million square meters of low-cost housing and two-limit housing (imposing limit on the housing price and space). Some demonstrators said that the government did not consider the health and safety of the ordinary people at the grassroots level when it enacted the policy. They now stand forward to express their opinions is not for themselves but for the heath of the people who will move into the community in the future. The report claimed that there were nocasualties when police dispersed the crowd. Jishou railway transportationresumed normal operations after protesters and onlookers left the site. It isreported that several hundred police and armed police clashed with students,leaving 20 people injured. The young boy fell from a building andbroke his legs since he thought the textile factory called the police to catchhim. This Ningbo official said that nobody was injured during the protest. (Seevernacular file: mp0906b.pdf) Attachments:

headline: SCMP: Investors Riot as Get-rich Scheme Fails in Hunan
text: Nine people were detained in two days of riots between armed police and thousands of investors protesting against banned investment schemes, the Xiangxi prefecture government in Hunan province said yesterday.The protesters blocked main roads and trains in Jishou, the seat of the prefecture, on Wednesday and Thursday to demand government action after a finance-raising property development company failed to pay investors the high interest rates it had promised, according to a statement on the prefectural government website.It said protesters left the scene after provincial vice-governor Xu Xianping and other leaders rushed to Jishou on Thursday in a bid to defuse tension. Rail and road services had reopened.The website said executives of the Fuda Property Development Company were "under control", apparently referring to their detention, and officials would investigate to help investors get their money back.It said provincial armed forces chief Wang Xiaorong had arrived in Jishou to oversee public security and armed police dealing with the demonstrations. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said at least 50 protesters had been injured and 20 people detained, including a local news photographer. But officials said no one had been injured and police had detained only nine "lawless people".The centre said yesterday morning that 5,000 People's Liberation Army soldiers from the Hunan military region had been sent to Jishou to patrol the railway station and downtown area.It said the unrest indicated the extent of underground fund-raising activities in the region in which up to 150,000 people had invested in illegal schemes in the prefecture of 2 million people.Netizens in Xiangxi said many residents, even civil servants, the unemployed and elderly had put money into such schemes because of a lack of other investment opportunities and low interest payments by banks.A research report posted on a Tianya.com forum said local officials had encouraged private companies to expand through public fund-raising but had failed to set up monitoring systems. It said that between 2004 and 2006 at least 50 companies had raised at least 20 billion yuan (HK$22.82 billion) illegally for various projects with promises to pay investors 30 per cent interest monthly. But in June, the prefectural government banned civil servants from participating in such schemes, causing a withdrawal of investment funds of at least 300 million yuan in July and early last month. That caused an immediate financial crisis for some companies, with some closing down and others forced to decrease interest rates. That angered many people.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English -- Website of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper; URL: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Police fire shots at protesters in central China, injure 5: watchdog
text: HONG KONG, Sept. 22 -- Hundreds of students and teachers clashed with police in central China's Sichuan Province last week where gunshots were fired but no one was killed, a human rights watchdog said Monday.About 500 students and teachers from a music conservatory in the capital Chengdu gathered after three teachers, who had reported to police about a fight between several office staff and a citizen, were themselves beaten up by office staff last Thursday, the Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.The Hong Kong-based watchdog said the protesters surrounded the office and clashed with about 100 police officers.A police chief fired several shots when the situation started to get out of control, dispersing the crowd and leaving five people injured during the scuffle, the center said.No mainland media has reported on the incident.==Kyodo

headline: HK Center: Zhejiang Workers Block Highway, Company Stock Trading Suspended
text: This center has learned that the China Printing & Dyeing Holding Limited (stock number 200511864G), a company listed in Singapore with 3,000 workers, is facing bankruptcy and has not paid workers for six months. More than 1,000 workers staged a demonstration yesterday [ 8 October], blocking the Jinke bridge highway in Zhejiang's Shaoxing city. As a result, the company issued an urgent announcement yesterday on suspending its stock trading for 1400 hours. The global financial turmoil is impacting China's economy. Some of the enterprises that depend on banks overseas and funds raised by the public at home will go bankrupt, increasing the danger of social turmoil in China.This center has been informed that more than 1,000 workers blocked the Jinke bridge highway since nine o'clock yesterday morning, paralyzing traffic that involved over 100,000 people. Hundreds of public security officers were on guard along the highway but no conflicts occurred. The protesters dispersed at around?one o'clock in the afternoon. The company issued an urgent notice to the Singapore Stock Exchange at two o'clock yesterday afternoon on suspending its stock trading for 1400 hours. The company is one of the largest dyeing mills in China. Faced with capital shortages recently, the company is likely to go bankrupt in the near future. The company has failed to pay workers' salaries for one to six months and is also behind in payment of 200 million yuan to suppliers. High level officials of the company have disappeared and they might have left the country.There are reports saying that China will subscribe to $200 billion of US treasury bonds, which has evoked great attention of the people at home. China has been criticized for the management and use of its foreign exchange reserves. The global financial turmoil has seriously impacted Chinese enterprises that depend on lending from overseas banks. Bankruptcy of these enterprises will lead to large numbers of workers losing their jobs, which will further aggravate turmoil in China. [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:

headline: HK Center: Zhejiang Residents Besiege Police Station for Mishandling of Traffic Accident
text: This center has learned that an unrest took place last night [ 13 October] in Zhejiang's Yiwu, where over 1,000 residents besieged the police station and smashed vehicles in protest against a foreigner beating a local resident. Hundreds of anti-riot police were dispatched to the scene to guard against any possible turmoil. The Yiwu Choucheng Police Station confirmed the incident but refused to disclose which country the foreigner came from. This center has learned that around 1930 hours last night, a foreigner knocked down a local resident on a motorbike while he was driving a car and dashing through the red light near the Honglou Guesthouse in Chouzhou Road. Instead of extending an apology, the foreigner used his cell phone to hit the resident's head, making him bleed all over his face. The move evoked anger of the masses, who overturned the foreigner's car and started to smash it. Hundreds of police rushed to the scene to save the foreigner. When learned that the foreigner was released instead of being detained, over 1,000 residents besieged the Choucheng Police Station that was responsible for handling the incident, demanding an explanation. The residents dispersed at around 2100 hours. The Choucheng Police Station confirmed the incident but refused to comment on which country the foreigner was from and why the police station did not fine the foreigner for beating the local resident. A staff member of the Honglou Guesthouse told us that the Chouzhou Road, the busiest part of Yiwu city, was sealed for half an hour. The situation was tense when over 1,000 residents gathered there and hundreds of police were on guard. Only a few months are left till the 20th anniversary of the 4 June incident. China's social situation seems to be more or less similar to the one 20 years ago. The greatest similarity is that the people are dissatisfied and have no place to vent their discontent. If an unrest takes place, providing an opportunity for the pent-up grievances to burst out, the masses will take an active part to air their discontent and grievances. [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:

headline: Hong Kong Center: Dongguan Workers Protest for Back Wages; Taiwan Owner Absconds
text: The Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy has learned that around 1,000 workers of the "Hetang Pets Goods Company Limited" in Mulberry Garden of the Eastern District in Dongguan blocked the highway near the city's Liuhua Park on the afternoon of 13 October in protest against arrears of wages, and the Taiwan owner absconding with money. The weather was cold and the workers were shivering under heavy rain. Later, the authorities dispatched more than 100 antiriot police to disperse the workers. Twenty of the workers were arrested and their whereabouts is still unknown. The Banqiao and Yuwu police stations in the Eastern District confirmed the protest. This center has learned that the Taiwan owner of the company suddenly left the city with his money. It is believed that the owner is heavily in debt and he has also not paid his workers for three months. The workers requested the assistance of the city labor management departments in resolving the problem but failed to get any response. For this reason, they started to block the highway from the afternoon of the day before yesterday, bringing thousands of vehicles in the city to a standstill. Many of the workers were shivering amid the wind and rain. At around 1500 hours, the authorities dispatched more than 100 antiriot police to disperse the protesters. Twenty of the protesters were arrested and their whereabouts is still unknown. If the arrested workers are not released, some protesters threatened to join workers of other factories to demonstrate in front of the Dongguan government building. The police stations in Banqiao and Yuwu of the Eastern District confirmed the news. There are now 100 million migrant laborers working in all parts of the country and the conflicts between labor and capital have never ceased. Article number one of the Chinese Constitution stipulates that China "is a state led by the working class." The Party Constitution also calls the CPC?the "vanguard of the working class." Up to now, however, the authorities still ban the workers from establishing independent trade union federations to protect their interests. [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- a Hong Kong-based fax service with reports on dissidence, protests, and human rights in China]Attachments:

headline: Chinese protest after money doesn't grow on trees
text: By Ian RansomBEIJING, Oct 20 (Reuters Life!) - Hundreds of people in Beijing scuffled with police outside a government office on Monday, demanding help recovering money from a get-rich-quick scheme involving tree plantations to stem desertification.More than 30,000 investors, mostly retirees, sunk 1.3 billion yuan ($190 million) into a company's tree-planting scheme in the arid northern region of Inner Mongolia, lured by promises of huge returns within eight years.Authorities seized the company's plantations and sued its directors for false advertising after the project was exposed as a failed pyramid scheme, state media reported earlier this year.Police in Beijing detained several protesters for putting up a banner outside the government office, as angry investors from across the country complained of dead trees and lost life savings.Protesters complained the tree plantations on land transferred for the scheme had been left to wither and die after the company was investigated and its assets seized."(The company) planted trees in the desert in Inner Mongolia, then sold them to us. It was supposed to green the desert," said a Beijing resident surnamed Li, who lost about 100,000 yuan in the scheme."The company planted about 720,000 mu (48,000 hectares), but about 40 percent died," Li added.The scheme, which saw some farmers transfer their land to the company to use for its plantations, has shone the spotlight on China's recent rural reforms, which will allow farmers to transfer their land-use rights.China's rural residents own the product of their land but not the land itself and were barred from trading their land-use rights.The state-owned land system, a hangover from the huge collective communes set up under Mao Zedong, is routinely abused by local governments who often seize rural plots to sell to factories or developers, often paying only minimal compensation to farmers.State media have hailed the reforms as a landmark step in guaranteeing farmers' rights and boosting the country's agricultural output through larger, more efficient farms.Protesters welcomed the reforms, but expressed doubts that they would protect rural residents from opportunistic officials."Of course, these reforms are beneficial. But there needs to be more public supervision otherwise people will keep getting cheated," said a Beijing resident who declined to leave his name.($1=6.828 Yuan) (Editing by Bill Tarrant)

headline: SCMP: Collapsed Firms' Staff Demand Pay
text: More than 1,000 mainland workers of the Hong Kong-listed company BEP International marched to demand the authorities help in getting their unpaid salaries.The workers, in uniform and mostly from outside Guangdong province, lost their jobs after BEP International announced it would shut its production line in Shenzhen from today.The workers, some carrying placards, rallied outside the factory in Xixiang village before marching 12km to the government office."Without money, we can't support ourselves in Shenzhen," one migrant said. "We also have to wire money back to support our families."They claimed they had not been paid for two months.The government agreed to help workers contact the company's management, and the protesters left. Officials said they would give the workers 300 yuan (HK$340) each as a subsidy.BEP, founded in 1986, is an export-oriented company. Most of its annual output of five million home appliances was sold to Europe, North America, elsewhere in Asia, the Middle East, Australia and New Zealand. It set up the 22,000 square metre Shenzhen factory in 1992.In Hong Kong, a minor scuffle broke out when about 30 construction workers were stopped by security guards while they were protesting over unpaid wages outside the InterContinental Hotel in Tsim Sha Tsui. The protesters claimed the hotel had not paid them after they finished outer wall decoration works last year.In Central, about 10 self-employed technicians who took jobs outsourced by Tai Lin Radio Services, marched to government headquarters, calling for help in getting their pay. They claimed Tai Lin owed them a total of HK$1.5 million.Tai Lin Radio Services, one of Hong Kong's oldest appliance store chains, folded on Friday with the loss of 260 jobs. Barely a week earlier, U-Right International Holdings, a garment maker and retailer, went into liquidation, costing hundreds of jobs.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English -- Website of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper; URL: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: AFP: Rights Group Says Over 1,000 Chinese Workers Protest Over Unpaid Wages
text: BEIJING, Oct 28, 2008 (AFP) - More than 1,000 textile workers took to the streets in eastern China after their employer apparently fled abroad, leaving four months of wages unpaid, a Hong Kong-based rights group said Tuesday.The workers blocked four streets in downtown Wujiang city, Jiangsu province, for five hours Monday afternoon, the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said. They launched the protest because the owner of their company, Chunyu Textile Company, had suddenly gone missing on Friday, apparently escaping abroad along with members of his family, leaving wages unpaid, the centre said. The protesters only agreed to disperse after a city official emerged, promising to find a solution to their plight. Wujiang officials contacted by AFP Tuesday confirmed a protest had taken place, but declined to go into details. "Some workers from the textile factory took to the street, but I'm not sure how many," said an official with the city Labour and Social Security bureau. It was unclear if the company owner had fled because of economic difficulties linked to the ongoing global economic and financial crisis, which has had a big impact on China's exporters. In the southern Chinese export hub of Dongguan, the owner of a Hong Kong-listed toy factory fled after his company went bust earlier this month, leaving 7,000 workers jobless and owed back pay. Many of those workers protested, forcing the local government to help pay some of the back wages. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: SCMP: Broken Promise Spurs Workers To Protest at Shenzhen Watch Factory
text: Hundreds of workers at a Shenzhen watch factory owned by a Hong Kong company protested yesterday against a broken pledge made by the city's top official to offer them satisfactory compensation.Shenzhen Communist Party Secretary Liu Yupu visited the plant in Xixiang town on Sunday and directly told hundreds of workers that the government would give them a "satisfactory reply" on both their back wages and other losses within a week.Mr Liu had won thunderous applause at the time, one of the witnesses said.However, an official with the municipal Labour Department told the labour representatives yesterday that the workers might get back only part of their severance pay and other compensation the factory owed them, and that the process would probably take a long time.Hundreds of workers at a Shenzhen watch factory owned by a Hong Kong company protested yesterday against a broken pledge made by the city's top official to offer them satisfactory compensation.Shenzhen Communist Party Secretary Liu Yupu visited the plant in Xixiang town on Sunday and directly told hundreds of workers that the government would give them a "satisfactory reply" on both their back wages and other losses within a week.As the march began, around 60 police in riot gear, along with more than 100 other officers and security guards, arrived. The police sealed off the factory's only access road by lining up across it.Hoping to pacify the marchers, the deputy head of the town government, surnamed Ye, went to the factory and told them the liquidator representing their Hong Kong owner - the Peace Mark (SEHK: 0304 , announcements , news ) Group - had refused to deal with mainland authorities.The local labour department had then secured all the remaining assets before beginning an assessment of their value for an auction, Mr Ye was quoted by a worker as saying.Mr Ye called on them to wait until next Wednesday for another arbitration result."Someone said 'We have no choice'," one of the workers said. "Apparently all we can do is just wait and wait. But most of us won't give up until we get back all we deserve."Also, a senior sales official with Guangdong-based Midea Appliances, a manufacturer of home appliances that employs about 70,000 people on the mainland, warned that the company might lay off staff this year in the wake of the worldwide economic downturn.[Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English -- Website of Hong Kong's most prominent non-PRC-owned English-language daily newspaper; URL: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Kyodo: China Worker Protest Ends After Gov't Vows To Foot Bill for Unpaid wages
text: Hong Kong, Oct. 30 Kyodo -- A municipal government in China's Fujian Province has agreed to settle unpaid wages of thousands of workers of a factory closed down there this week, after hundreds of workers rallied outside the factory, a former employee said Thursday.The former personnel department head, who identified himself by surname Jiang, told Kyodo News by telephone that hundreds of workers who had rallied outside the factory in Xiamen since it was shut down Monday have dispersed after the city's government promised to foot the bill for their wages.The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy had earlier reported that more than 1,000 workers had staged daily rallies outside the factory demanding for unpaid wages after the factory's owner fled Xiamen last Saturday."The rally was not as serious as it was reported," Jiang said. "The government promised to pay up workers' wages for September in one or two days. No workers are rallying outside the factory now that public security officers have taken control of the factory."Jiang said unpaid wages amounted to more than 10 million yuan ($1.46 million) for the months of September and October.He said the owner is in the United States and out of contact, but he would not say why the factory was closed or why the owner left China.Star Group, the company that runs the 6,000-worker factory, is said to be Hong Kong-funded, with an annual export value of about $50 million. The factory made toys, handicrafts and garden ornaments for major U.S. stores.It has been speculated that the global financial crisis might be behind the factory's shutdown.News about Hong Kong-funded factories collapsing in southern China's industrial hotbeds has been reported frequently in recent weeks and it is estimated that millions of workers all over China might lose their jobs next year.Toymaker Smart Union Group in Dongguan and watchmaker Peace Mark in Shenzhen -- both cities in Guangdong Province -- went out of business amid the financial crisis. In both cases, local governments stepped in to settle the unpaid wages to end workers' protests. [Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English -- English service of Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]

headline: Chinese police attacked by angry residents
text: BEIJING (AP) - Protesters attacked a police station in southern China after a motorcyclist died in a crash after a traffic officer threw a radio at him, a state news agency reported.Some 400 protesters gathered at the station, threw stones and set fire to a police car as about 2,000 spectators watched Friday, the report said. The violence lasted until early Saturday.Traffic police had set up a checkpoint Friday morning to catch illegal motorists in Shenzhen, a city that borders Hong Kong, the Xinhua News Agency reported.When the motorcyclist, Li Guochao, tried to drive past the checkpoint without stopping, an employee of the traffic post threw a radio at Li, 31, who lost control and hit the pole. He later died of his injuries, Xinhua said.Li's family carried his body to a local police station, Xinhua said. The protesters attacked about two hours later.The protesters attacked a police station, although the traffic post was run by a separate city government department, according to Xinhua. The report did not mention any other deaths or injuries.The traffic post employee who threw the radio, identified only by the surname Lai, was detained by police, Xinhua said.

headline: Displaced residents protest outside military's headquarters
text: More than 100 people staged a peaceful protest in front of the Central Military Commission building in inner Beijing yesterday morning, against what they said was unfair compensation for moving out of their neighbourhood.Protesters were aware the rally would not yield any immediate results, given past experiences, but they insisted on taking to the street."We are not troublemakers and we just want to see our dear senior military officials to tell them what their subordinates have done in suppressing us little guys," said one protester, Wang Zhenhua . The 57-year-old is a former resident of East Diaoyutai, where about 140 families were evicted two years ago to make way for high-rises owned by the military.Police quickly turned up and told the protesters to go home or face detention for "disrupting normal social order"."I told you this is not the place for a gathering. Staying here any longer won't solve your problems, but will certainly get all you folks into serious trouble," a police officer told the crowd assembled at the building on West Changan Avenue.The protesters said the government had failed to keep its promise to give them priority in buying government-sponsored budget houses."They paid us from 5,000 to 10,000 yuan (HK$5,700 to $11,400) a square metre to move out, but the market price in 2006 was at least 15,000 yuan a square metre. It's a pure robbery backed up by the police machine," said Zhang Wei , a leader of the group of protesters.They said they had raised the issue with district and municipal officials but had not received a reply. The group were going to stage a protest during the Olympics, which prompted officials to say they would have an answer if they kept quiet during the Games. But they still have not had a reply. "They admitted the promise was just a lie, but what we can do about it?" Mr Zhang said.The group has applied to protest 13 times, but each was denied by police without any specific reason.A police officer was seen recording every person in the gathering with a digital camera, with another officer telling him to get closer to record their voices too.Many protesters appeared to be scared by the camera, but Mr Wang was unfazed. "I don't really care about what they do afterwards, for I did not do anything wrong, but require my legal rights being protected," he said. "If they don't think I have suffered enough, they can do whatever they have got to do."

headline: China Daily: Reform in Taxi Management
text: The unreasonable taxi management system is the root cause of recent strikes by taxi drivers, says an article in China Youth Daily. The following is an excerpt:On Nov 10, hundreds of taxi drivers in Sanya, Hainan province, halted operations and gathered at the gate of the municipal government, demanding the government solve problems such as high management fees, rampancy of unlicensed taxies and contract terms.These problems have already troubled taxi drivers in Chongqing, who went on strike earlier this month. It is no secret that high management fees or the charges paid to taxi companies are a common problem in domestic taxi industry. If this problem could only be solved through strikes, the cost would be too high and it would also set a bad example for solving social problems.The taxi could have been independently run by a taxi driver and the management of taxies could have been fully handled by the passenger transport office affiliated with the local traffic management bureau. It is similar to what a small business owner should do when opening a shop- he or she only needs to register at the local government department, that monitors the administration of industry and commerce. They do not need to be attached to any trade association or to pay any management fees.From this perspective, taxi companies are a completely unnecessary link. It is this link that extracts quite a large part of the money earned by taxi drivers with their hard toil. However, this unreasonable system has been here for years and across the country backed by certain interest groups.As taxi companies repeatedly raise the management fees despite dissatisfaction of taxi drivers and the rising conflicts between the two sides, extreme reactions such as strikes are inevitable. We urgently need a reform of taxi management in China.[Description of Source: Beijing China Daily Online in English -- Website of China's official English-language newspaper, offering both the website of the paper and additional content; URL: http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/]

headline: Protest in China flares over land dispute: state media
text: Up to 2,000 people attacked a local Communist Party headquarters in northwest China early Tuesday in protest over a land dispute, state media reported.The protesters smashed windows of the party building and nearby cars in Longnan city, Gansu province, in a dispute over the forced demolition of homes and eviction of tenants, Xinhua news agency reported.About 30 people protesting the eviction plans gathered at the party headquarters Monday morning but the crowd swelled to about 2,000 throughout the day and into the evening, it said.Xinhua gave few other details but an Internet posting from someone claiming to be a Longnan resident said the crowd was dispersed early on Tuesday morning after police were called in.The official state media did not offer further details on the dispute, but government-backed land grabs, often in collusion with developers, have become one of China's most sensitive social issues.According to the Internet posting, locals in Longnan were refusing to relocate to make way for a new government building that was being partially funded by earthquake relief funds from a recent quake that hit southwest China.Gansu neighbours Sichuan province, which was at the epicentre of the May 12 earthquake that left up to 88,000 people dead or missing.sai/kma/jw

headline: Xinhua: 2nd Ld-Writethru: Taxi Operation Resumes After Brief Stoppage in Suburbs of China's Chongqing
text: CHONGQING, Nov. 19 (Xinhua) -- Taxi drivers resumed work Wednesday afternoon in the Yongchuan suburb of southwest China's Chongqing Municipality after briefly protesting a government plan to increase the number of taxis for fear of competition.Yongchuan authorities set up a meeting for Thursday morning with the nine taxi companies in the district.Drivers went on strike to demonstrate opposition to a proposal by the local government to raise the number of cabs from 330 to 430, saying it would cut in to their business.A cab driver, surnamed Yao, told a Xinhua reporter that his boss asked him to stop work in the morning and asked him to resume work at noon."There are some misunderstandings among the tax drivers on the policy to increase taxi numbers," said Hu Longyi, director of the district's public transportation and traffic administration."We have given detailed explanations to the taxi companies and they agreed to resume operation," he said.According to the official, the local government made the decision to put more taxis on the road as 330 was "far from enough" to meet demand."We have received complaints from citizens that it is hard to get taxis in Yongchuan, especially at rush hours," said Hu.From 2000 to 2004, the district added only 75 cabs and there has been no more added since 2004.According to a survey conducted by the administration in August, 800 out of 1,000 respondents supported the taxi increase policy.The district held a public hearing on the subject a month ago, in which 30 representatives from various parts of the community participated."All the representatives voted for the [taxi increase] policy except the two from the taxi companies," said an official with the administration who declined to give his name. "I think basically, they were afraid of more competition."The district, about 60 km west of the city center, has a population of more than 350,000.[Description of Source: Beijing Xinhua in English -- China's official news service for English-language audiences (New China News Agency)]

headline: UPDATE 1-Chinese cabbies clash with police in Guangzhou
text: (Changes dateline, adds details from Xinhua, paragraphs 6-7)BEIJING, Nov 24 (Reuters) - Hundreds of taxi drivers in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou clashed with police on Monday during a protest against the alleged beating of a cabbie by an official, at a time of rising tensions in the trade.Several hundred cabbies were shown scuffling with police on Hong Kong's Cable TV during a march to protest the weekend beating of a local taxi driver by three drunken men, one of whom claimed to be a city official, according to local media reports.Authorities denied any of the attackers had been officials, Cable TV reported."Our pressure is great and our burden heavy," one driver told Cable TV. A number of cabbies were shown being dragged to waiting vehicles by police officers.The head of Guangzhou's public security bureau Wu Sha was quoted by the China News Agency as saying the drivers should remain calm, while pledging to resolve the matter in accordance with the law.The protesters had dispersed by noon on Monday, China's official Xinhua news agency said, adding that police had detained the three who had beaten the cab driver.The man who had claimed to be a government official was actually a businessman who had been "sent for labour education for two years for mass gambling" in 2000, Xinhua said, without giving the source of its information.In recent weeks, a wave of taxi strikes has broken out across China against unlicensed competition, high fuel prices and rising rental fees, which have threatened drivers' livelihood as the Chinese economy comes under strain from the financial turmoil.Other signs of recent social strains include mass factory closures and protests by newly laid-off workers in China's industrial heartland of Guangdong province, riots in northwestern Gansu province and a mass petition in Beijing.Protests and incidents of "mass unrest" have risen in China in recent years, sparked by a slew of grievances including official abuse of power, land seizures and labour disputes. (Reporting by James Pomfret in Hong Kong and Ian Ransom in Beijing; Editing by Mark Trevelyan)

headline: BBC Monitoring China Social Unrest Briefing 13-26 Nov 08
text: The following is a roundup of reports on social unrest in China as available to BBC Monitoring between 13 and 26 November 2008Gansu riotOn 17-18 November, a large-scale riot took place in Longnan city, Gansu Province, where thousands of people attacked the municipal government and clashed with police, state media reported.Thousands attack Longnan city governmentProvincial newspaper Gansu Ribao quoted the Longnan municipal government as saying on 20 November that the riot was triggered when representatives of 30 households in Dongjiang town, Wudu District, went to the municipal Communist Party committee headquarters on the morning of 17 November to demand an official response to the housing, land and livelihood problems that would result from the relocation of the Longnan municipal government to another county.The crowd steadily grew during the course of the day. At midnight, over 2,000 people began throwing stones and bottles, injuring 69 armed policemen, two public security policemen and three journalists. Some rioters then forced their way into the compound. They vandalized two government buildings, smashed 12 vehicles and set fire to the guards room and the reception room. They also seized a fire engine that had come to put out the fire and drove it into the compound, but were later stopped by the policemen.After this, the police took "resolute measures" to disperse the crowd and restored order by 4 a.m., according to the government.(Gansu Daily website, Lanzhou, in Chinese 21 Nov 08)Government buildings, cars set on fireAccording to the Longnan government, at 8 a.m. on 18 November, people gathered again at Communist Party headquarters. At about 10.30 a.m., some of them charged into the compound, attacking the police with iron shovels, sticks, bricks and stones and smashing three sedan cars.After the police took "coercive measures" and made some arrests, rioters gathered again and set fire to three government buildings and the 12 sedan cars that had been destroyed the night before. In addition, they also destroyed and burned seven police cars. The government said a total of 110 office rooms and 22 vehicles were vandalized and burned during the incident.The local government said that 30 rioters had been placed under criminal detention. Xinhua news agency quoted an official as saying the police initially detained 110 people, but later released 80.(Gansu Daily website, Lanzhou, in Chinese 21 Nov 08; Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1606 gmt 20 Nov 08)Allegations of police brutality, death of protestersAllegations of police brutality were made by overseas-based Chinese-language media sources.According to the human rights website Canyu.org, the police used tear gas to disperse the crowd of over 10,000 people, and beat several protesters to death.US-based Chinese-language news website Dajiyuan (The Epoch Times) reported that six or seven protesters were killed and more than 100 were injured.(Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Nov 08; Dajiyuan website, New York, in Chinese 19 Nov 08)Mass protests in BeijingOver 1,000 protest against investment scamsOn the morning of 19 November, over 1,000 people gathered in front of the Beijing municipal government building to protest against two major investment scams, US-based Chinese-language news website Dajiyuan reported.Most of the protesters were victims of the "illegal fundraising" case involving the Yilin Forest Group. There were also victims of the Xinguoda investment scam, which allegedly involved Li Xiaoyong, son of ex-Premier Li Peng, the report said.More than 100 policemen were dispatched to the scene but no clashes took place, it was reported.Xinhua news agency reported the protest and said it involved "nearly 400" petitioners. The Xinhua report did not mention the companies involved in the scams.(Dajiyuan website, New York, in Chinese 19 Nov 08; Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1811 gmt 19 Nov 08)Demonstration at Ministry of Justice against forced demolitionAlso on 19 November, over 100 victims of forced demolition staged another demonstration outside the Ministry of Justice, US-based Chinese-language news website Boxun reported.The protesters blocked traffic, but were soon dispersed by the police, the report said.(Boxun website, USA, in Chinese 19 Nov 08)Ex-bank employees protest redundancies, demand compensationOn 20 November, over 1,000 former bank employees from across the country gathered in front of the State Letters and Complaints Bureau in Beijing to demand reasonable compensation, Dajiyuan website reported.The protesters were ex-employees of three major state-owned banks - Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), China Construction Bank and Agricultural Bank of China. They said they had been forced to take redundancies and were not given reasonable compensation, the report said.According to the US-funded radio station Radio Free Asia (RFA), altogether 3,000 ex-bank employees from various parts of the country gathered in Beijing to protest. The police arrested the protesters' representatives and thwarted their plan to protest at the Great Hall of the People on 21 November.(Dajiyuan website, New York, in Chinese 20 Nov 08; Radio Free Asia website, Washington DC, in Chinese 21 Nov 08)Beijing rounds up "beggars", "vagrants"Following the mass protests in the capital, the Beijing municipal government announced on 20 November that, as it was getting cold, the government would provide accommodation and meals to "vagrants and beggars", Xinhua reported.The municipal "relief administration centre" would "reinforce street patrols, check the identities of vagrants and beggars, and provide them with beds and meals". It would also "provide tickets home" once the identities were confirmed.According to Radio Free Asia, on 19 November, a large number?of policemen arrested hundreds of petitioners from the letters and complaints offices of the State Council and the National People's Congress.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0908 gmt 20 Nov 08; Radio Free Asia website, Washington DC, in Chinese 20 Nov 08)Taxi, bus driversShantou: Over 1,000 taxi drivers protest against unlicensed cabsOn 20 November, over 1,000 angry taxi drivers went on strike in Shantou city, Guangdong Province, to protest against competition from unlicensed operators, Guangzhou-based newspaper Nanfang Dushi Bao reported.Drivers complained that officials tacitly allowed unlicensed taxis to operate in return for a monthly fee for each vehicle.Over 200 drivers parked their cars outside the municipal government building, creating a five-hour traffic jam in the city centre, according to Hong Kong newspaper Ta Kung Pao.Some protesters overturned law-enforcement vehicles. A large number of anti-riot police arrived at the scene and made some arrests, Canyu.org reported.On 21 November, the taxi drivers organized small groups to smash unlicensed taxis in the streets.(Nanfang Dushi Bao website, Guangzhou, in Chinese 21 Nov 08; Ta Kung Pao, Hong Kong, in Chinese 21 Nov 08; Wen Wei Po, Hong Kong, in Chinese 22 Nov 08; Canyu.org, in Chinese 21 Nov 08)Guangzhou taxi drivers protest beating, clash with policeOn the night of 23 November, over 100 taxi drivers in Guangzhou, capital city of Guangdong Province, staged an overnight protest against the beating of a fellow driver, Xinhua news agency reported.The protest was triggered by a dispute between a taxi driver and another driver at a toll-gate. The latter was joined by his two passengers in beating up the cabby, one of whom claimed to be an official in the local government, the report said.More than 100 taxi drivers crowded at the scene, some of whom were so angry that they stopped passing vehicles, Xinhua reported.The protesters clashed with the police on the morning of 24 November, according to Nanfang Wang, the official news website for Guangdong province.The police detained the three people involved in the beating, and denies any of them were officials, it was reported.According to Beijing Youth Daily, on the night of 24 November, more than 100 taxi drivers took coordinated action to intercept and smash unlicensed taxis in the streets of Guangzhou.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1412 gmt 24 Nov 08; Nanfang Wang, Guangzhou, in Chinese 24 Nov 08; Beijing Youth Daily, Beijing, in Chinese 26 Nov 08)Chaozhou: 600 taxi drivers go on strikeOn 16 November, about 500-600 taxi drivers in Chaozhou city, Guangdong Province, went on strike, Guangzhou-based newspaper Yangcheng Wanbao reported.Over 100 taxi drivers parked their cars outside the Chaozhou municipal government compound, demanding the authorities restrict the number of taxis operating in the city and putting a limit on the quota of taxi licenses issued, the report said.(Yangcheng Wanbao website, Guangzhou, in Chinese 17 Nov 08)Chongqing: 300 taxi drivers go on strike in YongchuanOn 19 November, about 300 taxi drivers went on strike in Yongchuan District, Chongqing Municipality, Xinhua news agency reported.The drivers were protesting against the district government's plan to increase the number of taxis, the report said.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in Chinese 0805 gmt 19 Nov 08)Hubei: Taxi drivers in Suizhou city protest over feesOn 24 November, all of the 500-600 taxi drivers in Suizhou city, Hubei Province, went on strike against a new government-imposed license fee, human rights website Minsheng Guancha (Civil Rights and Livelihood Watch) reported.A group of taxi drivers gathered near the city's railway station, and another group petitioned at the the municipal government, the report said.(Minsheng Guancha website, Suizhou, in Chinese 24 Nov 08)Yunnan bus drivers strike in protest over new rulesOn 18 November, some 500 bus drivers in Dali Bai Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province, went on strike, trapping a large number of passengers at the stations and disrupting normal traffic, Xinhua news agency reported.The drivers were protesting against the new rules released by the government-owned Dali Transport Company (Group), which said the buses' ownership would be transferred from the individual drivers to the company.The strike ended on 21 November after the local government agreed to order the transport company to abolish the new rules, it was reported.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1652 gmt 20 Nov 08)Shaanxi: Xi'an taxi drivers urge crackdown on illegal pedicabsOn 24 November, over 100 taxi drivers staged a strike in Zhouzhi County, Xi'an Municipality, Shaanxi Province, local newspaper Xi'an Wanbao (Xi'an Evening News) reported.The protesters demanded that the local government crack down on illegal pedicab operators, it was reported.(Xi'an Wanbao, Xi'an, in Chinese 25 Nov 08)Workers' protestsShenzhen laid-off workers block road to seek back payOn 12 November, over 100 laid-off workers from a corrugated paper company in Futian District, Shenzhen city, Guangdong Province, blocked traffic in protest over unpaid wages, according to Guangzhou-based newspaper Yangcheng Wanbao.Some protesters threw stones and bricks at the police officers. Four policemen and four company staff members were slightly injured in the clash, the report said.But Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily reported that the clash was triggered when the police used force to disperse the 300 protesting workers, hitting them with batons and injuring more than 10 of them.(Yangcheng Wanbao website, Guangzhou, in Chinese 13 Nov 08; Oriental Daily, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Nov 08)Over 300 workers stage protest in Shenzhen to demand unpaid wagesOn 18 November, over 300 workers from a Hong Kong-invested clothing factory staged a protest in Shenzhen's Longgang District to demand payment of approximately 6.2m yuan in unpaid salaries and compensation, according to Hong Kong newspaper Wen Wei Po.Some workers clashed with police at the scene, the report said.(Wen Wei Po, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Nov 08)Guangdong: Dongguan toy workers protest layoffs, smash police carsOn 25 November, more than 500 workers of a leading toy producer in Dongguan, Guangdong Province, smashed police vehicles and company offices when protesting against the company's decision to lay them off, Xinhua news agency reported.The workers rallies at the gate of the Hong Kong-invested Kaida Toy Corp. Ltd, which employs 8,000 people. About 1,000 police and security guards were called in to disperse the crowd. This infuriated the protestors, who overturned a police vehicle, smashed at least four police motorbikes and broke windows and computers in the company's office building, the report said.The report quoted witnesses as saying that at least five workers were injured in the clash.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0510 gmt 26 Nov 08)Yunnan: Migrant workers demand back payOn 24 November, several dozen migrant workers gathered outside the Yunnan branch office of GOME Electronic Appliances Holdings Limited, China's top electronics retailer, to demand that the company repay unpaid wages, local newspaper Chuncheng Wanbao reported.According to Hong Kong newspaper Ming Pao, GOME's Kunming branch office issued a statement claiming that the workers were owed payment not from GOME, but from a property management company.(Chuncheng Wanbao, Kunming, in Chinese 25 Nov 08, Ming Pao, Hong Kong, in Chinese 25 Nov 08)Jiangxi: 500 workers protest against layoffsOn 25 November, about 500 workers blocked a road outside Huayi Compressor Co., China's biggest compressor manufacturer, in Jingdezhen, Jiangxi Province, after the company laid off 300 workers, according to the Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy.(Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 26 Nov 08)TeachersShaanxi teachers protest in Beijing About 500-600 laid-off teachers from Weinan city, Shaanxi Province, broke through blockades set up by local police authorities and staged a mass sit-in demonstration at the State Letters and Complaints Bureau in Beijing on 17 November, according to human rights website Minsheng Guancha.They urged the government to address their livelihood problems, but talks between their representatives and the bureau produced no concrete results, the report said.(Minsheng Guancha website, Suizhou, in Chinese 21 Nov 08)Shandong: 4,000 laid-off teachers stage sit-in at provincial governmentOn 26 November, 4,000 laid-off teachers from across Shandong Province gathered outside the provincial Communist Party committee headquarters in the provincial capital Ji'nan and staged a mass sit-in demonstration, Minsheng Guancha reported.This was the biggest action to date by teachers in Shandong Province, the report said. Earlier this month, on 12 November, over 1,000 laid-off teachers petitioned the local government in Jining Prefecture.(Minsheng Guancha website, Suizhou, in Chinese 26 Nov 08)PunishmentsShanghai cop killer executedOn 26 November, Yang Jia, a 28-year-old man who had been convicting of killing six police officers in Shanghai on 1 July this year, was executed in Shanghai with the approval of the Supreme People's Court, Xinhua reported.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 0325 gmt 26 Nov 08)Six jailed over Guizhou riotOn 14 November, the People's Court of Weng'an County in Guizhou Province sentenced six people to jail terms of up to 16 years for their involvement in the 28 June Guizhou riot, Xinhua reported.Up to 30,000 people were involved in the protest, prompted by a controversial police report on the death of a 17-year-old schoolgirl.Two alleged gang members were convicted of arson and attacking local authority buildings and sentenced to 16 years and 15 years respectively. Four others were convicted of attacking state authorities or disturbing social order, and received sentences of two to seven years, the report said.The court would continue to hear cases of suspects involved in the unrest, said Xinhua.(Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1136 gmt 14 Nov 08)Other reportsChongqing: Villagers clash with mining company over environmental damageOn 21 November, villagers in Shanqing village, Kaixian County, clashed with staff of a mining company, resulting in "light injuries" and damage to cars and equipment, local newspaper Chongqing Wanbao (Chongqing Evening News) reported.Villagers complained that the mining operation by the Chongqing Zhongyuan Coal Mining (Group) Co., Ltd. had damaged the environment, leading to landslides and water shortages, the report said.According to Radio Free Asia, over 20 villagers who went to obstruct the mining operation on 21 November were badly beaten up by thugs hired by the company, leading to severe injuries. Over 1,000 people later gathered at the mine to protest, smashing and setting fire to vehicles including police cars.(Chongqing Wanbao, Chongqing, in Chinese 23 Nov 08; Radio Free Asia website, Washington DC, in Chinese 24 Nov 08)Guangdong: 200 ex-soldiers clash with police in ZhanjiangOn 21 November, 200 recently demobilized soldiers gathered in front of the municipal government of Zhanjiang city, Guangdong Province, to protest against the alleged beating of three of their fellow ex-soldiers in a police station, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported.About 400 anti-riot policemen arrived at the scene and clashed with the protesters, injuring at least 30 of them. All protesters were arrested, the report said.(Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong,?in Chinese 26 Nov 08)Guangdong: Shanwei villagers protest on hit-and-run policemanOn 14 November, hundreds of villagers blocked a road in front of the Honghaiwan Public Security Bureau in Shanwei, Guangdong Province, to demand the authorities deliver a policeman involved in a hit-and-run accident, Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily reported.An on-duty policeman killed a villager and seriously injured another in a traffic accident in the early hours of 13 November. When family members of the dead came to the police station later that day to seek an explanation, the police ignored them and later all the policemen disappeared.On 14 November, villagers rallied at the police bureau to demand action. The Shanwei City Public Security Bureau later said that the culprit had surrendered himself and the authorities had paid compensation to family members of the dead, the report said.(Oriental Daily News website, Hong Kong, in Chinese 16 Nov 08)Orange farmers surround offices of Shanghai newspaperOn 18 November, more than 100 angry farmerssurrounded the offices of Shanghai's official newspaper Jiefang Ribao to vent their anger at a report published by Xinwen Chenbao (a subsidiary newspaper of Jiefang Ribao) that local oranges were infested by parasitical insects, Hong Kong newspaper Wen Wei Po reported.Claiming the article had adversely affected orange sales and their livelihoods, the farmers demanded that the newspaper buy all their oranges. Over 30 policemen were dispatched to the scene. Additionally, local sources were quoted as saying that a Shanghai TV station was also surrounded by orange farmers.(Wen Wei Po, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Nov 08)Zhejiang: Street vendors clash with police, overturn cars in WenzhouOn the evening of 12 November, dozens of street traders in Wenzhou city, Zhejiang Province, clashed with about 10 law enforcement officers who attempted to stop them from selling on the streets, Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily reported.Liu Yuhe, deputy head of Wenzhou Administrative Law Enforcement Bureau, as well as bureau assistant Lu Ke, arrived on the scene to intercede but were besieged by angry street vendors. Other protesters overturned two government vehicles and pulled another onto the road, paralysing traffic for over two hours, the report said.(Oriental Daily News website, Hong Kong, in Chinese 15 Nov 08)Heilongjiang farmers block entrance to provincial governmentOn the morning of 19 November, over 90 farmers from Chaoyang Township, Xiangfang District, Harbin city, protested in front of the Heilongjiang provincial government and blocked its main entrance for nearly an hour, local news website Dongbei Wang (Northeast.cn) reported.Several protesters climbed over the railings and tried to charge at the main door. The police arrested three protesters and sentenced to a 10-day administrative detention, the report said.(Dongbei Wang website, Harbin, in Chinese 21 Nov 08)[Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in English -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]
source_human: Beijing Youth Daily, Beijing, in Chinese
notes_human: Provincial newspaper Gansu Ribao quoted the Longnan municipal government as saying on 20 November that the riot was triggered when representatives of 30 households in Dongjiang town, Wudu District, went to the municipal Communist Party committee headquarters on the morning of 17 November to demand an official response to the housing, land and livelihood problems that would result from the "relocation of the Longnan municipal government to another county".

headline: China: Taxi Drivers Conduct Non-violent Strikes in Two Cities in Guangdong
text: GUANGZHOU, Nov. 28 (Xinhua) -- Hundreds of taxi drivers took to the streets over the past two days in two southern Chinese cities in Guangdong Province, demanding the government limit the number of licensed taxis and resolutely crack down on unlicensed cabs.They rallied on a square outside the municipal government building in Chaozhou since Thursday morning, but no violence was reported, said Su Yangqin, head of the Chaozhou Municipal Transport Bureau.The city mayor Tang Xikun met with representatives of taxi drivers Thursday evening, he said."Most of the taxis are operating today, though more than 10 taxis and their drivers are still gathered on the square," he said.A protesting driver surnamed Wang said they had staged a strike earlier this month, but the government had not fulfilled their promises to crack down on illegal taxis or stop issuing more license plates to taxis."Therefore we have to go on strike again," he said.Licensed drivers have complained too many taxis were operating in Chaozhou and unlicensed taxis stole their business.The city has about 800 licensed taxis, according to Su."In response, we have decided not to issue new license plates to taxis in the coming two years. We will also take resolute measures to crack down on the illegal taxis," he said.Su also revealed that about 30 drivers had complained to the government that they were unwilling to go on strike, but they were forced to do so by some other drivers. Yet Su did not say how the government will treat the issue.In the neighboring city of Jieyang, taxi drivers have rallied on a square in front of a railway station since Wednesday morning, protesting the same issues as those in Chaozhou.They also called for establishing a drivers' association and reducing rental fees paid to the taxi companies.Almost 100 taxis and their drivers were still gathered on the square on Friday and dozens of drivers also protesting outside the municipal government building.No violence was reported, but protesting drivers complained that about four or five of them were hurt by police on Wednesday afternoon when they were told to disperse. The local police declined to comment on Friday."We are protecting our legitimate interests and not asking too much. I think it won't be difficult for the government to satisfy our demands," a driver surnamed Liu told Xinhua.The city reports 895 licensed taxis, said Yang Jianwei, deputy head of the Jieyang Municipal Transport Bureau."We haven't added more taxis since 2003, and actually, we have no plan to increase the number of taxis even now," Yang said. "The reason why we do so is just to protect their interests and reduce competition."He said local authorities have been committed to cracking down on illegal taxis in recent years."We will continue to resolutely crack down on unlicensed taxis," he said.In addition, Yang said the local authorities would help set up a taxi drivers' association to offer a channel for them to file their complaints.He said some drivers had been forced to take part in the strike, like those in Chaozhou, but he did not elaborate.Huang Shuili, vice mayor of Jieyang, said the government was studying other demands by the taxi drivers.Strikes are rare in China, but several taxi strikes have been reported this month in Chongqing, Sanya, Yongdeng and Shantou over high rental fees and unlicensed taxis.Taxi drivers in those towns resumed work after the local authorities promised to reduce rental fees and resolutely crack down on illegal taxis. [Description of Source: Beijing Xinhua in English -- China's official news service for English-language audiences (New China News Agency)]
notes_human: Taxi: Hundreds of taxi drivers took to the streets over the past two days in two southern Chinese cities in Guangdong Province, demanding the government limit the number of licensed taxis and resolutely crack down on unlicensed cabs.      12/23: After offering a few carrots, the Chinese government on Monday revealed it has not lost its skills in wielding the stick to calm down any possible agitations arising out of rising joblessness across the country. It has announced formation of a special police force to crush mafia-like gang operations.The move comes a day after the central government in Beijing has ordered provincial governments to create new job opportunities for migrant workers returning to villages from closed factories in south China. It is obviously worried that jobless workers might indulge in agitations and demonstrations to vent resentment.

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 2-3 December 2008
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from Ming Pao ,?Wen Wei Po ?for the period 2-3 December 2008: Losing warrants investors arrested after clashing with police in Beijing -- Respected, independent Hong Kong daily Ming Pao (2/12) reports that over 40 individual investors protested in front of the headquarters of the China Securities Regulatory Commission [CSRC] at around 9am (Beijing time) on 1 December.? The daily reports that individuals claimed to have lost money by investing in China Southern Airlines warrants, and demanded the CSRC cover part of their losses.? According to the article, all protesters were arrested after clashing with police at cordons around the CSRC building.? (See vernacular file: mp1202a.pdf) Shaoguan Smelter Factory workers protest unilateral contract change -- PRC-owned Hong Kong daily Wen Wei Po (3/12) dispatch by Ao Min-hui reports that several hundred Guangdong workers gathered outside a smelting factory in Shaoguan on 1 December over an unresolved labor dispute.? The daily reports that Shaoguan Smelter Factory management unilaterally changed the employment contracts of workers, leading to the protest.? Shaoguan government representatives were dispatched to mediate the dispute and the workers dispersed peacefully after blocking the road for two hours.? (See vernacular file: wwp1203b.pdf) Attachments:

headline: AFP: Nearly 1,000 Workers Stage Sit-In at Shanghai Factory
text: SHANGHAI, Dec 9, 2008 (AFP) - Nearly 1,000 workers staged a rare sit-in protest outside a Shanghai factory Tuesday in the latest sign of strain in China's manufacturing industry, which has been hit hard by the economic crisis.The workers were protesting because managers at the computer and telecoms equipment factory had failed to fully pay at least six months' worth of overtime, bonuses and benefits, one of the organisers said. "I know the economy is bad now, but none of us can stand being badly treated by our employers," organiser Ding Xiaohua said. The phone went unanswered at Huan Hsin Group, which owns the factory, when AFP tried repeatedly to contact them Tuesday. Several police cars blocked the gate of the factory in southwest Shanghai while about a dozen officers surveyed the peaceful protest, which began on Monday. Workers said Tuesday afternoon that some colleagues had been taken away by police, while a cordon was set up to separate the striking workers from bystanders. "It's near the end of the year, most of us are migrant workers so we want to go back home with some cash so we can enjoy the spring festival," said Ding, a 24-year-old technician. The most important holiday in China, the spring festival is in late January. Ding said the workers were each entitled to a 1,200-yuan (175-dollar) bonus after working from June to September in temperatures greater than 40 Celsius (104 Fahrenheit). The summer bonus was supposed to be in addition to their basic 960 yuan monthly salary. Ding said managers were also paying just over half of the overtime workers were entitled to and were failing to pay the full required amount for medical insurance. On the sidelines of the protest, a factory worker named Xiao Chen said he was torn about joining the sit-in. "I don't know if I should join them," he said. "I can't afford to lose this job even though the pay is low. "If I quit I don't think I can find another job before the spring festival because many factories are closing down or laying off workers." China's export growth has slowed significantly with many factories in the industrialised south closing and the economy expanding at the slowest rate in five years. [Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: China detains human rights activists
text: Chinese police have detained dozens of human rights protesters who had gathered outside the country's Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Beijing.China is planning to publish its first assessment of human rights in the coming months.However, about 40 people gathered outside the ministry protested that ordinary Chinese citizens would not be allowed to contribute to it.The event came on the 60th anniversary of the UN Declaration of Human Rights.

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 16-18 December 2008
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from Boxun Xinwen Wang, Wen Wei Po for the period 16-18 December 2008: 500 PRC activists protest forced demolition of households and deprivation of labor rights -- Boxun Xinwen Wang (17/12) of the New York Boxun News Network, a US-based, self-described "non-profit" Chinese language news website "relying on a loose network of volunteer reporters," notes that on 17 December more than 500 mainland activists staged a mass demonstration in front of the Beijing city government building to protest against forced demolition of households and deprivation of labor rights -- and to demand protection of human rights.? According to the website, the two-hour protest -- monitored by security forces at the scene -- ended peacefully.? (To be processed as CPP20081218718002) Guangdong province feels the strain of local plant closures -- PRC-owned Hong Kong daily Wen Wei Po (16/12) notes that figures released by government organs in Guangdong province indicate that there were at least 117 enterprise closures and cases of unpaid salaries in the city of Dongguan alone in September and October.? According to the report, in response, governments of various counties in the Zhujiang Delta have dispatched ad hoc groups to closely monitor local enterprises, factories -- and their owners.? (See vernacular file: wwp1216t.pdf) Police beatings lead to separate protests in Shandong and Hunan provinces -- The Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy (18/12), a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, protests and human rights violations in China, reports that on 17 December, over 100 people in Liaocheng city (Shandong province), stormed Liaocheng city government offices to protest and demand justice in the case of a pedicab driver whose relatives suspect was beaten to death by law enforcement officers during his detention at the city's administrative law enforcement bureau.? In a separate incident, on 16 December, furious relatives of a man in Hunan province, who was beaten unconscious by police, blocked key local?highways in protest, paralyzing traffic.? (To be processed as CPP20081218702014); (See vernacular file: ic1218.pdf) Attachments:

headline: Home owners confront with police in South China over transformer substation
text: Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)[Xinhua: "Home Owners Confront With Police in S.China Over Transformer Substation Construction"]GUANGZHOU, Jan. 1 (Xinhua) - More than 500 home owners in south China's Guangdong Province were confronting with police on Thursday evening, asking the authority to stop building a transformer substation near their residential area.They started to confront with more than 150 policemen at the west gate of Junjing Garden Residential Quarter from 9 p.m., according to a resident surnamed Wang.Some home owners were drumming at around 10 p.m. and shouted to the police outside the gate, asking them to leave and release the home owners who were detained for protesting the building of the transformer substation, Xinhua reporter saw at the scene.China Southern Power Grid and Guangzhou Municipal Power Supply Bureau, who were in charge of the construction, had not explained to the home owners, Wang said.There was no scuffle between the two sides.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1559 gmt 1 Jan 09

headline: HK Report: 2,000 Veterans Storm Shaanxi Government Office, Clash With Police
text: Although the Chinese Lunar New Year is approaching, activities regarding the protection of rights are still continuing among the people. Nearly?2,000 retired, military-turned cadres recently gathered outside the provincial government office to protest. They were not satisfied with their poor benefits, difficult lives and numerous years of fruitless petitioning. At one time, the protestors tried to charge through the gates of the provincial government office and clashed with the police. According to a source, one of the veterans was suspected to be overly worked up and unfortunately died from a heart attack.According to sources, the petitioning veterans came from Xi'an, Xian Yang and other cities. Most of them joined the military during the 1950s and 1960s. Some of them have even participated in the Korean War. After being?discharged from the military, they were transferred to work in the enterprises. They are?over 60-years old now; the oldest is over 80-years old.One Person Died of Heart Attack While?En Route?to?HospitalLast Thursday [ 8 Jan 2009] morning, nearly 2,000 retired, military-turned cadres protested outside the provincial government office with banners. They requested to talk to the provincial leaders directly. They were shouting slogans and singing the military songs of their time. At one time, the protestors wanted to storm into the?provincial government office. The relevant authorities immediately dispatched police officers to the scene, and a helicopter was even dispatched for surveillance. Several scuffles occurred between the protestors and police. According to sources, during the scuffles, a 67-year old veteran suffered a heart attack and died while en route to the hospital. Local media "Xi'an Ribao" has reported this incident. It reported that after the government's secretary general and other officials had a meeting lasting almost three hours with the representatives of the petitioning veterans, most of the petitioners dispersed in the afternoon. The report emphasized that the government has always attached importance to the difficulties faced by the veterans and has taken a series of improvement measures. URL: http://www.the-sun.com.hk/]Attachments:

headline: Hong Kong centre reports migrant workers blocking roads in six Chinese cities
text: [multiple events] Text of report by Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy on 16 January[Information Centre for Human Rights & Democracy: "Migrant Workers Owed Back Wages Block Roads in Six Cities"]Migrant Workers Blocking Roads Yesterday, Today in Hohhot, Wuhan, Nanjing, Chengdu, Xian, NanningOur centre has learned that road-blocking incidents involving hundreds of migrant workers occurred in at least six cities yesterday and today, affecting transportation for hundreds of thousands of people. Here are the statistics:Time Location Number of People CauseMorning 16 Jan Outside Hohhot municipal government building 500 Construction company owes migrant workers back wagesMorning 16 Jan Donghu Development Area, Wuhan 300 Area developer owes migrant workers unpaid wagesMorning 15 Jan Qingyang Area, Chengdu 500 Real estate company owes migrant workers back wagesAfternoon 15 Jan Jiefang South Road, Nanjing 500 Nanjing High and New Tech Industry Development Zone owes migrant workers back wagesAfternoon 15 Jan North 2 Ring Road, Xian 200 Demonstrations by migrant workers owed back pagesAfternoon !5 Jan Zhonghua Road, Nanning 500 Construction company owes migrant workers back wagesMigrant workers demonstrating outside the municipal government building in Hohhot today held banners with the wording "Repay Me My Money Earned by Hard Toil, I Have to Go Home for the Chinese New Year."In addition, our centre has learned that the Propaganda Department under the CCP Central Committee issued a circular 15 January banning the reporting of road-blocking by migrant workers. Over the past 10 days, the authorities not only have strictly limited the reporting of demonstrations by the formal news media, but have also tightened controls on the Internet. Just about every posting on demonstrations that brought traffic to a standstill has been taken down.Source: Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 16 Jan 09
