headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. In the southern island province of Hainan, riots by thousands of villagers forced the authorities to relocate a coal-fired power plant. Villagers at a nearby township stormed and destroyed a government building in anger at the plant's relocation to their locale. Residents in southwest Chongqing destroyed police cars and attacked police in a protest against an unpopular district merger. In southwest Sichuan, two Tibetans died after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule. Environmental protests Hainan villagers fight police in coal plant protest 11 April: Riot police used tear gas, pepper spray and batons on nearly 10,000 residents from Yinggehai village as they continued a month-long protest outside the township government in Foluo, Ledong County, Sanya, Hainan, over the construction of a coal-fired power plant, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Over 1,000 protesters still took to the streets on 14 April, despite a district construction committee official's pledge that construction would be halted pending an environmental impact assessment. 18 April: Villagers from Xiaoganqing suddenly attacked and killed a deputy police chief and injured 15 officers on 18 April with machetes and clubs amid protests against a mining operation, the state-run Yunnan Net website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 13, 16, 17 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13, 15 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 14, 16 Apr 12; Yunnan Wang, Kunming, in Chinese 20 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Apr 12) Rural unrest Guangdong/Jilin/Heilongjiang/Inner Mongolia: Land disputes 9 April: Police clashed with over 1,000 villagers from Fangniu, Beian County, petitioning the government in Mudanjiang City, Heilongjiang, amid ongoing protests since 22 March to demand the return of requisitioned farmland that had turned fallow, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 12, 19 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 23 Apr 12) Urban unrest Chongqing: Protests over district merger continue 10-12 April: A statement by the Chongqing government on the official local news portal Cqnews.net said that around 10,000 residents in the former Wansheng District of Chongqing protested for three days against the merger of the affluent district with poorer Qijiang County in October. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The shop owners rioted and destroyed buildings in clashes with police. 19 April: Over 20 employees at a shopping centre in Xi'an, Shaanxi, blocked a road after the authorities ignored their petitions to stop a property developer's takeover of the mall site, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 23 Apr 12) Strikes elsewhere 12-13 April: The entire workforce at a factory owned by Swiss company Nestle in Laixi City, Qingdao, Shandong, went on strike for two days to demand higher wages, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. Some workers resumed work on the evening of 13 April and production returned to normal on 14th. 13 April: Nearly 2,000 workers at an iPhone factory run by Taiwanese firm Foxconn in Taiyuan, Shanxi, went on strike to demand pay rises, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The strike ended after the management agreed to their demands. 14 April: Around 3,000 striking workers at a garment fabric factory run by the Hong Kong Ocean Group in Sigang Township, Zhangjiagang City, Jiangsu, blocked roads and clashed with police in protests against receiving less pay, Molihua.org reported. 20 April: Nearly 1,000 workers deployed from Shenzhen in Guangdong Province to work at a factory in Shangluo City in northwest Shaanxi run by BYD, a Shenzhen-based maker of solar cells, went on strike in protest at not receiving higher Shenzhen-level wages, Molihua.org reported. Police later drove back hundreds of employees blocking a highway to the factory. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 17, 23 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 14 Apr 12) Henan/Hubei: Taxi, bus driver strikes 17 April: Over 1,000 taxi drivers in Kaifeng City, Henan, clashed with police in protests to demand the return of private operating licences taken away by the government, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 18 April: Around 100 striking bus operators in Jingzhou, Hubei, protested against a ban from 15 April on size and weight restrictions on vehicles crossing four bridges in danger of collapse, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The two were cousins. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 19 Apr 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protesters arrested 5 April: Around 60 Tibetans were arrested for protesting against a visiting communist party working group staging patriotic re-education and anti-Dalai Lama campaigns at the Quzha (name as transliterated) Monastery, Litang County, in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 14 April: Around 100 Tibetan residents of Andu Village, Upper Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) County, were injured when they were attacked by police during a protest against an alleged land grab by officials, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Security forces arrested 15 young Tibetans in Doda village, Dzatoe Township, Dege County, Kardze Prefecture, suspected of putting up posters and distributing leaflets in the area calling for Tibetan independence, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Over 1,000 Tibetans petitioned the local government to protest against the police's closure on 14 April of a Tibetan civic welfare group for being an "illegal organization" involved in political activities as well as the arrest of over 200 members from the organization in Datongma (name as transliterated) District, Kardze County, Kardze Prefecture, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. Over a dozen people were injured in clashes with police. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 16, 18, 23 Apr 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]

(Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 23 Apr 12) Strikes elsewhere 12-13 April: The entire workforce at a factory owned by Swiss company Nestle in Laixi City, Qingdao, Shandong, went on strike for two days to demand higher wages, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. Some workers resumed work on the evening of 13 April and production returned to normal on 14th. 13 April: Nearly 2,000 workers at an iPhone factory run by Taiwanese firm Foxconn in Taiyuan, Shanxi, went on strike to demand pay rises, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The strike ended after the management agreed to their demands. 14 April: Around 3,000 striking workers at a garment fabric factory run by the Hong Kong Ocean Group in Sigang Township, Zhangjiagang City, Jiangsu, blocked roads and clashed with police in protests against receiving less pay, Molihua.org reported. 20 April: Nearly 1,000 workers deployed from Shenzhen in Guangdong Province to work at a factory in Shangluo City in northwest Shaanxi run by BYD, a Shenzhen-based maker of solar cells, went on strike in protest at not receiving higher Shenzhen-level wages, Molihua.org reported. Police later drove back hundreds of employees blocking a highway to the factory. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 17, 23 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 14 Apr 12) Henan/Hubei: Taxi, bus driver strikes 17 April: Over 1,000 taxi drivers in Kaifeng City, Henan, clashed with police in protests to demand the return of private operating licences taken away by the government, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 18 April: Around 100 striking bus operators in Jingzhou, Hubei, protested against a ban from 15 April on size and weight restrictions on vehicles crossing four bridges in danger of collapse, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The two were cousins. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 19 Apr 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protesters arrested 5 April: Around 60 Tibetans were arrested for protesting against a visiting communist party working group staging patriotic re-education and anti-Dalai Lama campaigns at the Quzha (name as transliterated) Monastery, Litang County, in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 14 April: Around 100 Tibetan residents of Andu Village, Upper Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) County, were injured when they were attacked by police during a protest against an alleged land grab by officials, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Security forces arrested 15 young Tibetans in Doda village, Dzatoe Township, Dege County, Kardze Prefecture, suspected of putting up posters and distributing leaflets in the area calling for Tibetan independence, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Over 1,000 Tibetans petitioned the local government to protest against the police's closure on 14 April of a Tibetan civic welfare group for being an "illegal organization" involved in political activities as well as the arrest of over 200 members from the organization in Datongma (name as transliterated) District, Kardze County, Kardze Prefecture, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. Over a dozen people were injured in clashes with police. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 16, 18, 23 Apr 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]

headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. In the southern island province of Hainan, riots by thousands of villagers forced the authorities to relocate a coal-fired power plant. Villagers at a nearby township stormed and destroyed a government building in anger at the plant's relocation to their locale. Residents in southwest Chongqing destroyed police cars and attacked police in a protest against an unpopular district merger. In southwest Sichuan, two Tibetans died after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule. Environmental protests Hainan villagers fight police in coal plant protest 11 April: Riot police used tear gas, pepper spray and batons on nearly 10,000 residents from Yinggehai village as they continued a month-long protest outside the township government in Foluo, Ledong County, Sanya, Hainan, over the construction of a coal-fired power plant, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Over 1,000 protesters still took to the streets on 14 April, despite a district construction committee official's pledge that construction would be halted pending an environmental impact assessment. 18 April: Villagers from Xiaoganqing suddenly attacked and killed a deputy police chief and injured 15 officers on 18 April with machetes and clubs amid protests against a mining operation, the state-run Yunnan Net website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 13, 16, 17 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13, 15 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 14, 16 Apr 12; Yunnan Wang, Kunming, in Chinese 20 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Apr 12) Rural unrest Guangdong/Jilin/Heilongjiang/Inner Mongolia: Land disputes 9 April: Police clashed with over 1,000 villagers from Fangniu, Beian County, petitioning the government in Mudanjiang City, Heilongjiang, amid ongoing protests since 22 March to demand the return of requisitioned farmland that had turned fallow, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 12, 19 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 23 Apr 12) Urban unrest Chongqing: Protests over district merger continue 10-12 April: A statement by the Chongqing government on the official local news portal Cqnews.net said that around 10,000 residents in the former Wansheng District of Chongqing protested for three days against the merger of the affluent district with poorer Qijiang County in October. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The shop owners rioted and destroyed buildings in clashes with police. 19 April: Over 20 employees at a shopping centre in Xi'an, Shaanxi, blocked a road after the authorities ignored their petitions to stop a property developer's takeover of the mall site, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. In the southern island province of Hainan, riots by thousands of villagers forced the authorities to relocate a coal-fired power plant. Villagers at a nearby township stormed and destroyed a government building in anger at the plant's relocation to their locale. Residents in southwest Chongqing destroyed police cars and attacked police in a protest against an unpopular district merger. In southwest Sichuan, two Tibetans died after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule. Environmental protests Hainan villagers fight police in coal plant protest 11 April: Riot police used tear gas, pepper spray and batons on nearly 10,000 residents from Yinggehai village as they continued a month-long protest outside the township government in Foluo, Ledong County, Sanya, Hainan, over the construction of a coal-fired power plant, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Over 1,000 protesters still took to the streets on 14 April, despite a district construction committee official's pledge that construction would be halted pending an environmental impact assessment. 18 April: Villagers from Xiaoganqing suddenly attacked and killed a deputy police chief and injured 15 officers on 18 April with machetes and clubs amid protests against a mining operation, the state-run Yunnan Net website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 13, 16, 17 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13, 15 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 14, 16 Apr 12; Yunnan Wang, Kunming, in Chinese 20 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Apr 12) Rural unrest Guangdong/Jilin/Heilongjiang/Inner Mongolia: Land disputes 9 April: Police clashed with over 1,000 villagers from Fangniu, Beian County, petitioning the government in Mudanjiang City, Heilongjiang, amid ongoing protests since 22 March to demand the return of requisitioned farmland that had turned fallow, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 12, 19 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 23 Apr 12) Urban unrest Chongqing: Protests over district merger continue 10-12 April: A statement by the Chongqing government on the official local news portal Cqnews.net said that around 10,000 residents in the former Wansheng District of Chongqing protested for three days against the merger of the affluent district with poorer Qijiang County in October. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The shop owners rioted and destroyed buildings in clashes with police. 19 April: Over 20 employees at a shopping centre in Xi'an, Shaanxi, blocked a road after the authorities ignored their petitions to stop a property developer's takeover of the mall site, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 23 Apr 12) Strikes elsewhere 12-13 April: The entire workforce at a factory owned by Swiss company Nestle in Laixi City, Qingdao, Shandong, went on strike for two days to demand higher wages, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. Some workers resumed work on the evening of 13 April and production returned to normal on 14th. 13 April: Nearly 2,000 workers at an iPhone factory run by Taiwanese firm Foxconn in Taiyuan, Shanxi, went on strike to demand pay rises, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The strike ended after the management agreed to their demands. 14 April: Around 3,000 striking workers at a garment fabric factory run by the Hong Kong Ocean Group in Sigang Township, Zhangjiagang City, Jiangsu, blocked roads and clashed with police in protests against receiving less pay, Molihua.org reported. 20 April: Nearly 1,000 workers deployed from Shenzhen in Guangdong Province to work at a factory in Shangluo City in northwest Shaanxi run by BYD, a Shenzhen-based maker of solar cells, went on strike in protest at not receiving higher Shenzhen-level wages, Molihua.org reported. Police later drove back hundreds of employees blocking a highway to the factory. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 17, 23 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 14 Apr 12) Henan/Hubei: Taxi, bus driver strikes 17 April: Over 1,000 taxi drivers in Kaifeng City, Henan, clashed with police in protests to demand the return of private operating licences taken away by the government, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 18 April: Around 100 striking bus operators in Jingzhou, Hubei, protested against a ban from 15 April on size and weight restrictions on vehicles crossing four bridges in danger of collapse, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. Police later drove back hundreds of employees blocking a highway to the factory. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 17, 23 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 14 Apr 12) Henan/Hubei: Taxi, bus driver strikes 17 April: Over 1,000 taxi drivers in Kaifeng City, Henan, clashed with police in protests to demand the return of private operating licences taken away by the government, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 18 April: Around 100 striking bus operators in Jingzhou, Hubei, protested against a ban from 15 April on size and weight restrictions on vehicles crossing four bridges in danger of collapse, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The two were cousins. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 19 Apr 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protesters arrested 5 April: Around 60 Tibetans were arrested for protesting against a visiting communist party working group staging patriotic re-education and anti-Dalai Lama campaigns at the Quzha (name as transliterated) Monastery, Litang County, in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 14 April: Around 100 Tibetan residents of Andu Village, Upper Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) County, were injured when they were attacked by police during a protest against an alleged land grab by officials, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Security forces arrested 15 young Tibetans in Doda village, Dzatoe Township, Dege County, Kardze Prefecture, suspected of putting up posters and distributing leaflets in the area calling for Tibetan independence, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Over 1,000 Tibetans petitioned the local government to protest against the police's closure on 14 April of a Tibetan civic welfare group for being an "illegal organization" involved in political activities as well as the arrest of over 200 members from the organization in Datongma (name as transliterated) District, Kardze County, Kardze Prefecture, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. headline: Xinhua: Order Restored After Protest Against District Merger Ends in Chongqing
text: People began to rally in several places in the Wansheng economic development zone of Qijiang district on Tuesday and the protest swelled to nearly 10,000 people on Wednesday, blocking expressway exits and roads and smashing and setting fires to police cars.Police fired tear gas on Wednesday morning, trying to disperse the protestors.By Wednesday night, protestors left and traffic resumed in the district.No one died in the rally though there were small clashes between the police and protestors. Those who suffered minor injuries in the clashes were all sent to hospitals.A local official who requested anonymity said the protest was triggered by an earlier merger between the former Wansheng district and Qijiang county, which were regrouped as Qijiang district at the end of last year.Disgruntled residents from Wansheng complained that their business was affected after the merger while some worried about the lowering of their healthcare standard.Chongqing Mayor Huang Qifan rushed to the scene to persuade the protestors to return, and the municipal government issued a guide on Wednesday, promising the smooth economic development of Wansheng by offering preferential policies to former Wansheng residents.Officials from the Chongqing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) said the protest was related to the people's economic interests, and had no connection with the case of Wang Lijun, Chongqing's former police chief, or the investigation of Bo Xilai, former Party chief of Chongqing.[Description of Source: Beijing Xinhua in English -- China's official news service for English-language audiences (New China News Agency)]

Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 13, 16, 17 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13, 15 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 14, 16 Apr 12; Yunnan Wang, Kunming, in Chinese 20 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Apr 12) Rural unrest Guangdong/Jilin/Heilongjiang/Inner Mongolia: Land disputes 9 April: Police clashed with over 1,000 villagers from Fangniu, Beian County, petitioning the government in Mudanjiang City, Heilongjiang, amid ongoing protests since 22 March to demand the return of requisitioned farmland that had turned fallow, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 12, 19 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 23 Apr 12) Urban unrest Chongqing: Protests over district merger continue 10-12 April: A statement by the Chongqing government on the official local news portal Cqnews.net said that around 10,000 residents in the former Wansheng District of Chongqing protested for three days against the merger of the affluent district with poorer Qijiang County in October. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The shop owners rioted and destroyed buildings in clashes with police. 19 April: Over 20 employees at a shopping centre in Xi'an, Shaanxi, blocked a road after the authorities ignored their petitions to stop a property developer's takeover of the mall site, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 23 Apr 12) Strikes elsewhere 12-13 April: The entire workforce at a factory owned by Swiss company Nestle in Laixi City, Qingdao, Shandong, went on strike for two days to demand higher wages, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. Some workers resumed work on the evening of 13 April and production returned to normal on 14th. 13 April: Nearly 2,000 workers at an iPhone factory run by Taiwanese firm Foxconn in Taiyuan, Shanxi, went on strike to demand pay rises, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The strike ended after the management agreed to their demands. 14 April: Around 3,000 striking workers at a garment fabric factory run by the Hong Kong Ocean Group in Sigang Township, Zhangjiagang City, Jiangsu, blocked roads and clashed with police in protests against receiving less pay, Molihua.org reported. 20 April: Nearly 1,000 workers deployed from Shenzhen in Guangdong Province to work at a factory in Shangluo City in northwest Shaanxi run by BYD, a Shenzhen-based maker of solar cells, went on strike in protest at not receiving higher Shenzhen-level wages, Molihua.org reported. Police later drove back hundreds of employees blocking a highway to the factory. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 17, 23 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 14 Apr 12) Henan/Hubei: Taxi, bus driver strikes 17 April: Over 1,000 taxi drivers in Kaifeng City, Henan, clashed with police in protests to demand the return of private operating licences taken away by the government, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 18 April: Around 100 striking bus operators in Jingzhou, Hubei, protested against a ban from 15 April on size and weight restrictions on vehicles crossing four bridges in danger of collapse, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The two were cousins. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 19 Apr 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protesters arrested 5 April: Around 60 Tibetans were arrested for protesting against a visiting communist party working group staging patriotic re-education and anti-Dalai Lama campaigns at the Quzha (name as transliterated) Monastery, Litang County, in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 14 April: Around 100 Tibetan residents of Andu Village, Upper Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) County, were injured when they were attacked by police during a protest against an alleged land grab by officials, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Security forces arrested 15 young Tibetans in Doda village, Dzatoe Township, Dege County, Kardze Prefecture, suspected of putting up posters and distributing leaflets in the area calling for Tibetan independence, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. 15 April: Over 1,000 Tibetans petitioned the local government to protest against the police's closure on 14 April of a Tibetan civic welfare group for being an "illegal organization" involved in political activities as well as the arrest of over 200 members from the organization in Datongma (name as transliterated) District, Kardze County, Kardze Prefecture, RFA reported, quoting Tibetan exiles. Over a dozen people were injured in clashes with police. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in English 16, 18, 23 Apr 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]

The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 14, 23 Apr 12) Strikes elsewhere 12-13 April: The entire workforce at a factory owned by Swiss company Nestle in Laixi City, Qingdao, Shandong, went on strike for two days to demand higher wages, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. Some workers resumed work on the evening of 13 April and production returned to normal on 14th. 13 April: Nearly 2,000 workers at an iPhone factory run by Taiwanese firm Foxconn in Taiyuan, Shanxi, went on strike to demand pay rises, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 18 Apr 12) Ethnic minorities Sichuan: Two Tibetans self-immolate 19 April: Two Tibetans - Choephak Kyab and Sonam - died several hours after burning themselves in protest over Chinese rule near the Dzamthang Jonang Monastery in Dzamthang (Chinese: Rangtang) County, Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. headline: Kyodo: Protesters Against Hainan Power Plant Ransack Gov't Property: Group
text: Photographs posted on the Jasmine Places website, which frequently reports on mass protests and strikes in China, show groups of people gathering in what was said to be Ledong Li Autonomous County in Hainan on Monday, with some holding a banner reading ''No to coal power. Protect the environment.'' Protesters reportedly ransacked the county government building, leaving the twisted office plates on the ground.Other protesters stormed into the government building in Foluo township, ransacking the place and a nearby staff quarters, the website said.China Guodian Group, a state-owned enterprise, planned to build a 1,400-megawatt coal-burning power plant in Yinggehai township in southwestern Hainan this year, with operation set to begin in 2014.Despite opposition from various villages, the government announced last week that it will move ahead with the project.Massive protests broke out Wednesday and Thursday, during which riot police fired tear-gas canisters at protesters, leaving more than 60 people injured, including children who suffered tear-gas effects inside a kindergarten and a primary school, the website said.As the situation was contained with police reinforcement Friday, the government decided to move the planned power plant to Foluo township, 2 kilometers north of Yinggehai.The announcement failed to appease the villagers and led to the protests Monday at Ledong county and Foluo township, reportedly with thousands of people taking part.Protesters stormed into the government building in Foluo township after waiting for hours but failed to meet township officials, the website said.The Ledong county government, which oversees the townships, could not be reached for comment.[Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English -- English service of Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]
