headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. In the southern island province of Hainan, riots by thousands of villagers forced the authorities to relocate a coal-fired power plant. Villagers at a nearby township stormed and destroyed a government building in anger at the plant's relocation to their locale. Residents in southwest Chongqing destroyed police cars and attacked police in a protest against an unpopular district merger. In southwest Sichuan, two Tibetans died after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule. Environmental protests Hainan villagers fight police in coal plant protest 11 April: Riot police used tear gas, pepper spray and batons on nearly 10,000 residents from Yinggehai village as they continued a month-long protest outside the township government in Foluo, Ledong County, Sanya, Hainan, over the construction of a coal-fired power plant, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Over 1,000 protesters still took to the streets on 14 April, despite a district construction committee official's pledge that construction would be halted pending an environmental impact assessment. 18 April: Villagers from Xiaoganqing suddenly attacked and killed a deputy police chief and injured 15 officers on 18 April with machetes and clubs amid protests against a mining operation, the state-run Yunnan Net website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 13, 16, 17 Apr 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13, 15 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 14, 16 Apr 12; Yunnan Wang, Kunming, in Chinese 20 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 20 Apr 12) Rural unrest Guangdong/Jilin/Heilongjiang/Inner Mongolia: Land disputes 9 April: Police clashed with over 1,000 villagers from Fangniu, Beian County, petitioning the government in Mudanjiang City, Heilongjiang, amid ongoing protests since 22 March to demand the return of requisitioned farmland that had turned fallow, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 12, 19 Apr 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Canyu.org, in Chinese 18 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 23 Apr 12) Urban unrest Chongqing: Protests over district merger continue 10-12 April: A statement by the Chongqing government on the official local news portal Cqnews.net said that around 10,000 residents in the former Wansheng District of Chongqing protested for three days against the merger of the affluent district with poorer Qijiang County in October. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Apr 12; Chongqing Net, Chongqing, in Chinese 12 Apr 12) Beijing: Petitioners protest outside Central Political and Law Commission 16 April: Police took away more than 40 petitioners from Tianjin, Shandong, Henan, Hubei, Jiangsu and other provinces who protested for nearly two hours outside the Communist Party of China Commission of Politics and Law in Beijing, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported. They chanted: "Down with corruption in the judiciary, give us back human rights" and other slogans. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Guangdong/Shaanxi: Shop owner protests 19 April: Several thousand shop owners in Baoan District, Longhua Township, Shenzhen, Guangdong, blocked a main road after police failed to prevent injuries to over 20 owners who were resisting forcible eviction by a demolition crew, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 19 Apr 12; Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 21 Apr 12) Anhui: Disabled tricycle drivers petition government Recently, around 40-50 disabled tricycle drivers rode to the Anhui provincial government in Hefei to petition for higher fuel subsidies, the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders reported on 17 April. (Chinese Human Rights Defenders website, USA, in Chinese 17 Apr 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Factory strikes 10 April: All staff at Hong Kong-owned garment factory Rich Square in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand a pay rise, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. 12 April: The entire workforce at the Japanese-invested Rhythm watch factory in Daning Village, Humen, Dongguan, Guangdong, went on strike to demand better benefits, Molihua.org reported. 18-22 April: Over 1,700 employees at the Taiwan-invested Lacquer Craft Furniture Co in Dalingshan Township, Dongguan, went on strike for several days to protest against the company's move to dismiss staff who had worked at the factory for more than 10 years before its relocation to Jiaqing in Zhejiang Province, Molihua.org reported. headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 18 April
text: The following highlights are from Tung Fang Jih Pao and Ping Kuo Jih Pao for the period 18 April 2012: Two Seperate Hainan Towns Protest Power Plant Construction: On 18 April 2012, popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao reported that over 10,000 residents of Foluo Town, Ledong County, Hainan Province stormed the town government's office on 16 April after learning from the Ledong County Government's official website that a controversial power plant was going to be relocated to Foluo.? The plant had originally been planed to be located in?Yingge Town, approximately two kilometers away from?Foluo, but officials?proposed moving it after Yingge residents protested against the plant's constructions due to their concerns about pollution.? The report said Foluo protesters stormed the government office?where the power plant launch?ceremony?was held after waiting for several hours outside, but finding no officials willing to respond to their petition.? [see vernacular file tfjp0418a.pdf] Taxi Drivers Riot in Henan: Ping Kuo Jih Pao, an independent Hong Kong daily often critical of Beijing, reported on 18 April that a riot occurred in Kaifeng city, Henan Province, on 17 April, afterthe city's taxi drivers staged a strike to protest against the local taxi regulations.? The riot blocked traffic, and a number of taxi drivers were reportedly injured by anti-riot police. Other taxi drivers were reportedly arrested.? [See vernacular file: pkjp0418a.jpg] No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.? ??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline . headline: China social unrest briefing 12-25 Apr 12
text: [multiple events] The last fortnight has witnessed five environmental protests by villagers across China. Villagers in southwest Yunnan killed a police officer and stabbed 15 other police amid fears that mining was damaging local housing. In the southern island province of Hainan, riots by thousands of villagers forced the authorities to relocate a coal-fired power plant. Villagers at a nearby township stormed and destroyed a government building in anger at the plant's relocation to their locale. Residents in southwest Chongqing destroyed police cars and attacked police in a protest against an unpopular district merger. In southwest Sichuan, two Tibetans died after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule. Environmental protests Hainan villagers fight police in coal plant protest 11 April: Riot police used tear gas, pepper spray and batons on nearly 10,000 residents from Yinggehai village as they continued a month-long protest outside the township government in Foluo, Ledong County, Sanya, Hainan, over the construction of a coal-fired power plant, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Over 100 people were injured, including primary school and kindergarten pupils. Villagers fear that sea pollution from the plant will destroy their fishing businesses and farmland. 12 April: Villagers marched to the Foluo government and threw petrol bombs and stones at riot police who were firing tear gas, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The conflict continued until evening. In Sanya, around 1,000 Yinggehai residents and supporters from Sanya protested outside the city government in the evening against the police crackdown. 13 April: Police fired tear gas at several thousand villagers in continued clashes outside the Foluo government, Molihua.org reported. In Sanya, hundreds of people protested outside the city government again and citizens raised funds for Yinggehai village. 16 April: Thousands of residents of Fengtang Village (2 km away from Yinggehai), as well as neighbouring townships, protested outside the Foluo government at state-run China Guodian Corp's plans to relocate the power plant to their area, Molihua.org reported. Protesters stormed the building when officials failed to receive their petition. They destroyed offices on three floors, set off firecrackers, burned files and documents and destroyed entrance signs as well as a government workers' accommodation building. By evening, riot police occupied the township. 17 April: Around 10,000 people continued protests outside the Foluo government before dispersing in the afternoon, Molihua.org reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 16 Apr 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 15, 19 Apr 12) Environmental protests elsewhere 6 April: Police clashed with villagers in Gaolifang Township, Taian County, Anshan City, Liaoning, blocking roads and surrounding the township government building to protest against a foreign-invested nickel plant causing environmental pollution and harm to public health, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Residents told the US-funded Radio Free Asia that the protests were still continuing on 13 April. 9 April: Around 200 residents armed with hoes from the two villages of Shanqugang and Dashitang in Luoping Township, Luoding City, Guangdong, clashed with police and construction workers building a high-voltage cable, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. 13 April: Some 2,000 villagers from Xiamutao, Shiqiao Township, Lianyungang, Jiangsu, brought traffic to a standstill as they clashed with police during a protest against the Whitestone Steel Factory's installation of potentially harmful high-voltage cables directly above their village, The Epoch Times reported. Riot police beat participants as they overturned a police vehicle on a nearby highway. 13-14 April: Around 10,000 residents in Binhai New District, Tianjin, clashed with police and protested at the Dagang Century Plaza calling for the cancellation of a planned Sino-Saudi joint-venture petrochemical polycarbonate plant that began construction in early April, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Over 1,000 protesters still took to the streets on 14 April, despite a district construction committee official's pledge that construction would be halted pending an environmental impact assessment. 18 April: Villagers from Xiaoganqing suddenly attacked and killed a deputy police chief and injured 15 officers on 18 April with machetes and clubs amid protests against a mining operation, the state-run Yunnan Net website reported. The police had tried to persuade the villagers to stop their protest campaign since 12 April outside the government in Renhe Township, Yongsheng County, Lijiang, Yunnan. The villagers feared that the development of a coal mine was endangering their land and demanded to be relocated and compensated. The authorities said the police maintained a high level of restraint and no villagers were injured. The Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said over 100 villagers had attacked the police after mistaking the deputy police chief's warning shots fired in the air as gunshots against them. From 9 to 14 April, police raided the village to arrest petitioners, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported. 10 April: Police dragged away 500 villagers from Fuli Village, Jixian County, Heilongjiang, lying on train tracks at Fulitun Railway Station to demand adequate compensation for a land takeover, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Over 100 people were injured. On 11th, clashes continued as armed police guarded the train station. 12 April: Dozens of villagers from Maojia clashed with police and officials in a protest over a forcible takeover of farmland in the Huifa Development Zone, Dehui City, Jilin, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two villagers were sent to hospital. 11 and 17 April: Over 1,000 elderly people and women from Xianqiao Village, Chaoan County, Chaozhou, Guangdong, held two protest marches to the county government to demand the return of farmland secretly sold off by a former party secretary to a company, RFA reported. 7 April: Staff at a cement factory in Haibowan District, Wuhait (Chinese: Wuhai) City, Inner Mongolia, fought with over 200 coal miners in a protest against illegal coal mining in the cement plant area, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. The cement plant staff were forced to retreat and many of them were injured in clashes;16 cement plant cars were destroyed. The statement said the protesters threw stones and bricks at police. They also destroyed 12 police cars and burned four more. The government stressed that the incident was unrelated to the recent dismissal of the city's party secretary Bo Xilai and denied witnesses' reports that at least two people had been killed on 10th. Residents, however, said protests were continuing, though no violence or arrests were reported. 13 April: Police issued five security orders banning gatherings, demonstrations or attacks on government buildings, any blocking of roads, distribution of leaflets or the sending out of information via text message or the internet, following clashes between police and protesters in Wansheng, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. headline: Angry villagers kill policeman in China riot
text: Angry villagers protesting a local mining operation in southwest China attacked security forces with machetes and clubs, leaving one policeman dead and 15 injured, local authorities said Friday.The riot occurred on Wednesday when police were dispatched to a government building in Yunnan province's Renhe township to try and persuade villagers staging a protest in front of the building to leave, authorities said."Suddenly villagers attacked the police with machetes and wooden clubs, leaving 16 injured, one of whom died later while receiving treatment," said a statement released by the government of Lijiang -- which oversees Renhe."During the incident, the police maintained a high level of restraint and not one villager was injured," it added.Earlier this month, locals from Xiaoganqing village complained that the development of a local coal mine was endangering their lands and demanded their homes be moved and that they be compensated, the statement said.A spokeswoman for the Lijiang government told AFP those complaints went unanswered and so the villagers moved their protest to the Renhe government building, where they stayed one week until the violence on Wednesday.The spokeswoman, surnamed Yu, said the dead policeman was Wang Shaoyong, vice director of the public security bureau of Yongsheng county, which oversees the village.Local police refused to tell AFP whether any of the villagers had been arrested following the incident.China faces increasing pressure from public discontent over land disputes, which have in the past months sparked several violent protests against authorities in various parts of the country.Earlier this month, hundreds of ethnic Mongols living in China's northern region of Inner Mongolia blocked roads as they protested the alleged illegal occupation of their land by a forestry firm.Authorities arrested 22 people amid accusations of police brutality, rights groups say.Land grabs also triggered a huge revolt against authorities in the southern village of Wukan in December, in a case that attracted international media attention and eventually led to rare concessions by the provincial government.sai/mbx/jms

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 2 May
text: The following highlights are from Tai Yang Pao ?for 2 May 2012: Retirees Protest Inadequate Pensions in Harbin: Popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tai Yang Pao reported on 2 May that several thousand retired workers have staged a series of continuous protests and blocked roads in front of the Heilongjiang provincial government building in Harbin since 28 April. The disgruntled retirees demanded that the Heilongjiang governor step down after a recent readjustment of the pension scheme system that reportedly favors senior government officials at the expense of?grassroots workers. Many Heilongjiang retirees also complained that their pension incomes were much lower than their counterparts in other provinces. Dozens of protesters were injured when they clashed with hundreds of riot police dispatched to the scene.? (see vernacular file: typ0502.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.? ??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. headline: WCT: Hongta Workers in Yunnan Stage Protest Against Corrupt Bosses
text: The workers accused the company's general manager Wang Yanjun and vice general manager Wang Yuexing of selling the company's assets and transferring money illegally, sacrificing the interests of their local staff. About 1 billion yuan (US$159 million) invested by General Motors is said to have been transferred back to Hongta's headquarters in Changchun in China's northeast. As a result, the Qujing branch has insufficient funds to operate normally and the company faces a deficit despite annual sales of 80,000 vehicles. Workers have not seen a pay raise in a decade and the company does not provide housing or other benefits to its employees. The protestors demanded the company retrieve GM's money and announce publicly how much the corrupt bosses have made over the last two years. In addition to demanding higher pay and more benefits, the protestors also urged the company headquarters in Changchun to no longer dispatch executives to Yunnan but hire local managers instead. headline: WCT: 10,000 Protest County Merger in Chongqing District
text: About 10,000 citizens from Wansheng district began their march on May 24. Despite the rain and threats from authorities that martial law would be imposed, protestors on Thursday walked quietly with umbrellas in hand. Residents believe the plan to merge their district with Qijiang - a project orchestrated by Bo Xilai, the defenestrated former Communist Party chief of Chongqing - would exacerbate growing economic woes since the neighboring county is much poorer than Wansheng. A protestor said that it is wrong to feed the people of Qijaing with money earned by the citizens of Wansheng, reported Chinese Jasmine Revolution. Violence broke out in Wansheng during protests held April 10-11, at which rioters set police vehicles on fire. Although the local government decided in the end to appease protestors, clashes between civilians and the police occurred nearly every night. Businesspeople and shopkeepers operating in the district launched strikes against the government, saying they would shut down if authorities did not move to stop the merger. Police vehicles are now patrolling the streets, with riot squads having been ordered to move into the district, say Chinese netizens. Although Chinese internet users say the protests cannot be put to rest by force, Li Mingqing, the new party secretary of Wansheng, declared that the government will not make any concessions regarding the merger policy. A protestor said that it is wrong to feed the people of Qijaing with money earned by the citizens of Wansheng, reported Chinese Jasmine Revolution.               http://cn.rfi.fr/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD/20120527-%E9%87%8D%E5%BA%86%E4%B8%87%E7%9B%9B%E7%BD%A2%E5%B8%82-%E4%B8%8A%E4%B8%87%E6%B0%91%E4%BC%97%E6%95%A3%E6%AD%A5%E7%A4%BA%E5%A8%81%E5%8F%8D%E5%AF%B9%E5%90%88%E5%B9%B6/

headline: Migrant workers go on rampage in China after death
text: BEIJING, May 29 (Reuters) - About 1,000 migrant workers went on the rampage in a city in eastern China on Tuesday, smashing up cars and protesting in front of a government building after a worker was apparently killed by his employer, state media said.The protest began in the morning in Ruian, near Wenzhou in the wealthy province of Zhejiang, the official Xinhua news agency reported."Around 1,000 migrant workers rushed the government office building, turning over an iron fence gate, and damaging over a dozen cars with stones and bricks," Xinhua's English language report said."Local government sources said the protest was sparked by the death of 19-year-old migrant worker Yang Zhi, allegedly killed by his employer Xu Qiyin during a dispute over salary," it said.The protest ended just before midday after the family of the dead man was given 300,000 yuan ($47,300) in compensation, Xinhua said.Police have detained Xu, and ordered him to pay the compensation, the report said.It provided no further details, and Reuters was unable to reach the government for comment.China's ruling Communist Party worries that the tens of thousands of sporadic protests over land grabs, corruption and economic grievances that break out across the country every year could coalesce into discontent that would threaten its control.In December, a village protest in southern China over land grabs and the death of a village organiser drew national attention after officials conceded to protesters' demands.No official counts of the number of protests, riots and mass petitions have been released in recent years. But most estimates in government-sponsored studies put such "mass incidents" at around 90,000 a year in recent years.In 2007, China saw more than 80,000 "mass incidents", up from more than 60,000 in 2006, according to the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.($1 = 6.3450 Chinese yuan)(Reporting by Ben Blanchard; Editing by Louise Ireland)

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 29 May
text: The following highlights are from Nanfang Ribao , Tai Yang Pao, and Tung Fang Jih Pao for the period 26-29 May 2012: Ten Thousand Protest Police Brutality in Zhuhai: According to a 26 May unattributed report in popular, independent HK daily Tai Yang Pao , nearly 10,000 angry citizens blockaded roads in Zhuhai, Guangdong on 24 May to protest the violent manner in which traffic cops cracked down on the illegal soliciting of passengers by motorbikes. The report alleged that?the traffic police?confiscated the motorbike of an elderly couple who made?their living by collecting garbage, yelling that they would beat the old man to death.? As an angry crowd gathered, the traffic cops used pepper spray to disperse the onlookers, injuring a 10-year-old boy and a two-year-old girl.? The protesters dispersed late in the evening after the local authorities sent scores of policemen to the scene.[see vernacular file: tkp0526a.pdf] Chengguan, Vendors Clash in Shenzhen: Guangzhou Nanfang Dushi Bao , a popular and occasionally outspoken daily newspaper affiliated with Nanfang Ribao , the daily newspaper of the Guangdong Provincial CPC Committee, on 26 May 2012 carried a report by staff correspondent Guo Tao on a fight between dozens of urban management enforcement officers [chengguan] and street vendors in Shenzhen's Luohu District on 7 May. The report noted that large numbers of onlookers surrounded the site to stop the police from taking away a female vendor who had been knocked to?the ground. The standoff lasted over an hour, until the female vendor was sent to?Luohu Hospital. Following an on-site investigation, the police said that the urban management officers did not assault anyone and the handed the incident over to the neighborhood authorities. The Nanhu neighborhood stated that more than a dozen law enforcement personnel arrived after receiving a complaint from residents that someone was collecting waste without a license. In the course of the inspection, the two sides began to fight, added the report. [See vernacular file: nd0526a) Workers Block Highway to Protest Unpaid Wages: Guangzhou Nanfang Dushi Bao , a popular and occasionally outspoken daily newspaper affiliated with Nanfang Ribao , the daily newspaper of the Guangdong Provincial CPC Committee, on 26 May 2012 carried an article by staff correspondent Guo Qiucheng?that reported over a?dozen workers blocked a state highway in a protest to demand back wages. According to the report, the workers complained that they have not been paid for the past 8 months.??The Boluo Labor Department had reportedly promised after mediation that they would be paid soon, but the contractor, Zhongtai Construction Group, could not honor the payment. The report said that a dozen workers blocked the Boyi section of the 324 highway, paralyzing traffic for more than an hour. As the workers refused to leave , the report added that antiriot police arrived to remove them by force. [See vernacular file: nd0526b]? Death of Teenager in Police Detention Sparks Protest in Jiangxi: Popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao on 29 May reported that several hundred residents in Nanchang city, Jiangxi province, protested outside the provincial government office on 28 May, demanding an investigation into the death of a 16-year-old?who reportedly "died suspiciously in police detention on suspicion of theft."? Police sent to the scene of the protest to keep order, but no clashes was reported.? (See vernacular file: tfjp0529a) Hainan Villagers Riot Over Power Plant Construction: According to a 29 May report in popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , over 1,000 villagers in Zhanfeng township, Hainan province, took to the street on 26 May in protest against the construction of a coal power plant nearby.? After the protest, the local county government dispatched over 1,000 police to block the roads leading to the village.? It was reported that villagers clashed with the police, and anti-riot police had fired teargas to disperse the mob.? Villagers were said to have been assaulted by the police, with one villager reportedly dead, and a number of protesters injured.? (See vernacular file: tfjp0529b)?? headline: Protest in Chinese province ahead of Tiananmen crackdown anniversary - paper
text: Ping Kuo Jih Pao, an independent Hong Kong daily often critical of Beijing, carried on 31 May 2012 an unattributed report on a protest in Fujian province demanding redress for victims of the 1989 pro-democracy crackdown in Beijing. According to the report, a group of Fujian residents were inspired by a 28 May gathering by dozens of Guizhou residents commemorating victims of the Tiananmen massacre, and decided to stage their own protest outside a local court in Fujian on 29 May to mark the upcoming 23rd anniversary of the Tiananmen crackdown. The residents reportedly carried banners reading "Redress the 4 June Incident," and "Support Premier Wen's Political Reforms." According to an activist, some protesters were arrested by public security officers who broke into their residences after the protest.Source: Apple Daily, Hong Kong, in Chinese 31 May 12

headline: REFILE-UPDATE 1-"Hundreds detained" in Tibet after self-immolations
text: (Refiles to correct Hao Peng's title, sixth paragraph)BEIJING, May 31 (Reuters) - Hundreds of Tibetans in Lhasa have been detained by Chinese security officers after two self-immolation protests against Chinese rule over Tibet, a U.S.-broadcaster said, stoking concerns of spreading unrest amo n g Tibetans in China.On Sunday, two Tibetan men set themselves on fire in Lhasa, state news agency Xinhua said, the first time in four years of a major Tibetan protest against Chinese rule. One of the men died.China has branded the self-immolators "terrorists" and criminals and has blamed exiled Tibetans and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, for inciting them.At least 35 Tibetans have set themselves on fire since March 2011 in protest against China's six-decade rule over Tibet, according to Tibetan rights groups. At least 27 have died.Late on Wednesday, Radio Free Asia cited a source as estimating that about 600 Tibetans had been detained since the Sunday's protests in Lhasa. The number could not be independently confirmed because foreign journalists are barred from entering Tibet.Hao Peng, deputy party secretary in the Tibet Autonomous Region, has urged authorities to tighten their grip on the Internet and mobile text messaging, reflecting government fears about unrest during a month-long Buddhist festival which started last week.The move is the latest in a series of measures the government says are intended to maintain stability."Hao Peng stressed that...the trouble caused by the activities of the Dalai clique has persisted, and the situation for stability maintenance is still complicated and grim," the official Tibet Daily newspaper reported.The detentions come amid news that a Tibetan woman had set herself ablaze on Wednesday afternoon in Aba prefecture in southwestern Sichuan province, according to Tibetan advocacy group Free Tibet and Radio Free Asia.Experts say Beijing may introduce tighter restrictions to halt the growing unrest in China's ethnic Tibetan areas.Beijing considers the Dalai Lama, who fled into exile in India in 1959 after an abortive uprising against Chinese rule, a separatist. The Dalai Lama says he merely seeks greater autonomy for his Himalayan homeland.(Reporting by Sui-Lee Wee; Editing by Ken Wills and Jonathan Thatcher)

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 14 June
text: The following highlights are from?the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, Tai Yang Pao ,?and Tung Fang Jih Pao ?for the period 14 June 2012: Large Riot Breaks Out in Jiangsu Over Investment Dispute: According to a 14 June report from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service that reports on dissent and unrest in China, 500 owners of shops in the Wuyao Taiwan Commercial Arcade in Jiangsu's Rugao City, who suspected that they had been cheated by their landlords, staged a demonstration in front of the municipal government offices on 12 June. The report said that the local authorities dispatched around 1,000 public security officers to impose a curfew and disperse the protesters, which resulted in a clash that injured 10 people. After promising high returns, the report stated that the commercial arcade attracted more than 5,000 investors from Shanghai and Jiangsu. However, the shops that were promised to be ready for buyers in March of this year have not yet been completed, added the report.(see vernacular file: ic0614a.pdf)Chengguan Brutality Sparks Confrontation in Henan: According to an unattributed 14 June 2012 report in popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , an urban management enforcement officer (chengguan) in Xuchang city, Henan, was "encircled" by more than 1,000 angry citizens after he reportedly beat up a street vendor. Over 100 police officers arrived on the scene to maintain order, and at one point, one of the police officers "pulled out his gun." According to the report, however, the citizens "refused to give in," and "insisted that the urban management enforcement officer apologize." A secretary of the Xuchang Political and Legal Committee also reportedly arrived to pacify the crowds, and assured that a "satisfactory solution" will be found. The crowds then "gradually dispersed." (see vernacular file: tfjp0614a.pdf) Guangxi Villagers Protest Gas Pipeline: According to a 14 June report from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, villagers of Langnan Township in Guangxi's Tengxian county rioted and clashed with armed police on 14 June over a gas pipeline project. In order to coordinate with the Chinese-Burmese gas pipeline and the second line project for transmitting?gas from West to East China, the report stated that the preparations for laying?300 km of pipeline in Guangxi started in April 2012. As the pipeline was "too close" to residences in Langnan Township and the villagers were scared of the large 1-meter?diamater pipeline, the report said that "hundreds of villagers clashed with over a hundred SWAT and armed police on 14 June, leaving 10 villagers injured and 3 arrested." The report added that "the purpose of the two projects is to alleviate China's over reliance on the Strait of Malacca." (see vernacular file: ic0614b.pdf) Guangzhou Residents Clash with Developer: According to an unattributed 15 June 2012 report in popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tai Yang Pao , a "few hundred" owners of an apartment building in Guangzhou's Tianhe District protested outside the developer's office building with banners around 9am on 13 June, accusing the developer of hiding the fact that the apartment building is "located next to a highway at the time the units were open for sale." The protesters first gathered outside the developer's office building, but later "took over the entire road and paralyzed traffic in the area." A few dozen riot police officers were dispatched to the scene and had reportedly resorted to violence to disperse the crowds "after urging the protesters to no avail." According to the report, a protester was "dragged across the ground for a few meters" while another protester "fainted from being beaten with a police baton." After two clashes, representatives were sent by the area's legal office to "mediate between the developer and the owners." Both parties reportedly agreed to negotiate. (see vernacular file: typ0615a.pdf)? No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.? ??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. headline: Tibetan man self-immolates in China: rights groups
text: A Tibetan man died after setting himself alight on Friday in a remote area of northwestern China in protest against Chinese rule, rights groups said, the latest such incident to hit the country.The middle-aged man self-immolated in front of a Chinese military compound in Qinghai province's Huangnan Tibetan autonomous prefecture, the Tibetan Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said.Security officers put out the flames within minutes, said the India-based group, which gave the man's name as Tamding Thar and described him as a former nomad.Another group, the London-based Free Tibet, said he died at the scene and up to 500 people protested to demand the return of his body, which authorities later released to his family. It gave his name as Tamdrinthar.In a brief dispatch, China's official Xinhua news agency confirmed a person died of self-immolation in the province on Friday, but gave no details as to the victim's identity or gender.Authorities were investigating the incident, the report said.Free Tibet said the act "was a clear and absolute rejection of Chinese rule: he set fire to himself at a location that represents to Tibetans the brutality of China's occupation."The government of Jianzha county -- where the incident took place -- refused to comment on the case while calls to local police went unanswered.Since March last year, at least 38 people have set themselves on fire in Tibetan-inhabited areas of China in protest at repressive government policies, according to activists.On May 27, two Tibetan men set themselves alight in front of the Jokhang temple, a renowned centre for Buddhist pilgrimage in the centre of Lhasa -- the capital of the Tibet region.It was the first such incident to hit the city. Travel agents in Lhasa said last week Chinese authorities had closed Tibet to foreign visitors.Tibetans have long chafed under China's rule over the vast Tibetan plateau, saying that Beijing has curbed religious freedoms and their culture is being eroded by an influx of Han Chinese, the country's main ethnic group.Beijing, however, says that Tibetans enjoy religious freedom and have benefited from improved living standards brought on by China's economic expansion.ly-bxs/cc/pst

headline: Summary: Guangdong Shaxi Township To Further Suppress Migrant Worker Rioting
text: Popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang JihPao on 29 June 2012 carried a report by staff reporters from Zhongshan to follow up on the 25 June riot in Shaxi Township, Zhongshan City, Guangdong Province. According to the report, the atmosphere in Shaxi remained tense as of 28 June as dozens of military vehicles loaded with armed policemen patrolled around the township government. A circular reportedlyhad been issued by the Guangdong Provincial CPC Committee to inform residents that a "rat sweeping" campaign would be carried out by the armed police force and the local police on the evening of 28 June and therefore advised residents to stay home. The campaign was interpreted by many as the police plan to suppress the city's migrant workers from Sichuan. Reporters said injured migrant workers allegedly assaulted by the local police were frequently seen at the local hospital. According to Internet sources, seven protesters were killed by the police despite the government'sdenial of any casualties. headline: Construction of factory in China halted after demos
text: The construction of a metallurgical plant in southwest China was halted Monday following protests by residents who feared the pollution it would have created, the local government said.The Sichuan Hongda group factory in the city of Shifang in Sichuan province was to have produced metal alloys."Faced with a lack of understanding and opposition from the local population... a committee of the (Communist) Party and of the city government has decided to ask the company to halt construction," said a statement posted on a local government website.Photos posted on Sina Weibo, the popular Chinese microblog, showed crowds of at least several hundred people protesting against the construction of the factory.The government also announced the formation of a working group tasked with collecting opinions and suggestions from residents about the project.It is common in China for environmental concerns to take a backseat to growth and industrialisation, which sometimes results in protests.In December, clashes broke out between police and opponents of the construction of a thermal power plant in the southern city of Haimen.Sometimes the authorities are forced to abandon or modify plans when faced with public opposition.In 2011, a factory which produced solar panels was temporarily suspended in the eastern city of Haining following protests, while residents of the northeastern city of Dalian were successful in halting a planned petrochemical plant there.boc/ia/txw
notes_human: http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2012/07/201207022032.shtml#.VMww6lXF8Sg                Tens of thousands of people took to the streets, some of whom besieged the city government headquarters in Shifang, Sichuan, yesterday, smashing police cars and clashing with thousands of anti-riot police on the second day of protests against a factory they say will poison the city.Shifang authorities said yesterday the government would temporarily suspend construction of the 10.4 billion yuan (HK$12.7 billion) molybdenum-copper alloy factory by Shanghai-listed Sichuan Hongda.Yesterday's protest was among the largest triggered by environmental concerns since tens of thousands of people took to the streets in Dalian, Liaoning, late last year. That protest forced the local government to temporarily suspend the building of a petrochemical plant.Shifang authorities said that at least 13 people were injured in yesterday's protest as police used tear gas and stun grenades to disperse crowds from government buildings and streets. Witnesses said many more were injured.  Monday when, according to the official account, protesters in the city of around 430,000 attacked government offices with bricks and stones, smashed cars, and clashed directly with police and government employees. The city government has said only 13 people were injured. "Anyone who has incited, planned or organised illegal gatherings, protest marches or demonstrations or those who have engaged in smashing and looting ... will be punished severely," the police said.?"Anyone using the Internet, mobile text messages and other methods to incite, plan or organise illegal gatherings, protest marches or demonstrations must immediately stop their illegal activities."

headline: China social unrest briefing 5-18 Jul 12
text: [multiple events] Mass protests continued in Shifang, Sichuan Province, as hundreds of people clashed with police while demanding the release of protesters detained during demonstrations against a heavy metal processing plant in early July. Workers at two factories in southern Guangdong went on strike after factory owners absconded without paying wages. Striking workers at a lighting factory in Chongqing demanded the withdrawal of French shareholders from the factory's board of directors. Angry tourists blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the tourist site of Lake Tianchi in the northeast province of Jilin was closed while a former Beijing party chief toured the area. An unidentified Tibetan man died after self-immolating near Lhasa and another teenage Tibetan monk also died after self-immolating in Sichuan. The third anniversary of inter-ethnic violence in northwest Urumqi passed without incident amid heightened security. Environmental protests Sichuan: Anti-pollution protests break out again in Shifang 3 July: The Shifang city government denied reports by the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders that two people were killed in clashes with police during mass protests from 1-3 July against a heavy metal processing plant in Shifang, Sichuan. On the evening of 4 and 5 July, hundreds of people again gathered outside city government offices in the evening to demand the release of six detained demonstrators, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. 9 July: Hundreds of people blocked traffic while protesting outside the city government and clashed with police, the independent Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily News reported. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 4 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5-6 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 9 Jul 12; Oriental Daily News, Hong Kong, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Guangdong: Residents block port in protest over dump trucks From 2 to 6 July, property owners in the Haihao Huating Estate, Xixiang, Bao'an District, Shenzhen, Guangdong, used cars to block the entrance to the Dachan Bay Port in protest at air and noise pollution caused by dump trucks bringing landfill for land reclamation, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. On 6 July, riot police finally persuaded the protesters to leave the site. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 7 Jul 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Striking workers beaten by hired thugs 16 July: Around 20 thugs hired by the China Construction Third Engineering Bureau Co in Shenzhen, Guangdong, allegedly beat up eight migrant workers from Hubei Province who had gone on strike over a delayed construction project, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two workers were severely injured and one was lightly injured. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Chongqing: French-invested lighting factory workers go on strike 13 July: Workers at the NVC Lighting Co. headquarters in Chongqing and its production bases in Wanzhou, Huizhou and other places in Chongqing went on strike, crippling operations at 36 centres, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. The employees called for the company's founder and former chairman Wu Changjiang to return to the board of directors and for French company Schneider Electric to withdraw entirely from NVC. They also demanded 15 per cent of company shares. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) Guangdong: Worker protests over wage arrears 3 July: Around 1,000 electronics factory workers blocked roads outside the government in Humen Township, Dongguan City, Guangdong Province, to demand wages after the factory owner absconded, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 17 July: Workers at the Taiyuan Waterworks Factory in Panyu, Guangdong, blocked the Dagangshan Bridge after the factory owner absconded without paying four months of wages, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported, quoting Internet users. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 4 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Migrant workers block road in pay protest 13 July: Migrant workers blocked roads for several hours in Yuxiangmen, Xi'an, Shaanxi, after a real estate group hired thugs to beat workers demanding pay rises, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Hainan: Department store employees on strike 10 July: Striking workers at the Shengsheng Department Store, Hainan Province, staged a sit-in outside the store in protest at reduced employee wages and benefits, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Ethnic minorities Tibetan self-immolations 13 July: An unidentified Tibetan man died in hospital a week after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule in the seat of Damshung County (Chinese: Dangxiong), Lhasa Prefecture, Tibet Autonomous Region, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The man, in his 20s, was rushed to a military hospital after the protest but could not be saved. 17 July: Tibetan monk Lobsang Lozin, 18, died after self-immolating in front of the prayer hall of the Gedhen Tashi Choeling Monastery in Barkham (Chinese: Ma'erkang) County in the Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9-13 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 17 Jul 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protester beaten 4 July: Authorities beat and detained a young Tibetan man, Kelsang Tenzin, 22, who staged a solitary protest against Chinese rule and demanded the release of all political prisoners in Tibet in front of county offices in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9 Jul 12) Xinjiang: Security tight on ethnic violence anniversary 5 July: Authorities tightened security checks at airports and stations and police patrols in the regional capital, Urumqi, and Kashgar City in Xinjiang, around the third anniversary of ethnic violence between Han and Uighurs in 2009 that left at least 200 people dead, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5 Jul 12) Tianjin: Uighurs block highway to protest On 5 July, which marked the third anniversary of the riot in Xinjiang's Urumqi, some 100 Uighurs blocked a highway in Tianjin's Binhai New Area, the Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The police confirmed the incident but refused to explain the reason. Sources revealed that the protest was due to Uighurs' dissatisfaction with the fact that the government characterized the 29 June Tianjin Airlines incident as a "hijack" attempt. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, 6 Jul 12) Petitioners Beijing: Petitioner protests, attempted suicides 28 June: Police stopped a father and son from Wenshang County, Shandong Province, trying to commit suicide by drinking pesticide under the national flag at Beijing's Tiananmen Square to protest against the forcible demolition of their home in June 2011, the US-based Chinese-language news website Boxun reported. 6 July: Authorities in Beijing detained 10 eviction protesters for five days after they staged a protest in Tiananmen Square, kneeling en masse in front of the portrait of late leader Mao Zedong, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The protesters were residents of Shiliuzhuang Village, Fengtai District, on the outskirts of Beijing. (Boxun, USA, in Chinese 11 Jul 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Beijing: Officials hold petitioning forum 13-14 July: Several hundred officials attended a conference on petitioning at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post reported. Leaders, including the president, premier, vice-president and vice-premier, met the delegates for a photo call. Zhou Yongkang, central leader in charge of law and order, praised the work of officials in charge of petitioning and encouraged them to improve the protection of petitioners' rights and to maintain social stability. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 16 Jul 12) Other reports Jilin: Tourists protest over site closure 16 July: Tourists protested, blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the authorities blocked access to Lake Tianchi in Mt Changbai, Jilin Province, while former Beijing party secretary Liu Qi toured the area accompanied by the governor of Jilin, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported, quoting posts by netizens. (Canyu.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12) Guangdong/Yunnan: Land disputes 12 July: Residents armed with farming tools and sticks from the villages of Liwuwei and Huangniutan, in Xiaojiang Township, Yangshan County, Qingyuan, Guangdong, clashed with construction workers and police while trying to stop a mining company operating on forcibly requisitioned farmland, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Police dispersed the crowd with truncheons and teargas, the Hong Kong daily Ming Pao added. Around 16 people were injured and at least seven people were detained. 15 July: Villagers clashed with police in Dongjing, Nanzhuang Township, Chancheng, Foshan, Guangdong, in protests against the takeover and filling in of fishponds, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Two were injured in the clashes. 15 July: Villagers were injured trying to stop a forcible land takeover by excavators in Jiufu Village by the county government of Zhenhong in Yunnan, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Around 1,000 villagers then marched to the county government. Ten people were injured in clashes with police outside the building. The villagers dispersed after negotiations with the authorities. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 15-16 Jul 12; Ming Pao, Hong Kong, in Chinese 15 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Guangdong: Car dealers protest traffic curbs Hundreds of used car dealers protested outside government buildings in Guangzhou against new rules released on 7 July slashing by half the number of licence plates to be issued in the next year, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Car dealers said the ban on transferring licence plates would affect their business. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Chongqing: Crowd protests against urban inspectors 16 July: Around 1,000 people surrounded a team of urban inspectors (Chinese: chengguan) on Shengli Rd, Yongchuan District, Chongqing, who allegedly beat and wounded an elderly fruit hawker, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Clashes broke out after riot police reportedly beat up a youth taking photographs. Fighting also erupted on a bus between police and three detained youths, and bus windows were smashed. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Crowd surrounds drunk driver's car 14 July: Taxi drivers and onlookers brought traffic to a standstill while surrounding a Hyundai car after the driver allegedly crashed drunkenly into a taxi in Baoji, Shaanxi Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Crowds threw water bottles at police cars. Riot police finally rescued the driver after six hours. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]
source_human: The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 9 July
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from?Tung Fang JihPao ?for the period 8-9 July 2012: Protesters Complain About Industrial Pollution in Jianxi Province: According to a 9 July report in popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang JihPao , a few hundred people in Jian city, Jiangxi Province, took to the street on 4 July and protested against the operation of a local industrial park that they complained was causing serious pollution and threatening their children's health.? The protestors reportedly blocked the roads and caused a serious traffic jam. Police were sent in to stand guard at the scene.? (See vernacular file: tfjp0709a.pdf) Villagers in Guangdong Province Protest School Demolition: Popular, independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang JihPao , on 8 July reported a protest by villagers against local officials in Liguang village, HuidongCounty, Guangdong Province.? Protesting villagers alleged the village cadres had taken bribes and forcibly demolished a primary school to build a temple last year.? Several hundred children were affected and needed to go to the school in the next village. Villagers also complained of being threatened when they tried to petition to higher authorities. Local authorities promised to build another school, but villagers feared that it could not be completed by September when the new school year will start.? (See vernacular file: tfjp0708a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: HsinPao, Ching chi JihPao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang JihPao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping KuoJihPao, Sing Tao JihPao, PhoenixNewsline. Attachments:

headline: Around 600 protest in south China city over car quota system - Hong Kong paper
text: Text of report by Mimi Lau in Guangzhou headlined "600 in Protest Over Car Quota System" published by Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post website on 10 JulyAbout 600 owners of second-hand car dealerships in Guangzhou protested yesterday against the city's new vehicle-registration quota system, saying it had effectively put them out of business.The dealers, including those from remote districts such as Conghua, Zengcheng, Huadu and Panyu, gathered in People's Park near a popular shopping district in the morning, then demonstrated in front of the city government headquarters and went to the Guangdong provincial government offices in the afternoon.Luo Jialiang, 53, the owner of a second-hand car business with more than 30 cars in stock, organised the demonstration. He said the policy, announced with only a few hours' notice last week, was destructive to their livelihoods."It is unreasonable to limit the sales of used cars, as it has no impact on the overall volume of Guangzhou's cars," Luo said. "Transactions of second-hand cars should not be capped. We are very angry."Another owner of a second-hand car dealership said she expected that at least 40,000 people would be out of a job in Guangzhou due to the policy, and that about 1,500 second-hand dealers would be forced to close or relocate.A number of car dealerships have also closed their doors for the whole of July, after authorities said all car registrations, including second-hand filings, would be suspended for the month as details of the plan were still being sorted out."We are still paying rent and wages for our workers," the owner said, declining to give her name. "What are we going to do?"The car-quota policy was implemented on July 1, just three hours after it was announced by the Guangzhou Municipal Transport Commission on the night of June 30. The move was criticised as being too hasty and carried out without public consultation.However, authorities said the cap was necessary to curb the city's worsening gridlock and air pollution. Announcing the plan ahead of time would have surely resulted in a rush by many people to buy cars, which would have lessened the desired effects of such a quota.Under the new policy, new car registrations are capped at 10,000 a month, starting in August, or 120,000 a year. About 226,000 cars were sold in the city last year.Guangzhou is the fourth mainland city - after Beijing, Shanghai and Guiyang - where the local authorities have introduced administrative measures to control car sales."We don't understand the rationale of the government limiting registration of second-hand vehicles, as our businesses would not increase the total car volume in the city," Luo said. "We want the government to give second-hand cars a one-year grace period and to review whether it is really necessary to impose such a ban, with academic research and expert opinions to back up (the review)."Source: South China Morning Post website, Hong Kong, in English 10 Jul 12

headline: China social unrest briefing 5-18 Jul 12
text: [multiple events] Mass protests continued in Shifang, Sichuan Province, as hundreds of people clashed with police while demanding the release of protesters detained during demonstrations against a heavy metal processing plant in early July. Workers at two factories in southern Guangdong went on strike after factory owners absconded without paying wages. Striking workers at a lighting factory in Chongqing demanded the withdrawal of French shareholders from the factory's board of directors. Angry tourists blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the tourist site of Lake Tianchi in the northeast province of Jilin was closed while a former Beijing party chief toured the area. An unidentified Tibetan man died after self-immolating near Lhasa and another teenage Tibetan monk also died after self-immolating in Sichuan. The third anniversary of inter-ethnic violence in northwest Urumqi passed without incident amid heightened security. Environmental protests Sichuan: Anti-pollution protests break out again in Shifang 3 July: The Shifang city government denied reports by the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders that two people were killed in clashes with police during mass protests from 1-3 July against a heavy metal processing plant in Shifang, Sichuan. On the evening of 4 and 5 July, hundreds of people again gathered outside city government offices in the evening to demand the release of six detained demonstrators, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. 9 July: Hundreds of people blocked traffic while protesting outside the city government and clashed with police, the independent Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily News reported. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 4 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5-6 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 9 Jul 12; Oriental Daily News, Hong Kong, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Guangdong: Residents block port in protest over dump trucks From 2 to 6 July, property owners in the Haihao Huating Estate, Xixiang, Bao'an District, Shenzhen, Guangdong, used cars to block the entrance to the Dachan Bay Port in protest at air and noise pollution caused by dump trucks bringing landfill for land reclamation, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. On 6 July, riot police finally persuaded the protesters to leave the site. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 7 Jul 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Striking workers beaten by hired thugs 16 July: Around 20 thugs hired by the China Construction Third Engineering Bureau Co in Shenzhen, Guangdong, allegedly beat up eight migrant workers from Hubei Province who had gone on strike over a delayed construction project, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two workers were severely injured and one was lightly injured. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Chongqing: French-invested lighting factory workers go on strike 13 July: Workers at the NVC Lighting Co. headquarters in Chongqing and its production bases in Wanzhou, Huizhou and other places in Chongqing went on strike, crippling operations at 36 centres, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. The employees called for the company's founder and former chairman Wu Changjiang to return to the board of directors and for French company Schneider Electric to withdraw entirely from NVC. They also demanded 15 per cent of company shares. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) Guangdong: Worker protests over wage arrears 3 July: Around 1,000 electronics factory workers blocked roads outside the government in Humen Township, Dongguan City, Guangdong Province, to demand wages after the factory owner absconded, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 17 July: Workers at the Taiyuan Waterworks Factory in Panyu, Guangdong, blocked the Dagangshan Bridge after the factory owner absconded without paying four months of wages, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported, quoting Internet users. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 4 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Migrant workers block road in pay protest 13 July: Migrant workers blocked roads for several hours in Yuxiangmen, Xi'an, Shaanxi, after a real estate group hired thugs to beat workers demanding pay rises, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Hainan: Department store employees on strike 10 July: Striking workers at the Shengsheng Department Store, Hainan Province, staged a sit-in outside the store in protest at reduced employee wages and benefits, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Ethnic minorities Tibetan self-immolations 13 July: An unidentified Tibetan man died in hospital a week after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule in the seat of Damshung County (Chinese: Dangxiong), Lhasa Prefecture, Tibet Autonomous Region, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The man, in his 20s, was rushed to a military hospital after the protest but could not be saved. 17 July: Tibetan monk Lobsang Lozin, 18, died after self-immolating in front of the prayer hall of the Gedhen Tashi Choeling Monastery in Barkham (Chinese: Ma'erkang) County in the Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9-13 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 17 Jul 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protester beaten 4 July: Authorities beat and detained a young Tibetan man, Kelsang Tenzin, 22, who staged a solitary protest against Chinese rule and demanded the release of all political prisoners in Tibet in front of county offices in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9 Jul 12) Xinjiang: Security tight on ethnic violence anniversary 5 July: Authorities tightened security checks at airports and stations and police patrols in the regional capital, Urumqi, and Kashgar City in Xinjiang, around the third anniversary of ethnic violence between Han and Uighurs in 2009 that left at least 200 people dead, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5 Jul 12) Tianjin: Uighurs block highway to protest On 5 July, which marked the third anniversary of the riot in Xinjiang's Urumqi, some 100 Uighurs blocked a highway in Tianjin's Binhai New Area, the Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The police confirmed the incident but refused to explain the reason. Sources revealed that the protest was due to Uighurs' dissatisfaction with the fact that the government characterized the 29 June Tianjin Airlines incident as a "hijack" attempt. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, 6 Jul 12) Petitioners Beijing: Petitioner protests, attempted suicides 28 June: Police stopped a father and son from Wenshang County, Shandong Province, trying to commit suicide by drinking pesticide under the national flag at Beijing's Tiananmen Square to protest against the forcible demolition of their home in June 2011, the US-based Chinese-language news website Boxun reported. 6 July: Authorities in Beijing detained 10 eviction protesters for five days after they staged a protest in Tiananmen Square, kneeling en masse in front of the portrait of late leader Mao Zedong, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The protesters were residents of Shiliuzhuang Village, Fengtai District, on the outskirts of Beijing. (Boxun, USA, in Chinese 11 Jul 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Beijing: Officials hold petitioning forum 13-14 July: Several hundred officials attended a conference on petitioning at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post reported. Leaders, including the president, premier, vice-president and vice-premier, met the delegates for a photo call. Zhou Yongkang, central leader in charge of law and order, praised the work of officials in charge of petitioning and encouraged them to improve the protection of petitioners' rights and to maintain social stability. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 16 Jul 12) Other reports Jilin: Tourists protest over site closure 16 July: Tourists protested, blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the authorities blocked access to Lake Tianchi in Mt Changbai, Jilin Province, while former Beijing party secretary Liu Qi toured the area accompanied by the governor of Jilin, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported, quoting posts by netizens. (Canyu.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12) Guangdong/Yunnan: Land disputes 12 July: Residents armed with farming tools and sticks from the villages of Liwuwei and Huangniutan, in Xiaojiang Township, Yangshan County, Qingyuan, Guangdong, clashed with construction workers and police while trying to stop a mining company operating on forcibly requisitioned farmland, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Police dispersed the crowd with truncheons and teargas, the Hong Kong daily Ming Pao added. Around 16 people were injured and at least seven people were detained. 15 July: Villagers clashed with police in Dongjing, Nanzhuang Township, Chancheng, Foshan, Guangdong, in protests against the takeover and filling in of fishponds, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Two were injured in the clashes. 15 July: Villagers were injured trying to stop a forcible land takeover by excavators in Jiufu Village by the county government of Zhenhong in Yunnan, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Around 1,000 villagers then marched to the county government. Ten people were injured in clashes with police outside the building. The villagers dispersed after negotiations with the authorities. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 15-16 Jul 12; Ming Pao, Hong Kong, in Chinese 15 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Guangdong: Car dealers protest traffic curbs Hundreds of used car dealers protested outside government buildings in Guangzhou against new rules released on 7 July slashing by half the number of licence plates to be issued in the next year, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Car dealers said the ban on transferring licence plates would affect their business. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Chongqing: Crowd protests against urban inspectors 16 July: Around 1,000 people surrounded a team of urban inspectors (Chinese: chengguan) on Shengli Rd, Yongchuan District, Chongqing, who allegedly beat and wounded an elderly fruit hawker, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Clashes broke out after riot police reportedly beat up a youth taking photographs. Fighting also erupted on a bus between police and three detained youths, and bus windows were smashed. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Crowd surrounds drunk driver's car 14 July: Taxi drivers and onlookers brought traffic to a standstill while surrounding a Hyundai car after the driver allegedly crashed drunkenly into a taxi in Baoji, Shaanxi Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Crowds threw water bottles at police cars. Riot police finally rescued the driver after six hours. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]
