headline: China social unrest briefing 5-18 Jul 12
text: [multiple events] Mass protests continued in Shifang, Sichuan Province, as hundreds of people clashed with police while demanding the release of protesters detained during demonstrations against a heavy metal processing plant in early July. Workers at two factories in southern Guangdong went on strike after factory owners absconded without paying wages. Striking workers at a lighting factory in Chongqing demanded the withdrawal of French shareholders from the factory's board of directors. Angry tourists blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the tourist site of Lake Tianchi in the northeast province of Jilin was closed while a former Beijing party chief toured the area. An unidentified Tibetan man died after self-immolating near Lhasa and another teenage Tibetan monk also died after self-immolating in Sichuan. The third anniversary of inter-ethnic violence in northwest Urumqi passed without incident amid heightened security. Environmental protests Sichuan: Anti-pollution protests break out again in Shifang 3 July: The Shifang city government denied reports by the US-hosted rights website Chinese Human Rights Defenders that two people were killed in clashes with police during mass protests from 1-3 July against a heavy metal processing plant in Shifang, Sichuan. On the evening of 4 and 5 July, hundreds of people again gathered outside city government offices in the evening to demand the release of six detained demonstrators, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. 9 July: Hundreds of people blocked traffic while protesting outside the city government and clashed with police, the independent Hong Kong newspaper Oriental Daily News reported. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 4 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5-6 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 9 Jul 12; Oriental Daily News, Hong Kong, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Guangdong: Residents block port in protest over dump trucks From 2 to 6 July, property owners in the Haihao Huating Estate, Xixiang, Bao'an District, Shenzhen, Guangdong, used cars to block the entrance to the Dachan Bay Port in protest at air and noise pollution caused by dump trucks bringing landfill for land reclamation, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. On 6 July, riot police finally persuaded the protesters to leave the site. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 7 Jul 12) Worker unrest Guangdong: Striking workers beaten by hired thugs 16 July: Around 20 thugs hired by the China Construction Third Engineering Bureau Co in Shenzhen, Guangdong, allegedly beat up eight migrant workers from Hubei Province who had gone on strike over a delayed construction project, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Two workers were severely injured and one was lightly injured. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Chongqing: French-invested lighting factory workers go on strike 13 July: Workers at the NVC Lighting Co. headquarters in Chongqing and its production bases in Wanzhou, Huizhou and other places in Chongqing went on strike, crippling operations at 36 centres, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. The employees called for the company's founder and former chairman Wu Changjiang to return to the board of directors and for French company Schneider Electric to withdraw entirely from NVC. They also demanded 15 per cent of company shares. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) Guangdong: Worker protests over wage arrears 3 July: Around 1,000 electronics factory workers blocked roads outside the government in Humen Township, Dongguan City, Guangdong Province, to demand wages after the factory owner absconded, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. 17 July: Workers at the Taiyuan Waterworks Factory in Panyu, Guangdong, blocked the Dagangshan Bridge after the factory owner absconded without paying four months of wages, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported, quoting Internet users. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 4 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Migrant workers block road in pay protest 13 July: Migrant workers blocked roads for several hours in Yuxiangmen, Xi'an, Shaanxi, after a real estate group hired thugs to beat workers demanding pay rises, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Hainan: Department store employees on strike 10 July: Striking workers at the Shengsheng Department Store, Hainan Province, staged a sit-in outside the store in protest at reduced employee wages and benefits, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. (Molihua.org, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Ethnic minorities Tibetan self-immolations 13 July: An unidentified Tibetan man died in hospital a week after self-immolating in protest against Chinese rule in the seat of Damshung County (Chinese: Dangxiong), Lhasa Prefecture, Tibet Autonomous Region, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The man, in his 20s, was rushed to a military hospital after the protest but could not be saved. 17 July: Tibetan monk Lobsang Lozin, 18, died after self-immolating in front of the prayer hall of the Gedhen Tashi Choeling Monastery in Barkham (Chinese: Ma'erkang) County in the Ngaba (Chinese: Aba) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9-13 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 17 Jul 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protester beaten 4 July: Authorities beat and detained a young Tibetan man, Kelsang Tenzin, 22, who staged a solitary protest against Chinese rule and demanded the release of all political prisoners in Tibet in front of county offices in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9 Jul 12) Xinjiang: Security tight on ethnic violence anniversary 5 July: Authorities tightened security checks at airports and stations and police patrols in the regional capital, Urumqi, and Kashgar City in Xinjiang, around the third anniversary of ethnic violence between Han and Uighurs in 2009 that left at least 200 people dead, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5 Jul 12) Tianjin: Uighurs block highway to protest On 5 July, which marked the third anniversary of the riot in Xinjiang's Urumqi, some 100 Uighurs blocked a highway in Tianjin's Binhai New Area, the Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The police confirmed the incident but refused to explain the reason. Sources revealed that the protest was due to Uighurs' dissatisfaction with the fact that the government characterized the 29 June Tianjin Airlines incident as a "hijack" attempt. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9-13 Jul 12; The Epoch Times, New York, in English 17 Jul 12) Sichuan: Tibetan protester beaten 4 July: Authorities beat and detained a young Tibetan man, Kelsang Tenzin, 22, who staged a solitary protest against Chinese rule and demanded the release of all political prisoners in Tibet in front of county offices in the Kardze (Chinese: Ganzi) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 9 Jul 12) Xinjiang: Security tight on ethnic violence anniversary 5 July: Authorities tightened security checks at airports and stations and police patrols in the regional capital, Urumqi, and Kashgar City in Xinjiang, around the third anniversary of ethnic violence between Han and Uighurs in 2009 that left at least 200 people dead, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 5 Jul 12) Tianjin: Uighurs block highway to protest On 5 July, which marked the third anniversary of the riot in Xinjiang's Urumqi, some 100 Uighurs blocked a highway in Tianjin's Binhai New Area, the Hong Kong Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. The police confirmed the incident but refused to explain the reason. Sources revealed that the protest was due to Uighurs' dissatisfaction with the fact that the government characterized the 29 June Tianjin Airlines incident as a "hijack" attempt. (Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, 6 Jul 12) Petitioners Beijing: Petitioner protests, attempted suicides 28 June: Police stopped a father and son from Wenshang County, Shandong Province, trying to commit suicide by drinking pesticide under the national flag at Beijing's Tiananmen Square to protest against the forcible demolition of their home in June 2011, the US-based Chinese-language news website Boxun reported. 6 July: Authorities in Beijing detained 10 eviction protesters for five days after they staged a protest in Tiananmen Square, kneeling en masse in front of the portrait of late leader Mao Zedong, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. The protesters were residents of Shiliuzhuang Village, Fengtai District, on the outskirts of Beijing. (Boxun, USA, in Chinese 11 Jul 12; Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 10 Jul 12) Beijing: Officials hold petitioning forum 13-14 July: Several hundred officials attended a conference on petitioning at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post reported. Leaders, including the president, premier, vice-president and vice-premier, met the delegates for a photo call. Zhou Yongkang, central leader in charge of law and order, praised the work of officials in charge of petitioning and encouraged them to improve the protection of petitioners' rights and to maintain social stability. (South China Morning Post, Hong Kong, in English 16 Jul 12) Other reports Jilin: Tourists protest over site closure 16 July: Tourists protested, blocked roads, threw water bottles and demanded an apology and refund after the authorities blocked access to Lake Tianchi in Mt Changbai, Jilin Province, while former Beijing party secretary Liu Qi toured the area accompanied by the governor of Jilin, the China-based civil rights website Canyu reported, quoting posts by netizens. (Canyu.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12) Guangdong/Yunnan: Land disputes 12 July: Residents armed with farming tools and sticks from the villages of Liwuwei and Huangniutan, in Xiaojiang Township, Yangshan County, Qingyuan, Guangdong, clashed with construction workers and police while trying to stop a mining company operating on forcibly requisitioned farmland, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Police dispersed the crowd with truncheons and teargas, the Hong Kong daily Ming Pao added. Around 16 people were injured and at least seven people were detained. 15 July: Villagers clashed with police in Dongjing, Nanzhuang Township, Chancheng, Foshan, Guangdong, in protests against the takeover and filling in of fishponds, the unofficial Molihua.org website reported. Two were injured in the clashes. 15 July: Villagers were injured trying to stop a forcible land takeover by excavators in Jiufu Village by the county government of Zhenhong in Yunnan, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy reported. Around 1,000 villagers then marched to the county government. Ten people were injured in clashes with police outside the building. The villagers dispersed after negotiations with the authorities. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 15-16 Jul 12; Ming Pao, Hong Kong, in Chinese 15 Jul 12; Molihua.org, in Chinese 16 Jul 12; Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, Hong Kong, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Guangdong: Car dealers protest traffic curbs Hundreds of used car dealers protested outside government buildings in Guangzhou against new rules released on 7 July slashing by half the number of licence plates to be issued in the next year, the US-funded Radio Free Asia reported. Car dealers said the ban on transferring licence plates would affect their business. (Radio Free Asia, Washington DC, in Chinese 13 Jul 12) Chongqing: Crowd protests against urban inspectors 16 July: Around 1,000 people surrounded a team of urban inspectors (Chinese: chengguan) on Shengli Rd, Yongchuan District, Chongqing, who allegedly beat and wounded an elderly fruit hawker, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Clashes broke out after riot police reportedly beat up a youth taking photographs. Fighting also erupted on a bus between police and three detained youths, and bus windows were smashed. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 17 Jul 12) Shaanxi: Crowd surrounds drunk driver's car 14 July: Taxi drivers and onlookers brought traffic to a standstill while surrounding a Hyundai car after the driver allegedly crashed drunkenly into a taxi in Baoji, Shaanxi Province, the US-based Chinese-language newspaper The Epoch Times reported. Crowds threw water bottles at police cars. Riot police finally rescued the driver after six hours. (The Epoch Times, New York, in Chinese 15 Jul 12) [Description of Source: Caversham BBC Monitoring in Chinese -- Monitoring service of the BBC, the United Kingdom's public service broadcaster]

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China 19 Jul 2012
text: The following highlight?is from Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy?for 19 July 2012: Tianjin Residents Protest Construction of Underground Railway: According to the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy (19 July), a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, hundreds of Tianjin residents blocked the No. 2 Bridge Station of the municipality's light rail as well as the bridge over the rail on 18 July in protest against the underground railway that undermined the foundation of the nearby residential homes. The report stated that many households have found cracks on the walls. As the protest led to a traffic jam from downtown Tianjin to Tanggu, the report noted large numbers of policemen dispatched to the site. At the meeting on maintaining stability held on 18 July, Tianjin Party Secretary Zhang Gaoli called for "earnestly taking precautions against and cracking down on the sabotage of the hostile forces." (see the vernacular file: ichrd0719a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.???PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: HsinPao, Ching chi JihPao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang JihPao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping KuoJihPao, Sing Tao JihPao , PhoenixNewsline. headline: UPDATE 1-China cancels waste project after protests turn violent
text: (Recasts)QIDONG, China, July 28 (Reuters) - Chinese officials cancelled an industrial waste pipeline project on Saturday after anti-pollution demonstrators occupied a government office in eastern China, destroying computers and overturning cars.The demonstration was the latest in a string of protests sparked by fears of environmental degradation and highlights the social tensions the government in Beijing faces as it approaches a leadership transition this year.It was also the second cancellation of an industrial project this month, as officials buckle under pressure from protests.Zhang Guohua, city mayor of the eastern China city of Nantong, said in a statement the city would terminate the planned pipeline that would have emptied waste water from a Japanese-owned paper factory via the coastal town of Qidong into the sea.The decision came hours after about 1,000 protesters marched through the city of Qidong, about one hour north of Shanghai, shouting slogans against the pipeline.Several protesters entered the city government's main building and were seen smashing computers, overturning desks and throwing documents out the windows to loud cheers from the crowd. Reuters witnessed five cars and one minibus being overturned.At least two police officers were dragged into the crowd at the government office and punched and beaten enough to make them bleed.Environmental worries have stoked calls for expanded rights for citizens and greater consultation in the tightly controlled one-party state.The outpouring of public anger is emblematic of the rising discontent facing Chinese leaders, who are obsessed with maintaining stability and struggling to balance growth with rising public anger over environmental threats.The protest followed similar demonstrations against projects the Sichuan town of Shifang earlier this month and in the cities of Dalian in the northeast and Haimen in southern Guangdong province in the past year.The leadership has vowed to clean up China's skies and waterways and increasingly tried to appear responsive to complaints about pollution. But environmental disputes pit citizens against local officials whose aim is to lure fresh investment and revenue into their areas.(Additional reporting by Carlos Barria; Editing by Nick Macfie)

After the protest Saturday, the Qidong government announced on its website that plans to build the water discharge project had been scrapped.The official Xinhua News Agency said thousands of residents took to the streets but dispersed after the government announcement. Later Saturday hundreds of police, some in riot gear, arrived in the coastal town just north of Shanghai and took up positions outside the government offices.     Thousands of locals surrounded Qidong government offices on Saturday morning as protestors clashed with police, leading to scores of injuries and even rumors of at least two deaths. Hundreds of armed police from Nantong, which administers Qidong, were despatched to the area in an effort to suppress the growing violence and looting of government offices. The number of demonstrators varied widely from source to source. Chinese netizens claimed there were as many as 100,000 protestors, while France's AFP reported around 50,000 participants. Official Chinese media said roughly 10,000 people took part. The Qidong government eventually relented and promised to abandon its plans of building a 100 km pipeline from a city factory run by Japan's Oji Paper Co that would have pumped up to 150,000 tons of waste per day to China's east coast.

headline: AFP Cites Exile Group: Hundreds of Tibetans Demonstrated in Northwest China 14 Aug
text: Beijing, Aug 15, 2012 (AFP) - Hundreds of Tibetans demonstrated in northwest China after police beat four people, an exile group and a US broadcaster said, following a recent string of self-immolations in the region.The London-based Free Tibet said hundreds of people gathered outside police headquarters in Qinghai province's Tongren county Tuesday after police dragged four ethnic Tibetans from a car, beat them and threatened them with guns.US broadcaster Radio Free Asia quoted witnesses as saying the police appeared to be drunk, and "severely beat" the four men. Tongren government and security officials could not immediately be reached for comment.The protests followed reports of clashes in the neighbouring province of Sichuan on Monday, where two ethnic Tibetans set themselves on fire on Monday to protest Chinese rule, leading to bloody clashes between residents and police."Tensions are high as Tibetans are not prepared to sit back and allow Chinese state oppression to continue unchallenged," said Free Tibet director Stephanie Brigden.Exile groups say nearly 50 ethnic Tibetans, many of them Buddhist monks and nuns, have set themselves on fire since March 2011 to protest restrictions on their religious freedom.An influx of Han Chinese, the country's largest ethnic group, to China's vast Tibetan-inhabited areas has also created tensions.Violent anti-government protests in the Tibetan capital in Lhasa in 2008 later spread to other areas populated by Tibetans, prompting tight security in these regions that has at times led to clashes.Beijing insists Tibetans are free to practise their religion and have benefited from improved living standards under Chinese rule.cdh/cc/ac[Description of Source: Hong Kong AFP in English -- Hong Kong service of the independent French press agency Agence France-Presse]

headline: SCMP: 'Shots Fired - At Least in Print'
text: China's state media issued a stark warning to Japan yesterday over interfering in the Diaoyus, with a Communist Party mouthpiece saying Beijing is prepared to take action to defend its sovereignty over the disputed islands. The rhetoric came as about 30 mainland activists protested at the Japanese embassy in Beijing, demanding China declare war against Japan to claim the islands, known as the Senkakus in Japan.Waving Chinese national flags, the protestors chanted slogans demanding China take action against Tokyo after Japan arrested five Chinese activists who landed on the islands. Seven others on the boat were arrested "China should declare war against Japan to claim back the Diaoyu Islands," one banner read. Police stepped up security around the embassy, but the protestors were largely uninterrupted. They presented a letter, with a blade enclosed, addressed to Japan's prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda. "Noda commits a crime that is unforgivable by Chinese people," the letter said. "Your only way out is to cut open your belly with the blade." Chen Fule, one of the activists, said they had no plan to sail to the islands as they "were having difficulty in renting a boat". In a move seen as indicating Beijing is preparing to take tough action, a commentary in the overseas edition of People's Daily said China had no reason to tolerate Japan's actions and could respond to the dispute in a way similar to its handling of tensions with the Philippines over the Scarborough Shoal, known as Huangyan Island, in the South China Sea. Action taken by Beijing over the shoal dispute included curbing imports of bananas from the Philippines, and warnings from officials Beijing was prepared to take necessary action to defend its territory. "If diplomatic rhetoric does not calm Japan down, then only action can force Japan to retreat," said the commentary written by Jia Xiudong, a researcher at the China Institute of International Studies. The commentary said China would not hesitate to "eradicate Japan's illusion to get control of the Diaoyu Islands". The Global Times , published under People's Daily , warned in an editorial that "Japan must abandon the illusion that China will retreat in the face of Tokyo's provocation". "Japan has to make a choice: back up and create the conditions to reduce tensions ... or head into a full confrontation with China. Whatever Japan's choice, China will respond accordingly," it said. "China has no reason to compromise with Japan over the issue." In Taipei, several dozen activists demonstrated in front of Japan's de facto embassy. "Stop occupying Diaoyu Islands," they shouted outside Japan's Interchange Association, which represents Japan in Taiwan in the absence of official ties. "Despite all odds, we will never give up and we will do all we can to go to the Diaoyu Islands and declare our sovereignty over them," said Yin Pi-hsiung of the Taipei-based Chung Hwa Baodiao Alliance. Yin and three others were forced to cancel plans to join Hong Kong counterparts in travelling to the islands after the boat skipper refused to sail, in what they say was "pressure from government authorities." Taiwan's foreign ministry, however, said the government would never obstruct any fishing boat operations as long as they were legal. On a proposal by some Taiwanese activists that Taipei should co-operate with Beijing in asserting sovereignty over the island group, foreign ministry spokesman Steve Hsia said: "We will never co-operate with the mainland over this issue." [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post in English -- Well-respected non-PRC-owned daily newspaper and Hong Kong's most prominent English-language daily; features extensive original reporting on Hong Kong and PRC political issues and an even-handed editorial line]

headline: Kyodo: Report Says One Killed in Protest Against Mining Operation in PRC's Tibet
text: Hong Kong, Aug. 16 Kyodo -- Chinese police fired teargas canisters and gunshots to disperse a crowd of about 1,000 people protesting against a mining operation in Tibet, killing one protester, a U.S.-based media reported Thursday.A Tibetan man named Nyima was killed during the police crackdown on Wednesday when the protesters marched to a mining site in the town of Choeten to oppose the mining operation for fear of pollution, Radio Free Asia said, quoting Lobsang Palden, a Tibetan monk in India.Six other protesters were detained, the broadcast said.Local Tibetans were told by the Chinese mining company that the project was ordered by the local government, the report said. headline: WCT: 300 Henan AIDS Patients Bust Down Government Door
text: Henan officials told the protesters in April that the government will answer their requests within two months. The patients have asked for an extension of their free-drug programs, an increase in designated hospitals for AIDS treatment, compensation for their economic losses and financial aid for their children's tuition fees, according to the state-run news agency Xinhua. The officials failed to answer them as promised and have repeatedly skirted the issue. On Monday, the protesters tried to enter the office but were beaten back by baton-wielding police officers. Some of them were dragged into the building by police, according to the BBC. In 1995, the blood collection program paid poor farmers and peasants in the province to draw and extract plasma from their blood. Their blood was transfused back into their bodies after extraction. However, the procedure was conducted without any safety protection or screening and often with contaminated and reused equipment, causing massive numbers of HIV infections in the province. Local officials were said to have covered up the pandemic, which may have caused hundreds of thousands of cases of infection in the area. The patients had filed a lawsuit to demand compensation in local court but were rejected. Without an alternative petitioning channel, the family members of the patients have held numerous protests in front of the local health department and government office, according to the BBC. [Description of Source: Taipei Want China Times Online in English -- English-language e-paper published by Taiwan's Want Want China Times Group, focusing on China/cross-Strait news for Taiwan, featuring original reporting and reports garnered from China and Taiwan media sources; URL: http://www.wantchinatimes.com/]

headline: Kyodo: Further on 'Over 60,000' Chinese Join 'Largest' Anti-Japan Protests
text: [multiple events] Beijing, Sept. 15 Kyodo -- (EDS: UPDATING WITH HIGHER NUMBER OF CITIES, ADDING DETAILS) More than 60,000 Chinese citizens staged anti-Japan rallies Saturday in at least 28 cities in protest at Japan's nationalization of a group of islets in the East China Sea controlled by Japan but claimed by China and Taiwan.In terms of the number of participants and cities involved, the anti-Japan protests were the largest since the two countries normalized diplomatic relations in 1972, surpassing the scale of protests that occurred in 2005, according to a diplomatic source in Beijing.Some rallies turned violent, with protestors clashing with armed police and destroying Japanese-brand cars, in the wake of Chinese authorities' tacit approval of anti-Japan demonstrations and a flood of anti-Japan reports and broadcasts by official Chinese media.At a rally in Beijing outside the Japanese Embassy participated in by several thousand protestors, some of them broke through barricades and clashed with armed police as they attempted to break into the compound.Carrying Chinese flags, the protestors denounced the Japanese government's announcement Tuesday that it had bought privately owned land in the Senkaku Islands, which China calls Diaoyu, to bring the territory under state control.They hurled plastic bottles and eggs into the embassy grounds and chanted slogans such as "Protect the Diaoyu Islands" and "Slap economic sanctions on Japan." It was the fifth straight day of anti-Japan demonstrations in front of the embassy.Elsewhere in China, about 10,000 people joined a protest in Changsha, Hunan Province, with some attacking Japanese-brand cars and breaking windows of the Japanese supermarket store Heiwado. Some of about 10,000 protestors in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, broke into and ransacked more than 10 Japanese restaurants.In Qingdao, Shandong Province, protestors entered a Jusco supermarket run by the Aeon group of Japan and destroyed facilities there, according to the Japanese consulate general there.In southern China's Guangdong Province, hundreds of people protested in the cities of Guangzhou, Zhuhai and Dongguan.Japanese restaurants, shops bearing Japanese brand names or local shops adjacent to Japanese shops were broken into and ransacked while riot police stood by watching, footage from Hong Kong media showed."Down with Japan! Long live China!" some protesters chanted.Hong Kong's Now TV showed an unidentified man saying that China should engage Japan in battle because it "invades our territory." "Japan is shameless, they took advantage of us. Chinese people should stand united," he said.Hundreds of police stood guard outside the Japanese consulate general in Guangzhou, preventing protesters from getting near.Protests also broke out in cities like Shanghai, Chongqing, Zhengzhou, Nanjing and Kunming.Such protests are likely to continue up to the 81st anniversary Tuesday of the start of the 1931 Mukden Incident, also known as the Manchurian Incident, in which the Imperial Japanese Army blew up a Japanese railway in southern Manchuria to serve as a pretext for invading northeastern China.The series of protests came apparently in response to calls on Internet sites to rally Saturday and Sunday across China against Japan's nationalization of the Senkakus.China claims the islets have been part of Chinese territory since ancient times. In talks last Sunday in Vladivostok, Russia, President Hu Jintao told Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda that China firmly opposes Japan's moves to put them under state control.Premier Wen Jiabao said Monday that China will "absolutely make no concession" on issues concerning the country's sovereignty and territorial integrity.Japan maintains the Senkaku Islands are an integral part of Japanese territory and that there are no territorial disputes between the two countries. Taiwan also claims sovereignty over the uninhabited islands, which are known as Tiaoyutai to the Taiwanese. [Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English -- English service of Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]

headline: Kyodo: More on Chinese Continuing Anti-Japan Rallies in Beijing Over Senkakus
text: [multiple events] Beijing/hong Kong, Sept. 16 Kyodo -- (EDS: ADDING INFO) Chinese protesters continued anti-Japan demonstrations Sunday across the country against Japan's nationalization of a group of islets in the East China Sea claimed by China and Taiwan, with violent clashes between demonstrators and riot police reported in at least one city.Rallies took place in at least 56 cities including Beijing, Shanghai, as well as Guangzhou and Shenzhen in Guangdong Province, and Chengdu in Sichuan Province. A demonstration in Guangzhou drew more than 10,000 people.In a rally in Shenzhen, about 10,000 people clashed with riot police as they forced their way toward a Japanese department store, Hong Kong's TVB reported.Police fired tear gas at the agitated crowd who chanted slogans such as "patriotism is not a crime," but failed to disperse them, footage showed.The crowd called for the release of other protestors detained by authorities for organizing the Sunday rally in the southern China city, according to a participant.Some protestors climbed on top of an armed police vehicle as a police helicopter hovered nearby.Such developments sparked concerns among authorities that the anti-Japan protest could turn into an anti-government demonstration.In Guangzhou, thousands of people faced off with riot police outside the Japanese consulate as they wielded Chinese flags and pictures of late Chinese leader Mao Zedong, Hong Kong broadcaster Now TV showed.Protestors marched toward the consulate, holding banners reading, "The Diaoyu Islands are China's territory that is not to be violated!" and "Down with little Japan. Return the Diaoyu Islands." A series of protests came in response to calls on Internet sites to stage protests in at least 33 cities on Sunday in the wake of Japan's announcement Tuesday that the government had bought privately owned land on the Senkaku Islands, which China calls Diaoyu, to put them under state control.As some protesters vandalized Japanese factories, stores and restaurants Saturday, observers were closely watching how Chinese authorities would respond to such violent acts.As police tightened security around the Japanese Embassy in Beijing with the deployment of about 1,000 armed personnel, multiple groups marched on a street in front of the embassy, asserting Chinese sovereignty over the islands.It marked the sixth straight day of anti-Japan demonstrations in front of the embassy.Similar protests also took place in Qingdao, Shangdong Province, and Nanjing, Jiangsu Province.On Saturday, more than 80,000 took to the streets in at least 57 cities to denounce Japan's nationalization of the islands, marking the largest anti-Japan protests in China in terms of participant numbers and breadth since the two countries normalized diplomatic relations in 1972.The Chinese Foreign Ministry said it was trying to calm the situation by asking citizens to "express their demands in a legal and rational way." Chinese experts on relations with Japan said irrational and violent protests would not have a positive impact on the territorial dispute and may have the opposite effect."These irrational moves can actually escalate the crisis between the two nations, and may be what the Japanese right-wingers are expecting to see," Liu Jiangyong, vice dean of the Institute of Modern International Relations at Tsinghua University in Beijing, was quoted as saying in the Sunday issue of the China Daily. [Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English -- English service of Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]
source_human: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English

headline: SCMP: Rumour Police Beat Man to Death Sparks Riot in Luzhou, Sichuan
text: Hundreds of angry passers-by hurled bricks and bottles at police and overturned and set fire to police vehicles in a protest after the officers were accused of beating a driver to death in southeastern Sichuan yesterday. Video clips and photographs said to be taken at the scene in Luzhou , and widely circulated online, showed hundreds of protesters surrounding a man lying on the ground and a few policemen. The protesters were then seen overturning and setting fire to at least three police vehicles. However, one witness said the police had not beaten the man. She said she believed he could have died from a heart attack. "At around 5.30pm, I rushed to the scene, which is around 100 metres from my office, and saw that the victim, who was then surrounded by three traffic policemen, was suffering from some kind of heart attack, before asking someone to help him to get his drugs from his vehicle," she said. She said the man, in his 40s, was a fish vendor in the street where she worked. "I left the scene when the man was still conscious after having swallowed two drug tablets," she said. "When someone told me the man had died, I went back to the scene at about 6.30pm and found out that was true." She said she had not noticed any injuries on the man's body. But rumours that he had died from a police beating circulated quickly in the city, and around 1,000 protesters turned up at the scene, she said. Some shouted "hand over the killer", some threw bricks, stones or glass bottles at the police, and others overturned police vehicles before setting them alight. Online reports said the police had to fire tear gas to disperse the crowd. Luzhou police declined to comment last night. [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English -- Website of well-respected non-PRC-owned daily newspaper and Hong Kong's most prominent English-language daily; features extensive original reporting on Hong Kong and PRC political issues and an even-handed editorial line; URL: http://www.scmp.com]
source_human: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English
notes_human: Escalate:                            http://www.voachinese.com/content/sichuan-luzhou-riot-20121017/1528606.html         10/22:  Section: General News - As many as 10,000 Chinese rioted in southwest Sichuan province Wednesday after residents said a truck driver was beaten to death by police during a routine traffic stop.The official Xinhua news agency says calm has been restored in the city of Luzhou as of early Thursday. Although no casualties were reported, it says seven police cars were burned during the unrest. Online reports say police used tear gas to disperse the protesters, who attacked police with rocks and bottles.State media quickly denied reports that the man, identified as Luzhou resident Gan Junyuan, was beaten by police. The Communist Party-controlled Global Times quoted officials who said he died of an "acute disease" after being told to move his illegally parked vehicle. Xinhua said Gan "suddenly felt uncomfortable" and died while scuffling with police. It said doctors who were called to the scene were not able to save his life.Pictures and video circulated on Chinese social media, which could not be independently verified, show a body lying motionless next to a truck as police held back protesters.The local government has promised to conduct an investigation.Tens of thousands of riots break out across China every year in response to police brutality, land grabs, factory pollution and other grievances. So far, the protests have been localized and have not posed a serious threat to the rule of China's Communist Party.The party is working hard to enforce calm ahead of a sensitive once-a-decade leadership transition that begins next month with its 18th Party Congress in Beijing. - VOA

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 21-22 October 2012
text: The following highlights are from?Ming Pao and theHong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy?for the period 21-22 October 2012: Hainan Villagers Protest Building of Thermal Power Plant: According to an unattributed 21 October report in the well-respected Hong Kong independent daily Ming Pao , a series of protests sparked over the building of a thermal power plant in Yinggehai in the Li ethnic autonomous county in Ledong, Hainan Province, starting 13 October. The report says as many as 6,000 villagers who opposed to the project faced off with about 3,000 police at night. Police fired tear gas to disperse and arrest the protesters, and the term "Yinggehai" has been blocked on the mainland Internet. (See attached Vernacular: mp1021a.pdf) Protesting Hainan Villagers Fight Police With Molotov Cocktails, Torches: According to the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy (22 October), a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, around 10,000 residents of Leshan County's Yinggehai township in Hainan clashed with thousands of armed police on 20 and 21 October over the construction of a power plant. The report notes that the residents reacted strongly for fear that the thermal power plant, which involves an investment of 3.9 billion yuan, will contaminate the environment. The armed police fired large numbers of tear-gas canisters, and the report states that the residents used bricks, Molotov cocktails, and fire torches to fight back. As a result, around 100 residents were injured and 50 were arrested, the report adds.??(See?attached vernacular: ic1022a.pdf)? No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. headline: East China city assures public after protests over chemical plant expansion
text: Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News Agency)Ningbo, 24 October: A district government in eastern Chinese city of Ningbo on Wednesday [24 October] assured the public that a petrochemical plant it plans to expand meets "the most stringent discharge standards," two days after local villagers protested over pollution concerns.The expansion is planned to be built in the Ningbo Petrochemical Economic and Technical Development Zone in the Zhenhai District with a combined investment of nearly 55.8 billion yuan (8.8 billion U.S. dollars).Nearly 200 local residents protested outside the district government's offices on Monday over safety and pollution fears, as they believe the planned expansion is located too close to their homes."The farmers who blocked the roads have left," said a statement issued by the district government on Wednesday.The statement urged residents to voice their demands in a rational way and to maintain social stability and harmony.The district government has promised to resettle villagers who have had to relocate because of the expansion, as well as threatened punishment for a "very small number of people who were involved in instigating, making up rumours and organizing illegal activities."The statement said advanced technology will be used to ensure that the plant's production is environmentally friendly.Similar protests have erupted in several other cities in recent years. In 2007, thousands of people in east China's city of Xiamen protested the construction of a paraxylene (PX) plant over health concerns. The plant was eventually relocated.Last year, authorities in northeast China's city of Dalian ordered a PX chemical plant to shut down after local residents took to the streets to demand that the plant be relocated over concerns regarding possible toxic chemical leaks.Similar protests have also been reported in the cities of Chengdu, Nanjing and Qingdao.Source: Xinhua news agency, Beijing, in English 1206gmt 24 Oct 12
locality_human: Ningbo Petrochemical Economic and Technical Development Zone in the Zhenhai District
notes_human: Escalate (PX)    http://www.boxun.com/news/gb/china/2012/10/201210282202.shtml#.VM6idFXF8Sg                NINGBO, China, Oct. 28 -- More than 3,000 people marched in the streets of the eastern China city of Ningbo on Sunday to protest a local chemical plant expansion project, which they say would harm public health and cause environmental pollution.The protesters blasted the Ningbo municipal government for backing the chemical plant project and called for the resignation of Ningbo mayor.Local residents have gathered every day in front of the Ningbo municipal government over the past week, and the turnout Sunday was the largest so far.China has been hit by a series of protests in recent months by angry residents complaining about environmental pollution caused by the construction of new industrial plants.At least two industrial projects, a metallurgical plant in Sichuan Province and a waste-water treatment plant in Jiangsu Province, were scrubbed in July in the wake of public protests.Responding to Internet postings, residents in Ningbo gathered in the city's business district Sunday morning and later marched toward the municipal office, where they were held back by riot police guarding the government premises.The protesters demanded that the municipal government revoke the decision giving the go-ahead for the chemical plant expansion project and that the mayor resign to take responsibility.Apparently in a bid to ease public anger, Ningbo authorities said Sunday the mayor and other senior city officials met with representatives of the residents the previous day to listen to their views on the chemical plant project."We will continue to seek the public's opinion," a statement released by the city said.==Kyodo                       According to the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy (30 October), a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, about 5,000 armed police reinforcements sent in from other areas since 27 October have not been withdrawn from Ningbo as the authorities are still concerned about a possible mass rally or protest over a Sinopec plant expansion plan.?It was reported that the Ningbo protest may reach?a climax again this weekend as people from Shanghai, Hangzhou, and other areas may join the protest.?More than 200 protesters, some of them elderly, were beaten by the special and armed police during the five-day clash over the plant expansion.? [Description of Source: Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy in Chinese -- Hong Kong-based fax service founded and run singlehandedly by Chinese dissident Frank Lu Siqing, which claims to relay reports on dissidents, protests, and human rights from claimed informants in the PRC]Attachments:

headline: Tibetan students protest in northwest China over self-immolations
text: Text of report by Japanese news agency KyodoHong Kong, 9 November: Thousands of Tibetan students in northwestern China's Qinghai Province rallied Friday [9 November] after a string of self immolations by Tibetans to protest Chinese suppression in the Tibetan-inhabited region, according to the Tibetan government-in-exile.The Central Tibetan Administration said on its website about 5,000 students from four different schools, some of them wearing uniforms, marched in the streets and gathered outside a government office building in Tongren County of the Huangnan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, known as Rebgong by Tibetans, early in the morning.They raised slogans demanding freedom for Tibetans and the return of the Dalai Lama to Tibet.The crowd then rallied near the Rongwo monastery where a large number of local Tibetans from neighbouring areas have amassed to show solidarity with Kalsang Jinpa, 18, who died of self immolation there Thursday.No confrontations were reported during the rally, the government said.Tamdrin Tso, a mother of a young son, also died in a self-immolation for the same causes and drew several thousand Tibetans to protest into the streets in Tongren on Wednesday.A photograph posted on the Molihua website that frequently reports human rights violations in China shows hundreds of Tibetans in a sit-in protest Friday in an unidentified piazza in Tongren.But a staff members of the county party's committee office said she has not heard of any protest or self immolations in the past days.Four other Tibetans, including three teenage monks and an unidentified man, also made suicide attempts in nearby provinces this week, raising to 69 the total number of self-immolated Tibetans since February 2009.At least 56 of them are known to have died, the U.S.-based group International Campaign for Tibet said.The Dalai Lama, who lives in India in self-exile after a failed uprising against the Communist regime in 1959, urged Beijing to "take practical measures" and stop suppressing Tibetan people by power during his current visit to Japan.Denying suppression, Beijing has called the Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist and blamed him and his "clique" for masterminding violent acts against China, including the mass protest in Lhasa in 2008 and the self-immolations.Source: Kyodo News Service, Tokyo, in English 1105gmt 09 Nov 12

headline: SCMP: 'Wenzhou Villagers Riot Over Substation They Fear is Health Threat'
text: More than 1,000 villagers have clashed with police in Wenzhou over the construction of an electrical substation, despite recent central government promises for changes to reduce "not in my backyard" movements. Hundreds of the protestors in Liuliang and Fangbei villages were injured after confronting police, in a bid to stop construction of a 220-kilovolt substation. The project would require building high-voltage power lines over their homes, which some feared could threaten their health. At least four police cars and a local media van were badly damaged in the clashes, which involved protests in each of the two villages. The earlier protest, in Liuliang, involved about 1,000 villagers and 2,000 police, the Hong Kong-based Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy said yesterday. Two police cars were smashed and officers closed roads to the restive village. A smaller protest in Fangbei continued until yesterday afternoon, when police called in reinforcements to help disperse some 300 villagers, said one resident who uploaded a video of the scene to the internet. The footage shows police firing tear gas at stone-throwing protesters. Local residents have been trying to stop the project for more than a year and have petitioned in the provincial capital of Hangzhou , as well as Beijing. Protesters reportedly clashed with police during a rally outside the township's government headquarters last year. "So far, authorities haven't responded to us on this," a villager said. "They haven't given us any money for this damaging project, either, although they always claim that they have distributed compensation to us." Disputes over large construction projects are occurring with increasing regularity on the mainland, including a successful effort to stop the expansion of a petrochemical plant in Ningbo last month. Last week, Environment Minister Zhou Shengxian blamed the rise of "not in my backyard" movements on poor management by local authorities and promised measures to improve transparency and environmental reviews. headline: Global Times: Beijing Parents Protest Non-Locals Taking College Entrance Exam
text: Dozens of furious non-local parents shouted slogans and held signs outside the complaint office of Beijing Education Bureau Thursday, accusing the bureau of stalling over when? non-Beijing registered children will? be able to sit the gaokao (national college entrance examination) in the city. The bureau told the Global Times that the issue is still under discussion, while the parents say a resolution is urgent, as gaokao registration will take place from December 1 to 5.In March, Minister of Education Yuan Guiren said that the ministry would launch a policy concerning the non-local gaokao takers and would request the local bureaus to decide how to implement the changes.? So far Beijing education bureau has failed to issue any commitment as to when these non-local students will be able to sit the test in Beijing. Du Guowang, one of the some-50 parents who have protested at the bureau every Thursday since September 20, said time was running out for his Beijing-educated 17-year-old son.? "I would have no choice but to send him back to Inner Mongolia [Autonomous Region] to sit his exam," he said. Du said that he is disappointed in the Chinese education system, and if his son cannot sit the exam in Beijing, he would have to sell his house to fund his son's university education overseas. A mother surnamed Jin from Heilongjiang Province said she will probably sue the education bureau for their delay in implementing the new policy.? She was also discontent because a foreigner can take the gaokao in Beijing, but not a Chinese citizen registered outside the capital.? "This is not fair to us," she said.According to the Beijing gaokao application notice for 2013, issued Wednesday, applicants must either be a high school student with a Beijing hukou (household registration) or a foreigner with a permanent resident permit.? A media officer, surnamed Wang, from the Beijing Education Bureau said that despite the complaints of the non-local parents, it will take time to decide when students without a Beijing hukou could sit the gaokao here. "It involves cooperation with other government bureaus like the public security bureau to push this policy forward," he said.For foreigners, the policy has been in place for years, he said. In November, Heilongjiang Province became the first region in China to enforce the regulation that migrants to the province can sit the gaokao, the Xinhua News Agency reported. Jiangsu and Anhui provinces have said they will follow suit from 2013.?? [Description of Source: Beijing Global Times Online in English -- Online version of an English-language weekday newspaper, sponsored by Renmin Ribao (People's Daily), that launched on 20 April 2009 and is aimed at English-language audiences; Global Times focuses on PRC international and domestic political issues and features translations from its Chinese-language sister paper, Huanqiu Shibao, as well as unique content; URL: http://en.huanqiu.com]

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 24-26 Nov 2012
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from Tung Fang Jih Pao and the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy for the period 24-26 November 2012: Guangdong Villagers Rally Against Incinerator Construction: Tung Fang Jih Pao , a popular independent Hong Kong daily, carried an unattributed report on 24 November 2012 noting that several hundred Guangdong villagers staged rallies?from 22 November against the planned construction of a waste incinerator in Xinzuotang village. Villagers contend that the waste incinerator will be merely 300 meters away from the closest neighborhood, instead of the 1,200 meters promised by the authorities. Demonstrators marched to the Boluo township government building to voice their opposition yesterday (23 November). The protest is expected to continue on 24 November. (see vernacular file: tfjp1124.pdf) Riot Erupts Over Police Beating of Motorcyclist in Sichuan: According to a 24 November report in the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, over 10,000 Sichuan residents joined a riot and clashed with the police in Guangan city in Lingshui County on 21 November 2012, after a motorcyclist was beaten by police. Twenty protesters were reportedly injured, and two police vehicles were vandalized.? (see vernacular file: ic1124.pdf) China Said Tightening Measures Against Petitioners: According to a 26 November report?from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, over 100 Shandong migrant workers were arrested and detained by the police on 21 November 2012, apparently for staging illegal gatherings outside the Weifang city government building seeking government assistance in getting payment of salary arrears from a construction company.?Most of the migrant workers were still in custody as of 25 November. Some of the migrant workers may be subject to a 30-day administrative detention. The report states that China?is?tightening measures against petitioners after the 18th CPC National Congress, for the sake of maintaining social stability. (see vernacular file: ic1126a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.? ??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. (see vernacular file: tfjp1124.pdf) Riot Erupts Over Police Beating of Motorcyclist in Sichuan: According to a 24 November report in the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, over 10,000 Sichuan residents joined a riot and clashed with the police in Guangan city in Lingshui County on 21 November 2012, after a motorcyclist was beaten by police. Twenty protesters were reportedly injured, and two police vehicles were vandalized.? (see vernacular file: ic1124.pdf) China Said Tightening Measures Against Petitioners: According to a 26 November report?from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, over 100 Shandong migrant workers were arrested and detained by the police on 21 November 2012, apparently for staging illegal gatherings outside the Weifang city government building seeking government assistance in getting payment of salary arrears from a construction company.?Most of the migrant workers were still in custody as of 25 November. Some of the migrant workers may be subject to a 30-day administrative detention. The report states that China?is?tightening measures against petitioners after the 18th CPC National Congress, for the sake of maintaining social stability. headline: Kyodo: School in China's Qinghai Under 'Military Lockdown' After Mass Protest
text: Hong Kong, Nov. 27 Kyodo -- (EDS: UPDATING WITH SCHOOL LOCKDOWN) Three more Tibetans have died after lighting themselves on fire to protest Chinese repression of Tibetans, bringing to at least 22 the number of self-immolations so far this month, the Tibetan government-in-exile said Tuesday.Sangay Dolma, a 17-year-old nun, died Sunday in Qinghai Province's Huangnan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture; Kunchok Tsering, an 18-year-old man, did likewise Monday in Gansu Province's Gannan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture; and Gonpo Tsering, a 24-year-old man, did so in the same Gansu prefecture, the India-based Central Tibetan Administration said on its website.It said Gonpo Tsering set himself on fire in the prayer hall of the Ala Dheu Monastery. He raised slogans calling for freedom and respect for human rights in Tibet and the return of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, from exile in India.After his protest, local Tibetans from the neighboring villages gathered in huge numbers to offer their prayers and condolences, drawing a heavy presence of security forces, the report said.The three newly reported self-immolations come after it was reported Monday that former Tibetan monk Wangyalm, in his 20s, set himself on fire in Sichuan Province's Garze Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture earlier that day. It was not known whether he survived as authorities quickly arrived on the scene and took him away.The government-in-exile said that despite its repeated appeals to Tibetans living under Chinese rule "not to take drastic actions," 85 of them have self-immolated since February 2009 "in protest against the Chinese government's repressive rule." Most of them have died.Meanwhile, according to India-based news portal Phayul, Chinese authorities are keeping a medical school in Qinghai's Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture under "military lockdown" with students contained inside the campus following Monday's mass protest there against the Chinese government.The report said three students of the medical school have been arrested, while five of some 20 students injured during the police crackdown remained in critical condition.The students were calling for "equality of nationalities, freedom of language, respect for truth, and reestablishment of governance," Phayul said. Chinese armed forces were seen in video clips using violent force to break up the demonstration.The protest was said to have occurred after Chinese authorities requested students to answer a 10-point political questionnaire and made "disparaging remarks" against the Dalai Lama in patriotic education sessions.Radio Free Asia quoted an exile source as saying the protest was in response to "the distribution of a book condemning the study of Tibetan language as devoid of relevance and the self-immolations as acts of stupidity."] The government-in-exile and the Dalai Lama have urged the Chinese government to address the underlying causes that are pushing Tibetans to set themselves on fire in Tibetan-populated parts of China's western provinces of Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan that were carved out of Tibet in the distant past.Chinese authorities vilify the Dalai Lama as an "anti-China separatist" seeking Tibetan independence "under the cloak of religion," while alleging that he masterminded the 2008 riot in Lhasa and the self-immolations.The Tibetan spiritual leader, who fled Tibet in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule, has renounced violence and insists that he only seeks "genuine autonomy" for Tibet to protect its culture, religion and language.[Description of Source: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English -- English service of Japan's largest domestic and international news agency, owned by nonprofit cooperative of 63 newspaper companies and NHK]
source_human: Tokyo Kyodo World Service in English
locality_human: Gonghe Xian, Hainan Zangzuzizhizhou,  Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture,
notes_human: http://www.epochtimes.com/gb/12/11/27/n3739616.htm%E4%B8%8D%E6%BB%A1%E4%B8%AD%E5%85%B1%E5%88%B6%E8%A3%81-%E9%9D%92%E6%B5%B7%E4%B8%8A%E5%8D%83%E5%AD%A6%E7%94%9F%E6%B8%B8%E8%A1%8C-%E4%BC%A0%E5%86%9B%E8%AD%A6%E5%BC%80%E6%9E%AA%E9%95%87%E5%8E%8B.html                  On Monday, about 1,000 students at a Tsolho Medical Institute staged a bold protest about 900 kilometers (550 miles) to the north in Hainan prefecture in Qinghai province. Riot police fired shots into the air and released tear gas and beat the students with rifle butts, sending 20 students to the hospital, some with serious injuries, Free Tibet reported. Four students were detained as of Tuesday, according to U.S.-funded broadcaster Radio Free Asia.

headline: Caijing: Authorities Investigate on Huaxia Bank Over Troubled Wealth Products
text: Head of Shanghai's banking regulatory commission has reportedly headed to Huaxia's Shanghai branch to "conduct a survey" as the event keeps simmering. Chinese media said after being aware that they couldn't be repaid by the wealth products, some 30 investors were demonstrating in Lujiazui, Shanghai, outside a Huaxia branch, chanting slogans like "Huaxia Bank, Repay Our Money."Huaxia has blamed an employee at a Shanghai branch for selling the wealth management products without permission. In a statement late on Sunday, Huaxia said the deposit products the employee sold were four Zhongding-issued instruments, available since 2011, which were backed by returns from a pawn shop and a car sales company in the province of Henan.Police are investigating on the issue for alleged breaches of the law, the statement said, without giving more details.Huaxia's Shanghai branch at Jiading District suspended operations on Saturday, citing interior decoration one day after revelations began circulating on China's most popular microblogging platform Sina Weibo.[Description of Source: Beijing Caijing Online in English -- Website of an influential unofficial economic reform biweekly carrying in-depth, insider stories on financial and general economic issues; URL: http://www.caijing.com.cn/english/]
notes_human: Bank: It is an all-too-familiar tale. Depositors trust a bank with their cash in the hope their wealth will be managed well, only to find that the money has evaporated at the end of the agreed term. In the latest scandal to rock China's banking industry, dozens of depositors lost their multimillion-yuan investments in a "wealth management product" (WMP) sold at a Shanghai branch of Huaxia Bank. The sorry saga was a rude reminder that Ponzi schemes thrive on the mainland, where millions of residents still believe that banks are the safest havens for their lifelong savings. On Tuesday evening, more than 40 depositors protested against alleged malfeasance by Huaxia Bank at an outlet in Jiading district in Shanghai. They vented their anger at the bank after being informed that Zhongding Wealth Investment Centre, which issued a WMP to them last year, would be defaulting on its repayment to them. "Huaxia is a state-owned bank, and to some extent, it is doing business under the government's directions," an investor surnamed Gong said. "How can we trust the government and the Communist Party ... now that a state-owned bank refuses to pay our money back?" Fitch Ratings says mainland commercial banks have sold an aggregate 12 trillion yuan (HK$14.9 trillion) in WMPs, most of which offer a higher yield than banks' deposit rates and so are attracting an increasing number of customers. Gong, a retired worker, said she was convinced by Pu Tingting, a customer manager at the Jiading outlet, that the Zhongding product was worth buying. "She told me the branch's chief had also bought the product," Gong said. "I trusted the bank and its staff, so I decided to buy, too." The WMP offered an annualised interest rate of 11 per cent, more than triple the benchmark deposit rate set by the central bank. Huaxia Bank said in a statement that Pu was a rogue employee and the product was sold without the bank's authorisation. An official at the Jiading outlet, who was from the bank's Beijing headquarters and declined to be identified, told the South China Morning Post that Pu had been taken by Shanghai police, who are carrying out a criminal investigation. The victims said their total investment in the Zhongding product could amount to more than 500 million yuan. Xiao Gang, chairman of Bank of China, warned the number of defaults in similar schemes could soar in the future and eventually trigger a liquidity crisis in the banking system. Mainland banks worked closely with trust companies or other entities that package trust loans into WMPs, with the lenders acting as middlemen to sell the products, Xiao wrote in a commentary published in the China Daily in October. The Zhongding WMP provides a vivid snapshot of the practices the institutions engage in. Zhongding raised the money through Huaxia Bank to fund the construction of car dealerships in Henan province. The victims said Huaxia Bank informed them the borrower was found to have committed crimes. "Shouldn't Huaxia take responsibility?" said Zhou Guowu, an investor who spent 500,000 yuan on the Zhongding product. A report on internet portal NetEase reported that Pu's husband said she had been made a scapegoat by the bank. At least five investors claimed they knew Pu well and said the bank encouraged her to promote the sale of the Zhongding WMP. "Our money was deposited into Huaxia's accounts via the branch's counters," said one investor. "For ignorant investors like us, we were buying Huaxia Bank's product and we want our money back from Huaxia." An official with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, who asked not to be named, said the WMP sector had recently been spinning out of control in a fundraising spree. "Lacking efficient regulations, more scandals are set to surface as banks blindly and aggressively issue WMPs," he said. "What's worse, to our knowledge, some customer managers are helping cash-hungry businesses raise funds through the WMPs without official approval from the banks." About 55 per cent of outstanding WMPs were scheduled to mature this quarter, and a further 19 per cent would expire in the next quarter, Fitch said. It said WMPs at mainland banks grew 3.5 trillion yuan in the first nine months of this year, of which 85 per cent were sold by mid-size joint-stock or city and rural commercial banks. "Proceeds raised from the products containing credit can be used to repay, roll over or purchase borrowers' existing loans," Charlene Chu, Fitch's head of Chinese bank ratings, said in a report. "This can give the appearance of high repayment rates of corporate loans - and by extension, strong banking-sector asset quality and corporate-sector health - when, in fact, the loans are not being repaid by borrowers themselves but rather by investors." Xiao, who is tipped to replace Zhou Xiaochuan in March as the central bank's governor, has compared the proliferation of WMPs on the mainland to shadow banking. "Regular banking and shadow banking are not isolated from each other," he wrote in the commentary. "Many activities in the two systems feed into each other and could influence each other if things start to deteriorate." [Description of Source: Hong Kong South China Morning Post Online in English -- Website of well-respected non-PRC-owned daily newspaper and Hong Kong's most prominent English-language daily; features extensive original reporting on Hong Kong and PRC political issues and an even-handed editorial line; URL: http://www.scmp.com]

headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 4-5 December 2012
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from?Tung Fang Jih Pao and Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy?for the period 4-5 December 2012: Wenzhou Bus Drivers Clash With 500 Special Police: A 4 December report?from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, notes that approximately 200 bus drivers in Zhejiang's Wenzhou city staged a protest outside the city government on 4 December 2012 and clashed with 500 special police, out of discontent over a mandatory nationalization plan?affecting 13 privately run bus companies. Reportedly, 10 bus drivers were injured during the scuffle. Dozens of bus drivers blocked?10 bus lanes and disrupted local traffic. It was reported that over 1,000 Wenzhou bus drivers?have taken?part in a general strike since 30 November 2012.??(see vernacular file: ic1204a.pdf) Shantou, Sichuan Villagers Demand Compensation for Land: According to an unattributed 4 December 2012 report in the popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , a few thousand villagers in Shantou protested outside the city government office building on 3 December, accusing village officials of selling their land without proper compensation. Holding a banner that 10,000 people had signed, the villagers chanted slogans while police officers stood guard outside the building. Meanwhile, over 1,000 villagers gathered around the Shantou party committee building. A few university students were reportedly "chased away" by the police for taking photos at the scene. According to the report, the village officials were accused of having "misappropriated a few hundred million yuan." On 30 November, a group of villagers in Sichuan clashed with the police after "blocking traffic with vehicles" to protest against the local government, which has been accused of misappropriating the villagers' compensation after expropriating part of their land for a construction project. According to the report, the police "fired tear gas at the demonstrators," while rumors are circulating on the Internet that "a number of people have been beaten and arrested." (see vernacular file: tfjp1204a.pdf) Beijing Police Detain Petitioners on 'Legal Awareness Day': A 5 December report?from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, notes that over 3,000 Chinese petitioners have been arrested and detained by the Beijing police on 4 December 2012, which marked China's "Legal Awareness Day." It is reported that over 50,000 petitioners gathered in Beijing on 4 December 2012. Some detained petitioners were released from the Jiujingzhuang Detention Center on the outskirts of Beijing in the evening of 4 December 2012, while the whereabouts of some others remains unknown.? (see vernacular file: ic1205a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 10-11 December
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from?Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy for the period 10-11 December 2012: Nanning Uyghurs Protest Police Action Against Street Vendors : ?A 10 December report?from the Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, notes that approximately 100 Uyghurs staged a protest outside the police station in Guangxi's Nanning city on 9 December 2012, after police officers confiscated Xinjiang-style nut cakes from street vendors. No bloodshed was reported. This is the latest dispute arising between Han Chinese and Uyghurs after scuffles broke out over the?sale of Xinjiang nut cakes in Hunan's Yueyang city in late November.? (see vernacular file: ic1210c.pdf)Jiangsu Shipyard Workers Clash With Riot Police: The Hong Kong Information Center for Human Rights & Democracy, a Hong Kong-based fax service which reports on dissidence, reports that 5,000 Jiangsu workers of the Jingjiang Eastern Shipyard clashed with several hundred riot police on 10 December 2012,?and at least 20 workers were injured. Thousands of disgruntled shipyard workers blocked the Jiangyin Yangtze Bridge in protest against wage arrears. This group of workers staged a labor strike on?11 December 2012 and blocked roads near the Jiangsu East Heavy Industry Company Limited. The Jingjiang Eastern Shipyard has reportedly produced some of the accessory parts of China's "Liaoning" aircraft carrier. (see vernacular file: ic1211a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline. headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 30 December 2012
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from?Tung Fang Jih Pao and Nanfang Dushi Bao ?for?30 December 2012 : Yunnan Prison Workers Protest Delayed Payment of Salaries: ?According to an unattributed 30 December 2012 report in the?popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , a few dozen migrant workers surrounded Yiliang prison in Yunnan on 28 December morning, protesting against delayed salary payments by the prison, their employer. The workers blocked and paralyzed traffic near the prison and as a result caused a major traffic jam in the area. The police reportedly intervened and persuaded the workers to leave. The workers finally dispersed after an hour. (see vernacular file: tfjp1230a.pdf)Factory Workers Protest 'Unreasonable Dismissal': According to an unattributed 30 December 2012 report in the popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , a few hundred factory workers protested outside a manufacturing plant against "unreasonable dismissal without compensation." The workers reportedly blocked the factory's trucks and were "at a stalemate with the police." The workers accused the factory management of "sending people to beat them up." According to the report, the workers remained outside the factory as of 20 December. (see vernacular file: tfjp1230b.pdf) Guangdong Workers Demand Return of Pension Fund: According to a 30 December report by reporter Feng Leiliang and Guo Weihao in Guangzhou Nanfang Dushi Bao , a popular and occasionally outspoken daily newspaper affiliated with Nanfang Ribao , the daily newspaper of the Guangdong Provincial CPC Committee, 300 workers rallied at a factory on 29 December in Foshan, Guangdong Province, demanding that their employer return their social security fund.?A group of policemen and government officers were later sent in to keep order. The workers said they feared that their employer would soon close down the factory, as it was undergoing restructuring, and that they could not get back their social security fund.?(See vernacular file: nd1230a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS-covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline . headline: Highlights: Civil Unrest in China, 30 December 2012
text: [multiple events] The following highlights are from?Tung Fang Jih Pao and Nanfang Dushi Bao ?for?30 December 2012 : Yunnan Prison Workers Protest Delayed Payment of Salaries: ?According to an unattributed 30 December 2012 report in the?popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , a few dozen migrant workers surrounded Yiliang prison in Yunnan on 28 December morning, protesting against delayed salary payments by the prison, their employer. The workers blocked and paralyzed traffic near the prison and as a result caused a major traffic jam in the area. The police reportedly intervened and persuaded the workers to leave. The workers finally dispersed after an hour. (see vernacular file: tfjp1230a.pdf)Factory Workers Protest 'Unreasonable Dismissal': According to an unattributed 30 December 2012 report in the popular independent Hong Kong daily Tung Fang Jih Pao , a few hundred factory workers protested outside a manufacturing plant against "unreasonable dismissal without compensation." The workers reportedly blocked the factory's trucks and were "at a stalemate with the police." The workers accused the factory management of "sending people to beat them up." According to the report, the workers remained outside the factory as of 20 December. (see vernacular file: tfjp1230b.pdf) Guangdong Workers Demand Return of Pension Fund: According to a 30 December report by reporter Feng Leiliang and Guo Weihao in Guangzhou Nanfang Dushi Bao , a popular and occasionally outspoken daily newspaper affiliated with Nanfang Ribao , the daily newspaper of the Guangdong Provincial CPC Committee, 300 workers rallied at a factory on 29 December in Foshan, Guangdong Province, demanding that their employer return their social security fund.?A group of policemen and government officers were later sent in to keep order. The workers said they feared that their employer would soon close down the factory, as it was undergoing restructuring, and that they could not get back their social security fund.?(See vernacular file: nd1230a.pdf) No other file-worthy items were noted in PTS-covered sources today.??PTS scans on a daily basis the following sources in Chinese: Hsin Pao, Ching chi Jih Pao, Ming Pao, Wen Wei Po, Ta Kung Pao, Hsiang Kang Shang Pao, Tai Yang Pao, Tung Fang Jih Pao, Feng Huang Wang, Ping Kuo Jih Pao, Sing Tao Jih Pao, Phoenix Newsline . Attachments:
